PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits for Optometric Examinations
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled—
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
1.Optometry has been covered by Medicare since its inception in 1975, and currently provides eye care to over 2.4 million people each year.
2.Removal of optometric benefits from Medicare will increase Government expenditure on eye care, as people will instead obtain their care from a more expensive source.

3.The cost to the public of eye care will increase, both through the removal of benefits for optometric consultations and the shift to ophthalmologists who generally charge well over the schedule fee.

4.The visual welfare of the community will suffer as people are discouraged from seeking eye care. Many eye diseases, such as glaucoma, do not produce symptoms until they are in an advanced stage. Any discouragement from seeking regular eye care will increase suffering from these diseases.
5.The removal of benefits for optometric examinations will disadvantage children, as undetected visual disorders will adversely affect their development and school performance.
6.Access to eye care will be reduced, particularly in rural areas, as part-time and visiting optometric practices will no longer be economically viable, and alternate care is not available.
We therefore request that the Parliament take steps to ensure that Medicare continues to be a universal health insurance system and that all eye examinations by optometrists are covered.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Religion Declaration
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:
The United Nations Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and of Discrimination Based on Religion and Belief:
prohibits all forms of religious discrimination, thus potentially restricting the freedom of Australians to make any choices on the grounds of their belief;
could lead to US-style prohibitions on public Christian prayers, Christmas carols or nativity scenes;
has the potential, according to the NSW Attorney-General, to restrict greatly the freedom of religious groups;
and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only the legally-weak term "respect" for the rights of parents in Article 5;
could result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
act to disallow these two International Instruments from the HREOC Act.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PARA.TAB: This petition of certain residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House—

PETITION.PARA: that with more than ten per cent of Australians unable to obtain useful, paid employment, the concepts of the level playing field and zero tariffs are rejected because they produce substantial losses and provide no benefits, despite wordy defence of them by economic rationalists.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore urge the House to act to ensure that Australia:-

PETITION.PARA: maintains processing industries based on our well-established rural industries;

restores profitability for Australia's farms and factories; and

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Joint Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the committee's report entitled Australia, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, together with evidence received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I would like to thank the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) for allowing me to table this report. He is now the chair of the subcommittee that prepared the report. A lot of the work was done during the previous parliament, and I thank him for his courtesy.

PARA.TAB: As far as I know, this is the first report by this parliament on the major international financial institutions, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The report has been in preparation for over two years; in fact, it would have been tabled about six months ago if the election had not intervened. In 1991 the committee proposed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, that an inquiry to examine Australia's relationship with the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund be held.

For countries like Australia, membership of the bank and the fund offer both the potential to influence their policies and the opportunity to export Australian goods and services to developing countries under their programs. However, to date Australia has failed to capitalise adequately on either of these two types of opportunities offered by membership.

In its 1989 report on third world debt, the committee examined the impact of international financial institutions, through IFI adjustment programs, on developing countries. The committee recognised that, while the primary responsibility for economic policy lies with recipient country governments, the bank and the fund have considerable power to influence those governments. Since the committee's 1989 report was published, the bank has accepted the need to address issues such as poverty and the environment as a necessary part of its policy of growth through structural adjustment. Whilst acknowledging that the bank is attempting to deal with these issues, many witnesses and commentators consider that the change in actual policies has been inadequate, and called on Australia to play a much more active role in influencing bank and fund policies.

Particular areas of concern addressed by witnesses to the inquiry were the failure of the bank and the fund to lead a process of major debt reduction for severely indebted countries; the social problems created by the current focus of both the bank and the fund on structural adjustment loans; the failure of the bank and the fund to address cross-sectoral issues such as unemployment, inequity, poverty, population growth, land redistribution and environmental issues in developing countries; the failure of the bank or the fund to learn from its mistakes adequately through program evaluation; and the dominance of the fund and the bank by industrialised countries with a particularly narrow and naively theoretical philosophy of unconstrained markets, regardless of the extent of market failure.

The committee addressed each of these areas of concern and concluded that there was at least some validity in all of them, and we made a series of recommendations about the effectiveness of fund and bank policies aimed at addressing them. For example, our recommendation No. 25 urged that the bank and the fund strengthen the advice that they give to recipient countries during loan negotiations dealing with poverty, population growth, land redistribution and the environment. We urged more effective evaluation of their programs to see whether they are in fact working. Of course, the bank and the fund do that, but we urged them to extend that approach.

We urged that member countries support the issue of special drawing rights. I was profoundly concerned to see that Australia at present is not amongst those governments which are supporting the issue of special drawing rights. A new issue of SDRs would be of direct benefit to developing countries in easing their current account constraints.

We also urged Australia's executive directors to take more initiative in the development of bank and fund policies. There is a tendency, it would seem, amongst our executive directors to be extremely cautious in the kinds of involvement they have in policy development within the bank and the fund, and we urged them to inform themselves better on the needs of the developing countries, the recipient countries themselves, and to be more active in urging more sensitive policies.

We also recommend that the link between the bank's capital base and its lending, which is on a one-for-one basis at present, be broken so that the resources that it can lend to developing countries can be increased in ways other than by simply increasing its capital base.

The Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Trade believes that membership of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund has considerable benefits for Australia. That membership provides the opportunity to participate as an active member of the international economic and financial system and to influence the multilateral development banks' policies so as to increase the effectiveness and equity of those policies.

Membership also provides opportunities on a regional level for Australia to encourage bank and fund involvement in South-East Asia and the South Pacific, thereby enhancing our regional bilateral development programs. Australia is also able to participate in the development debate in our region through the World Bank's research into the economies of this region.

In relation to the commercial activities of the World Bank, involvement in bank financed business opportunities can help Australian firms in becoming established and to serve export markets in developing countries, including in the Asian region. From a commercial perspective, therefore, the benefit to be gained from Australia's membership is the opportunity to participate in the procurement of goods and services.

In this area Australian service providers such as consultants and engineering firms perform better than our manufacturers. There are a number of reasons for this, not least of which is Australia's technical excellence in the fields demanded by the World Bank and the approach taken by service providers. The committee has made a number of recommendations about ways of strengthening Australia's commercial involvement in World Bank activities.

Another theme of the report is the need to increase the openness of bank activities, and the committee makes a number of suggestions for dealing with that. Perhaps the most original suggestion is for the establishment of an interparliamentary assembly to monitor the fund and the bank. The committee proposes that that should meet annually; that the meetings should be organised through, perhaps, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund; that membership should come from countries which currently provide the executive directors for the bank and the fund; and that the Speaker and the President of the Australian Parliament should take the initiative in organising a preliminary meeting.

The committee also states that it is very important that the policy of widely advertising the positions of executive directors in the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund be continued. We applaud the Treasury for opening up those advertisements, but we urge that the selection process should ensure that strong weight be given to experience in development finance issues. That should be through the selection criteria.

The Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade was also concerned about the increase in the proportion of Australia's aid program which goes through the international financial institutions. The committee supports that and it would, of course, like to see the aid program increased, but it recommends that that portion of the aid program going through the multilateral development banks should be separated out as a component of the aid budget.

In conclusion, I would like to thank the members of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in both the 36th and 37th parliaments, and particularly the current chair of the subcommittee, the honourable member for Werriwa. All members of the subcommittee participated actively. It was a very interesting and valuable inquiry. I warmly thank the members of the committee secretariat, particularly Cheryl Samuels and Marina Ellis, for their work. It was a quite difficult and technical inquiry and they worked very hard at it. I am very grateful for their work. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very appropriate that the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) table the report entitled Australia, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund because, in the previous parliament, he chaired the subcommittee, did most of the work and involved himself very heavily in it. The honourable member also has a lot of experience in, and academic and practical knowledge of, the issues surrounding aid and development cooperation.

PARA.TAB: It was not my intention to speak today. I had assumed that the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) would be here. He expressed to both the honourable member for Fraser and me his wish to speak on behalf of the opposition; and he too, of course, was involved in this committee right through the last parliament and was very heavily involved in the report.

From what I have learnt from all my colleagues on the committee, there were a lot of very strong opinions about the bank. There was evidence of contentions and allegations in various places but, in others, evidence, knowledge and information were lacking. This says a lot in itself, inasmuch as the bank hitherto has not exposed itself to the degree of scrutiny that the committee clearly sees as being necessary. It is one thing to attack the bank's operations on first principles but, since we are in a heavily ideological area and in an area where there will always be a very strong debate about development issues, it is very important that there be full scrutiny, given the amount of money that the taxpayers are putting in.

My involvement with the bank when I was minister for primary industry was really in terms of visiting the bank when I was in Washington—where I was given some insight into the work being done by Australians in the World Bank—and also in terms of directors reporting to me on my way through. As Treasurer, I attended the World Bank and IMF meeting in Bangkok in 1991. Most of my work then was done in two committees over the weekend, and consisted of a day's work on the development committee and another day on another committee, the name of which now escapes me.

Those meetings were very active, open and interactive, and there was real debate in them. But US views—or what I would call a banker's ascetic view of the world—tended to be the dominant ideology. One would see some of the developing nations and the donor nations divide. Australia, being the sort of middle power it is could play a bridging role, as we so often do in international fora. I did not give a speech to the plenary session. I think it was intended by my officials that I give a vacuous speech. I remember helping the Mongolian delegate write his speech. Seeing that he could not speak English and I could not speak Mongolian, that was not a very effective exercise, but he gave a speech.

The speech that I did not give—we did table something in the plenary session—said that Australia was going through the worst recession in 60 years. Although I did not say it, I certainly believe that I have to be responsible. That speech was boxed, and the person in Treasury who wrote it was looking at one out of four relevant measures. I will not debate whether at that exact time we were in the worst recession for 60 years. That is history.

The World Bank, with the IMF agency as part of it and with the International Development Association, is part of a spectrum of development cooperation assistance given to the developing world. The IMF's role has diminished somewhat since the collapse of Bretton Woods. It is now an agency which tries to impose conditionality and tries to give advice to governments on the way they see fit to run their economies. The IMF often clashes with governments of developing countries, because the political realities in those countries do not square with what is seen as the proper way to go about things.

The World Bank is very much at one end of the aid spectrum inasmuch as we are dealing with long-term finance, and dealing commercially. We are dealing with loans of up to 40 years. The IDA does a lot better work. There are other banking agencies such as the Asian Development Bank and the African Development Bank. I attended a meeting as Australia's representative of the Asian Development Bank last year in Hong Kong. The position that Australia took there was that it was about time that the embargo on Vietnam was dropped and that Vietnam be allowed to receive funds. This is something that I think most Australians would feel rather strongly about.

It is a long time since the Vietnam War ended but, again, this shows that the World Bank has a US dominance. Australia, in again taking the bridging role, pointed out that just because there was a domestic political issue Vietnam should not be denied the international assistance that other developing countries are given. We have seen plenty of areas where the victor has helped the vanquished.

All of these international agencies suffer the same deficiencies as any international bureaucracy. In terms of the administration of the funds, AIDAB, our own aid agency, is actually about 3.8 times more efficient. The non-government organisations are the ones that most stridently oppose much of the work, or some of the work, of the World Bank. NGOs are a lot more flexible, of course, than a body like the World Bank and governments, including the Australian government. The World Bank has to deal government to government, while NGOs can actually deal with the people on the ground. Some of the views of the NGOs are accepted uncritically, but the NGOs are not monolithic and they really do cover a wide spectrum of aid. At least they do constantly concentrate on poverty and the real issues in development and are constantly there as a check and a balance and a continuation of the debate which is so essential.

My objection to the World Bank and the way Australia deals with it is that because departments of treasury and finance, in the donor countries particularly, are the ones concerned with the World Bank it becomes a closed shop or a closed order. I accept the line that a bank is a bank, but our own banking system has shown that if this is regarded as something that is not subject to scrutiny one can get into a lot of trouble—ask John Bannon.

The whole question of conditionality is a very difficult one. Conditionality in human rights, conditionality in terms of macro-economics are all difficult for a bank. I accept that confidentiality of assessments is needed when the bank is making assessments about countries, but that does not mean that the views of the bank should not be identified by the donors, should not be identified at World Bank meetings and should not be subject to scrutiny.

In regard to the US view of the world since the cold war—particularly with respect to republican administrations; I do not know about the present administration in the US—a spokesman for the US at the World Bank meeting I attended said quite clearly that it is no longer a question of how much money the United States puts into development. They actually put in a very small amount compared with other countries in the OECD, but they really see it as a matter of whether or not countries are going to have democratic systems, market systems, and adopt family values. Of course, in Australia we would point out that this did not stop them helping formerly anti-communist countries which had none of those attributes. One can point to some of the fiercely anti-communist countries that did not have much to do with democracy or market systems, for that matter.

The other objection I have is that the proportion of the aid budget going to the World Bank has been increasing in real terms. It is going to the international agencies, where I think we will always be and we will always do our bit but, in looking at the whole amount that we spend on aid, the arguments of the Department of Treasury and Department of Finance in Australia were always against targets, against many forms of aid, but always accepting the level of contribution. The scrutiny that was applied to AIDAB was never envisaged as having to be applied to the World Bank and this committee clearly does not share that view.

Overall, Australia gets back about 87-89 per cent of the amount we spend on aid, through whatever means. We do reasonably well in terms of procurement but we can do a lot better and I share exactly the views of my colleague the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) in saying that we could do more. If business people were going through Washington a lot more, if they worked it harder, I think we could do better.

One of the overall conclusions of the committee which the honourable member for Fraser touched on is that there is need for more scrutiny. In my experience representing Australia at a meeting of the World Bank, I really do believe that this is essential. Parliamentary scrutiny has to be more closely directed to the Treasurer's report. We know how busy this parliament is, but we do put in a lot of money; we need a body like the World Bank. However, that is not a reason for it to be a closed order, and the honourable member for Fraser and I will be seeing honourable members about this inter-parliamentary assembly. I thank the committee members and particularly the staff, who did a sterling job.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a new member of the 37th parliament I was obviously a new member of the committee. I must say that it was a fascinating experience for me to join a committee which was enriched by the presence of a former treasurer and ministers for trade. There was not only the last speaker, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), but also the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). The right honourable member for New England is not able to be here today but I know he has a great interest in this report. He has a fascinating political background and has a wide knowledge of the world. I must say that I felt privileged to be able to be part of the concluding stages of the report and the inquiry.

PARA.TAB: I would particularly like to pay tribute also to the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). He was the first chairman and he continued his work in the 37th parliament. His words, direction and leadership are reflected very much and very often in this report.

Having said all that, I must say that I believe that the report is going to be one that will lead to a lot more activity, action and inquiry about the operation of the World Bank. If its sole effectiveness is to do that then it will have done its job very well. The World Bank is indeed a giant. I understand it employs 6,000 to 7,000 personnel. It is present and operates throughout many parts of the world and has a huge responsibility in terms of helping address the problems of poverty. It also helps countries recover from disasters and wars.

I was interested to hear the honourable member for Werriwa refer to Vietnam and to the fact that often in history it is the vanquished who have been helped by the victor and so the World Bank's role in Vietnam is seen as being appropriate. I agree that it is appropriate but I wonder whether it is not the victor being helped by the vanquished. I think perhaps it is in many circumstances.

I was very troubled in the short time that I was part of the inquiry, leading to the finalisation of the report, to learn of the lack of scrutiny and the lack of knowledge and information that our parliament has about the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The recommendations in the report are absolutely vital and urgent and must be implemented. The role of the World Bank is not going to diminish in this troubled world for the next 20, 30 or 50 years. It will take an increasing role. Also, I think Australians are entitled to know more about the World Bank because we are a significant shareholder and we are a significant player in the world. Although we are a small country we are influential and respected throughout the world for our contribution towards helping address the problems of impoverished countries and for our efforts to try to achieve peace.

It is interesting too that this report recommending more scrutiny by the parliament and by the departments of government is being released just prior to the 50th anniversary of the United Nations which will take place in 1995. It is good to see that Australia has been honoured with the chairmanship of the planning committee for the 50th anniversary of the United Nations, which is very appropriate.

I would see that the two activities—the review of the United Nations which inevitably will occur and will be focused when the 50th anniversary occurs, and the recommendation of this report that the parliament and the government take more interest and become more aware of the World Bank's activities and effectiveness—will together marshal our scarce resources and help address some of the grave problems of the world.

Putting it bluntly, I do not believe that any member of this parliament, from either side, or any Australian from whatever walk of life would approve of World Bank funding being given to countries which do not respond to the need to strengthen and give human rights to people or being given to those which do not address problems of anarchy and lawlessness. I regret to say that, over the years, inevitably there must have been occasions when World Bank activity has occurred in good faith in countries but has not achieved the necessary cooperation and reaction from the people in power in those countries at the time. (Time expired)
Motion (by Mr Langmore) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—In accordance with standing order 102B, the debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House notes the positive financial and social impact of the Budget on the people of Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: With all the huffing and puffing that is going on at the moment in the Senate regarding the budget, many very important items that have an effect on the lives of the majority of Victorians have been overlooked. I would like to remind this house and Victorians of a number of them and also use this opportunity to make the House aware of the other Victorian budget and its disastrous consequences for the people of Victoria.

PARA.TAB: I would first like to speak about our elderly, our veterans and other social security recipients. There are 588,212 pensioners, 83,880 service pensioners and 250,912 social security recipients in Victoria. This adds up to 933,004 people. I will repeat that number so that honourable members get a bit of an idea of the number of people who receive government moneys. I repeat: 933,000. That is about 11 times the number of the people who attended the real football grand final and saw the mighty Bombers win.

All of these people will receive benefits from this budget. Even though it is very hard to determine the total increase in monetary terms, it would be in the region of $3 a week. If this is correct, the increase to the Victorian economy from this budget, for this group of people alone, is $2,769,000 per week—that is, approximately $138 million per year. These people do not put their money under the bed; they spend it, and we all benefit—especially our shops.

Of course, there are benefits besides the financial one. The benefits are increases to the community aged care package to allow older persons to remain in their homes, improved access to respite care, a seniors health card, a Commonwealth dental scheme, a mature age allowance, increased earned income, increases for palliative care, and child-care cash rebates. These benefits will also put millions of dollars into the Victorian economy.

Our veterans will benefit as well. They will receive extra funding for hostel development and emergency funding for telephone counselling. Something I am very pleased to say is that there has been a pilot scheme in the Dunkley electorate over the last three years—that is, the veterans' advice network. It will extend to Geelong, Ballarat and Gippsland, as well as to the Melbourne metropolitan area, from the existing branch office. Staff employed in the network will work with local communities, providing information on education, advocacy and community development focus.

In the area of the Victorian environment, there are programs, such as Australian Alps National Park, endangered species, ocean reserve 2000, national land care, save the bush, one billion trees, and national wetlands. As well as these programs there are many more of these innovative schemes, which will inject millions of dollars into very important areas. Some of this money will go to community groups, which work long and hard to protect our fragile environment.

The 1993-94 budget will provide $1.3 billion for labour market program assistance for the unemployed throughout Australia, and $350 million is allocated for Victoria. There is $136 million allocated for TAFE funding. The Commonwealth, through the Department of Employment, Education and Training, will inject millions into the Victorian economy.

The Department of Primary Industries and Energy has done a great deal to assist our rural community in Victoria with programs in this budget, such as money for the Murray-Darling Basin; the national landcare program; a program to introduce world best practice in agriculture; expansion of rural counselling; funding to encourage the use of solar heaters; and the abolition of the assets test on the supplementary boarding allowance for isolated children.

As I said at the beginning of this speech, this budget is good for Victorians. However, the spite and bitterness that have permeated the opposition since it lost the unlosable election is being vented on this budget and therefore on the people of Victoria. It wants to stop the budget. It wants to stop all the benefits I have listed, and the many more that I have not, and try to create a 1975 situation.

It keeps telling us that it is a conservative party and it swears to uphold the conventions of the country. However, when they cannot get their own way, it is always the conservative parties who will manipulate, cheat and take treacherous actions to achieve their ultimate goal, and that goal is power. Remember 1975: ever since then it has been trying to justify this act of treachery.

If the Liberals block the budget or have the tax cuts delayed, or removed, it will have a disastrous effect on the Victorian economy. In 1991-92 there were 1.1 million people working and earning between $20,000 and $50,000 per year—51 per cent of all Victorian taxpayers. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) stated that the tax cuts were worth approximately $8 to $10 per week: 1.1 million workers by $10 is approximately $10 million per week. I repeat, $10 million per week. Yes, that is right: that is what they are worth and they are worth that to Victoria. If these tax cuts are stopped, $10 million per week will not go into our economy; $10 million per week will not be spent in our small businesses. Honourable members can imagine what effect that will have.

These economic troglodytes opposite think that stopping this budget is a smart thing to do. Jeffrey Kennett's Liberal government in Victoria, I am sorry to say, is taxing the people so much that they are leaving: they are shifting to Queensland, and places like that, to get away from him. The Liberal Party is even taxing business. This is the party of business. In Victoria, what does Jeffrey Kennett do? He puts a land tax on small business. Therefore, he is taxing businesses down; they are his natural allies who prop him up all the time.

The Liberal Party is sacking people. It is closing schools and kindergartens; it is closing rail lines; and on and on it goes. It has even got to the stage now that people are being thrown off the work care scheme and on to Commonwealth social security benefits. It is a fact that, if a person has his foot cut off in Victoria, under the Liberals' new accident compensation scheme, it is not considered a serious accident. A person can stand on one leg with his foot cut off at the ankle, and it is not a serious accident. This is the sort of thing that Kennett is doing in Victoria.

However, there are a few people who are starting to hit back at his budget cuts. Recently, the Premier of Victoria started to attack the Family Court. One of the judges had the temerity to speak out and say that the Victorian budget was bad for young people and for child care in Victoria. Fancy someone speaking out against the Premier of Victoria; how dare he! The bishop attacked the Premier and he got a bit of a burst. Anyone who speaks out against the Kennett government is attacked. There is only one person who can answer and that person is Jeffrey Kennett; all his ministers are gagged; they are not allowed to speak.

He is also closing down ambulance stations. We saw recently that an ambulance could not get to an injured police officer. That police officer died—it is believed, although it is not certain—because of the changes that have been made to the ambulance services.

In its budget, which has not been mentioned too much, the Victorian government added 3c a litre to diesel fuel. So the truckers had the temerity to speak up against this, and what did Jeffrey do? He attacked them. `How dare they attack me!' was his response. He has also dumped the head of the Liquor Licensing Board because that person had the temerity to say that Jeffrey Kennett got his liquor licence for his sly grog in a suspect way.

The federal budget is the only economic package that keeps Victoria going. Despite all that the Liberals are doing, I am now pleased to say that the federal government policies such as low inflation, low interest and injections of federal cash are reviving Victoria. Confidence has returned and we are again on the move, thanks to the federal government budget.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) must surely have been jesting—albeit a rather bitter and cynical jest—when he submitted this particular item of private members business. What he is suggesting in this motion is almost an impossibility. How can this House note the positive financial and social impact of the budget on the people of Victoria when the sad and unfortunate fact is that there is nothing positive to note? From the moment the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) resumed his seat after delivering his now totally discredited speech on 17 August, it was already apparent to most Australians that the 1993 budget and the words `positive impact' are mutually exclusive terms.

PARA.TAB: Nothing that the honourable member for Dunkley has said in this debate today has done anything to change that fact. Furthermore, in this motion, the honourable member for Dunkley has failed to define which version of the budget he is actually referring to. Is it mark 1, mark 2, mark 3 or, for that matter, any other subsequent versions that may yet emerge along the way? Not that this lack of definition is of any real consequence because, despite the improvements and modifications so far forced on the government by the opposition—and rest assured we intend to keep working on it—the budget is still, and will doubtless remain, deficient in many significant respects. With the best will in the world one cannot salvage the unsalvageable.

Let us start by examining the impact of the budget on unemployed Victorians. There is no doubt that unemployment is one of the most significant problems facing Australia and Australians today. It is a very real tragedy that so many people cannot find work. In Victoria there are almost a quarter of a million people registered as unemployed and thousands more who are not receiving unemployment benefits but are nonetheless actively seeking employment, or are underemployed. There are many others of all ages and from all walks of life who have given up all hope of ever finding a job. What does this budget do for them? Nothing; nothing at all.

The increase in unemployment figures for August only serves to confirm the sorry fact that this government has failed to take any positive or constructive measures to assist unemployed Victorians to get back to work. The Treasurer's claim on budget night that `the primary objective of this budget is jobs' has been shown to be little better than a cruel and heartless hoax. Rather than offering any prospect of improvement in the already desperate unemployment situation, this budget reinforces the depressing probability of unemployment remaining at unacceptable levels for the foreseeable future. In fact, the likely impact of some of the anti-business measures in this budget will be to exacerbate this problem. One cannot hope to increase job opportunities in times of economic uncertainty by increasing imposts on business. It just does not work that way.

Let me demonstrate this point by examining another of the budget measures that have the potential to impact in a very negative way on many Victorians, particularly in my electorate of Casey which includes the wine making area of the Yarra Valley. I refer of course to the exorbitant and unjustifiable proposed 55 per cent increase in the sales tax on wine.

Mr David Wollan, the Managing Director of the Tarrawarra Vineyard, Yarra Glen, has written to me about this matter. Unfortunately, the anticipated financial and social impacts identified by Mr Wollan are certainly not of the positive variety. I quote some extracts from his letter:

SPEECH.PARA: I am managing director of, and a shareholder in, a small wine producing company in Victoria's Yarra Valley. I am outraged at the Government's proposal to increase the sales tax on wine from 20% to 31% . . .

PARA.TAB: Let me explain some of the specifics as they affect my business. Our turnover is less than $1 million but over the past 5 years 35-40% of this has been in export sales.

We have spent a small fortune developing markets in the USA, UK, Japan, Hong Kong, Germany, New Zealand, Spain, Canada and Malaysia. We have yet to see a profit from this effort but in spite of our small size, we have persevered in building a place for our brand of premium Australian wine in these markets.

I employ a winemaker, a vineyard manager, a secretary/bookkeeper, a salesman and 2 vineyard/cellar hands. We are sitting on almost a million dollars of stock at cost and our investment in vineyards, winery buildings and plant is over $2 million.

Previously—at 20%—sales tax on the domestic portion of our modest sales would have earned the Treasury $60,000 to $80,000 per annum. With the increase in the sales tax to 31% this should generate another $35,000 to $45,000. Sadly it does not work like this.

We are unlikely to be able to pass this impost on to our local consumers as the price elasticity of demand for wine is high. (Research done for a report to the Victorian parliament by its Economic Review Committee a few years ago showed that a 10% increase in the price of wine leads to a 17% drop in demand.)
We cannot afford a sales decline of this magnitude so we will have to absorb most, if not all, of this impost if we are to survive.

But what sort of survival is it? Our losses will increase by close to the full extent of the tax (i.e. $40,000). This is the annual cost of employing a person or the cost of our export market development activities.
What do you suggest we do? Add another person to the million unemployed or forsake the $200,000 plus of export revenue we generate annually?

In the great scheme of things these figures are small change and beneath the concern of our Treasurer and his advisers. But Australia, as a modern industrial nation can only slide into further decay if small, enthusiastic, quality oriented businesses such as ours are pushed to the wall by capricious Government action . . .

My wines have won major national and international awards. They are finally being treated seriously internationally, but just as we start to get results, we are tripped up by the same government that tells us how vital our export effort is!
The protected producers of the European Community are paid subsidies to fill wine lakes; we are encouraged to retrench our workers and choke off our market development.

Maybe the sensible thing would be to close the business down and sell my winemaking services to the Europeans who value my cutting-edge technical skills. My workers can then join John Dawkins' army of unemployed and perhaps then—as he adds up the benefit pay-outs, he might reflect on how much cheaper it would have been to let us get on with our business.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst David Wollan's comments are directed towards the wine industry, the sentiments he expresses could just as readily be applied to many other small business enterprises in Victoria and, indeed, Australia. The winegrowers are by no means the only potential victims of this latest Labor budget.

PARA.TAB: One of the saddest and most unsatisfactory aspects of the budget is that it is the battlers, the low-income earners, the poor, the disadvantaged and the vulnerable—many of whom are farmers, pensioners and self-funded retirees—who will suffer most from the inequitable measures it contains. They are the ones who will be hardest hit by the increases in wholesale sales tax and fuel excise which will result in price rises for a wide range of basic commodities.These increases came into effect on budget night. More than six weeks later, the necessary legislation has still not been passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is that?

—The government has refused to present the bills in accordance with the requirements of the constitution. The government is therefore collecting these taxes without the necessary legislative authority. Does the honourable member for Dunkley think that this extraordinary and unacceptable situation, with consumers standing to lose as much as $20 million through the payment of indirect taxes which may never be legal, constitutes a positive financial and social impact of the budget on the people of Victoria?

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the honourable member for Dunkley does. Perhaps he and his Labor colleagues also think it is fair and reasonable to promise personal tax cuts and then withhold them. So far, the timing of the introduction of the long awaited, legislated for tax cuts has been altered three times. It is worth noting that for every week the personal income tax cuts are delayed, the government saves itself about $50 million. The first round of cuts, rescheduled for mid-November, is now unlikely to be introduced by that date, and the second round, as we already know, has disappeared into the never-never.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —In any event, by 1996-97 bracket creep will have effectively wiped out any cursory benefits that the tax cuts may offer. This, combined with the higher indirect taxes, will leave everyone significantly worse off. Perhaps there may be positive financial or social impact for the people of Victoria, although I must admit I cannot imagine what it could possibly be, in light of the government's decision to change the rules halfway through the game in regard to taxation of lump sum payments of unused accrued annual leave. What about those Victorians—and there are thousands of them—who are simply not able or not permitted to take their full entitlements every year? It is often not their decision or choice to build up substantial leave credits, but they are going to be penalised for it.

PARA.TAB: What about the farmers struggling to survive in the ongoing rural depression? What is in the budget for them? The Victorian Farmers Federation is strongly opposed to the proposed indirect tax increases, which will add significantly to farm costs at a time when the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics predicts that farm incomes will fall yet again. Where is the positive impact in that for Victorian taxpayers and people? I say to the honourable member for Dunkley that this budget and what it represents are a disgrace to this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The value of the federal budget to the people of Victoria in real terms is clear, particularly in direct contrast to the actions of the Kennett state government. The electorate of Corinella has the 11th highest proportion of people under the age of five—over 11,000 kids—of any electorate in Australia, and it also has one of the highest proportions, at 55.5 per cent, of couples who are both in the labour force. The federal budget included a child-care rebate which will greatly assist many of these young couples in my electorate. In addition, we announced a further 29,000 child-care places, sales tax exemptions for child-care centres and assistance to establish new playgroups.

PARA.TAB: The success of further sections of the federal government's child-care policy requires the cooperation of the Kennett government, cooperation that we have received from other state governments but not from Kennett. This is not unexpected, given the Kennett government's draconian cuts to the preschool system—cuts that, according to Kindergarten Parents of Victoria, could force kindergarten fees up about 300 per cent; cuts that will see voluntary preschool committees of management, already stretched to the limit, having to find an average of an extra $16,500 per year.

In education, where the Kennett government is only prepared to match the average, the difference is again stark. In my electorate, the Kennett government has already closed four schools and more are set to close when the results of the ridiculously named quality provision task force process become known. This QPT process is nothing more than the Kennett government doing a Pontius Pilate, washing its hands of responsibility for education, setting staff against school councils, against parents and against other schools.

The federal government has not washed its hands of the young people of Australia. In those areas of the education system that the federal government has responsibility for, we are not prepared to search for educational areas showing signs of excellence, cut them down to an average and attempt to dress it all up as quality provision. The approach of the federal government to educating our young people could not be more different. In higher education—and this is an issue of concern to me because the number of young people in my electorate going to university is far too low—this year the federal government is putting in $4.6 billion. That is about twice the OECD average in terms of the contribution to higher education in a national budget. Our contribution is about 4.5 per cent, compared with Japan's 1.1 per cent of its budget provisions.

Included in federal government initiatives are measures to ensure that more university places are available to our young people when they leave what is left of the Victorian school system. If we were to follow the principles of the Kennett government and say that averages only are good enough and it is all we are going to do, we would be cutting our expenditure in half. There would be no funds available for the new Monash University campus at Berwick which, when it is completed, will service a significant proportion of my electorate.

When the federal government talks about quality provision in the education sector, it does not take a Kennett style approach and close universities. Instead, we are providing $76 million to enhance quality in universities. Those areas of the education system that fall under the responsibility of the federal government are governed by policies concerned with the long-term welfare of our young people and our country, rather than a Kennett style approach of cut first and ask questions later.

If the people of my electorate were given the choice of cuts in education, child care and kindergartens and thousands of government employees sacked, versus no state budget deficit, I know which one they would choose. The approach of the Kennett government is not one of financial responsibility but one of uncaring political zealotry. It is not an approach of planning for a stable future, because the lack of cohesion and the social costs created by the financially punitive measures inflicted on the less well off in Victoria will more than offset any savings. While the federal government has delivered on its election promises, what the Kennett government has been doing, and continues to do, to the people in my electorate, constitutes one of the best arguments yet for putting the issue of the abolition of the states on the republican agenda.

Looking at other areas of the federal budget, the objective is to promote jobs through fiscal stimulus, export and industry restructuring facilitation, and strong employment education and training programs. Over 100 separate spending commitments will be implemented. The government has honoured all commitments made to farmers and resource industries, including more than doubling its previous commitment to RAS. In one of our fastest growing export areas, tourism, there will be an additional $80 million over the next four years. Initiatives are to include regional tourism development, special interest tourism marketing development and eco-tourism development.

Contrast that with the approach of the Kennett government. Twenty-three teaching positions are to be cut from the five secondary schools in the Shire of Cranbourne, which will double the number of teaching positions cut in the electorate since the Kennett government was elected. The results of the quality provision task force to be announced on 15 October are expected to include that more than 100 schools in Victoria be closed and 2,400 more teachers be sacked. It is a disgrace. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion by the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) borders on contempt of this parliament. The motion says that we should consider the positive impacts of this budget on the state of Victoria. That is a joke, from a mob sitting opposite on the treasury bench that never expected to win an election, that did not expect to form government, that had no plans in place to do anything—no vision for the future and no concept of how to get Australia out of the mess that it had put us in.

TAB.TAB: I tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that Victorians on the street, and average Australians all over the country, know in their hearts that they too expected a coalition win and now they are in mass confusion, because they do not understand what is happening to them. Australians expected positive programs to address unemployment to try to lead this nation out of the mess that the current federal government has gotten us into. Instead, what do they get? They get this budget that is based on deceit, lies, misunderstandings, misrepresentations and untruths.

PARA.TAB: Government members fought an election campaign and I know the honourable member for Dunkley never expected to win. In his heart he never thought he had a prayer of winning at the last federal election. The honourable member for Dunkley and lots of his colleagues who sit on the other side of the House now say what a wonderful job this budget will do for Victoria. Did the honourable member for Dunkley fight for it in caucus? Did he say, `Prime Minister, this is a terrific budget.'? Did he say, `Joe Dawkins, Treasurer, this is a fantastic budget.'? I bet he did not. I bet he said, `This is going to kill my constituents. I will never retain my seat in 1994 or 1995 or 1996, whenever we have the next federal poll'—it might be sooner than later with the way we are going.

This is a budget framed on dishonesty and deceit. The honourable member for Dunkley talked at length about the huge number of people in Victoria receiving government benefits and spoke of that as a positive initiative of this budget. It is a crying shame, is it not, that we have 13 per cent of our people in the state of Victoria unable to find jobs, unable to find fulfilling employment to take care of themselves and their families—their children, their loved ones. They have no jobs but they can expect a government handout.

It is good that we do not have a social underclass in this country, but I tell honourable members that we are rapidly developing a welfare mentality based on Labor's approach of taking as much money as possible from the population—from anywhere, it does not matter where from, there is no strategic planning—and redistributing it. Do not worry about providing real jobs, do not worry about encouraging a real economy out there, do not worry about doing real quality things which will make a difference to the lives of Australians, and to Victorians in particular.

There is 13.1 per cent unemployment in Victoria and this government attacks the people who are unemployed, those who are on social security benefits, because the government has opted for a mishmash of tax increases that will impact particularly hard on those who are at the bottom of the income scale. The government makes no apologies for that. Why not? It is because the misrepresentations that they made going into the federal election campaign led them to conclude that the economy was in great shape. They thought we would come roaring out of the recession, that the tax cuts that were l-a-w, law, were affordable and in place, and that we needed no further taxes to cover those tax cuts. Wrong! Wrong! Wrong!

So the deficit increases. That is not to the benefit of Victorians. Unemployment will continue to increase until we can do something about micro-economic reform and encourage industry to invest in new capacity. But taxing industry is not going to encourage industry to invest and it is not going to encourage industry to provide new jobs. The honourable member for Corinella (Mr Griffin) finally entered the debate in the last 30 seconds of his speech and said, `Hooray, I have the solution, let us abolish the states'. We will abolish Victoria, will we? That is his simplistic solution. We will abolish Victoria and then the federal budget will be seen to have done its job and it will be terrific for Australia! (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ignore the comments of the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) because I felt that he totally missed the point of the whole debate. I would like to address my remarks to the positive impact of the budget on people and I want to focus on a particular group of people. One of those positive aspects resulting from the budget is the announcement that a mature age allowance will be introduced from 20 March 1994. This social security measure is particularly relevant to my electorate of McMillan in Victoria and will benefit a large number of those workers considered to be long term unemployed who currently receive the newstart allowance.

PARA.TAB: A massive restructuring of major industries within my electorate will take place. The State Electricity Commission of Victoria and Australian Paper Manufacturers have seen their work force numbers reduced significantly. In fact, in the SEC over the last few years the employment numbers have dropped from 10,000 to 5,200. That is in the SEC alone.

A large proportion of those who have left these industries as part of the restructuring processes were workers accustomed to long-term and secure employment, many of them having served their particular industry for up to 30 years or longer. Past years have seen a large number of these workers aged between 60 and 65 years slot into the social security system, firstly, as recipients of the jobsearch allowance and later the newstart allowance.

The combination of a particularly difficult current labour market in my electorate and the relatively new but necessary tightening of social security measures used to assess the genuineness of benefit recipients have seen these workers placed in a burdensome and often inconvenient predicament. While work and activity tests serve an essential purpose for the majority of newstart recipients, they could prove humiliating for workers in the 60 to 65 age bracket who are required to attend retraining courses with other long-term unemployed people much younger than themselves.

In addition to the required attendance at retraining courses these workers have also had to personally hand statements to the regional social security department on a fortnightly basis to ensure continuation of their payments. Those statements must outline the several measures the recipients have taken in an effort to obtain employment during the past fortnight. These are difficult procedures for people 60 and over.

The subsequent introduction of a mature age allowance is a responsible and sensitive government reaction to this situation which has been intensified in recent years and I am very pleased to see the measure announced. I know from gauging the reaction of many workers in this category within my electorate that the measure is a very welcome one and one I feel will contribute to maintaining their self-esteem.

The mature age allowance will benefit those aged 60 and over who are eligible for newstart allowance, have received income support for 12 months or more and have 10 years qualifying residence in Australia. Transfer to the mature age allowance will be voluntary and recipients will not have to continue to satisfy the newstart allowance work activity tests.

While this will save recipients both time and money they will benefit even further by retaining the right to use CES facilities if they wish. The mature age allowance payment will be the equivalent to the age pension. For a single person it is $312.10 per fortnight and for couples it is $260.30 each per fortnight. Those on the allowance will receive the same fringe benefits as people on the age pension, including a pensioner health benefit card and the payment of a pharmaceutical allowance and telephone allowance.

In addition, the income of those who choose to receive the mature age allowance will be assessed under the pensions income and assets tests, which are more generous than those for newstart payments. Those on mature age allowances will also have the pension free area applied to them. This free area, unlike the newstart one, is increased each year to match price rises. Recipients will also be able to travel overseas for a period of up to 26 weeks while remaining on the payment, and their superannuation benefits will continue to be preserved until they reach age pension age, or until they access those benefits.

The mature age allowance is a budgetary measure which more than adequately reflects the federal government's recognition of the difficulties faced by older, unemployed people in the current labour market. It will be of particular benefit in Victoria, where the Kennett government is systematically setting about implementing its infamous slash and burn policies, with little regard to the effect those policies have on everyday Victorians.

The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) mentioned in his speech the confusion about the fact that the Labor government won. Certainly there is confusion because we won, but it is amongst those sitting on the side of the House from which he was speaking. Honourable members opposite do not know how to handle not being in government, even after having spent 11 years sitting over there, with another three ahead of them now.

The honourable member for La Trobe also mentioned the social underclass. That is what we would have had, had we had a Liberal government. That is why it was rejected. That is why this measure is a very positive one in relation to the budget for the people of Victoria, as well as for the state of Victoria itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the height of arrogance for the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) to put this motion about the budget impact on Victorians before the House for consideration, and to give himself yet another opportunity to pursue his incessant bashing of the government of Victoria. I have not been in this House very long, and yet I have only ever heard the honourable member for Dunkley pursue that line. I wonder whether he has anything constructive or positive to say.

PARA.TAB: Why does the honourable member for Dunkley hate Victoria? The honourable member should look at the last decade in Victoria and consider the abysmal financial management of Victoria by his mob. Perhaps, to shut him up once and for all, I should remind him that the Kennett government in Victoria assumed the responsibility to clean up Victoria's problem: a $70 billion debt, which amounts to $45,000 per family in Victoria.

The honourable member for Dunkley should recognise that. He should also recognise the deficit in the current account of $1.2 billion—spending every year more than what the state could earn. On top of that, there were unfunded liabilities for workcare and superannuation, which added another $1.8 billion to the deficit, bringing the total to $3 billion per year.

The honourable member for Dunkley suggested that it is the new government in Victoria that is forcing people to go to Queensland. I would suggest that he consider the fact that those people left Victoria when it was under the governments of Mr Cain and Mrs Kirner. Putting this motion before this House just creates an opportunity for diversion, which is typical of the tactics used by the current government and the honourable members who sit on that side of the House.

Let me point out a few additional difficulties that the Victorian government confronts in Victoria. Victoria is the one state in this nation that suffers under the difficulty of competing with imports. It is the one state in this country that needs those costs of imports reduced. I would suggest that the honourable member for Dunkley should concentrate on the budget this federal government has put forward, rather than on condemning other governments which are trying to take constructive action.

The impact on all Victorians of the fuel price increases will be more than the $3 per week suggested by the honourable member for Dunkley for those low income people and pensioners he mentioned. By the time that the impact of the wholesale sale tax increases on every consumer item from soap and cosmetics to food items is felt, the extra cost will be at least $5 per grocery trolley per week. Three dollars is hardly enough to compensate for those benefits that the honourable member for Dunkley put before the House.

I would like to suggest that the honourable member for Dunkley consider the desperate position of grape growers in my electorate. They contribute something like 50 per cent of the grape production in Victoria. They now face the prospect of a reduced demand across the whole of Australia. There is a reduced demand of 50,000 tonnes per annum of wine variety grapes, because of the massive hike in wholesale sale tax on wine. That tonnage represents the entire production of wine grapes in the Barossa Valley.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in your electorate, though.

—The honourable member for Dunkley should take note that there is very little joy and very little that is positive for the wine grape growers in my electorate which, I would remind him, is a significant part of Victoria—some 20 per cent of its geographical area. The Kennett government was faced with the difficulty of how to manage and how to cut back this deficit. Even with the difficult decisions it has already made, its current account deficit is still, this year, $700 million. The deficit went from $3 billion to $700 million in 12 months. The leader of the Labor Party in Victoria made an absolute fool of himself yesterday, racing all over the state saying that he would run a balanced current account. How on earth does he propose to further reduce the $700 million which the Kennett government has been able to achieve?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House acts urgently to respond to the recommendations in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission's report entitled The call for recognition to ensure:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)an end to the discrimination against the descendants of South Sea Islanders;
(2)acceptance of programs to provide these persons with equal opportunities in building, health education and legal representation;
(3)the retention of their culture, arts and heritage; and
(4)that descendants of South Sea Islanders remain proud Australians.

The report by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission on the situation of Australians who are South Sea Islanders was handed down on 15 December 1992, which was some nine months ago. My motion calls for this House—and, through it, this government—to act urgently to respond to the six recommendations that are listed in that report. Perhaps, in contrast to a history of 125 years or longer of discrimination against these people, a nine-month delay may not appear too long to some people. But it is too long; and I would hope that this House, all political parties, and the government would act without delay to end this discrimination against South Sea Islanders and their descendants.

PARA.TAB: At our current state of social and economic development—and particularly with many of the Mabo claims and decisions—some Australians would believe that the most disadvantaged group in Australia are the 229,000 people of Aboriginal descent and the 27,000 people of Torres Strait Island descent. This is not the case. By far the most disadvantaged are the 15,000 to 20,000 South Sea Islander descendants of those early islanders who, from the 1860s, were blackbirded or kidnapped from their home islands of Vanuatu; the Solomons, including Guadalcanal; the Gilberts; and many others, to be indentured in the cane farming industry of Queensland and northern New South Wales.

Some of the conclusions from the report are interesting. The report said that South Sea Islanders have suffered from essentially racial discrimination and harsh treatment. In fact, the statistical profiles in the report indicate that they are one of the poorest groups in Australia. The report also says that the South Sea Islanders as a group are in a situation of high need, with particular difficulties observed in school retention rates, employment skills, home ownership and health. While material benefits have been given to South Sea Islanders, governments have denied South Sea Islanders recognition as a distinct black minority group.

The report also says that such lack of recognition, over time, contributed to increased tensions amongst the South Sea Islanders themselves and between them and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. Lastly, the South Sea Islanders are now being denied access to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander programs, and are being forced into mainstream programs which are seen by them to be culturally inappropriate, with the result that those programs are not used.

As the report notes, legally the original workers were not slaves but indentured labourers, receiving some #6 per year for a three-year contract, #18 altogether. But that slavery is more than a legal concept; it is a way of describing how two groups of people relate. As a result many South Sea Islanders during the inquiry referred to themselves as the descendants of slaves.

In his book Fragments of a Lost Heritage, Noel Fatnowna, a close and sincere friend to many, traces his heritage, in much the same way as an American descendant of a slave traced his origins back to Africa in the internationally proclaimed book Roots. Fatnowna traces his heritage back to his grandfather and grand-uncles at a time when they were blackbirded from Malaita. It is clear that their removal from their homeland to Australia was most involuntary. I indicate this not from an intent to build into this argument a guilt complex but to say that no other ethnic group, not even the original convicts, came to our shores with less recognition or greater discrimination than did the South Sea Islanders.

The change in our constitution in 1967 to recognise the indigenous Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and the formation of ATSIC in the late 1980s compounded the discrimination; it did not relieve it. This is in stark contrast to the role South Sea Islander descendants played in the creation of the great Australian sugar industry, in decentralising Queensland to towns right along the coast, and in bringing South Sea Islander culture and heritage to Australia and maintaining it there.

On the last statistical count in my electorate of Dawson there are 3,224 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, yet no part of those statistics indicates the numbers of South Sea Islanders—who total, as the report notes, 3,420 in the Mackay region and 1,634 in the northern region of my electorate. As the report points out, the major discrimination is that South Sea Islanders are not included in any ATSIC programs. This means that they are not included in the benefits of the funds allocated to ATSIC. My understanding is that $1,316 million of Commonwealth funds were allocated in 1992-93 to ATSIC and other Commonwealth programs for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. Yet, as the report indicates, in health, education, housing and community services, South Sea Islanders suffer the same disadvantages as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders but have access to none of those funds.

South Sea Islander home ownership rates are lower than those of any other racial group in Australia. As evidence, in Mackay, South Sea Islanders who were previously in the Aboriginal housing society are being severely discouraged from the ownership and renting of cooperative housing and are being expelled from the membership. There is obviously a discrimination that is not being redressed by the state housing authorities, yet $327 million has been allocated through ATSIC in 1992-93.

In the health area the report suggests that the South Sea Islanders suffer a relatively high incidence of diabetes and that they die younger than Australians overall. Again, $67 million provided to ATSIC is not available to South Sea Islanders.
It is interesting to note a survey in the report of 39 South Sea Islander schools by a Mr Simon Bliss concludes that, in education:

SPEECH.PARA: Islander students continue to experience difficulties in language skills and mathematics;
they do not have their right to an appropriate education secured in government policy;
very few services exist to support Islander students' educational difficulties;
South Sea Islanders are a minority group in education;
Islander students experience considerably higher rates of difficulties in education than their non-Islander peers;

Again I mention that $295 million has been specially allocated to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, yet these people with greatest difficulties have access to none of that. The unemployment rate for South Sea Islanders is 28.5 per cent, 2.5 times the national average. This reflects a system that does not deliver adequate education, health, housing or opportunity for income earning to the South Sea Islanders themselves.

PARA.TAB: I do not wish to dwell too long on report statistics. Sometimes they can be a bit loaded one way or the other and sometimes the findings are not accurate. Nor do I want to dwell too much on the negative aspects of this discrimination, except to say the report itself is well worth reading for its coverage of the proud history of the South Sea Islanders in Australia.

I want to place on record the contributions that these descendants of the South Sea Islanders are making as Australians to Australian culture, the economy, sport and many other areas. I pay tribute to all the South Sea Islanders who contribute in all these ways to the economy of Queensland and Australia and to the social and community fabric of their own electorate. I particularly mention those people who have formed the Australian South Sea Islanders United Council Inc. In particular, I thank Patricia Corowa and two people from my own electorate, Colin Andrew and Christine Andrew, brother and sister, who are making sure that the rights of the people are being pushed.

I spoke previously of Noel Fatnowna, a most respected member of the Mackay community and an islander descendant himself. He was the author of the book Fragments of a Lost Heritage. Again, I suggest that, for anybody who wants to know what happened in those earlier days and what is still happening, this should be compulsory reading. He contributed positively to Australian culture. Unfortunately, Noel died in 1991 and through that we lost a great Australian.

Three South Sea Islanders—Francis Fewquandie, Norman Womal and Noel Howard—gave their lives in the Vietnam War while many other of these descendants fought in World War II and Vietnam. Probably the proudest is Mal Meninga, who captains the Australian Kangaroos. I identify him as one of the truly great sportsmen in Australia today. Henry Tongoa, in 1901, set up the first Pacific islander association.

Most importantly, South Sea Islanders play an integral part in our Christian churches and, through that, in our society. They have retained their dignity, their heritage and traditions. They are good and proper Australians. We should start treating them as Australians by implementing the recommendations of this report, The call for recognition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will start by reading from a book. It reads:

PARA.TAB: The master hurried them down a plank onto the timber which appeared to be floating on the water. The men who had been standing and looking at them now began to grab and push them towards huge brown and black animals that were tied to flat pieces of timber. Skinny short sticks with thick hard brown vines attached, were used to prod Wacvie and his fellows up onto the flat timber, behind the big animals.

The men were shackled with irons, and their legs, not having touched land for many weeks, were unsteady. Some felt as though their feet would snap from their ankles, and some felt they could not walk at all. The horse-drawn drays were difficult to climb onto because each man had to lift himself up with his hands and then drag his feet up by his body.

Side by side they sat, each leaning against his neighbour to give physical support to each other. When all the drays were loaded with the black men, they were drawn into a line facing the unmade road. Dressed in broad-brimmed hats, white linen shirts and trousers, white men walked by the drays, casting their expert eyes over the black men.
After strolling around the drays many times, they gathered together in groups to discuss the condition of the slaves.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose we could think that that might be a quote from a novel written about the Deep South in America, about slavery in that country; but it is not. It is a quote from a novel by Faith Bandler about her father. Faith Bandler is a well-known writer in Australia and a descendent of a South Pacific Islander, Wacvie Mussingkon.

PARA.TAB: This is a story about Faith's father, Wacvie Mussingkon, who in June 1883 was kidnapped from Craig Cove, a village on the coast of Ambrym Island in the New Hebrides. He was sold as a slave in Mackay, Queensland, and that is where the quote comes from. He worked in the sugar plantations until he escaped in 1897, finally settling in Tumbulgum in New South Wales where he died in July 1924.

It is not often that we have the opportunity in this House to speak on a bipartisan motion like this one. I commend the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) for putting this motion before the House and drawing to the House's attention the human rights report. There is a call for recognition of the South Sea Islander people, who, unlike a lot of other people in Australia, were not migrants who came to this country of their own choice. They were brought here under slave conditions. When that particular period of our history finished, they were then forced to go back to their homeland and were not necessarily taken back to their own particular island. I commend the honourable member for Dawson for drawing this issue to the attention of the House and I am particularly pleased to have the opportunity to speak on it.

When some time ago I read the book by Faith Bandler about her father, I was particularly moved. I had seen Faith Bandler on a TV show one night speaking about the plight of the South Pacific Island people in Australia and I got her book out to read about her father. It sat there for some time before I got the opportunity to read it. Earlier this year I had the opportunity to visit a number of South Pacific islands and I took this book with me. After visiting some of those islands, I read this book on the way home. It takes a long time to get home from some of those islands, so I had plenty of time on the plane. It was a fitting time to read it, when we think about how these people have been treated.

The report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission tabled in this House on 6 May, which the honourable member for Dawson has referred to, marks an important milestone in the fight for the recognition of the rights of South Sea Islander people in Australia. The report, The call for recognition, is a stinging indictment of the century of discrimination and injustices suffered by these proud people. The vast majority of these people are descended from the Melanesian group and were brought to Queensland to work in the sugar industry during the latter part of the 19th century.

This government has been proud of its record of recognising the unique place of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Australian society. Of course, that is a very important topic at the present time as we consider the Mabo legislation. We have put in place a range of programs in areas such as health, community welfare and employment in an attempt to recognise the special needs of these people. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has also been established in order to give these people more power over their own lives and their destiny as a people.

While we still have a long way to go before Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders gain their rightful place in Australian society, at least the problems of indigenous people have been recognised and the need for action has been broadly accepted by the community.
