Sadly, the same cannot be said for the plight of the South Sea Islander people. The report of the human rights commission sums up their history by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The South Sea Islander history over the past century indicates that their general treatment was as close to slavery as the laws of the time would allow. White Society used them as labourers when needed and discarded them when no longer needed: they were coerced and expendable labour.

South Sea Islanders today suffer discrimination and the social problems that go with it similar to those that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people experience, but unfortunately there are few programs which are targeted at addressing this discrimination.

PARA.TAB: According to the results of a census of South Sea Islanders conducted last year, they are 2 1/2 times as likely to be unemployed as other Australians, have average weekly earnings at half the national level and have the lowest rate of home ownership of any group in this country. Yet the only way in which these people can access government assistance is by denying their heritage and claiming to be Aborigines or Torres Strait Islander people. No group should be forced to deny its heritage in this way, and I endorse the remarks of the honourable member for Dawson. Not only does it force them to live a lie; it also creates tensions between them and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, which are certainly not needed.

Many South Sea Islanders are being denied access to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander programs, meaning that even this avenue of financial assistance has been cut off to them. It is essential that South Sea Islanders receive rightful recognition as a unique minority group that has suffered as a result of racial discrimination.

I believe that the report before us needs urgent attention by the government and I hope that the government will pick up the points that have been made here today by the honourable member for Dawson and other speakers to this motion. To highlight the great tragedy and our shame I quote again from the foreword of Faith Bandler's book, where she talked about her father:

Wacvie Mussingkon was an islander of the group which white men call the New Hebrides. He grew to manhood in the gentle rhythms of an island village. He swam, caught fish, played in the trees, joined in the mourning for the dead and knew the coming of islanders with gifts for the dancing ground.

But this life ended in the few moments that it takes to shackle a man. He was taken by blackbirders to the sugar plantations of Queensland. Colonial Australia had developed its very own slave trade to secure cheap labour for the canefields, and Wacvie was a victim of this crime.

His days become governed by the clock instead of the sun. Unable to understand what was happening to them, he and his fellow islanders suffered the cruelty of overseers, meagre food, bug-infested quarters, and gruelling days of labour under the tropical sun.

But Wacvie never lost his sense of human dignity. He had to fight against despair, bewilderment, and apathy, but for his fellow-captives he became the symbol of all that they had lost and all that they might hope for.
His struggle to gain control over the pattern of his life, so cruelly distorted by captivity in an alien land, is the continuing thread of this book.

Wacvie Mussingkon was the father of Faith Bandler, the author. He told his story to her and she has written it into this biographical novel. Simply and urgently, but without bitterness, she tells a story which is at once an indictment of man's inhumanity to man and an insight into a portion of Australian history which most of us choose to forget.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I congratulate the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) for bringing forward this motion. It is a very important motion not only to South Sea Islander Australians but also, I believe, to the whole of the Australian community. The 20,000 descendants of the South Sea Islanders living in Australia are really the forgotten people of Australia. It is interesting that some 8 per cent of that population is living on the north coast of New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: In considering any aspect of what we do in this place and in the politics of Australia, I always prefer to believe very strongly that the `P' in politics stands for people. If we are not concerned about people, what on earth are we doing here? I am reminded of this when I think of a gentleman that the honourable member for Dawson mentioned, the late Noel Fatnowna. To my mind, he epitomises everything that was great and good in the South Sea Island people.

I was privileged to first meet Noel Fatnowna in Mackay in 1977. I recall very vividly that my wife and I were to meet him in a milk bar/coffee shop. We were supposed to be there for about half an hour; some four hours later we were still there. He was drinking milkshakes; we were drinking coffee. The conversation was flowing like a great rushing torrent.

Noel Fatnowna was, I believe, a marvellous man. He was widely respected throughout North Queensland. I am speaking about him because, for me, he epitomises the contribution that has already been made by South Sea Island people and will continue to be made. He was remembered particularly for his services in Mackay as a caring and dedicated ambulance officer for over 40 years. He was a familiar figure throughout the whole community. He provided an enormous amount of leadership for the Islander community most importantly towards good community relations, better housing and better health. He went out of his way to speak to school students about the common citizenship of all Australians. He was a very visionary person.

He was a peacemaker and he had this enormous capacity to put other people's worries ahead of his own. I think it was very significant that he was invited to represent the Kanakas on the Queensland Aboriginal and Islanders Commission. I use the term `Kanakas' deliberately because it is not a pejorative one: it is a word that means `man of the islands' and it is a word that all South Sea Islanders or Kanakas can use with pride. This was the very first time that the Australian South Sea Islanders or Kanakas had ever been represented formally on anything.

I recall very well indeed the four-hour initial meeting with him. I preface my next comment by saying that his skin colour was very dark—he was indeed black—and he had an enormous and wonderful sense of humour. I recall him saying to me during that meeting, `It is hard to be an ambulance officer at an accident after dark. Unless I smile at the patients they will not see me'. That is an indication of the sort of man Noel was and an indication of the sort of people these wonderful South Sea Island people are. Some 60,000 were brought here from the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Fiji and Papua New Guinea between 1863 and 1904. They were used to plug the shortage of labour at the end of convict transportation. By 1906, in spite of having provided the backbone of the Australian sugar industry, they were no longer welcome in this country because of the White Australia Policy but, fortunately, we have changed mightily since that time.

I want to say to the people of Australia and to the honourable members of this parliament that the recommendations of the report on the situation of Australian South Sea Islanders should be implemented by the government. I support the statements of honourable members who have already spoken on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dodd Mr P.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As other honourable members have suggested, the South Sea Island people are the forgotten people. The first point I make is that all previous governments are responsible for this disgraceful situation. Labor governments and the predecessors of the present coalition have all had a disgraceful record, going back to the last century, in relation to what was basically slave labour. I have to say, as a proud trade unionist in this parliament, that the trade union movement also should stand condemned for its reaction historically to South Sea Island people.

PARA.TAB: But we have to look to the future now, and I congratulate the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) on bringing this matter before the House. South Sea Island people constitute a considerable part of his electorate but, as previous speakers have said, there are South Sea Island people throughout the Australian community, including in my electorate at Cairns, Innisfail and Port Douglas. The most northern part of my electorate is probably the most multicultural part of Australia. A lot of South Sea Island people who came to the Torres Strait area are obviously distant relatives of the people further south. Obviously, as the member for Leichhardt, I support this motion.

It is estimated that there are between 15,000 and 20,000 descendants of South Sea Islanders in Australia and 12,000 of them identify themselves as South Sea Islanders. They include—I think quite proudly—the current captain of the Australian Kangaroos, Mr Mal Meninga. His achievements and his quite proud statement that he is a South Sea Islander are obviously very significant. The report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission says that the South Sea Islanders are clearly one of the most disadvantaged groups in our society. Their unemployment rate is 28.5 per cent and their youth unemployment is about 50 per cent. The average weekly earnings of these people is $270 compared to the Australian average of $504. They have the lowest level of home ownership in Australia, apart from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people, so very clearly they are a disadvantaged group.

This is not the first report that has made such recommendations. In 1977 the report of the royal commission into human relationships made similar recommendations, at least with regard to the benefits paid to South Sea Islanders. Unfortunately, the government of that time did not act. I join with all honourable members who are supporting this motion to call on the government to act now. When one looks at that report and takes into account what I have just said about the disadvantage, the most important recommendation of the report is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Islanders should be identified as a high-need group in equal opportunity, access and equity programs, and they should be employed in government agencies dealing directly with the South Sea Islander community, most particularly in the Department of Social Security, the CES, and Housing Department offices in Queensland and Northern New South Wales.

I think that this is the most important thing that we can do and something that we can do immediately. As the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) will know, the committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs is looking at the effectiveness of the government's program for access and equity for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people. Although this would certainly be outside our terms of reference, clearly there is a need for access and equity for South Sea Island people. That is shown by the statistics that I referred to earlier.

PARA.TAB: The rest of the government's response is going to be a little more complex. The access and equity matter is one that can be handled very quickly. Extending further benefits would require budget allocations. I am not saying that this should not be done—I would support that—but that is something that cannot be done next week. I would certainly support the motion that is before the House that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission be supported, and I commend the motion to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter Mr R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot help but praise the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and record in Hansard his concern for the people of Torres Strait Island descent. Like him, I resigned from the front bench in a government, and the Parliamentary Library told me it was without precedent that a person stood down voluntarily from a cabinet without going for a superior position. Of course, I did it after I had been a minister for six years so it did not matter very much to me, but to him it was a very great sacrifice. I am told by the library that it was without precedent in Australian parliamentary history. It shows both the courage and the integrity of the man and it also gives people like me something to follow and something to aim at. So I do not hesitate to embarrass him by making a substantial comment about him.

PARA.TAB: There have been references earlier to blackbirding, and I would like to give honourable members an idea of what we are talking about here. I quote from what I have here:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1863 the infamous blackbirder, Ross Lewin, started the trade proper with the kidnapping of 67 men on the schooner Black Dog

That was a very apt name in view of the way these people were treated. If anyone here has any doubts about the slave status of these helpless individuals, Lewin advertised these 67 proud men as being for sale at #7 each. How cheap was a human life in those days!

PARA.TAB: To hide this dreadful trade in human lives behind the often misunderstood term of blackbirding belies some of the terrible stories that are today well documented. Those stories include those such as the horror that occurred on the brig Carl on the night of 17 September 1871 when the part owner and captain of the vessel, one Dr James Patrick Murray of Melbourne, and his crew shot some 80 natives that they had kidnapped from the Buka Passage in the northern Solomons when they tried to break out. These men, some only wounded, were thrown overboard to drown or be taken alive by sharks. The estimable Dr Murray got off scot-free when he turned queen's evidence. Even though the state government of Queensland tried to legislate against the forceful removal of Pacific Island natives, only one charge of slave trading was ever laid in the sad history of blackbirding—and that case failed.

There has been a lot of discussion about that outstanding and ingratiating personality, Noel Fatnowna. It was hard for anyone to come in contact with Noel without remembering him. I found his book Fragments of a Lost Heritage very moving. In fact, I read it in almost one sitting. It was very engrossing—a small version, if you like, of Roots, telling who he was, where he came from and what his forebears had suffered and achieved. When they came out to Australia—and, in a lot of cases, it is fair to say that there was genuine indentured labour—a lot of these people, like many of our own forebears, came out because they wanted something better for their kids, or maybe there was a bit of romance and excitement attached to it as well.

When they arrived, things were pretty grim but they got an awful lot grimmer when the trade union movement—and I am not criticising the rising power of the trade union movement; at the time, they did a good job for our country—unfortunately interspersed with its drive to achieve the rights and privileges which they had every right to fight to achieve—an element of flagrant racism. A cursory reading of the Worker, as it was called, a newspaper in Queensland and the organ of the Australian Workers Union, would indicate the breadth and depth of feeling against people of South Sea Island descent in the state of Queensland.

The laws that they passed—and they were probably good laws overall—had a dreadful effect upon the people of South Sea Islander descent. They went through a period of 20 or 30 years when they had little ability to stay alive. I think in Noel's book, or it may have been in another journal that I read, it said that `Staying alive time' lasted for a period of 20 or 30 years. They lived simply in the bush and off the kindness and generosity of a lot of white people who lived in the neighbouring towns who took them under their wing. They were able to stay alive and get jobs when times got better and became eventually an integral part of the community.

One cannot talk about the South Sea Islanders without reflecting upon the fact that they brought Christianity to the Torres Strait. In fact, the Torres Strait was Christianised not by white priests but by the London Missionary Society bringing in priests from the South Sea Islands. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also congratulate the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) for introducing this motion. I think it is very worth while to be involved with honourable members on the opposite side in an area of commonality. The motion itself has to be seen in the context of a fairly novel interest in this matter over the last few years. The report we speak about was preceded in 1991 by the Evatt Foundation's publication Australian South Sea Islanders: A Report on the Current Status of South Sea Islanders in Australia. There is, for instance, in Sydney at the present time a display at the Powerhouse Museum of photographs contributed by Kerry Packer's Australian Consolidated Press which, whilst featuring the broader islander situation, touches upon this subject also.

PARA.TAB: I think it is important that when we speak to this motion today we understand that we should guard against this being another false dawn. As an earlier speaker commented, in 1977 there was a royal commission into human relationships and it made a number of points. It stated then that these people `are discriminated against' and that they `suffer from many of the disadvantages which affect Aboriginals'. That royal commission also determined that these people suffer unjustified hardship because of this exclusion from benefits stemming from the 1967 referendum and that action should be taken to extend to them eligibility for benefits now available to Aboriginals. So 16 years ago there were those kinds of suggestions around.

This particular submission goes very deeply into the very real hardships experienced by the people. I think a number of those South Sea Islanders would feel a degree of irony that people such as Faith Bandler were involved in the 1967 referendum which, for the first time, drove home to the Australian population and political structures the need to take positive discrimination in favour of Aboriginals. But, at the same time, what eventually happened was that in some cases South Sea Islanders were denied benefits because of this new emphasis on the needs of Aboriginals.

What we have seen in this document is a clear delineation of massive problems in the community. Unemployment is at 28.5 per cent, 2 1/2 times the level of the Australian population. And as other speakers have indicated, they have the lowest level of home ownership in the country. But what strikes me in this particular report and other documents is their education situation, their level of tertiary education admission. The fact that they do not get something like Abstudy has made them into a community that is lacking in qualifications and one that is left out of the system.

As earlier speakers have said, the position of both political parties in this matter has been very disconcerting. We had a situation where these people in many cases were forcibly brought to this country. They were housed in very unsatisfactory conditions. In 1868 measures were taken to bring in an inspectorate into their conditions, but even in that very year people were prepared to give up their wages if it meant not going back to the plantations. However, they were forcibly put back there by the Queensland legal system despite evidence of floggings, unsatisfactory food and accommodation.

What we saw through the later part of the 19th century, as earlier speakers have indicated, was that the trade union movement, very concerned with the reality that in some cases these people were undermining the wage structure—they were only here because they were cheap labour, they were not here out of friendship—instituted a situation to alter those laws. Over the next few decades we had restrictive clauses in awards saying that people of non-European descent could not work on farms over a certain size. There were actually bounties so that sugar produced by Europeans was favoured over any that was produced by South Sea Islanders. We had, from about 1906, forced deportation from this country, with a few minor exclusions such as that those who had lived here for 20 years or were married were allowed to remain. I once again congratulate the honourable member for Dawson in having the initiative to bring this motion before the House.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Order! The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)deplores the Prime Minister's constant rewriting of Australian history to suit his own political purposes;

(2)particularly deplores the Prime Minister's denigration of the Menzies years, a period of growth, employment and stability where Australia developed a strong national identity that reflected its role as a positive and beneficial influence in its region; and
(3)contrasts the Prime Minister's own legacy of record unemployment, economic decline, massive debt, rampant crime, family breakdown and a society where many feel alienated and powerless.
I start with two quotations. The first is:
Who controls the past controls the future: who controls the present controls the past.

That was a party slogan of the ruling party of Oceania in George Orwell's novel 1984, and was used as a justification for the alteration of history to engineer the present and the future. The second is:

Finally, the man who was Prime Minister for 17 years, during which Australia was united, steadily governed, and could offer a job to any man or woman who wanted one—Menzies is presented as a failure because he could not `read the direction of the river of life'.

That is from Peter Ryan in Quadrant magazine in September this year and is an indication of Ryan's view of Manning Clark's view of the Menzies era. As the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) has commented, the view that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has of Australian history is a comic book version of Manning Clark's view, which itself was heavily criticised in Peter Ryan's work in Quadrant magazine.

PARA.TAB: The attack by the Prime Minister on Australia's longest serving Prime Minister, Sir Robert Menzies, has also represented a crude attempt to mock the history of this nation. His constant character assaults and assassinations are galling to Australians who have used Sir Robert as a builder of national identity and a linchpin of good economic policies, under which employment opportunities boomed.

Sir Robert was at the helm of a golden age and, when contrasted to the tough times now faced by Australians as a legacy of 10 years of Labor government, that golden age makes a mockery of the present Prime Minister and his own government's abysmal performance. The Oxford History of Australia made the following comments:

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Robert Menzies remained . . . the only Australian Prime Minister since the First World War to retire at a time of his own choosing. This is a mark both of his political skill and the disarray of his Labor opponents, but more than either it reflects the economic buoyancy of the 1950s and 1960s when political changes came seldom . . . In political and economic terms Australia was a model of stability in a fast-changing world. To the extent that the Menzies government presented a reassuring image of resolute anti-communism and fidelity to great and powerful allies, it could claim credit for creating an attractive environment for large scale investors of overseas capital.

The same publication observed that, upon the retirement of Menzies in 1966, most Australians considered themselves significantly better off than they had been in a long time. Their average weekly earnings had increased by four per cent in real terms, representing roughly five times the rate of advance of living standards between 1901 and 1940.

PARA.TAB: Unemployment stood at 1.2 per cent in 1950, lower than at any other period in Australian history, and it compared favourably to Britain and the United States. In 1965 unemployment in Australia was still steady at 1.2 per cent and it climbed no higher than 3.2 per cent in late 1961 and early 1962. It is clearly wrong of the Prime Minister to attack that record when he can do nothing to free this country of 11 per cent unemployment and the worst statistic of 32 per cent youth unemployment.

The good fortune of this country continued throughout the 1950s and 1960s due to constantly expanding world trade, a stable international monetary system and vigorous export growth. Even then, the importance of trade with the South-East Asian region was recognised. The quest for new export markets dominated our nation's trade policies in the 1950s and 1960s, included the probing for new trade markets in south and east Asia, China and Japan. These trading relations were unhindered by our ties with the British monarchy.

I find it odd that, when the Prime Minister can admit that Menzies understood the power that a common national sentiment commands, he can also refer to Menzies' ideology as being sterile, and say that Menzies was not aggressively Australian nor aggressively proud of our culture. That, as the Prime Minister should well know, is a fallacy. Sir Robert Menzies' leadership was a way of life for Australians. He was accepted as a father figure and a living symbol of authority; unlike our present Prime Minister, whose divide and conquer, chop and change approach has earned him little respect amongst ordinary Australians.

Menzies respected the valuable institutions and influences of our British heritage: the law, parliament, the great works of the English language, liberty and individualism. He was a fierce and effective advocate for Australia. Menzies was not a fawner or a flatterer. His relationship with Churchill was one of admiration, but Menzies did not hesitate to clash with him as he sat in the British war cabinet. His love and respect for the monarch were sincere, but he said of the royal family in the late 1930s, `These royal sons are all triers, but they have a late flowering'.

The Prime Minister was overwhelmed by his visit to Ireland this month. He is trying to portray his excursion and his family's Irish heritage as justification for outrageous and divisive sectarian comments about the relationship between Catholics and the Australian system of constitutional government. This should be contrasted with Menzies' 1940 journey to Ireland to act as an honest broker with De Valera in Dublin.

The Prime Minister boasts about his role in developing a greater interest in Asia. It seems shallow when, as far back as 1936, Menzies was concerned about the effect of trade arrangements between British textile interests and Australia, and the effect that might have on our trade with Japan.

The Prime Minister and others make much of Menzies' anti-communist scaremongering, and yet the Prime Minister cynically used scaremongering in the recent election campaign, even though he had supported many of the measures contained in the coalition's Fightback program. In other words, his actions were hypocritical.

One could hardly argue, in contrast, that Menzies was anything but sincere in his detestation of communism, whose supporters and propagators in the union movement had even obstructed Australia's war effort in the Second World War until the Soviet Union was invaded by Germany and became an ally. Menzies has been proven to be right in his view that communism was a conspiracy against constitutional government and was committed to bringing about revolution. After the fall of the Soviet communist government, what has become known about the activities of the KGB and its huge array of client organisations, including Australian ones, has revealed the extent to which Stalin and his successors would use fellow travellers to suit the ends of constructing a huge empire that relied on terror, torture and repression for its maintenance of power.

Menzies saw the strength of democracy as being based on individuals making reasoned choices as to what was best for the country. He implemented policies to ensure that all those who had ability, regardless of economic background, could receive the best education the country could offer. `Elitist!' is the cry of honourable members opposite. However, that should be contrasted with the decline of our education standards, often in the name of political correctness.

Menzies' desire to encourage excellence should be contrasted with the elitism of those on the left who dominate much of academia and who, in some cases, are so intellectually cowardly that they are unable to question or criticise those of their colleagues who abdicate their responsibilities to be honest and scholarly in their work.

Menzies stood for the forgotten people, the middle class, who in Australia were largely unrepresented, having neither the power of organised labour nor the clout of wealth and influence. This should be contrasted with the sordid relationship between the Prime Minister and his mates in big business and the unions, to the extent that the so-called Kirribilli affair—a sleazy political deal to hand over the highest office in the land—was brokered by a magnate and a union boss.

Kim Beazley senior made the wry comment that, when as a young man he went to ALP forums, those present were the cream of the working class, while now those there, in many cases, represented the dregs of the middle class. Peter Walsh, in decrying the influence of a sinecured Balmain basketweaver class over ALP policy, asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Would Chifley have allowed the long-footed potoroo—or whatever fad was in vogue with the chattering classes—to take priority over one million unemployed?
This should be contrasted with the words of Menzies, who said:

The measurement and estimation of economic trends, the organisation of finance, the devising of plans for social security, the discovery of what to do. We have neglected it as an art, the delineating and practice of how and when to do these things and above all, how to persuade a self-governing people to accept and loyally observe them.

Is this the slavish voice of an abject fawner? Of course not. He was a proud and determined Australian leader whose latter-day successes in the Labor Party have sold out Australia's sovereignty through amassing a huge national debt and signing away Australia's self-determination in endless international covenants and agreements that serve to reduce Australia's capacity to make independent decisions.

PARA.TAB: Thanks to 10 long years of `hard labor' the people of this nation are rapidly losing hope about the security of their own economic futures. The inability of many families to cope with the recession and diminishing household budgets has placed an unnecessary strain on the family structure with the instances of separation, divorce and even child abuse escalating as a result of rising tensions and the loss of economic certainty.

Our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is doing nothing to offer people hope or security, and the anti-social behaviour which is becoming more evident in our community is testimony to the fact that people feel powerless and alienated and that they will continue to do so, republic or no republic, new flag or old. There are generations of people who grew up under Menzies, whose parents had jobs and made the best of what they had. They looked forward to great things for their children because of the prosperous climate in which they themselves lived.

In conclusion, without a past there is no future, no sense of progress, no value of human endeavour and no appreciation of history. We cannot apologise for our past. There can be no rebirth of this nation. We have made mistakes and we have recovered, and from that we have learnt important lessons. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay The Hon L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal Party has now been in opposition for nearly 10 1/2 years. It has lost five elections in a row. It has had three leaders and sundry leadership changes and challengers; it is floundering and looking for direction. Rather than face the harsh reality of looking to the future, the Liberal Party has trotted out the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) and their acolytes, and it is now trying to reinvent the past.

PARA.TAB: In the Liberal Party's tawdry search for a hero, the best it could come up with is the soporific myth of Robert Gordon Menzies. I suppose that is appropriate because Menzies himself, when he was Prime Minister in the 1950s and the 1960s, spent his time harking back to a Britain that was no longer there.

The government and the Australian people are looking to the future and attempting to develop a national outlook that is uniquely Australian, not attempting to hang on to a foreign monarch or draping ourselves in a flag that gives pride of place to a foreign standard.

I pity the teacher at a school like Campsie Public School or St Mels School Campsie in my electorate, when they are asked to try to explain to a second generation Australian student of Lebanese background the psyche behind eulogy of the former Prime Minister of Australia to a foreign queen:

SPEECH.PARA: I did but see her passing by,
And yet I love her till I die.
This was Menzies' eulogy to his monarch. It makes the flesh creep to say it now, nearly 20 years later.

PARA.TAB: The Menzies years were the lost years, unlike what we have heard from the honourable member for Moore. They were the years of slumber and a legacy of lost opportunities. The honourable member for Moore alluded to Judith Brett of La Trobe University. She is the author of Robert Menzies' Forgotten People and says:

SPEECH.PARA: The current liberal party is most deluded by this belief that the political stability of the fifties was a positive achievement, as it strives to regain Menzies' political success by reviving his political symbols. What it fails to see is that the effectiveness of these symbols was being undermined by social changes, even when they appeared to have achieved their greatest success. Politics lagged behind social change then, and the party seems determined it will continue to do so.

It is deplorable that the opposition's understanding of economics is so deficient that it mistook stagnation for stability. The Menzies' idea of economic policy was to sit back and do the bidding of Britain—a Britain which was already in 1961 turning its back on Australia and applying for membership to the EEC: the first of three applications before it was successful.

PARA.TAB: While Menzies' eyes were riveted on the fading glory of empire, canny politicians such as McEwen were turning to Asia. In 1966, while Menzies was still floating the British myth at the end of his reign, Japan quite appropriately overtook Britain as our largest trading partner. Menzies still hankered for a pre-war British society that no longer existed, even in Britain. The British had decided that they knew where their future lay. McEwen had an inkling of where Australia's future lay, but Robert Gordon Menzies relied upon those imperial dreams which he was never going to have come to fruition.

His view on Australia's physical place in the world was that it was not just inconvenient for travelling to the cricket, but also frightening and dangerous. So much so that, according to the cabinet documents—unlike the gloss that has been put on this by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing)—Menzies and the 1961 cabinet, rather than going out to Asia and looking at it as a place with which Australia should co-exist, considered nuking China and North Vietnam—a nice, friendly little gesture to the region of the world that we lived in! Obviously, at his sycophantic best, Menzies' explanation would have been that he had done it at the behest of great and powerful friends.

By the end of Menzies' reign, we were in a position where we were going to nuke our neighbours in order to still live on the coat-tails of Britain. Instead of looking at how to develop Australia and how to develop our economy, Menzies presided over an economy in 1966 where manufacturing—that is, the value added part of industry—represented less than 20 per cent of our total exports. The economies of the world were booming but, unfortunately, this Liberal hero saw no value in manufacturing, despite the excellent position that Australia was in after World War II to develop value added industries. In the eyes of Menzies and the Liberal Party of the day, if it could not be ripped up and shipped out, then forget about it. Menzies' legacy, which we are still trying to overcome, was that we missed the value added boat. Under the Keating government, we have been able to lift business expenditure in research and development, in an attempt to improve the value added part of our economy, to such an extent that today it is a record high, both in real terms and in dollar terms.

What was the standard of living of people in those days, and the standard of education of our community, compared with what it is today? In 1964, inflation and interest rates were about what they are today but, on the Holden car index in 1964, it took a worker 45 weeks pay to buy a standard Holden sedan. Today it only takes 40 weeks pay to buy a Holden Commodore. In 1964, the year my sister left high school, less than one per cent of Australians were in higher education. In line with Menzies' very British thinking, the class bias was in there with a vengeance. You did not get to go to Sydney University unless you came from the North Shore of Sydney. There is no doubt about that. This year, 3.2 per cent—over half a million Australians—are engaged in higher education, and the class barriers have been shattered.

The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the honourable member for Moore, and other Menzies acolytes mistook economic and social stagnation for stability. The saddest part of the Menzies myth is that the Liberals are trying to invent a hero who, it would seem, did not even like his own country. The Liberals are harking back to a man who wrote in his diary on the voyage home, after being duchessed in Whitehall, `A sick feeling of repugnance and apprehension grows in me as I near Australia'.
Again, Menzies' own words revealed what his tastes were and where his heart lay. He was the kind of man who thought a good night out was, as he wrote in his diary on 29 January 1941:

SPEECH.PARA: Dinner at the legation—quite amusing—sherry, 1928 Nuit St Georges, champagne—and port would have been served with the slightest encouragement.

For Menzies, the high point of his career was being made the Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports, a British honour that allowed him to lord it over part of Britain. It was awarded to him by a British monarch. That is a far cry from succeeding Churchill, as he had wanted to, as leader of the Imperial War Cabinet, which he grotesquely fantasised about in his diary.

PARA.TAB: He was the kind of man who, at a time when Ray Lawler was enjoying success, preferred Noel Coward. The only thing about Menzies which was outstanding was his well-modulated turn of phrase. He was a lazy man, as his biographers have said. Menzies' laziness was typified in his belief that Australia would be graciously allowed to ride on the economic coat-tails of Britain and in his belief that its monarch was equally okay to keep.
For all I know, the honourable member for Moore might be right. I am sure, in his rather twisted mind, he thinks he is. Maybe Menzies was acceptable in his time. I doubt it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The honourable member opposite ought to withdraw that remark about the state of my mind.

—I withdraw. It is defamatory to people with twisted minds. The Menzies myth is most certainly not applicable now. I conclude by paraphrasing a saying that the Anglophile Menzies may have even appreciated. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was nice, Leo.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Order! You will refer to members by their electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am moved to speak to this motion by the ongoing, quite deliberate and totally unacceptable rewriting of history by our Prime Minister (Mr Keating). To express the outrageous actions of the Prime Minister more succinctly, I can think of no other example than the recent discussion I had with a very dear friend of mine. This honourable lady is more Irish than the Prime Minister, for she was actually born there and her family, both directly and indirectly, fought hard and long for the independence of her Ireland.

PARA.TAB: She proudly migrated to Australia under Calwell's White Australia Policy in the 1950s and now calls it home. She brought with her her young family. She chose to come to Australia for she believed it would be the best place to bring up her young family and would provide them with a lifestyle and future which she found impossible to achieve in her Ireland. She rightly believed that Australia could reward her family in return for hard work and she was proven correct.

The Australia she came to—the Menzies 1950s—with its full employment, its low inflation, its low interest rates and secure social framework, was unique in the world of that era. Australia was prosperous, unlike now with debt out of control. This woman is staunchly Catholic, more so than the Prime Minister because she practises her Christianity every day and her siblings have traversed the world passing on the word of God—unlike the Prime Minister, who constantly uses unchristian verbal violence against those who have the temerity to disagree with his view, on this side but more so on that side of the chamber.

She has chosen to train her family in Christian ways and encourage them to fulfil their dreams, which Australia could provide and has provided. But how things have changed. My dear friend did not have a supporting parent's benefit, but was able to provide tertiary education for her five children—all of whom are now contributing to the community in civic service, be it in medicine or education.

She had a vision and she climbed her mountain. She now fears not so much for her children but more so for her grandchildren—those grandchildren who cannot get jobs, or who cannot get into university or even into the local preschool. She is concerned about the values of her community, which is more reliant on government welfare rather looking to reach for self-help and climb its own mountain. She worries about the increasing crime, the unemployment and ongoing division within the community, promoted by her Prime Minister. She thinks the Prime Minister of her adopted country should maintain a statesman stature but believes this is beyond him because he has betrayed the very people he thinks he represents. During the Prime Minister's recent visit to England and Ireland, she said:

SPEECH.PARA: Who does this person think he is . . . what right has he to tell the world that we want to be a republic when we the people have not voted on it.

How profound—the people have not yet voted on it! What a shame our Prime Minister cannot quite grasp this concept—the concept of democracy—but then again that is fairly typical of an insensitive, totalitarian toff.

PARA.TAB: Our history is rich with achievements. Who can forget the achievements of the disgraced Jack Lang, the mentor of our Prime Minister? Lang had his own government sacked, wreaked havoc on the social policies of the Labor Party, and bagged comprehensively the light on the hill for the true believers, Ben Chifley. Lang hated Chifley for his politics, his vision, his gentleness and his greatness in Australian history, and so too does our Prime Minister.

Who does the Prime Minister think he is to rewrite Australian history? He is a student of one of the worst politicians in Australia's history and a denigrator of all things Australian. The Prime Minister, for instance, wears Italian suits, collects French clocks, has a Paris option and calls Ireland home. Just who is this miserable example of Australian manhood, this wrecker of Australian values, to tell Australians who have helped build this great country what they want? If he were not the jackal of our history he would call the Australian people to express their point of view on the republic at the ballot box right now. But we know that our darkest Prime Minister will not do the right thing. He would do the Big Fella real proud.

Unlike Menzies, Keating has no vision. His is a poor memory that works only backwards. If our Prime Minister had half the stature of Chifley—only half—he might just be able to be mentioned in the same speech as Menzies.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a regrettable motion moved by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) and, indeed, it was a regrettable contribution by the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Evans). I do not doubt the sincerity of many of the points made by the honourable member for Moore, but as he dreamily walks down the time tunnel we will continue to progress the affairs of this nation.

PARA.TAB: I had the unfortunate experience earlier in the week of witnessing the coalition frontbench—all the Queen's men—dancing and frothing at the mere mention of an Australian republic. When the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) referred to the opposition frontbench members as a `motley bunch of lickspittles and fawning sycophants', I thought he was being a bit hard on them but, after seeing them earlier in the week, I now think he was being really charitable.

One of the elements of this motion is that the Prime Minister has rewritten history. Many who fought and died in the theatres of war in Asia agree wholeheartedly with the Prime Minister's interpretation of some events which occurred there. I have a constituent who spent 3 1/2 years, which included his 21st birthday, working on the Burma railway, and his interpretation of the events relating to the fall of Singapore are very much in line with the interpretation that the Prime Minister has given to that event.

The second element of the motion deals with the Menzies years. The honourable member for Moore is quite entitled to the view that he takes on those years, but it is not one that is shared on this side of the House. However, I wonder what Menzies would say about those who succeeded him in the Liberal Party who had control of the Australian Treasury for some seven years during the Fraser years. The economic legacy of those years is quite amazing. The inflation rate was double digit; growth was negative; interest rates were around 10 per cent; the unemployment rate was around 10 per cent; industrial disputation was the highest on record; and we had an inappropriate industrial structure hopelessly suited to taking on the challenges of the 1980s and the 1990s and taking us through to the 21st century.

I wonder what Menzies would have said about the architects of the disaster that we inherited in 1983, Hewson and Howard, because they sit in the engine room of Liberal Party economic policy and they still drive it. The sooner the honourable member for Moore and the honourable member for Cowan do the Liberal Party a favour and do in their leader, get on the front bench themselves and put a little sense into the coalition's economic policy, the sooner the affairs of the nation will move forward to meet the new challenges that this nation faces, rather than backwards down the time tunnel.

I have found the third element of this motion rather disturbing. The Prime Minister is a warm, friendly man. He is a family man. He certainly brings to the parliament a degree of colourful language in explaining situations and perhaps putting honourable members opposite in their rightful place. Be that as it may, I think there are people in the community who share the Prime Minister's vision for this country, who certainly share his concern for the unemployed in this country and who certainly support the fact that the government has set an economic framework here that will take us forward and not take us backwards.

There was one other point that I wanted to make but, as my time is nearly up, I will conclude my remarks. Time has certainly passed even the younger members of the opposition by. If they are continually going to hark back to the good old days of the Menzies era and get that warm inner feeling, I am quite happy for them to languish on the back bench for another decade. We will continue to progress the affairs of the nation along with the Prime Minister and we will share his vision, an Australian vision. It is very important to understand that his vision is a vision for Australia and for Australians. We do not hearken to anybody else in this world. We do not look backwards; we look forwards. This is an Australian vision for Australians and it is a cause of some regret that honourable member on the other side of the House do not share it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of pleasure that I rise to support the motion moved by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) on the rewriting of Australian history, and I congratulate him on his effort. It is really not that the honourable member for Moore stood to speak about Mr Menzies, but that the government has raised that subject in the past. Fancy anyone who has had Mr Whitlam for a Prime Minister and the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) having the temerity to attack Mr Menzies. I just cannot imagine that. Since the Whitlam era this nation has gone backwards at an ever increasing rate and I do not know where it is all going to end.

PARA.TAB: Just quickly, because I do not have much time, I quote from a message I received after some of the statements made by the Prime Minister about Britain's role in World War II:

SPEECH.PARA: Outraged at Prime Ministers slanderous accusation on Great Britain deserting Australia during the war, particularly in defence of Singapore.
My father fought in France in 1940 with 1st. Battalion Gordon Highlanders, was captured at St Valery and spent 5 years a P.O.W.

His best friend Lt. Col. J.H. Stitt, commanded the 2nd Battalion Gordon Highlanders in the defense of Singapore and spent the rest of the time as a P.O.W. One of my mothers best friends husbands was killed in the defense of Burma serving with the Cameron Highlanders. Where was . . .
No, I will leave that part out. It goes on:
I migrated to Australia in 1949—

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that part the truth?
—Okay, I will read it. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Where was Keatings (P.K.) family during the war?

I migrated to Australia in 1949, took out Australian citizenship in 1964. I have always filled my Tax Return in on time and paid tax . . . I have never claimed travel expenses that were not used . . . I have always been loyal to Australia and my superiors. P.K. was prepared to bring Australia to its knees for 6 months in order to fulfil his own selfish ambition. Who is the better citizen?
Please raise this matter in Parliament as you see fit.
I could go on and on about this. This is a statement made by Mr Menzies:

This is our great year of decision. Are we for the socialist state, with its subordination of the individual to the universal officialdom of government; or are we for the ancient British faith that governments are the servants of the people?
So asked Robert Menzies, introducing the coalition's election policy of 1949. This is what honourable members opposite are on about: it is the socialist state against free enterprise.

PARA.TAB: In Australia today there is serious unemployment, and 15- to 19-year-olds have a bleak outlook with 32.5 per cent unemployment. Under Mr Menzies the economy boomed, Australia rode high on world prices for primary products such as wool and wheat, there was a strong domestic demand from a fast growing population, unemployment was less than two per cent through the decade and average weekly earnings rose four per cent per year in real terms. In 1959 the population reached 10 million, over a million of whom were people who had arrived since the war.

I do not know why the Prime Minister has a hang-up. How is it we have a Prime Minister who is prepared to go overseas and denigrate our flag, denigrate our constitution and our form of government? These people here say that there is something wrong with Mr Menzies. Would you believe it? It is just unbelievable that people would try to defend the Prime Minister in this situation.

I am one person who thinks that there is no way that we in this nation can have true freedom, true democracy or a proper constitution unless we have economic freedom. We do not have economic freedom. How could there be with the situation that we have today of one million unemployed and with our nation absolutely going down the tube, as it were? Yet these people want to denigrate Mr Menzies. I just cannot believe that. I do not know if anyone in the House can believe it.

Also, we have the sectarian debate now. My grandmother was an Irish Catholic. I have no problem with the monarchy. I have no problem with the Australian flag, a flag which I am very proud of. I appreciate what the honourable member for Moore is doing here in bringing this motion before the parliament and I am sure that most people in Australia will agree with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) and the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) and to speak against the motion of the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing). In this instance it is the opposition members who are rewriting history as they, bereft of vision for the future of this country and saddled with policies that have been soundly rejected by the electorate, look back to past glories. They see a bygone golden era that is frustratingly out of reach. Their response is to vindictively vandalise the parliamentary process and learn nothing from experience, as Senator Vanstone has suggested in today's press.

PARA.TAB: The Menzies era can be viewed as a saga of wasted opportunities. Australia's economic development was founded on a postwar boom. There was expanding world trade, especially in those commodities which Australia was able to provide. The history of the Menzies era is one of boom and bust with the imposition of tariff restrictions to deal with rampant inflation and protect a manufacturing sector that was geared largely to domestic demand. The tariff obsession of Black Jack McEwen, against the advice of his own Tariff Board, ultimately led to problems in our manufacturing sector that it took Labor administrations to redress.

Following a near defeat in 1961 Menzies commissioned the Vernon report and then ignored its recommendations in 1965. This allowed him to make economic decisions for short-term political advantage rather than make decisions in the long-term economic interest of this country.

Despite Australia's relative economic prosperity, Liberal administrations spent increasingly less on social security as a proportion of GDP than the United States of America, the United Kingdom or New Zealand. Australia lost an opportunity to be a leader in information technology because Menzies saw no future in computing, despite the fact that the CSIRO built one of the first computers in the world in 1947. The cost to Australia in the importation of computing hardware continues to add to our deficit. I contend that much of Australia's economic policy during the Menzies era was grounded in Menzies' obsession with Imperial England.

The Maralinga atomic test debacle was unilaterally decided by Menzies, who assured his colleagues that it would involve `no conceivable injury to life, limb or property', but it resulted in no scientific value to Australia. Similarly, the Blue Streak project absorbed huge resources because, as one of his ministers said, `What we are about to do is vital to the United Kingdom government and indeed the free world'. When the British government abandoned the project it almost forgot to tell the Menzies government. Such was its attitude towards the colonies.

Much of the policy focus of the Menzies administration can be traced to the psychological history of its protagonist. Judith Brett's analysis is instructive. I will quote from her book, Menzies Forgotten People:

Menzies idealised England far beyond and far longer than most Australians of his day; from the point of later generations he idealised it to the point of parody, even wanting in the 1960s to name the major unit of Australia's new decimal currency the Royal . . . Menzies idealisation of England was in part a defence against envy and rage he felt against something which made him feel small.

SPEECH.PARA: Brett described it as the `narcissistic wound of colonial birth'. His continued sycophantic allegiance to Imperial Britain became linked to our adherence to American foreign policy and the Vietnam debacle. It deferred Australia's assumption of true independence until the election of the Whitlam government in 1972.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is once again leading Australia with a true vision of independence. The journey towards a republic and the effect of integration into the Asia-Pacific region will bring with it economic benefits by dragging this country away from the complacency and conservatism of the Menzies era and successive conservative governments, all of which failed to grasp the essential elements of this country's future.

The honourable member for Corio asked what Menzies thought of his successors. Menzies described his successors in an interview which appeared in the Bulletin in his retirement. He described them as `a contemptible little squirt', `a conceited little booby', `a very stupid fellow', `a mischievous destroyer'. Those are the sorts of attitudes that Menzies had to his successors, just as he had contempt for his contemporaries.

One of the lasting legacies that Menzies gave the Liberal Party was that he destroyed anybody who was a possible rival or a challenge to his leadership. Such were the problems he had with the need for personal power. His failure to win the prize that he coveted of knocking Churchill off in the war cabinet—as referred to by the honourable member for Watson—was indeed a slight from which he never recovered. The true legacy of the Menzies era can be seen in the members of the opposition in this chamber. They are completely bereft of vision, talent and ideas. Therefore, I speak most heartily against this motion.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)is of the opinion that the effect of the increase in wholesale sales tax on wine will be to:
(a)slash revenue from domestic wine sales by $100 million;
(b)reduce the income of grape growers;
(c)inevitably lead to the loss of jobs in vineyards, wine production, packaging, transport and marketing;
(d)inevitably lead to the demise of approximately 140 of Australia's 738 wineries; and
(e)force 500 grapegrowers to leave the wine industry; and
(2)calls on the Government to reverse its decision to increase the wholesale sales tax on wine.
That is the motion standing in my name on the notice paper.

We in South Australia have some major winegrowing areas in the Barossa and Clare valleys, in the Coonawarra in the State's south-east, at McLaren Vale just south of Adelaide, and in the Riverland, which is a major wine grape producer. The Adelaide Hills and Langhorne Creek are smaller producing areas but their wines are of no less quality for that.

PARA.TAB: Our wine industry is world class and highly competitive. Its 97 per cent share of the Australian market represents a substantial turnaround from our position only 10 years ago when—it is very hard to believe; when researching this speech I was surprised when reminded of it—Australia was a net importer of wine. We are now a net exporter, with overseas sales accounting for 20 per cent of total production, and we have increased from negligible levels of just a few years ago to 77.6 million litres, which is worth $234m in 1991-92. The industry is now confident of achieving exports of wine worth $1 billion by the turn of the century and, given the burgeoning markets of well-off, well-earning middle-class people in the Asian economies to our north, as their consumption habits shift a bit more in our direction this is a very realistic goal.

We will go a long way to eliminating this present current account deficit if we can emulate the wine industry more widely. This wine industry is the result of various stages of production that are carried out in Australia—crushing, distilling, blending, packaging and so on—which add approximately seven times the farm gate value of the raw material to the finished product. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to imagine what the effect would be of adding seven times the value of the entire primary export crop of this country, right across the board. Basically, in the wine industry this means that wages are paid to 10,000 Australian workers, $1.2 billion worth of sales to Australian retailers are cashed up, transport costs are paid to Australian transport companies, the costs of packaging materials are paid to Australian packagers, and also $400m worth of Commonwealth and State taxes are derived from the industry. This can be reinvested in our domestic economy in various ways and needs to be in capital equipment, building and financial services.

SPEECH.PARA: Those are not my words. I hope I would not put together a speech which was quite so boring! They are the words of the former member for Adelaide, Dr Catley, who stood in this place in defence of the South Australian wine industry some 12 months ago almost to the day. It is pertinent for this chamber to ask itself this morning: what is the present honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) doing about the wine industry? Honourable members will discover that the honourable member for Adelaide, who is a member of the opposition, is in fact batting for the South Australian wine industry.

PARA.TAB: What then would Dr Catley, were he still the member for Adelaide, be doing? Would he be doing what the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan), the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) and the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) are doing, sitting quietly on the government bench while their industry cops this tax?

Would they be sitting a little uncomfortably, as is the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), who says one thing in his electorate but is a little less verbose here about what this tax measure is doing to this particular industry? No single budget issue has generated the sort of unparalleled indignation that has been generated by the question of a wine tax on the industry, particularly in South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the beer drinkers?

—I will pick up the point made by the parliamentary secretary about beer drinkers in just one moment. I must take up the issue, in fact, as vehemently as the Adelaide Advertiser has taken it up, and as vehemently as the wine industry has taken it up in mounting an effective and professional campaign around Australia against this 55 per cent tax impost.

PARA.TAB: Even Premier Arnold, hardly noted as someone who kicks against the party line, has publicly denigrated Treasurer Dawkins for this particular tax measure. But nothing—not a word of indignation, not a word of criticism—do we hear from the government bench.

My notice of motion on the Notice Paper calls on the government to reverse this decision. I have placed it on the Notice Paper recognising that there will be government members who will want, quite rightly, to speak to it. But I hope that, in defence of what the government is doing, they do not stand up and run in this chamber in the next 10 minutes some sort of argument about tax equity, because this is not a question of tax equity at all, as picked up by the indignant interjections from people opposite and from the parliamentary secretary.

Let us look at the background of this push for a change in the way in which the wine industry is taxed. We on this side of the parliament believe in tax equity. That is why we proposed a goods and services tax. That is precisely why when the government ran against the promises it made in 1983 in Griffith—when it said it would not tax wine and then subsequently taxed wine—we did not vote against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you still support the GST?
—Of course I do. I still support the GST, yes. I make no bones about that. But let us come back to the point of this debate.
—Fifteen per cent on wine?

—Yes. To take up that interjection from the honourable member for Lilley, the wine industry would be far better off with a 15 per cent GST and no sales tax than with a 31 per cent sales tax, as any fool can see. But in the case of tax equity, in the case of the proposal that came from the brewers and the spirits industry, let us recognise that there is no parallel to be drawn between the brewing and the spirits industries and the wine industry. The honourable member for Hunter knows that, if he is honest about it. What does one do in the case of spirits or brewing? All one does is take hops and barley and add water in what is effectively a factory making and annual production. What happens in the case of the spirits industry? One takes sugar, an annual crop, and does precisely the same thing—in many cases with waste product.

PARA.TAB: What about the wine industry? Here one has to take root stocks that are suitable to a particular soil type, plant them, trellis them, and wait—as the honourable member for Hunter knows—at least three years, if lucky, to get into production and 10 years to break even. Having done all of that—is this any parallel with the brewing industry?—one has to harvest the product gently, either manually or, if by machinery, then only at night. Having done that, the product has to be laid down and blended, with all the art that is the wine industry, and exposed to maturation over an extended period of time. So let us have no nonsense, as the honourable member for Hunter knows, about this question of tax equity, because the simple reality is that there is no parallel between the brewing and spirits industries and the wine industry. That is not the opinion of the opposition. That is the opinion of our major wine competitors in Europe. For example, none of the tax measures in France, in Spain, in Italy and in Portugal are as severe as our existing tax measures, let alone the additional burden of a 55 per cent hike in the tax on wine as proposed by the government and, frankly, not defended by anyone on the government benches.

What is the other issue that people raise? They say, `We ought to be sensitive about health'. So we should. But the wine industry is the one alcohol producing industry that can claim to have had some real involvement in educating Australians about healthy drinking, because the wine industry has a vested interest—and I note that the honourable member for Lilley is acknowledging this point—in seeing that people's drinking habits are healthy.

The one area of the wine industry that offers a decidedly healthy alternative to every Australian—even those with an alcohol problem—is the production of lower alcohol wines. What has the government in this budget done to the production of low alcohol wines? Do honourable members know what has happened to wine makers—and this is a matter largely overlooked by the parliament—producing wines of an alcohol content of under 1.15 per cent? The government has lifted the tax on those people, not by 55 per cent but by 110 per cent. How can that be defended? How can it be defended when the simple reality is that that is a tax being borne by low alcohol wines, the alcohol content of which is, in most instances, less than 0.5 per cent?

In our usual exercise in consistency we can claim on this side of the House to have been honourable about this. We accepted that the wine industry ought to bear some sort of tax burden, so we did not vote against the first 20 per cent. We accepted that. We did not like it, but we tolerated it and so did the industry. But there can be no defence for this 55 per cent hike. We will not wear it, and if the government is wondering where we will be when next this matter is considered we will be opposing any increase in tax on wine in the interests of our electorate and the nation. What will honourable members opposite be doing?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve the right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the motion from the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) because I find his arguments somewhat spurious. This is the ultimate yuppie motion. It is incredible that the opposition can come into this place and join with the Greens in arguing the case for the champagne, chardonnay and camembert set.

PARA.TAB: I know why they do not want to argue this case in terms of tax equity. They do not want to argue this case in terms of tax equity because they do not believe in tax equity. They have not changed their approach to tax; they still support a system of flat taxation and they still support a GST so, quite naturally, they would want to avoid any argument about tax equity in relation to this matter. In the budget the sales tax on alcoholic wine and cider and other similar alcoholic beverages was increased from 20 per cent to 31 per cent from midnight on 17 August. It is the height of hypocrisy to argue that this change is not equitable—the absolute height of hypocrisy.

Wine has had special treatment over the years and, during the time it has had that special treatment, it has built up a very solid base, both domestically and for export. It is crazy to say that such a measure proposed by the government would cripple the industry. This is a classic example of special pleading from a vested interest which is seeking to maintain a regressive form of taxation and a special advantage for an industry which, frankly, does not require it. It is seeking to give an industry special treatment against all other similar industries. The government's proposals are fair; the existing position is quite unfair and quite regressive.

The opposition does not mind slugging a punter who wants to have a pot of beer about one third on tax while someone who is drinking a glass of wine, after these measures have come in, will be slugged about 17 1/2 per cent. Even under these measures, wine still has a very considerable advantage over beer, and this measure is about bringing some fairness back into the taxation of alcoholic beverages.

There is a compelling case for the wine industry making a larger contribution to revenue. Prior to this budget Penfolds Grange Hermitage was taxed at the same rate as lemonade. That is the opposition's idea of tax equity. We understand that; that is what the last election campaign was about. The opposition does not mind taxing everybody 15 per cent on the essentials of life, such as food and clothing, and it did not mind bringing down the price of luxury cars, furs and so on. That is the opposition's idea of equity—paying the same tax on lemonade as on Penfolds Grange Hermitage.

Wine has always been lightly taxed in this country compared to beer. That is because beer is subject not only to a sales tax but also to an excise tax. What the government is saying in these arrangements is that it will not be imposing an excise tax on wine, and that it will continue to give the wine industry very privileged treatment. Its privileged treatment is set to continue, which makes it even more puzzling why the wine industry did not accept the very legitimate compromise put forward by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in recent days. Wine will continue to enjoy a relative advantage over beer and spirits well into the future and, to that extent, inequities in the treatment of alcoholic beverages will continue.

Let us just look at some examples. We find that somebody who is buying a four-litre cask of wine will be paying 17 1/2 per cent of the post-budget purchase price in a form of Commonwealth taxation. Let us just think about that. That is a 17 1/2 per cent Commonwealth taxation on wine, so when punters go into the pub and pick up a glass of wine, they are paying about 17 1/2 per cent. But what happens if they are having a pot or a middy of beer? The tax is 32 per cent, one-third of the price. How can one justify that inequity continuing?

Let us take these examples further. The comparison is even more stark if we look at the dollars per litre of alcohol taken in Commonwealth taxation. On cask wine, it will be just over $3 per litre of alcohol compared with $18.50 per litre of alcohol for beer. The tax is $3 for wine but $18.50 for beer. That is the case for change. That is why the government has taken up the case. The government has also given a clear commitment in the budget papers that the excise-free status of wine will continue, and that guarantees the discrepancy. It is very clear that, under the new arrangements, wine still has a very considerable advantage.

Let us now deal with some of the arguments put about the effect on the wine industry. The government has chosen an approach which, whilst reducing the taxation advantages, still gives very considerable advantages. Let us have a look at what it would do to, say, a $10 bottle of wine. The cost would increase by only about 50c and, similarly, it would increase by about 50c for a seven-litre cask of wine. I know that honourable members are very moderate in their behaviour in this place, but I am sure that they have managed to visit, in their time, restaurants around this country. I have been to a local Chinese restaurant, say, and paid up to $10 for a bottle of wine. I could go to a similar restaurant down the road—perhaps to one that has a more expensive menu—and pay twice the price. The fact of the matter is that there are vast discrepancies in the price of wines in restaurants.

What we are talking about here is an increase in Commonwealth taxation of around 50c. Honourable members opposite cannot justify the tales of horror and woe which they and the wine industry are peddling around this place about a dramatic effect on consumption. When this issue was last revisited in 1984 and the wholesale sales tax arrangements were changed, there was no significant impact on consumption, nor was there over time. The growth of the wine industry in recent times has been in the export sector, and the wholesale sales taxes do not apply to the export sector, so an argument cannot be maintained in this place that there will be some dramatic impact on consumption and, in turn, on production and, in turn, on employment in the industry. It is simply not sustainable.

When the sales tax rate was increased to 20 per cent, all of these tales of woe were put about. It was predicted by the industry that there would be a 3.4 per cent downturn in 1986-87 but, in fact, cask and bottle sales increased by 1.86 per cent. Once again, it is the height of hypocrisy to be mounting the argument that consumption will be dramatically affected. The fact of the matter is that this is a very legitimate budget measure, which is introducing a degree of fairness into the taxation system and providing revenue for the government, so that it can pursue its very legitimate deficit reduction strategy—which is something one would think the opposition would have thought was a very important priority for any government.

So we now have this political coalition of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson); the shadow minister for foreign affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock); the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia; and the Greens. They are all getting behind the champagne, chardonnay and camembert set and are arguing for equity. That is just absolutely incredible. How dare the Greens talk about equity in the taxation system and come forth and support such an inequitable arrangement that is being supported by the Liberal and National parties! I think it really does demonstrate just how absolutely bloody-minded the opposition is in its treatment of all of the budget measures that have been debated in this place over recent times.

The government has made a very generous offer to the wine industry, which it did not take up, and it has not been taken up because the opposition, the Liberal and National parties, aided and abetted by the Greens, have decided on a process of maximum political destabilisation in this House. Is it any wonder that someone like Malcolm Fraser has had the following statements to make about the tactics of the Liberal and National parties:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate is running the risk of making Australia ungovernable. It is running the risk of turning the annual budget process into a series of bargains and trade-offs similar to those which occur in the United States. Good budgets are more often unpopular than popular. It is easy therefore for the Senate to seize such moments to destroy the integrity of a budget.

So what we now have is this incredible coalition of the Liberal and National parties and the Greens setting out to destroy the integrity of the budget process by supporting something as outrageous as the privileged treatment of wine in terms of taxation. What an incredible coalition it is. We now have the Greens supporting the Liberal and National parties in their pursuit of flat taxation and in their pursuit of unfair taxation arrangements. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I rise to support the motion of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). The honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) made great play on the tax equity argument, claiming special pleading by special interests. If we listen to the Labor Party, stand by for more tax increases on wine. That is a pretty incredible sort of argument based on that very convenient philosophy that if it is successful tax it.

PARA.TAB: Today I rise in this place out of concern for particular regions of South Australia where the effect is more dramatic than in other places in Australia, particularly in the Clare Valley and Port Lincoln, on the shores of Boston Bay, where we have a fledgling industry trying to get up. The effect of this increase in tax on these businesses, on their employees, on the community and the export wine industry has to be negative. To me, the truth lies in the sense of what is right and fair: not what is smart, not what is in the short-term interests of some expedient policy and not what is just trying to be pragmatic, but what is in the national interest and what is in the best interests of all Australians.
