My belief is based on the value of the individual and not based on a reliance on the state. It is based on my belief that taxation is not the answer. If the answer were just to tax it, I suppose we should have 100 per cent tax on everything. That seems to be this government's approach.

We cannot create wealth in this country if we have these sorts of taxation policies. We cannot improve our situation under this sort of taxation regime. We cannot lower unemployment under these sorts of taxation regimes. I would have thought that the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) would have been a little more supportive. He tried to be, but I was interested in those comments last night.

We come to the matter of whether the government had a mandate, and we come to the matter of l-a-w, law. It is about paying for these tax cuts. We come to the little interlude in Adelaide with the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and our South Australian Premier, Mr Arnold. I think we should call the wine tax the State Bank tax. That is what we will call the wine tax. We will call it the State Bank tax—a $600 million little package to sort out this little mess. I suppose we have to drink a little bit more now to pay for the State Bank. That is what the Treasurer said to the Premier—`You defend this wine tax and I will tell you about that little deal we did about the State Bank'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I wish to alert the public generally, and ageing Australians specifically, to inconsistencies in the prescription and dispensing of drugs under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, which at present is costing pensioners and other elderly people far more than is necessary. The elderly and infirm spend a far greater proportion of their income on drugs than is average, so it is even more necessary now, during the present severe recession, that the cost of their prescriptions should be minimised.

PARA.TAB: The `generic' or `benchmark' drug affair, which has been simmering for years, was catapulted to public notice recently when New South Wales north coast pharmacist, Stuart Keen, that `latter day Robin Hood', took on the medical and pharmaceutical establishment by coming out fighting for his customers' right to choose less costly benchmark brand drugs as against the more expensive better known premium brands. This was documented on the ABC's 7.30 Report of 6 July this year and followed by another segment presented once again on the 7.30 Report, this time on 25 August in Sydney and 26 August in Melbourne.

Both programs stated the original premise—that is, pensioners are paying more than they need to for their life-saving drugs. Some of our elderly citizens are constantly reliant on a number of drugs to keep them alive. So the cost of prescriptions for life-saving drugs can be exorbitant. It is ludicrous, and bordering on the criminal, that in many instances these prescriptions are obtainable at a much lower cost—that is, if generic or benchmark brands are prescribed instead of the premium brands normally favoured by doctors and stocked by pharmacists.

I am not suggesting that doctors deliberately prescribe dearer drugs for any kind of kickback from drug companies for personal gain. Largely, it is a matter of habit and lack of available time. Doctors are very busy and it is so much easier to prescribe the brand that he or she is familiar with than to look up the equivalent benchmark brand which would be prescribed at a lower cost to the patient.

To give honourable members some idea of the difference in costs, if the benchmark brand for a commonly prescribed treatment for blood pressure, Noten, is used instead of the premium brand, Tenormin, each prescription will cost $1 less to the patient. In other words, the pensioner will pay $2.60 for Noten and $3.60 for Tenormin even though the drugs are identical. To patients off the PBS, Tenormin will cost $11.18 while Noten is $1 cheaper at $10.18. Another more extreme example is to be found in the dispensing of one of the cortisone based ointments, Cinchocaine hydrochloride with hydrocortisone ointment 2 grams x 15, where the difference is a staggering $16.89 per prescription.

This is a considerable difference in cost, particularly to a person on a low income. When the patient takes the prescription to the pharmacist, further difficulties are encountered. The script is usually written for the premium brand drug. If a patient requests the cheaper benchmark alternative, as is his or her right, pharmacists have to cover themselves legally by making a phone call to the doctor concerned to verify substitution, which can be a lengthy and cumbersome process.

This is, of course, supposing that the pharmacist stocks the benchmark brand, which is not always the case. Pharmacist Stuart Keen commends the government's minimum pricing policy, but asserts that the policy and the law are not walking along the same road. In tenaciously taking his courageous stand to alert people to the existence of benchmark brand drugs in place of the more expensive premium brands for the financial benefit of his customers, he has incurred the wrath of the law, and fears that it could cost him his career. He is currently being investigated and is `under threat of prosecution' by Health Insurance Commission officers.

In the course of both presentations of the 7.30 Report, elderly citizens, who had been dispensed cheaper benchmark brands by Mr Keen, gave evidence of harassment and terror tactics by Health Insurance Commission officers who were investigating. It should be stressed here that Stuart Keen has not dispensed a benchmark drug against the prescription of any doctor since the irregularities of the law were made clear to him. He has subsequently sought every possible means of persuading doctors to allow people the alternative, if they should so wish, and has written letters and made phone calls to this end. I would say that at least in the Wingham area the community is well aware of people's right to choose.

In answer to the question as to whether benchmark brands are different from dearer brands, the answer is in the negative. As drugs or chemicals they are identical. They have the same active ingredients and the same clinical effects as the dearer brands. There may be differences in colour, shape and the agents that bind the active ingredients together, but these do not change the clinical effect of the medication. Moreover, all drug products listed under the PBS schedule have to meet the strict standards of quality, safety and efficacy set by the Drug Evaluation Committee and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee.

In defence of benchmark brands, many minimum price brands have been listed under the PBS for a number of years and are widely used in Australian hospitals, including the country's leading teaching hospitals. This means that people have been using the minimum price brands and have switched brands satisfactorily, often without knowing it. They have probably used one brand before going into hospital, have been switched to a lower priced brand whilst in hospital and then, when they have returned home, have changed to another brand, depending on their doctor's preferences.

We in Australia are lagging behind other comparable countries as far as lower priced drugs are concerned. This is particularly true of the United States of America where benchmark brands are used widely. Dr Con Costa, President of the Doctors Reform Society, wrote recently of the `universal use of generics in the public hospital system, with more than 80 per cent generic prescribing, even in the US privatised health system'. In Great Britain it is estimated that 45 per cent to 49 per cent of all NHS prescriptions are of the lower priced variety and their use is also increasing in New Zealand.

Already the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation has issued a press statement to the effect that benchmark brands of drugs should be more readily available. On 7 July, Mrs Norah McGuire, the National Secretary of the APSF, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Pensioners should not have to pay for expensive brands of drugs when cheaper ones are available and just as good.

The Australian Consumers Association on the same day, 7 July, took matters even further. Mr Phil Marchionni, deputy manager of policy and public affairs for the ACA, issued a press statement that said:

In some American states pharmacists can substitute generic drugs for brand name versions prescribed by doctors. In New Zealand, similar proposals are in the pipeline. Australian pharmacists should be able to dispense cheaper generic drugs.

He added that generic drugs are almost always the cheapest. I am sure that everyone in this place would agree that doctors, by the very nature of their profession, are, above all, kind people. Surely in that case it should be easy for them to help patients to save on their budgets. When benchmark brands are prescribed, the average saving is approximately $1.30 per prescription.

PARA.TAB: The Pharmacy Guild of Australia and the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association have so far declared their extreme opposition to the prescription and dispensing of benchmark drugs. One would hope that, given the obvious benefits to the patient, this ultra-conservatism will change.

I commend Stuart Keen for his tenacity in bringing the case for the prescription of benchmark drugs for the financial benefit of the patient to the public eye. In the original 7.30 Report, the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, commented that Mr Keen's heart was in the right place but he worried about the brain. On the evidence, the brain seems to be right too.

There have been some interesting late developments in this drug saga. Firstly, it has come to my notice that Rhone-Poulenc, a leading drug company which used to be known as May and Baker in Australia, has produced a benchmark drug, Uruvale, in direct competition with its own premium brand drug Orudis, and subsequently added $1.20 in price to its own premium brand. Apparently there have been other similar examples of this practice. As well as this, Stuart Keen is finding that local doctors are being extremely helpful, subsequent to pressure from the public, and even the Pharmacy Guild is less recalcitrant than previously.

However, the fact still remains that probably the great bulk of members of the Australian population are unaware of their choice with regard to prescription drugs. They should have that choice. In conclusion, I seek to table an advertisement from Canada which shows the link between the benchmark and premium drug.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I begin my grievance here today, I would like to remind the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred) that what he was saying has certainly got a lot of truth in it. I would also refer him to the 1991-92 report of the prescription drug inquiry of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs which was chaired by our Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins).

PARA.TAB: That was a bipartisan committee which spent a lot of time investigating the very problem that the honourable member has raised in this House of the difference between prescription drugs and generic drugs. That report makes interesting reading. I am very pleased that when it comes to acting on its recommendation the honourable member for Deakin will support the government in what we are trying to do.

My grievance is about what I would consider to be the noxious weed of negativity which is being sewn by a lot of the local media in my state, and which is trying to choke the spirit of Sydney's western suburbs. Sydney's west, which I am proud to say I was born in and where I have lived all my life, contains my electorate of Prospect. It also has a population in excess of 1.3 million people.

It has become fodder for the media over the years. Endless streams of negative stories are now appearing about crime, unemployment and crises in that area. They hit the headlines; they make the news bulletins. The most recent attention grabber was a news report which publicised the ramblings of a northern beaches mayor who blamed us westies for fouling Manly's beaches.

Residents of the western suburbs were portrayed as being environmental louts, visiting the beaches and leaving their rubbish behind them, ruining the beauty of the beaches. This statement was not, of course, backed by any statistics or facts. At the time I put it down to the ramblings of a person who needed to be certified.

However, while that bulletin was so ridiculous that people in our region glossed over it, yawned and laughed at the audacity of it, other articles have been more damaging. One was in the Sydney Morning Herald of 17 July of this year. I was shocked to find that according to that article the western suburbs was supposed to have developed an underclass, a class which apparently has all but taken over my electorate of Prospect.

That story started on page 1 of a reputable newspaper, and then continued in a lengthy series throughout that edition and also in the following editions of that week. It concentrated on a youth drop-in centre in my electorate nicknamed `the shed'. The journalist said that about a hundred kids who frequent the shed—a cold and draughty girl guides hall—had given up on their lives because they thought they would never find a job. That journalist wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Most would be regarded as dunces but their teacher says that, on the contrary, they have worked out that there are no jobs for poorer people like themselves, so why go to a normal school?
The journalist went on to say:
For many, The Shed is the end of the line. Most have already dropped out of school.

I can assure honourable members that the shed is not part of a formal education system within my electorate. It is run by the Fairfield Community Resource Centre, which is funded by grants from both federal and state governments.

PARA.TAB: Interestingly enough, articles like this seem to always appear when people want re-funding of particular programs, which is what a lot of this story was about. For some reason, journalists continue to leap on any chance they get to portray western Sydney, and often my electorate, in a bad light.

I have been asked to launch a book called Into the West next week. It is written by Dianne Powell, a very interesting person, whose father many years ago was mayor of our city. In her book, Ms Powell has chronicled press coverage of the western suburbs throughout the years. Through her work it is possible for all to see the continual and constant barrage of slings and arrows fired at Sydney's west by numerous journalists who have never taken the time—and this is what I am very concerned about—to travel out of the city and its immediate suburbs and come and see where the real people live.

In fact, it was interesting in reading through that book prior to my launching it next week to discover that what I am alarmed at now has been a continual thing; it goes back to the late 1800s. I grant it that there are times when the media has a point. But why do journalists continually harp on the negative issues and gloss over the very positive ones?

I agree with some articles that the Sydney Morning Herald put out about unemployment, particularly about the city of Fairfield, which is in my electorate of Prospect. But why do the same articles not mention that half of Fairfield's unemployed cannot speak adequate English? Why is Fairfield not mentioned as Australia's most multicultural city? While that comes with many rewards, we know there is a downside.

Fairfield itself takes in more first arrivals than any other area in Australia. When I say first arrivals I mean our new arrivals coming from overseas. A lot of these people do not speak English at the time they arrive. Or, if they do, they do not have adequate levels of English to help them to get jobs in their first year. However, we have recognised that problem and we are doing something about it.

I was pleased to see in June this year that something like 500 people graduated from the Fairfield and Cabramatta adult migrant English centres. Another 500 are going to graduate in December and we expect another 500 within the next six months after that. But what is interesting about that success rate is that amongst those first 500 graduates something like five per cent were already employed before they had graduated. There were some 70 who were in training courses, before the graduation took place, for hospitality and clerical industries, and over 180 were enrolled for further language training.

We are pushing our way out of the valley of unemployment in Fairfield and I am proud of how determined my constituents are in their search for work. These are people who are eager to give something back to Australia and I am glad that through our federal government programs we are helping them to achieve their goals. However, I am not glad that the press continues to dwell on the downside and this certainly casts a pall over any achievements that we have made.

If people read often enough that Fairfield is a city full of `the underclass' then they could start to believe it, and that would be a terrible shame. I do not want people who have travelled to Australia from more than 114 countries to arrive here and believe that they have no hope. Fairfield is a city of hope despite the continual bad press. I do not want long-term residents to think that their home is a city of hopelessness.

Five of the largest high schools in Australia are contained within my electorate and they are jam-packed with children who have a thirst for knowledge. Every year these and all other schools in Prospect turn out bright, educated individuals determined to make their mark. These young minds should not be discouraged by journalists anxious to fill their pages or air time with hard luck stories.

Because my electorate is such a multicultural and working-class area, I believe journalists have a preconceived idea of what happens in Prospect. Through these preconceived notions they assume that there will be problems at schools and in the streets. They assume that racism will rear its ugly head and cause numerous fights and even riots. Worst of all they assume that because people have been unemployed they will continue to stay unemployed.

I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, will agree with me that this is not the case. Students in my electorate have certainly not given up the fight. They are talented, they are ambitious and they are bright. In fact, two weeks ago the largest school in New South Wales, Fairfield High School, celebrated its annual multicultural day. Group after group took to the stage and celebrated with their cultural songs, their dancing and their musicians. They had something like 1,000 students participating. These children who have revelled in their own culture are making a wonderful contribution and merging into Australia's way of life.

I was also delighted to be involved in Prairiewood High School's environment day recently. The school is working hard to tie environmental issues into all of its lessons. Students have cultivated their own pesticide free greenhouse gardens. They have written plays and even transformed an ugly piece of land adjoining the school into a tree lined haven for outdoor studying. One class has even taken over the recycling collection. These are wonderful students and, if all students throughout Australia are as bright as those kids, Australia has a wonderful future.

The message I want to get across in the limited time left to me is that I wish journalists writing about western Sydney would take the time, the effort and the trouble to come out and be part of our community and see what we have to offer. I have made complimentary statements before in this House about certain journalists and the way that they have come out and inspected our area and written articles that are factual and truthful. I challenge other journalists now to make the choice to have first-hand experience in what they are writing about, to meet the people, see the facilities and look at the programs that are in existence, not only in my electorate of Prospect within the city of Fairfield but particularly in the western region of Sydney. I would hope that then we would have journalists writing the true facts—that it is an area of growth, an area that could be tied into the United Nations but, most particularly, an area where people have hope for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I am focusing on the role of the family in Australian society, and want to put the proposition to the House that the family ought to be considered as the fourth and most fundamental tier of government because, unless the family functions effectively, the other tiers of government also struggle to deliver their programs effectively to our society.

PARA.TAB: Monday of this week marked the 50th anniversary of Dame Enid Lyons's entry into parliament. Quite a bit has been made of her entry into parliament, and I remind honourable members that she was the first female parliamentarian and represented my electorate back in those times. In her maiden speech she quoted King George V:

SPEECH.PARA: The foundation of a nation's greatness is in the homes of its people.

I think we could do well to reflect on that aspect of her speech, particularly during this week as we are celebrating Dame Enid's entry into parliament.Not only was the Lyons family very prominent in Australian political history and made a tremendous contribution to it from many different aspects, but also it was a tremendous family. In fact, a lot of honourable members in this House would know that there were 12 children in the family, of whom one died very early in life and 11 survived—quite a formidable number to many of us today. Both Joseph and Enid Lyons were driven by the idea of the importance of the family as the fundamental unit in society, and much of their life apart from national life really did focus on encouraging family life. The principle of family unity, love and loyalty in a family unit pervaded the whole of their private and public life.

PARA.TAB: For many in the coalition the statement quoted by Dame Enid has become a motto. What does it mean to claim that the foundation of a nation's greatness is in the homes of its people? I want to make three particular points. In the first place, it means that the family is the fundamental social unit in which we all grow up and experience most of our lives. A grouping of people who are linked by blood, marriage or adoption and who reside in the same home is a common definition of the family. Contrary to claims sometimes made that the nuclear or traditional family is fast disappearing and despite the rapid growth in sole parent families, the 1991 census shows that the overwhelming majority of dependent children still live in homes with two parents.

There is the impression today that the structure of families is really disappearing but, when we go to the statistics, we find that about 90 per cent of Australians live in a social structure which all of us would say is a family. I think we are being deceived sometimes by the very narrow definition of the traditional or the normal family as two adults with two children. If there are three children, it is not normal; if there is a grandparent living with one child and mum and dad, it is still not regarded as a traditional, normal family. I think that that is nonsense. There is a great diversity of family groupings, and it is very important that we are aware of how this is sometimes portrayed to us.

The family provides the structure for social nurturing of children and young people and the avenue whereby adults express their aspirations, hopes and fears and responsibilities within a mutually supportive group. The Institute of Family Studies reports that 71 per cent of workers nominate family as the source of their greatest satisfaction in life. So it is this social unit that we live with that is of fundamental importance to us all. It is the greatest of boons to be fortunate enough to be born into a strong, healthy family. One of the best things we can do with our lives, particularly as adults, is to help create a good family ourselves. It is one of the greatest things we can do.

The basic provision is physical care and food and clothing and shelter, but more vital is the emotional care that the family provides for the child to feel loved and wanted, to develop good self-esteem and a general sense of worth. I think it is the same for adults as well, that a lot of our self-worth comes from our children. This is fundamental to our sense of dignity and wellbeing and just living life in a very positive sense instead of becoming sometimes depressed, as many people seem to today.

If children grow up in an atmosphere of love and warmth, they will become better equipped to cope with the pressures of adult life. The family is responsible for conveying attitudes and is responsible for the moral development of the child. Thus, the attitude children learn towards authority figures such as teachers and police will be reflected in the way in which they respond to such people and the degree to which they become good citizens. If we have good citizens, we have a healthy nation.

The family is the first experience children have of working within a community. In this fundamental social unit they learn to cooperate, share, display consideration, be honest, trustworthy—and sometimes dishonest, of course, but that is part of that nurturing at that stage—and reliable, to be hardworking and to develop a work ethic. Yet the value placed by governments today on the family does not reflect the vital importance family life plays in the overall wellbeing of society.

I believe that the Family Law Act effectively minimises parents' responsibilities to each other and also casualises the father's responsibilities. I came across this quote about the situation in the United States:

SPEECH.PARA: As for marriageable men, the system in the United States—
I do think it does tend to also accord here in Australia—
makes them economically useless. Their potential role as husbands and custodial fathers is squeezed out by the government and so they seek other outlets of affirmation.

There is that tendency in the way in which our systems have grown up. In 1993, not only do we see governments allowing families to wither on the vine, as the saying goes, but also an ever increasing intrusion by governments into the dynamics of family life, an intrusion based on the false conception that freedom for children and young adults is of higher importance than the exercise of responsible authority by parents. Fundamental to children being provided with the right atmosphere in which to grow up from being a total dependant to being independent is that parents be supported by the institutions of the state and not undermined.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is a sign of the times that more people today owe their livelihood to serving children in distress than ever before in history. Social workers deal with young homeless and street kids. Children turn to drugs and alcohol and welfare workers assist in their rehabilitation. The list could go on. This is fundamentally because families are not functioning as all of us would prefer them to, and I do believe that government systems which are now in place, both at state and federal levels, are not giving the supportive structures to family life that they should. All government programs are ultimately dependent for success on the good health of families. A sound family policy is almost the whole of a good welfare policy.

The second point which I raise, since time is brief, is that the family is also a fundamental administrative unit, apart from being a social unit. It is the unit on which decisions can be made, often without needing to have laws and regulations to make those decisions. Because there is mutual trust, I believe governments should recognise the fundamental importance of the family as an administrative unit in society. There has been a tendency over the last 50 or 100 years to move away from the family and for governments to believe, at all tiers, that administration is really that which is done by their bureaucrats.

I put it to the House today that we really should be focusing much more clearly on having strong family life and recognising the family's administrative role in society. If we did that, I believe that we would have a healthier society. We would have a stronger society and we would have less fallout than we have at the present time in a whole range of social areas. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity today to refer to a matter which is too seldom mentioned in this House. I refer, of course, to the catastrophic effect that our trade policies are having on the textile and clothing industry throughout our country. In Melbourne, Sydney, Adelaide, and in other areas, the employment opportunities lost have been quite significant, and that is a tragedy. I understand economics, and I understand the difficulties when we have tariff protection for industries. I also understand the advantages that this country would gain from free trade, from a level playing field approach. I know that we are an island nation; that we have too few people in this country to consume all the things we produce; and that our future is dependent upon our ability to sell our goods, our commodities and our produce overseas.

PARA.TAB: I am well aware that we are victim to the demands of the rest of the world. I often recall the story about when the Fraser government tried to impose restrictions on Asian nations exporting garments into Australia. Mr Fraser, as Prime Minister, went up to Malaysia and saw a number of Australian ships in the port. Those ships were still there four days later. He made diplomatic inquiries and asked, `Why are you not unloading the Australian goods which are there for your people to use?'. He was told that, because Australia had recently increased the tariff barriers which prevented Asian garments from coming into Australia, the Asians were not interested in taking the goods which we had exported to Malaysia.

I can understand that. If somebody denies the products which you want them to take, it is all right—and it is fair, I guess—for them to say, `All right. You do not want our garments? Then keep your wool. Keep your wheat. Keep your dairy products. Keep your iron ore and your coal!'. It is a very complex problem, but we must always be aware that the people who are the victims, the people who suffer as a result of trade arrangements, become tragic figures when they lose their jobs and there are no employment opportunities available to them.

This is a grievance debate—I guess that we have on these occasions an opportunity to grizzle, but also I think a grievance debate allow speakers to grieve—and today I want to grieve about what is happening to the textile and clothing and even footwear industries in this country. I do not want to specifically dwell on footwear production, because I have no footwear factories in my electorate, but I do have textile and clothing factories, and I grieve for the workers who are currently employed in those endeavours.

For many years, I guess since its early days, a large part of the Hunter electorate—places like Maitland, Cessnock, Kurri, Weston, et cetera—has been almost entirely dependent upon coal production. It has a very low industrial base and it is not at all diverse. It was essentially dependent upon coal. When people left school they went into the coal industry, although quite a few had no taste for the coal industry and went off to universities or teachers colleges. There was work for the males but there were no employment opportunities for the females. I guess that is how it came about that we had quite substantial developments of textile and clothing factories within the area, not just in Newcastle but National Textiles at Maitland and Depict Fashions at Weston and Kurri. We had Casben there for a while, we have Bonds in Cessnock, and many other textile and clothing producers.

These factories at one time were quite substantial. They were big employers and they offered job opportunities, particularly for women. The men went into the mines; the women went into the textile and clothing factories. But now, and for the past couple of years, the textile and clothing industries in my electorate are being killed. The three major companies, National Textiles, Depict Fashions and Bonds, have been in the city of Cessnock for between 10 and 20 years. Each of them at its peak employed 700 people. There were more than 2,000 jobs for the women of the Cessnock area. These women employed in those factories had no chance of gaining jobs elsewhere, unless they left the area completely. Many of them were new arrivals to this country who had a language problem, but they were able to gain jobs in the textile and clothing factories.

As I said, each of these factories employed 700 people. Take somebody like Depict Fashions in Kurri-Weston: it shed a couple of hundred people; it shed another couple of hundred people; earlier this year it shed about 126 employees; and just last week it shed another 93 employees. It now has 50 employees. For how long will it have 50 employees? It grieves me to say so, but I believe not for much longer. It just cannot compete. With the gradual removal of tariffs, the protective measures which we used to have in place for our textile and clothing industries, we become completely at a loss to compete.

It is not just the government. We have guaranteed that there will be a 25 per cent level of protection at the turn of the century, but those on the other side are strong in their resolve to see our textile and clothing industries disappear. They have guaranteed zero protection by the year 2000. It is not hard to understand why we cannot compete. In Australia, at one of the factories I mentioned, a machinist would earn between $1,600 and $1,800 per month. These companies are now going offshore; they have their factories, their operations, in China.

In China a machinist would receive $50 per month in the north and $20 per month in the south. There is no payroll tax, no super guarantee levy, no four-week holidays, no long service leave, no holiday loading. Australia does not want the type of tax regime which exists in China, Malaysia and Indonesia because there is no welfare in those countries. But that is the problem we face—that is the China syndrome. As well, we have the Asian syndrome in Australia, with subcontractors—backyard operators—operating out of their garages. An Australian made garment takes 20 minutes to manufacture and the cost of production may be $5 or $6. That is what it costs to make at, say, Bonds, Depict Fashions or National Textiles. A backyard operator paying non-award wages can produce the same garment for 50c or 60c. I hope that this government manages to find some measure for providing employment opportunities for those people who are being thrown on the unemployment scrap heap as a result of the removal of protection on the clothing industries. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is with this government, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) for failing to produce balanced, if limited, reform of our industrial relations system, with the overall objectives of reducing institutionalised constraints, encouraging innovative solutions to work-pay relationship problems, and generally freeing up the labour market to encourage investment in new productive capacity, improving productivity and expanding the job market.

PARA.TAB: Earlier this year on 21 April, the Prime Minister addressed the Institute of Company Directors. He spelt out, in fairly precise terms, his vision for reform of our fairly ancient, archaic, very wordy and constrained centralised system of determining pay and conditions of employment. He said that over time the safety net of wages would become simpler, with fewer awards and fewer clauses. He went on:

SPEECH.PARA: For most employees and most businesses, wages and conditions of work would be determined by agreements worked out between the employer, the employees and their union.
I would argue a bit about the union element, since some 70 per cent of the work force is unrepresented by unions, but in general I have got no problems with his statement. He said:
We want it—
that is, coverage of the work force by enterprise agreements—
to be close to one hundred per cent of employees under federal awards.
That is a fine objective. He also said:
And of course there are lots of employees who for one reason or another don't have a union to represent them.
It is not lots: 70 per cent of employees do not have unions to represent them. He said:
There are not enough enterprise bargains—and the bargains we do have are sometimes not sufficiently comprehensive.
That is demonstrably true. He said:
We need to find a way of extending the coverage of agreements from being add-ons to awards, as they sometimes are today, to being full substitutes for awards.

I say to the Prime Minister: fine sentiments. I largely agree with his sentiments and the objectives of this vision, if that is what it was, of the direction that our industrial relations system should take. But what is the government actually producing? Last week the Minister for Industrial Relations leaked a document, which is in fact an in-principle agreement between himself as minister and the ACTU's negotiating committee, on industrial relations reform. When we examine that document we find that there are a whole range of reform measures proposed, not one of which will satisfy the criteria put forward by the Prime Minister in his 21 April speech. An editorial in the Australian Financial Review earlier this year stated:

PARA.TAB: The long-term answer to the unions' problem is to help workers and their employers improve productivity, job security and real incomes.
However, the preoccupation of the unions with preserving their institutionalised power threatens their participation in genuine labour market reform.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the conundrum. The document, the in-principle agreement, lists item after item of further institutionalisation of the bureaucratic arm of trade unions' power: to give them more power either to disrupt or to control the system. In all of this agreement, in all of these seven pages, the word `employee' is written once and the word `unions' is written over and over again.

PARA.TAB: The minister wants to `strengthen the award system, in particular, to underpin enterprise bargaining'. I would not know how on earth the two sides of that statement are compatible. To strengthen the award system there is a bureaucratic procedural process that specifies in minute detail how employees shall work; where they shall work; when they shall work; how much they will be paid; what they shall not do; and what rules they shall conform to in terms of demarcation with other workers because they happen to belong to other unions. This is lodged in front of our quasi-judicial body, the Industrial Relations Commission, in page after page of bureaucratic speak.

The Australian Industrial Relations Commission is a unique body in the world: a group of lawyers-cum-judges, who make decisions about the lives of millions of Australians who never appear before the bench. Why do they not appear before the bench? Because they cannot. The only people who can appear before that bench are representatives of employers, that is, employer bureaucracies, and representatives of workers, that is, their unions—another bureaucracy. Three bureaucracies—the commission, the employers and the unions—decide what happens to Mary Bloggs and Joe Blow in their workplace in Coburg, Victoria. Terrific!

We are going to strengthen the award system and the bureaucratic processes. In fact, that will destroy any chance that we have at true enterprise bargaining which tries to get those three partners out of the way of the principal combatants, if there must be combat—that is, the employer and his work force—to allow them to sit down together and talk and make sensible decisions about how they will run the business together and how they will pay for the work that is done and under what constraints they will operate without interposing wills by unions, employer bodies or the IRC.

The minister is going to set up a new court `to deal with unfair dismissals'—a whole new arm of the industrial relations court. We will have another bureaucratic procedure, another lot of judges and another lot of lawyers and they will set up their own ethos over time, as has happened in the Family Court. We will get another whole set of procedures. What will be the requirements to be a judge of this unfair dismissal court? Will one have to have been unfairly dismissed or will one have to be an unfair dismisser in order to be qualified to sit on the bench of such an august body?

The minister wants to `make certain changes to the certified agreement provisions' of the industrial relations act in order to improve their operation. What he wants to do is to make sure that the no disadvantage test for certification is retained. In essence, that means that if one would like to change an award for an enterprise agreement one would have to prove that every clause, every word and every full stop in the award are outdone in the agreement. So one cannot trade in some of the benefits under the centralised award for something preferred under an enterprise agreement. The minister is going to establish a new division of the AIRC to deal with agreements. We have the freedom to bargain between employees and employers, but we are going to set up a bureaucratic mechanism to decide if what they agreed on is agreeable to the bureaucracy. It is an absolute nonsense!

The government is going to revise, in line with ILO recommendations—which is also a nonsense—sanctions applying to industrial actions. What that means is this: the minister is going to get rid of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act and give the bureaucrats and the unions another lot of bullets to put in their guns to fire at employers—to make sure that they acquiesce in union demands which have absolutely nothing to do with the legitimate right of employees to withdraw their labour if they are threatened. But the minister is allowing secondary boycotts, thus allowing people to put pressure on a particular employer by attacking a third party and driving that third party to the wall, and thereby making us more uncompetitive and losing us more jobs. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring to the attention of the House the now pressing situation of the Chinese students in Australia. Since our Olympic victory, we can expect to receive a vastly increased amount of world media attention between now and the year 2000. We must be extra careful not to besmirch our very favourable international image by an ill-considered and mistaken decision on this matter. The Tiananmen Square massacre saw about 18,000 Chinese students granted special visas, and these students have been joined by approximately 9,000 dependents and relatives. This situation is complicated by about 17,000 Chinese who, after Tiananmen Square, made visa applications to remain in Australia. If we decide to expel some or all of these people, we must be clearly aware that we are sending them back to tyranny.

PARA.TAB: I met Professor Harry Wu when he was in Australia in May of this year. He is the author of a serious study of the Chinese Gulag and was himself jailed for 19 years. His study clearly shows the existence of industrial slave labour camps in China today. Human rights and democracy are not part of the face of China today. I am aware that some members of the established Chinese community in Australia—people from parts of Asia other than mainland China—have not been as charitable to some of these new arrivals as they might have been. My view is that, whilst obviously not every student is perfect, nevertheless the Australian way is to err on the side of generosity.

The distinction in real life between pre-Tiananmen Square and post-Tiananmen Square is a technical one. I would urge the government to also be compassionate to the group of people who, since this dreadful event, are making their lives in Australia amongst us. The immigration of people to Australia is our greatest resource. One has only to see the situation and the wealth of a city like Singapore to see what can be achieved when a nation's only resource is people. I am proud to be here today and to be advocating that those students who were here before the Tiananmen Square massacre must be granted the full right to live in Australia and to join our national family. And those who have come since should also be considered in the framework of Australia's generosity.

There is and always has been a steady drumbeat of opposition to immigration in Australia. The Sydney Gazette of 1804 carried a letter from a farmer on the Hawkesbury River denouncing the arrival of new settlers. This reactionary position is over 200 years old, and it has always been wrong. All the parties in this House will recognise that our growing interaction with Asia is very much to our advantage, socially, culturally, economically and politically.

A favourable decision on this question will be very widely covered by the world media. An unfavourable decision will attract even more attention, and people will ask whether the decision is race based. Of course, everyone will say that there is no racial prejudice in an unfavourable decision, but our critics and enemies in Asia will ask, `When did Australians ever deport thousands of English or Europeans?'. I urge all honourable members to be especially aware of the trap right in front of us. For once, let us not put politics first, but put Australia first.

I am aware that many people say that these Chinese people should not jump the queue or get special treatment. But we have always done this sort of thing. In 1946 and 1947 we gave open preference to those people in displaced persons camps over the British living in Britain for places on the boats bringing those wonderful waves of migrants to Australia. We are now living next door to these people and some of their children are our colleagues in this parliament.

The immense human resources available to Australia from the presence in our country of these Chinese students should not be casually thrown away. The ugly truth about the immigration debate is that the enemies of immigration lack the courage to stand by their real racist views, at least in public. I am not a racist and I am also not a pessimist. I have great confidence that we can adopt a policy of building our homeland without destroying it environmentally or socially. The opponents of this view are basically racist and thus are cultural pessimists who think that we are not intelligent enough to help ourselves.

The decision on this momentous matter is to be made by the cabinet in June 1994. In reaching this decision the government must look to the future of our country. The Chifley cabinet in 1946, with the strong and principled support of Mr Menzies and the newly formed Liberal Party, made correctly the greatest decision ever made by an Australian government. The triumph that followed this decision, multicultural Australia, must now be backed up by a serious example of national self-confidence.

This is what this struggle comes down to: those of us who have confidence in Australia's future and in our own abilities to absorb and cope with the necessary changes to that future versus the pessimist, the frightened, the narrow and the shallow, those who are worried sick by such nonsense as skin colour, language and that terrifying observation that they are different.

Nations are put together, often roughly, based on very explosive elements, such as race, religion and ethnicity. Australia is being put together by none of these and this is a stroke of genius on our part. As far as I can see, Australia is the only nation in the world to be constructing itself on the basis of desire. Anyone who wants to be Australian, to live here with us, to share our ups and downs and share our future as it unfolds can do so. People do not have to be white; they have to want to be with us. People do not have to be Christian; they have to want to be with us. They do not have to be born here; they have to want to be with us. As a nation we have always welcomed those who want to share our lives. They repay us by vastly enriching this and future generations.

The Chinese students can be expected to make as great a contribution to our national life as have our neighbours from Italy, Greece, Lebanon, Britain and a hundred other countries. I implore this House to look at the future of our country and not some dark fears. Every objection we hear today was heard by our predecessors in 1946. If we can look after Australia in this manner as well as Chifley, Menzies and McEwen did, we are doing our duty and making our public lives worth while.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the late Warren Curry for a lot of the material that I have prepared here. He was the director of the Tobacco Leaf Marketing Board in Mareeba. We have heard a lot about the level playing fields and, in a rather brilliant article by Trevor Sykes in a recent Bulletin magazine, he describes us in rather sanguine terms as the only virgin in the brothel and then, in even more sanguine terms, he talks about our being constantly and continuously raped.

PARA.TAB: I represent one of those areas that is suffering greatly as a result of the policies of this government. I have to say in all honesty to the people of Australia, with whom we are communicating, that on our side of the House so many of the attitudes reflect the level playing field and so-called free trade. If we have heard it once, we must have heard it a thousand times, but let us face up to reality and state that the policies that are coming out of this parliament most certainly are those based on a level playing field, deregulation, and free trade policies.

I will always describe myself as a dry, sometimes even a super-dry, but I never expected the principle to extend to allowing sugar into this country subsidised at 193 per cent. Those are not my figures; they are the figures of the United States report to the President on international tariffs and trade in 1990. That is on page 2,776, if my memory serves me correctly.

We are not talking about some sort of bad principles here. We are talking about allowing European sugar into this country subsided at 193 per cent. I represent the magnificently efficient sugar industry. Honourable members will not see any human beings when they travel through the cane fields. They will not see any human beings when they travel through the mills. The sugar industry is so highly automated that there are virtually no human beings involved. On a comparable basis, the industry is about as efficient as it is humanly possible to be. It can compete, even when these countries are carrying these levels of subsidy.

The two biggest producers of sugar in the world are Europe and now Thailand. In Thailand, sugar was 22c a pound, yet the world price of sugar was 10c a pound. So Thailand most certainly is subsidising its product. We are trying to compete on the world market in sugar, but we have our own government removing the protection that enables us to be competitive on the world market, and making an absolute fool not only of this country but of every single one of us by posturing on the international stage instead of getting down to reality.

Let me move on to bananas. Bananas are responsible for providing some 5,000 jobs indirectly in the electorate of Kennedy. Bananas are worth some $300 million to the Australian economy. There is no way in the world, with a highly labour intensive product such as bananas, that we can compete ultimately against Central America where the people are working for $2 per day. Nor can we compete in the area of tobacco, which is another industry centralised in the electorate of Kennedy.

As every single one of these industries fall over and are smashed by the decisions made by this government and, I regret to say, by policies on my side of the House as well, and as tens of thousand of people are thrown out of work, let it be understood that it is on the conscience of the people in this particular parliament at this point of time in our history.

Whilst we are so cleverly removing the requirement that all Australian cigarettes contain 50 per cent Australian tobacco, the United States Congress has before it legislation, right at this very moment, which requires a 75 per cent content of United States tobacco in United States cigarettes.

It is not possible that Australia is right and America is right. One country is deadly wrong. It is this particular country, or at least its government, that is wrong. There is no doubt that it is out there in the streets, in the hearts and minds of the Australian people, that the principles lie. The last figure I saw showed that some 85 per cent of people agreed with the position that I am putting forward here and which Trevor Sykes put forward in the Bulletin.

Rice was being grown competitively for world markets here in Mareeba. We were suddenly advised by the Queensland government that water prices were going to go from an average of $6 per megalitre to $29 to $35 a megalitre. To put that into perspective, the water here is carried about 40 kilometres at most. In California in the United States they carry their water up to 600 kilometres and they charge $3.90 a megalitre. How in heaven's name can we compete against prices like that?

Not only do we have direct subsidies but we have huge indirect subsidies that enable other countries to become competitive. We cut the cost of production in tobacco almost clean in half. It was a brilliant exercise by an industry that had to become competitive and most certainly became competitive in a period of nine or 10 years. Where did it get us? Zimbabwe simply lowered the value of its dollar to such an extent that its tobacco again came in 40 or 50 per cent cheaper than our product. At the same time as Zimbabwe was lowering the value of its currency, we were in fact purchasing dollars at 100 miles an hour and propping up our currency. In fact, the then Treasurer, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), by his actions in raising interest rates and buying in the dollar, forced the dollar up. It fell to 59c in 1986 and he forced it up over the next 12 months to around 70c. Now he has run out of money and he has run out of ideas.

The world has run out of patience with us and no force in the world, please God, will be able to hold it up. If it was allowed to free-fall in 1986 and it fell to 59c when we only owed about $40,000 million, I leave to people's imagination what it will fall to when we now owe some $200,000 million. It will fall to an awful lot less than 59c.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will drop to 50c.

—Yes, I would say that 50c would be a fair enough figure. That is what it must fall to in order to help Mount Isa Mines, which has had to put 800 or 900 people off since 1990. Whatever criticisms people might like to make, no-one would doubt that it is a company that has over the years gained a reputation of having a sense of duty to the wider public. But, no matter what it does, it cannot work and continue to exist as a company unless something is done about the value of the dollar. There will be many more people put off at Mount Isa, and one must wonder about the security of all of our mining ventures in the longer term as long as the dollar stays as artificially high as it is at the present moment.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry went on the Four Corners program and he said, yes, we will have to allow bananas into Australia and the industry will have to learn to become competitive. Of its very nature it is a high labour input item, and Senator Sherry says it has to become competitive. How can we become competitive when wage structures in Central America are $2 a day and we have to pay, by law, between $8 and $10 an hour for our labour in Australia? I am 100 per cent behind our paying $8 to $10 an hour in Australia—that is what we should have in Australia—but if the government allows bananas to come in from overseas our banana producers have only two alternatives. One is to stop growing bananas, because they will grow at a loss, and the other is to go down to $2 a day wage levels to be able to compete. There is no other possibility. This parliament must make the decision whether we want to wipe out the $350 million a year banana industry and put another 10,000 or 20,000 Australians on the dole queues or whether we want to get away from this silly, stupid attitude. The principle is a good principle, but not when it is taken to the extreme lengths that it has been taken to at the present moment. I would venture to submit to the House that to allow bananas into this country is to act against the long-term future and welfare of this country. It would be a very serious act against that long-term welfare.

There is one other area that I would like to canvass before I sit down, and that is wool. This nation was getting $6,000 million a year for wool, and I hear constantly and continuously that somehow the minimum pricing scheme caused the collapse of the wool industry. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is a nation with a relatively short period of European involvement. It has the dubious record of not respecting objects of historic and cultural significance, and this applies to objects of Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal significance. I would like to spend a few minutes today talking about a crime that may be about to happen. It will be a crime against all the people of Australia and it will be a crime of mammoth proportions. No-one can deny our maritime heritage. Early immigration to this country was by sea and our wealth was derived through exports, using ships to cart our goods around the world.

PARA.TAB: To make our coastal sea lanes and the entrances to our harbours safe, lighthouses have been built around our enormous, sometimes raging, often rugged but always beautiful, coast. They have served our nation well. The families that manned them often had heroic tales, and certainly tales of hardship and privation, to tell from their work in keeping our ships safe. What family has had a seaside holiday and not gone to visit a lighthouse?

I happen to have two such lighthouses in my electorate. One is at Sugarloaf Point, Seal Rocks, adjacent to the Myall Lakes National Park. It is a uniquely beautiful site. This lighthouse was opened in 1875. The other light is the outer light at the entrance to Port Stephens, and that was opened in 1862. It is the outer light at Port Stephens that I wish to speak about in particular today because, like most lighthouses, it is under threat. Modern ships do not require lighthouses because they have more sophisticated means of communication which allow the ships to position themselves.

The outer light at Port Stephens was converted to electricity in 1960 and the lighthouse keeper withdrawn. The premises are now on offer to the New South Wales government. As we would expect, the New South Wales government claims it does not have the money to purchase the lighthouses and AMSA, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, the corporatised body that was set up to administer our maritime safety, has responded that such premises may be sold to private organisations if the state will not buy. I ask: who has the right to sell this property of such significance, property that is owned by the Australian people, was never paid for by anyone and where the costs of running the lighthouses have been funded by commercial shipping?

Local residents and boat owners even made a contribution of $30,000 to have the light reinstated when the power was cut off some years ago. The community also fought to have the building saved and to have a fence erected to prevent vandalism. Two years ago, vandals were successful in torching the residence and destroyed all the timber parts of the construction, yet an engineer's report claimed that the stone structure was sound and should be repaired as quickly as possible.

The $50,000 insurance money for this fire that was collected by the National Trust has been absorbed into the National Trust and not a cent of it has been paid to carry out any restoration at that site. I wish to object in the strongest possible terms to the impasse that exists over our lighthouses between the federal government and the state government of New South Wales. These lighthouses are a part of our heritage. They need to be retained by the people because they continue to provide that sense of our history that is so vital to us as a nation. They continue to be tourist attractions, as they have been for so long. They do not deserve to be allowed to decay into memories because two levels of government cannot sit down and make the decision that is necessary to safeguard our heritage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That grievances be noted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —During private members business this morning, the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) made much of the supposed generosity of the federal government to the state governments, particularly Victoria. Budget Paper No. 1 clearly shows that assistance to other governments has fallen from 21.7 per cent of total budget outlays in 1983-84 to a measly 13.5 per cent in 1993-94. Does the honourable member for Dunkley think this is generous?

PARA.TAB: Despite the erroneous claims of the honourable member for Dunkley, the federal government is squeezing Victoria and all other states in the same way as it is squeezing Victorians and all other Australians. The fact is this budget is dishonest, irresponsible, deceptive and discredited, and it becomes more so with each passing day. It has created uncertainty, controversy and confusion. Fortunately, there is still time to bring about some significant changes, particularly with regard to the increases in wholesale sales tax, the increase in tax on wine, the increase in tax on petrol, diesel and other fuels, and the retrospective increase in tax on unused accrued annual leave. These are measures for which the government clearly has no mandate.

The coalition will support the long awaited tax cuts because Australians were promised them, and they deserve them. However, we are committed to doing everything we can to protect Australians from those other unfair, unreasonable, unjustifiable and unacceptable tax increases. Hopefully, with the support of the minor parties, we will be successful in achieving this objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I received the Insight magazine from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I had heard about the comment of Bill Ferris, the Austrade Chairman, in connection with the republican issue. I thought it was a waste of good taxpayers' funds to have that comment reiterated within a government magazine where it operates as propaganda only.

PARA.TAB: It did give me an opportunity to read his views on why a change to a republic would change the trading aspects of Australia. I do not know how it would change it, but he did put some of his views. He does not recognise that Australia's reputation throughout the world, as far as getting the Olympic games is concerned, is based on what was done under the Australian flag—a very distinctive flag—and under the constitution we have had since 1901.

In spite of that, Mr Ferris goes on to say that Australia's image overseas is outdated, outmoded and possibly harmful to the promotion of our products and services. That is just badmouthing by a public servant who should know better. It is badmouthing of a situation where the problems that are created in this country could quite well be Austrade's problems and not those of the people who are competing.

In addition, if Mr Ferris, as the Austrade Chairman, does not recognise that the problems we have in Australia are excessive debt, excessive costs, a consumption tax on producers and things such as that, he should not be in the job. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a grand morning for the rewriting of history. It seems that honourable members from both sides of the House have burnt the midnight oil searching through their history texts. Honourable members on my right have tearfully looked back to good old Bob, once called Pig Iron Bob as he loaded the bullets for the Japanese prior to the Second World War. He, we are told, is the coalition's saviour. What a joke!

PARA.TAB: Here we have the rabid free traders harking back to the good old protectionist days of Black Jack McEwen and the Anglophile Menzies who, when the economy was going through a tough trot, slipped in import quotas to protect Australian industry from imports. Are opposition members trying to tell the House that they are now great supporters of protectionism rather than free trade? Are we to expect a private member's bill supporting increased tariffs and the resumption of quotas?

On the other side of the chamber, the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), whose precis of the Menzies years I support, now paints a picture of a classless Australia where working-class kids in their droves are trotting off to university. He conveniently ignores the fact that over the past 10 years the Labor Party has, at the behest of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), deregulated the financial markets, put a for sale sign above one public asset after another—Telecom will be next—and thrown up the very real possibility that non-unionists, or finks as the Prime Minister calls them, will receive the same rights as unionists in the deregulated enterprise.
The so-called true believers would paint a different picture. With the underclass growing, it is absurd for honourable members on both sides of the House to continue with this kind of myth making.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to bring to the attention of the House an issue which is of great concern to me. Some time ago, on Network Ten's Hinch program, I witnessed footage of several Asiatic black bears in the People's Republic of China in conditions which totally appalled not only my family but also many constituents of Stirling who were absolutely sickened by the treatment of the bears.

PARA.TAB: The use of black bears in China for the purposes of extracting bile for alleged medicinal purposes is not only inhumane, it is appalling and a situation which needs addressing immediately. We can be criticised for commenting on the affairs of another culture, another nation; however, the time comes when any decent human being has to say that enough is enough.

Approximately 8,000 of these bears are in captivity in cages so small that there is little room for them to move, which results in their going totally insane. All this is done so that every two weeks bile, prized as a remedy for anything and everything from colds to hepatitis and jaundice, can be extracted from their stomachs through a tube connected to their gall bladders, causing them excruciating pain.

I have had many calls to my electorate office regarding this issue. One particular person I would like to acknowledge is Mrs Mary Hutton, who has tirelessly worked on the issue since those scenes on the Hinch program were aired. She has organised a petition which will be tabled here next week, containing over 3,000 signatures calling on this House to take action against China's maltreatment of these defenceless animals. As the bears of China have no voice, let the bellow of pain of their human friends here in Australia be so loud and heart-rending that it will reach through to the cold-as-stone hearts of their captors and the government of the People's Republic of China.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am continually amazed by the vaudeville nature of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in this place during question time, and no doubt we will see some more today. It reminds me of his lost role in society. I think he should actually be a leading man for many of the musicals around the place and I think he should also possibly be the leading man in a musical based upon this place called the Rocky Horror Show. Could honourable members imagine the Prime Minister playing Frank N. Furter, dressed in his silk stockings, his high heels and his Zegna corsets? What about Riff Raff, his noble friend: that just has to be played by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). Remember that song they sang, Time Warp? I think the dealings of the Prime Minister and Treasurer with caucus are reminiscent of the chorus:

SPEECH.PARA: It's just a jump to the left
And then a step to the right
Put your hands on your hips
Put your knees inside
And then you pelvic thrust until you are going insaneayayayane
Let's do the time warp again.

The Prime Minister has proven he is always in a time warp and, dare I say, as he tries to ramrod his policies through this place, he needs an award, and I think that award should be the kiss of death.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take this opportunity to congratulate the Sydney Olympic bid committee on its highly successful effort to win the Olympics for Australia for the year 2000. I am sure that all Australians join with me in great pride that our nation will once again host this international event, which is the pride of amateur athletics around the world. But I do wish to issue a word of caution to those groups in the community who would use the Olympics and its ideals as a platform for their own partisan political or specific purposes. I caution the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in this regard that it is not appropriate for him to be issuing demands that we become a so-called republic by the year 2000 for the Olympics or that we change our flag, which so many Australians fought and died under, in order to satisfy some neo-classical response to prove that we are really Australians. We know we are Australians. We fought the Olympic bid under our flag, we fought the Olympic bid under our constitution and our monarch. I trust that all Australians will join in the spirit of the Olympics and be positive in outlook and, when other nations come to visit our shores, that we show them a truly united nation, that we are Australians from all walks of life, from all colours, all creeds, all religions, all races, from all corners of the earth. (Time expired)

—I was sitting in my office working and I heard three Liberal voices in a row and it just about gave me a heart attack, so I thought I had better come in here and say something on a subject that is dear to my heart, and that is Jeffrey Kennett.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at Jeffrey Kennett, the Liberal Premier of Victoria. I have a couple of little articles here. One is headed, `Kennett bans Sunday Age'. Any criticism of this dictator of Victoria—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker, the honourable member should call the Premier by his right name.
—Order! The honourable member for Dunkley is in fact reflecting on and using unparliamentary words against a member of another place, and I require that he withdraw those reflections.

—I will withdraw those, Mr Speaker. I was talking about the Premier of Victoria, whose rule has been claimed as jackboot tactics. I remember jackboots from history, and I think they were associated with the Nazi party. However, I would not like to say that the Premier of Victoria was associated with that. He has banned the Sunday Age and he has also banned the 7.30 Report, he will not go on that. In today's Age there is a little article which says that the Premier is quick to take up a defend-by-attack position, attacking Justice Fogarty for his critical child protection system report, attacking the commissioner for investigating his liquor licence, attacking journalists, questioning advertising and other contracts and a major tender. Methinks the Premier attacks too much. (Time expired)

—A lot of honourable members on the opposite side of the chamber are probably grinding their teeth because the balance in the Senate appears to be held by the Western Australian Greens. Any honourable members opposite who are regretting that ought to be wary, and ought to be aware that the reason why there are two Green senators from Western Australia is their own party's stuff-up at the last federal election.
—That's why you have two less in the House of Representatives.

—I say to the honourable member for Banks that we have got six senators, his party has four, and there are two Greens. The reason the Greens got elected is that the highly intelligent strategy of the honourable member's party was to support the Greens. That was because of Senator Graham Richardson's act, at the previous election and all the way through, of pandering to the Greens. As a consequence, the Labor Party now finds itself in the position of having to negotiate with two Green senators instead of senators of its own persuasion.

PARA.TAB: When honourable members opposite are sitting in their caucus room and considering the dilemma that is facing the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the rest of the party over the non-existence of the budget, they have to bear the consequences of the Western Australian Labor Party's electoral stuff-up in supporting the Greens at the last federal election. All I can do is advise honourable members opposite to stop pandering to the loony left interest groups and they will not find themselves in the same situation at the next election because, firstly, we will be in government, but also at least the preferences of honourable members opposite will go to elect senators who are going to— (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I had the opportunity to watch the ABC documentary So Help Me God and it brought back memories for me, because I was the public defender at the Campbelltown District Court before I entered the parliament. It showed what is happening in the legal system in New South Wales and it really has not changed over the years. But what the program did show was the commitment of legal aid lawyers in New South Wales, in particular the commitment of the legal aid solicitors at Campbelltown District Court.

PARA.TAB: But the other message from it was that at government level we should not forget that there is a crisis in the court system and too often we throw the money to the judiciary and the prosecution and forget about the defence. It is my view that any money that goes to remedy the legal system needs to go in proportion. We need to fund the legal aid system in New South Wales adequately and properly because if we do not we will have people who are unrepresented.

The program last night dealt with real life. It is a horror story that is happening in the local court system; it is untenable; it should not be allowed to exist. More money needs to be put to the defence side as well as to the prosecution and also, obviously, to the judiciary: we need a balanced approach. I commend the producers of the program.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Maritime Services Board of New South Wales has approved a heliport at Darling Harbour in Sydney. The New South Wales Environment Protection Authority is at present discussing conditions of approval with the Civil Aviation Authority.

PARA.TAB: The CAA has taken virtually no part in the heliport so far and gives every sign of paying lip service to any real enforcement of conditions of approval. A large number of helicopters operating on a self-regulation basis is a formula for disaster for both users and residents. It should not be allowed to operate without a proper regulatory system and an effective method of enforcement.

There is also no case whatsoever for any public subsidy for the 27 millionaire owners of helicopters in Sydney or the senior bureaucrats and ministers of the New South Wales and Commonwealth governments, not to mention the wealthy gamblers flying to the Darling Harbour casino who will be the main users of the heliport.

The CAA must fulfil its public obligation and fully monitor and control all helicopter movements and ensure that the user, not the public, pays. The helicopter users are already massively subsidised by the public by both the Federal Airports Corporation, through the Kingsford Smith facility, and through the Maritime Services Board virtually giving away the Darling Harbour site for a fraction of its value, without counting the costs of noise pollution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being approximately 2.00 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—I inform the House that the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services, Mr Howe, will be absent from question time. In his absence, questions should be directed to the Minister for Social Security.

—Before I call on questions, I must say that during question time yesterday an accusation was levelled at the honourable member for Maranoa, concerning an alleged reflection on the chair. I have had the opportunity to discuss this matter with the honourable member and am satisfied that in no way was the alleged offence attributable to him. However, in a general sense, any reflections on the chair are highly disorderly. There are appropriate methods under the standing orders to deal with such disagreements with the Chairman's or Speaker's ruling. I must also say to those members who level such accusations that they should perhaps check the facts more clearly.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. He knows that his budget tax cuts have been passed in this House, without opposition from the coalition parties. Why is he trying to deny those tax cuts to Australians by insisting that they can go ahead only if they are accompanied by tax increases for which he has absolutely no mandate. Why does he not join with us today to pass the tax cuts into law—l-a-w, law?

—Those opposite do not like it, do they? It is beginning to hurt, because they know as well as anybody how irresponsible it would be to pass on those tax cuts in the absence of a deficit reduction strategy. That strategy is the key to this budget. It is before the Senate and a key component of that package is the delivery of tax cuts from 15 November. I ask honourable members opposite what they have against the nearly five million taxpayers in Australia they will deny a tax cut to?
—Hypocrite.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will withdraw that reflection on the Treasurer.
—I withdraw.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is he aware of reports that overseas foreign exchange markets are concerned by threats to the stability of Australian fiscal policy? Can he say what steps the government is taking to do all it can to minimise the impact of any instability?
