ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have recorded, on a number of occasions, the approval with which the budget was greeted by financial markets; in bond yields, the all ordinaries index, the exchange rate and all the measures that one can take reasonable notice of in terms of gauging market opinion. The markets, in the broad, supported the budget strategy—and why would they not? It takes the budget deficit down to about one-half or one-third of that in most comparable countries, by the middle 1990s. That is the central element of the medium-term strategy of the budget, as well as providing a stimulus in the short term which the economy needs via tax cuts.

PARA.TAB: We are seeing this tired, defeated and desperate opposition, going down on its knees to the Greens—to put the country on its knees. This is what the federal opposition has now come to. It is trying to form a coalition with the Greens to bring the country to its knees. We then get the sort of unprincipled question that was put by the Leader of the Opposition a moment ago, about the irresponsibility of dealing with the tax cuts component of the budget and not with the medium-term deficit reduction strategy, which is contained in it.

This is the person who said that he was not going to be a politician. He was not going to be like the rest of us; he was going to be above the rest of us. He is someone who was going to be part of the new breed, who was not going to worry about popularity, political risks, short-sighted policies or engage in political opportunism. He was going to do the right thing in the public interest. Where is he? He is having midnight encounters with the Greens to try to thwart the elected government's budget and measures which reduce the budget deficit. While each Friday he is talking to the business community extolling the virtues of low deficits and balanced budgets, between times he is up here working out how to knock off the tax increases and the change in the budget balance which will reduce the budget deficit over time.

There is a lot of concentration on the two Green senators, but they are only two senators. It takes 38 votes to block measures in the Senate. Thirty-six of the 38 votes will be provided by the Leader of the Opposition's unprincipled coalition in the Senate. Yesterday we had Malcolm Fraser saying that the Senate is running the risk of making Australia ungovernable; it is running the risk of turning the annual budget process into a series of bargains and trade-offs similar to those which occur in the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. It is related to information that has been provided to the House being repeated. This information was provided by the Prime Minister yesterday. I suspect that, if he has to re-run it, he does not have anything else to run with.
—Order! You will resume your seat. There is no point of order. The Prime Minister is answering the question.

—That is what Malcolm Fraser said. Here is a new piece of information for the House. Liberal frontbencher Amanda Vanstone yesterday said that she has unfavourably compared the federal coalition's political judgment with that of the former Prime Minister in suggesting past errors of political judgment are being repeated. She went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: I hear party members and colleagues euphoric at the perceived realisation by the public that Labor has been exposed as useless liars and cheats that the public will not forgive or forget.

Her observation about the Liberal Party is entirely correct. We have the leader of the National Farmers Federation in this country, Mr Graham Blight, out for a second time saying that he does not regret his statements that the opposition's handling of the budget is fiscally irresponsible, not constructive and not politically astute. He said, `We were right then, and I am sure we are going to prove to be right in the long run'. That was said yesterday. That follows the other assaults upon the coalition which have now come from the former Prime Minister, from Senator Vanstone and from the leader of the National Farmers Federation. They are all calling into question this wrecking tactic of trying to thwart the passage of the budget measures while at the same time asking unprincipledly the question about the passage of tax cuts and voting against the funding of the budget measures.

PARA.TAB: Dr Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Goldstein.

—Today we saw again further encouraging signs that the labour market is beginning to improve. Yesterday I mentioned a number of indicators. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, vacancies were up 9.3 per cent in the three months to August to be some 30 per cent above their level of a year earlier. Overtime is up 1.5 per cent for the quarter to be 8.3 per cent above the level of a year earlier. Yesterday I gave the results of the DEET skilled vacancy surveys, which showed skilled vacancies up 25 per cent in the year to September and vacancies in trades up 50 per cent in the year to September. All of these signs are there; yet the group spiking the growth in national confidence and recovery is John Hewson and his federal opposition.

PARA.TAB: The opposition may go on with all its histrionics, its antics and the rest, but the fact is that this opposition does not have any policies now. It has abandoned Fightback; it has abandoned its GST. What does it boil down to when the person who was going to give us a new order in politics has not done the politic thing but the unpolitical thing? It has all boiled down to a coalition with the Greens to try to block in the Senate the legitimate government's legitimate budget.

At Christmas time when wage and salary earners lose their $8 to $10 a week, they can blame the Leader of the Opposition; they can blame the federal opposition for its wrecking tactics in the Senate and for denying people on modest incomes, who have had no wage increase in the last year, the $8 to $10 a week that would make a substantial difference to them, to their families, to the economy, to retailing and to our society in the broad. I conclude on this note: that the wrecking tactics of the Leader of the Opposition are now being noted by the former Prime Minister, his own party colleagues, the leader of the National Farmers Federation and other conservative people in this country who do not approve of the unprincipled behaviour which he is leading in the Senate of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Special Minister of State to current negotiations with the states on the Mabo issue and the meeting at officer level tonight. Consistent with the constitutional responsibilities of the states for land management, is it now the Commonwealth's intention that responsibility for native title will also be with the states and, provided that they adhere to existing state laws for the payment of compensation, any state may extinguish native title?
—This is the first Mabo question. The first one!
—The Prime Minister will cease interjecting.

—It has always been the Commonwealth's position to seek the cooperation of the states to resolve the issues raised by the High Court in the Mabo decision so far as land management is concerned. That has always been our position and we have, and certainly the Prime Minister has, gone to extraordinary lengths to negotiate with the states.

PARA.TAB: It is unfortunate that some states, Western Australia in particular, have refused to be part of those negotiations and discussions. The Western Australian government has always taken the position that the judges of the High Court were wrong in their decision and that the only way to resolve the question of Mabo was by a referendum. That position, of course, is also the position of the Liberal Party.

However, we have not taken the view that just because Western Australia has taken a dog in the manger position that we should not negotiate with the other states. Many hundreds of hours of negotiations between officials have occurred in an endeavour to reach an understanding so far as a cooperative scheme is concerned. Those negotiations continue. It is our hope that at least a majority of the states will join with us as this legislation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Will they be able to? It is native title.
—Order!
—You don't even know the first thing about the law.
—The honourable minister! The honourable member for Flinders has asked his question; listen to the answer.

—I am beginning to wonder whether John Laws is right about the honourable member for Flinders. The fact is that the High Court decided that the states could extinguish native title, and not only could but had done so wholesale for 200 years. It is a matter of simple law that that is the position. No-one except perhaps the honourable member for Flinders would doubt that that is the position. None of the players in this game has ever suggested that anything other than that is the position.

PARA.TAB: However, they can only do so in accordance with the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act. In other words, they cannot extinguish native title in a way that is discriminatory against Aboriginal people. They cannot do that because the High Court decided that they could not do that. That, of course, is the government's position too, that native title should not be extinguished in a discriminatory way.

That, of course, is not the position of the Liberal Party. The Liberal Party's view is that we should hold a referendum around Australia to allow the states to extinguish native title in a discriminatory way. But that is not the government's position.

The simple position is that we are negotiating with the cooperating states and we hope to reach agreement with them because we think that is the best and the most sensible solution for Australia, for the Aboriginal people and for reconciliation generally. We hope that will be achieved. If it is not, we will still not shirk our responsibilities as the Commonwealth government, our responsibilities to land management in this country and our responsibilities to the Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Treasurer inform the House as to how the PAYE or the tax instalment system applies to prepayments of annual leave and annual leave loading? Will that system apply in a way different from the usual way for prepayments of annual leave this December?

—Prepayments of annual leave are subject to PAYE deductions as follows: each week's leave pay is subject to deductions at the same rate as a normal week's pay on the basis of the PAYE tables in force at the time of the payment. The annual leave loading payment up to $320 is not subject to PAYE deductions unless the employee requests it to be. This is because the PAYE tables are designed to recover enough deductions from 52 weeks normal pay to cover the tax on that level of annual leave loading as well.

PARA.TAB: It is, of course, the government's intention that the PAYE system should operate in the normal way in relation to annual leave prepayments made this December as people take their annual holidays. Indeed, the budget provides for income tax cuts from 15 November, and therefore those cuts and the rates after those cuts would be reflected in the normal PAYE tables. That means that as employees go on holidays they would have their annual leave payments taxed on the basis of the new PAYE tables, not the ones which exist at the moment.

I have made the point on a number of occasions that, whilst the government is keen to do this, we cannot do it whilst the Senate is holding hostage the government's medium term deficit reduction strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you say this before the election?
—Order!
—Therefore it is a matter of regret that the opposition is continuing its tactics of delaying or threatening to delay those tax cuts.
—Come on! Why didn't you say this before the election?
—I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.

—What this actually means is that if we take the example of some ordinary working Australians, bus drivers, for instance, would be $36 worse off as they went on their annual leave as a result of the opposition's tactics, rather than as the government would like them to be. Schoolteachers would be $48 worse off as a result in relation to their holiday pay; nurses would be worse off by $56; firefighters by $64; ambulance officers by $68; and stenographer-secretaries by $20.

PARA.TAB: One has to ask the question: what is it that the Liberal Party has against these ordinary Australian working men and women? These are not wealthy people; they are representative of the bulk of wage and salary earners in this country who simply want to go on their annual holidays and actually have the pay in their hands which the government wants them to have. The government wants them to have the benefit for Christmas and for their annual holidays, and it is only the tactics of the opposition in the Senate which is putting this matter at risk. We now have an opposition dedicated to a strategy which will reduce the expenditure which all these families have in the lead-up to Christmas, thereby plundering the Christmas stockings of so many children around the country.

Secondly, the effect of denying this stimulus to the economy will be to reduce the number of jobs available, particularly in the retail industry over the Christmas period. Just to complete the trifecta, the opposition actually wants to lighten the pay packets of these working men and women as they attempt to take their families on their annual vacations. What do the Leader of the Opposition and his Liberals have against ordinary Australians? Why do they want to damage and punish them in this way? Why will they not do the decent and proper thing: pass the budget and let these payments flow?

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to all honourable members in this place that, under the standing orders, they are to refer to members by the electorate or their title, and I invite them to do so.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Yesterday, you drew attention to interjections, particularly interjections from people not sitting in their places, being disorderly. Does an exemption apply to the honourable member for Stirling?
—Whistleblower!

—You caught me somewhat off guard because I do not think I have heard the honourable member for Stirling. He is such a fine, upstanding member sitting in the second row. I thank the honourable member for Chifley for raising the matter. I invite all members to look at standing order 55.

—I refer the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories to her response to the question from the honourable member for North Sydney yesterday regarding logging in the New South Wales forests when she stated that she was still awaiting a reply from the New South Wales government. Is it not a fact that, contrary to what she told the parliament yesterday, the New South Wales minister, Mr Garry West, replied to her comprehensively on 8 February 1993? Did the minister mislead the House or was this another case of her just reading the cover—or in this case the envelope—rather than the contents?

—I was answering a question about the forest agreement and I was referring to correspondence between me and the New South Wales government. I have written a number of letters in relation to that matter.
—And you had a reply.

—I have had a reply to some and no reply to others. I would be quite happy to table two letters that I have sent: one to Mr Souris on 31 May on this matter, to which I have not received a response, and another one on 9 September.
—You misled the House.
—That is not the letter you referred to yesterday.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the National Party!
—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. What action is being taken to assist the export of food produce from Australia?

—At the outset, I can say that the government has done much and will continue to do more. I would remind the House that food exports from this country currently contribute $12 billion to our export earnings. Australia is by far a net food exporter. The significant change in the composition of our food exports should be noted. Last year, almost one quarter of our food exports were represented by high value added processed food. In other words, we are moving away from just the supplying of commodities as food to doing something with them before they leave this country.

PARA.TAB: The government has a strategy to treble the high value food process exports from this country by the year 2000. I point out that trebling the food exports in the high value processed food sector has a significance for this economy because at the moment off the base of $3 billion in high value added food process we have an industry employing 160,000 people. The food processing industry in this country is currently the largest manufacturing segment in our economy. If we are going to treble that base, not only is it good for our balance of payments but it is also great for jobs and terrific for regional development, because the activity will take place near to the source.

Therefore, the government has developed a strategy by which it will realise this potential. My colleague the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development and I jointly chair the Agrifood Policy Council that is seeing this strategy through. That $3 billion in processed food exports has really increased by $1 billion over the last two years. It took us eight years to complete the previous increase of $1 billion. Not only has the composition of food processing changed but also the rate of change has increased, and some very important recent examples indicate that this trend will continue.

Recently, the Prime Minister and I visited Tasmania where the Edgell food company is committed to a potato chip factory, which has the potential to realise $100 million in food exports. It has combined with the world best practices program that we announced during the election campaign and delivered in this budget—a program that was ridiculed by the opposition as being meaningless to growers but which has been welcomed by the Tasmanian potato growers.

The Mars food company in Ballarat has moved to continuous production because it secured an export contract to the former Soviet Union by building on Australia's strength in dairy production. Apple juice from Tasmania, because of its concentration on quality, recently secured a huge contract into Japan, as has the Atlantic salmon industry in Tasmania.

Recently, Goodman Fielder Wattie announced a breakthrough in a high fibre starch component which will add nutrition and health to the food we export, which will underpin the basis upon which we want to expand this industry by tapping into the fact that the world knows Australia is a producer of quality nutritional food. We will secure those export markets.

The common thread to how we have achieved the development of this strategy is that we have built upon our agricultural base; we have sought to do more with the food that is produced than just sell it in domestic markets; we have combined it with the innovative capacity of the nation; and we have developed marketing strategies. The government has had an active role in all of this, either in bringing the linkages in the chain together or putting them in touch with programs that we have developed in their interests.

But the opposition would not persist with those programs. In its Fightback document last year the opposition did not give one commitment to funding these programs. That is the fundamental contrast between the government and the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker: the opposition has been listening very quietly and attentively, but it is now almost half past two. This is an inordinately long answer on a matter that ought to be the subject of a statement.
—Order! The minister, I think, has illustrated his answer extremely well, but I would invite him to wind up.

—I am just about to do that, Mr Speaker. We understand the need to work with industry to develop programs to secure our opportunities. The opposition sees no role for government in this. It is little wonder that the leadership, including the National Farmers Federation, considers the other side of the House as having neglected their interests and being incapable of representing their interests, and so is getting behind these programs to make sure that they work.

—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I refer to the answer given a few moments ago by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, at the conclusion of which she indicated that she would table—
—And she placed them on the table.
—No, no, Prime Minister. I have got this one as well,
—She placed the documents on the table. I am asking whether they could be officially tabled.

—That would have been a reasonable request at the appropriate time, which was when the minister spoke. That point has now passed. I will ask the minister whether she was reading from private documents.
—No.
—At the time they were not required to be tabled.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a further point of order. At the conclusion of the minister's answer, she indicated she was going to table the documents. She actually moved the documents in the direction of the Clerk and dropped them between the dispatch box and the books on the table. We asked for those papers. The point is that she indicated that at the time. We did not ask for them to be tabled at the time, because the impression was that they had been.
—You have made your point; resume your seat. The minister is going to have to help me and refresh my memory. Did you make the offer to table documents? If so, those documents should be tabled.
—I said I would. The opposition did not ask for the documents, so I did not.
—Minister, I think that is a fairly moot point. If the minister made an offer to table the documents, I would suggest strongly that she table those documents.
—I made the offer. If opposition members now want them, they may have them.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. There are no free questions here dressed up as points of order. If those opposite want to ask a question, they can ask one. But if they want to take up question time with points of order, the next call will be on this side of the House.

—A general point has been raised in the Prime Minister's point of order—that is, question time is for questions, which I am endeavouring to ensure occurs. I would in fact like to move on to that point right now.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. We have a very simple situation here. The minister clearly indicated an intention of tabling something. It would be an absolute travesty of the proceedings in this place if she were to escape the responsibility of tabling documents that will determine whether or not she misled the parliament.
—Order! The point of order has already been made and the minister has indicated she is tabling the documents.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Where are they?

TALK.START.PARA: —It has just been done.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neville Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I preface my question by reminding the minister of his answer to a question by the honourable member for Page in this House on Monday in respect of funding of drought aid in Queensland. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: The other day I made an announcement of an additional $3.1 million, because the funding in that regard had run out.

In view of the minister's confirmation on ABC Radio in Toowoomba this morning that the so-called additional $3.1 million provided to Queensland farmers affected by prolonged drought was to be simply `reallocated from normal RAS'—I repeat, `from normal RAS'—that is, from rural adjustment scheme funding, has the minister not misled this House and perpetrated a cruel hoax on the desperate farming community of Queensland?

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been no misleading of the House, but if it took the opposition as long to ask a question like that as it has to work out over the last four days what I have said, there would never be any assistance flowing to drought affected people in Queensland. The simple facts are these: two weeks ago I announced additional expenditure under the exceptional circumstances provisions of RAS. Opposition members should read the press release and understand it—additional under the exceptional circumstances provisions of RAS. I also made the point that, with regard to being able to access those funds immediately, we would reorganise the existing RAS arrangements. That was done in full consultation with the Queensland government, the Grains Council and Queensland Graingrowers, who not only accepted that it was the only way in which we could get money in immediately, but welcomed and applauded the government's action in that regard. For those who want to make the point that this is sleight of hand—
—It is.

—Opposition members should just listen to this, because I know that they are going to have all their people coming across, trying to understand how RAS works. I will try to explain it simply for them now. What the government did in this recent budget was to more than double its estimates of money to be provided under the rural adjustment scheme over the next four years. That is not an insubstantial commitment, I might add. The previous forward estimates said that, for the next four years, we would have had something in the order of $200 million. We are making available $406 million, based on our best estimates at this stage of what is needed.

PARA.TAB: We have always said in relation to RAS that the assessment of what is actually needed will depend upon the circumstances at the time. We review on a six-monthly basis the adequacy of funding under RAS. If we find that more money is needed under the normal RAS, it will be forthcoming. I have made the commitment in the past that we will ensure that adequate funding is made available to farmers who need it. We will continue to do that.

One final point I want to make is this: this exercise has demonstrated, as has the exercise in July of this year with state ministers, that we provide the bulk of funding under RAS. Under the normal RAS, the Commonwealth has contributed in the past five years something like $500 million. Do honourable members know what the states have contributed? The answer is $16 million. Yet, they are the ones that administer the scheme, and they are always the ones complaining that not enough money is available. Not only will I make sure that adequate funds are available; I will make sure that the states pay their way, because I am about ensuring that those farmers who need assistance will get it. I have done it to date, and will continue to do it in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Given that Sydney has been chosen to host the 2000 Paralympics, could the minister tell the House what funding the federal government will provide to assist in staging the games?

—I thank the honourable member for her question. Members of parliament would be aware that, early in the week, I congratulated the Sydney Paralympics bid committee on its successful bid to stage the Paralympics in the year 2000. I believe that will be a fantastic event. I have met with paralympians on many occasions during the last few months—including President Ron Finneran—and have made it very clear to them that the Commonwealth was sympathetic towards the 2000 Paralympic bid and towards providing assistance.

PARA.TAB: It is clear that the position of the New South Wales and federal governments on funding the Paralympics was accurately stated to the International Paralympic Committee by Sydney bid official Bob Elphinston. Unfortunately, since that time, I think there has been some confusion about what he actually said. Discussions on this joint funding have already been held between the Prime Minister and New South Wales Premier John Fahey. As there has been confusion about the figures involved and the governments' commitments, I am very pleased to announce that the federal government will provide 50 per cent of the funding needed to meet the projected shortfall of the Paralympics. I am very pleased that that has the support, I hope, of both sides of parliament.The New South Wales government has announced today that it will meet the other 50 per cent.

The Paralympics budget states that the shortfall will amount to about $50 million, and today's announcement means that the federal government agrees to fund up to $25 million of that shortfall over the next seven years. Both governments are confident that the Paralympics will exceed their relatively modest fundraising targets and we hope, therefore, reduce the final amount to be supplied.

There are still a number of other issues outstanding that need to be resolved. These include things such as the structure of the administration. However, I am sure that this announcement of the funding will ensure a very successful Paralympics, and one we can all be proud of.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer the minister to the letter from her to the New South Wales Minister for Land and Water Conservation dated 31 May and which she tabled, reluctantly, earlier. Is this the letter she referred to yesterday in which she said a list was set out? Is it not true that the letter she tabled has no such list, and that the only letter which does have such a list is the one which she wrote in January to the then New South Wales minister responsible for forests, who replied to her on 8 February? Is it not clear that the minister has misled the House?

—This is very pedantic. Why do those opposite not get on to some of the key issues of the environment? I made it clear yesterday in answer to a question from the honourable member for North Sydney that I had written to the New South Wales government on the issue of the forest strategy. I have made clear today that I have written a number of letters. I have had a response from some people and I have not had a response from others. The basic point is that the issues have still not been resolved. That is the point. The point is that we must resolve the issues of interpretation of the forest strategy.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. Is the minister aware of recent press reports commenting on the improvement in business conditions for Australian industry? Secondly, would the minister inform the House of the performance of Australian manufacturing industry?

—I thank the honourable member for his question and note his strong interest as chairman of the industry committee in relation to these issues. Preconditions for a sufficiently high level of business confidence include outcomes such as historically low interest rates, low labour costs by international comparison, historically low levels of inflation, a very competitive taxation and investment regime, industrial relations harmony, and so on. But these are only preconditions. Business confidence, as all members of the House would concede, can be a very elusive thing. We have seen in the last little while, however—and there is no doubt as we have seen this evidenced in a whole range of surveys and by a range of official statistics and increasingly by anecdotal evidence, of which I am sure all members of this House would be aware—a clear increase in the levels of business confidence in this country.

PARA.TAB: Only yesterday the New South Wales Chamber of Manufactures quarterly survey of business conditions reinforced that improvement in business confidence. Some key results of that survey were that production orders and sale indices are positive and are expected to increase in the December quarter, and that firms have been consistently updating their equipment over the last couple of years and are well placed to utilise spare capacity to meet the expected upturn. Indeed, the chamber's executive director, Mr Phillip Holt, yesterday told ABC radio, `The survey is certainly showing greater confidence'.

As I said, confidence can be a fragile thing. We have seen in the last little while an increasing recognition in the business community that the tactics of the opposition are detrimental or inimical to an increase in business confidence. Why is business confidence important? Obviously it is important because it is a precondition to the increased levels of investment that we will need to see that will ensure a continued growth in our jobs market.

We are seeing from the opposition—which is not so much an opposition in this context; it is more a crew from Romper Stomper—in its approach to the constitutional and parliamentary arrangements in this place, an attempt to destabilise the parliamentary process and the government's budget. The Prime Minister has indicated the role of the Leader of the Opposition in this approach. My image of the Leader of the Opposition is that he has the two Greens out in front of him as a human shield on these issues. He is lurking in the background with a big lump of four-by-two with a nail through it. He is not out in the community admitting to the Australian people that his behaviour is in such stark contrast to the way that he described himself and his role in Australian politics. This bloke is not the Leader of the Opposition—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister will restrain himself and come back to the substance of the question.
—I raise a point of order. The minister made reference to the Leader of the Opposition in a way that I took exception to. He should withdraw it.
—I was listening very carefully because I, too, was concerned at the direction in which the minister's comments were going. I have asked him to return to the question, and he will.

—In conclusion, let me make the observation that it is beyond doubt that there is an improvement in the level of business confidence in this country; that in any country business confidence from time to time is a fragile thing; there is a clear link between levels of business confidence, investment and employment creation in this country; and the opposition's behaviour—and most particularly the behaviour of this so-called leader on the other side of the House, a leader who—
—I invite the minister to wind up.
—who made a record for himself indicating that he was not a politician, but one who indulges in grubby behaviour that ought to be stopped.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr Speaker, my question to you concerns whether the House of Representatives Practice as edited by Browning, in relation to pages 572-574, namely the content of Hansard still applies—whether the reproduction in Hansard of what members have said still applies. If not, could you please give this House some guidelines on what variations you have authorised?
—Are there specific instances to which the honourable member is referring?
—There are, Mr Speaker, but I think perhaps you need to have a look at those pages, pages 572-574, and give us some guidance.
—I will undertake to have a look at it, and I will get back to the honourable member shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table report No. 65 of the Law Reform Commission and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee—Collective investment: other people's money. This report completes the terms of reference given to the review by my predecessor, the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy), in May 1991. An earlier report concentrating on superannuation funds was published in April 1992. That report made a significant contribution to the government's proposals for the regulation of the superannuation industry.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity to thank the members of the review for their work in the preparation of the report. The report provides a comprehensive blueprint for the regulation of the collective investments industry. That industry has attracted, and will continue to attract, a substantial proportion of Australian household and corporate investments. Investments in unit trusts alone grew from $2 billion in 1980 to over $38 billion in 1992. The collective investments industry is rivalling the banking industry as the place where Australians want to invest.

The importance of the collective investments industry in the Australian economy underscores the need for an effective and efficient regulatory regime which both encourages business activity and ensures that investors are adequately protected. The recent Fitzgerald report highlighted Australia's national savings challenge. The collective investments industry will play a key role in meeting that challenge. But it will reach its full potential only under an effective and efficient regulatory regime that strikes the right balance between the efficient fundraising for business and providing effective protection for investors.

The recommendations of the review question the continued relevance of some of the existing features of the current regulation of prescribed interest schemes. The principal recommendation of the review is that each collective investment scheme should have a `responsible entity' which would be solely responsible to investors for the conduct of the scheme. This was seen by the review as necessary to remove the doubts and uncertainties that currently exist.

The review's recommendations include the removal of the current requirement for a collective investment scheme to have both a manager and an independent trustee, and the introduction of specific rules for the buyback of investment units held in collective investment schemes. The review recommends that responsibility for schemes should vest in the scheme operator which must establish appropriate compliance measures. Those measures could include the appointment of a third party to hold scheme assets or to assist with scheme management.

Other major recommendations to enhance regulation of collective investment schemes include: the introduction of a licensing regime for operators; increasing the level of disclosure to investors; increasing the obligations of intermediaries that advise investors; and increasing the powers of the Australian Securities Commission.

The government will carefully consider the views of all interested parties on the recommendations. Efficiency and investor protection must be fundamental to any changes to the system of regulation for collective investment schemes and I still have an open mind on how best to achieve those two goals.

The government will be placing a high priority on the development of an appropriate regulatory regime which takes account of the increasing importance of collective investments as vehicles for household savings and retirement incomes. The recommendations deal with issues which are fundamental to government policies on retirement incomes and securities market regulation. The government response will be made only after detailed consideration and further consultation with key industry groups.

In closing, I also want to emphasise from the outset that any changes to the law resulting from that consideration and consultation will have only a prospective application. I commend the report to the House and present the following paper:
Collective Investments Industry—Ministerial Statement, 30 September 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House take note of the papers.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The opposition welcomes the report of the Law Reform Commission and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee, entitled Collective investment schemes: other people's money. Collective investments include unit trusts, cash management trusts, equity trusts, property trusts and what are known as enterprise schemes, whereby investors pool funds to purchase various assets for one reason or another—maybe a racehorse, or a holiday home which they share on a time basis.

PARA.TAB: As the report of the Law Reform Commission and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee notes, these investments have been particularly popular over recent years. Investments in unit trusts alone grew from less than $2 billion in 1980 to over $38 billion in 1992. The report notes, however, that in relation to such investment schemes we are dealing with three different kinds of risks; that is the investment or market risk, the risk that the investment will decline in value; the institutional risk, the risk that the institution which operates the scheme will collapse; and the compliance risk, the risk that managers and others associated with the schemes will not follow the rules that are set out.

In relation to investment or market risk, although we would like all investors to share profits at all times, it is not something that can be fully dealt with by regulation. If regulation were to rule out the possibility of a loss on an investment, the probabilities are that it would rule out the possibility of a profit too. Investors in collective schemes, like investors in other sorts of schemes, must always take that investment risk. In relation to institutional risk, anybody who takes money from the public, invests it and undertakes obligations to investors should have some capital adequacy behind them—an adequacy that will provide for those who have rights or remedies the opportunity to enforce them.

The report recommends five per cent of total assets under management as a capital adequacy in relation to such schemes. Interestingly, it does not recommend a minimum liquidity requirement for any of the schemes. That, no doubt, will be something that the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) will closely look at. The third area of risk is the compliance risk. Compliance with regulations is designed to prevent investors losing money but, on some occasions, particularly in relation to this industry, compliance with the regulator's rules actually exposed investors. This industry is a classic case of where government regulation actually increased risk for those who are investing in these sorts of products.

Government regulation required managers to buy from unit holders their interests upon request. This contributed to problems in unlisted property trusts which led to the government freezing redemptions in 1991. Property trusts were investing long in property but were required by regulation to borrow short and to undertake to buy back unit holders upon request when they so sought it. Having invested long, they were unable to buy back short when they were requested to do so in large volumes. This led to a run on some of those trusts in the eventual freezing.

It is important, therefore, not to just regulate but to regulate in the right way, because regulation can, in some cases, increase risk. The report recommends that existing statutory buyback obligations should be repealed. The controversial part of the report, I suspect, will be dealing with the way in which collective investments are managed in the future. At present, we have managers who are required to hold securities dealers licences which establish, promote and operate collective investments and also trustees who must be approved by the Australian Securities Commission. Trustees under trustees law are required to look after the interests of the beneficiaries or the unit holders. They are there not so much to worry about the investment and the maximisation of profits but to worry about the safety of those who have invested their money and who are beneficiaries.

The report notes that this split of responsibilities has led, in some cases, to a confusion of roles. It is not entirely clear in each circumstance how the two powers interrelate. There may be circumstances where that confusion has undermined protection for beneficiaries. The answer to that may well be to make it clear what the different roles are, to separate them and to give clear guidance as to the way in which they would be exercised.

It is not automatically apparent that if protection has not been sufficient with the two functions being performed separately it will necessarily be better if it is performed by only one. The report recommends one entity, a scheme operator, responsible for all aspects of the scheme's compliance. There may well be a confusion of roles if the one organisation, the scheme operator, is required, on the one hand, to maximise profit for the investors but, on the other hand, to ensure that they are properly protected in relation to their legal rights.

The report that was brought down by the Law Reform Commission and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee obviously came to the conclusion that one entity would be better. But this, no doubt, will be hotly contested, particularly by those who are in the trustee industry. I note that the Attorney-General has undertaken to consult. We welcome that. We believe that he should be consulting very thoroughly indeed with those who are in the trustee industry.

For our own part, we think that there may well be something in having two entities with distinct roles, but we are also open to persuasion on that particular issue. The coalition will be taking extensive advice on that particular matter and will be discussing the matter with the trustee industry before coming to a final conclusion.

In conclusion, nothing is more important for people who are investing than to know that they are being protected against fraud or illegality, and to know that subject to investment risk their assets will be properly managed. If we as a country want to boost savings by encouraging people to set aside money it is of the utmost importance that a scheme be established that protects those people against the sharks and against unnecessary risk, so that they can go about investing in their own future and the future of the nation in a way which is reliable.
