TALK.START.PARA: —I think that now more than at any time in recent years the Australian community wants economic and community growth, but it wants growth with stability. We now have growth after coming out of a severe recession. The standards for measuring growth have been very clearly outlined and, by international standards, ours is quite consistently high. We are above the OECD average. Growth in Australia is expected to be 2.9 per cent in 1993 and 3.1 per cent in 1994, compared with the OECD average of 1.2 per cent for 1993 and 2.7 per cent for 1994.

PARA.TAB: In some respects, unfortunately, we do not have the incredibly rapid rate of growth of some of our neighbours to the north—the Asian tigers as they are often termed—but, of course, there are reasons for that. By the same token, very few of those countries have anything like the social systems of protection for their communities that we in Australia have. It will probably be many years before even the most powerful countries can achieve that.

Employment in Australia is expected to grow by about 0.7 per cent in 1993 and 1.4 per cent in 1994 while the labour market in the OECD, which consists essentially of non-Asian countries, is expected to experience a further decline in 1993 of 0.1 per cent before returning to slow growth in 1994 of 0.9 per cent. Conditions in Europe will be weaker than in the rest of the OECD, while the USA and Japan are in fact expected to consolidate growth in 1993 and improve further in 1994. Among the major OECD countries, Canada, the United States, Japan and Australia are expected to record the best output in employment growth in the next two years.

We are all searching for solutions. We are all searching for the reasons why our economies, and the world economy, are in a relatively precarious or, certainly for many people, a dangerous state. I do not think we have to look too far outside Australia to see some of the reasons. I believe that the changes in eastern Europe have added dramatically to the inability of governments of the world to respond effectively to that which would have been dealt with almost by the economic cycle that seems to come around every seven to 10 years.

The impact of the decline of the Soviet Union and the Eastern bloc powers has had a number of effects. It has affected defence spending, and that is obviously a good thing. The peace dividend is often talked about. We have seen some of the outcomes of that in this budget. But on a world scale it has created many problems in countries that we trade with. The decline in defence spending has had an impact on local communities and on defence procurement and production. Anyone who has been to Europe would have seen the power of the armies of Europe, whether it be Warsaw Pact or NATO forces. All those things have had drastic effects on a number of the major economies that we trade with.Obviously, in the long term, that will be incredibly beneficial on a scale the world has not yet seen or recognised, but at this stage I believe it is having a major effect on world demand and employment.

Of course, our trade is affected. By the same token, there is a problem for many countries in eastern Europe in that there is now a vastly increased labour market or world labour force due to the breaking down of the Iron Curtain boundaries. That is having an effect in western Europe, creating a great surplus of labour. Whole new labour markets are opening up which will have an impact on us.

In Australia we are looking for growth. As I have already indicated, we are well on target. We are likely to reach growth and surpass the average of other countries that we generally compare ourselves with. We need growth with stability, because what is clearly affecting us more than anything else at the moment—particularly in this period of the economic cycle—is the need for economic confidence and confidence in our country.

The instability created by the opposition in this House and in the other house regarding the passage of this budget is doing this country immense damage. Members of the opposition now have the opportunity to signal very clearly to the other house and to all Australians that they accept that they lost the 1993 election. I understand that it would be very hard for them to accept that because they really believed, as did many others, that they had it won.

In March this year the Australian people very firmly rejected their policies for very good reasons. They rejected the GST, the changes that were being proposed to Medicare, the industrial relations policies—in fact, they rejected Fightback in toto. The Australian people said no because they wanted stability. They did not want the disruption that would result from the types of policies that the opposition would put forward.

It was not, as has been spread by some of the opposition's apologists, as a result of fear campaigns; it was because people did not want that sort of instability. They did not want the sorts of changes they were told about at that time pushed upon them, let alone the ones that they were not told about. That is something that the opposition has to come to terms with. I do not believe it has come to terms with it. We only have to see the fits of pique from the opposition that go on in this place and that are reported in the media from time to time, particularly regarding the issues surrounding the tax bills, wholesale tax and indirect taxes. If it were just their egos that would be their problem. But the problem is that it is having a very great destabilising effect on our national confidence and our economic confidence, which is being reflected in many ways on a day-to-day basis, often on an hour-by-hour basis, particularly in relation to the situation pertaining to the Australian dollar.

Members of the Liberal and National parties are not the only ones who should bear the blame. The Greens in the other place have to look seriously at what they want to achieve and at what they are now imposing on the Australian economy and the Australian people, despite what they say.

If this issue is not resolved very quickly by these two people, as well as the leadership that should be shown by the opposition, then this country will not only be inhibited and restricted in the way in which it can resolve its economic problems; it will also be restricted in the way in which it is able to take advantage of the opportunities presented to it domestically and in the Asia-Pacific region. More and more people are becoming aware of the importance of that region.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has spoken about the Asia-Pacific region and APEC, and we have seen support for the Prime Minister coming from the President of the United States in the last week or so. We are beginning to understand far better our place in the world. For once in our history we are geographically located in the best place. The Olympic Games in the year 2000 and all that entails will have a potential, positive impact, despite the kerfuffle that the opposition would like to make from time to time regarding the flag and other relatively peripheral issues. We have an opportunity which we must grasp now. We must take the opportunity to capitalise on the confidence and the position of this country and do something about Australia's biggest problem, that of unemployment.

I am not particularly happy with some elements in this budget, most of which have been addressed. It is understood by members of any political party that, in any government budget, document or policy direction, you win some and lose some. But, when the decision has been made, you get on with the job. Nothing that I or other people in the community might be concerned about in this budget compares in any way whatsoever with what the opposition would have dished up had it been on this side of the House at this time.

The opposition can take no succour from any events which may have occurred in our party room over the last few weeks. What has transpired in our party room is a sign of strength, not weakness. It is a sign of vibrancy and vitality and not decay, which is symptomatic of those opposite. The opposition in this country is effectively in decay. It has no identity as a party and, after the last election, it has no policies left. The opposition is unsure of where to go. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) is obviously a lame duck, a temporary leader. He is a caretaker because the opposition cannot work out its identity and where it is going. In fact, the opposition has no principles—it has not even been able to define the principles that would take it into an election.

While the opposition may derive some succour from what the opinion polls indicate at the moment, the reality is that if an election were held tomorrow, because the people of Australia want growth, stability and confidence in their government, they would not be prepared to support or in any way entertain an opposition—or an opposition leader—which has not been able to articulate clearly the policies the people want. The government is having problems dealing with the opposition over the budget both here and in the other place. My advice to the opposition is to put the election behind it. The electorate will see it in a better light if it does that. The opposition has to come to terms with that, go out and develop policy, work out what it is really about and make itself relevant because people will not vote for any party unless it is relevant to their needs.

In this budget people have seen a response—despite what they may have felt about a number of decisions which, mainly, have been revised. If we look through the budget we see that more than 100 election commitments have been honoured—either in this budget, or have been factored into budgets through to 1996-97. Those things that the Australian people wanted from the government at the last election have been provided through well over 100 commitments.

When media commentators—those people on incomes of $1 million a year who have never had to take a tough decision in their lives and who just sit there and pontificate and mouth off editorial opinions every day to millions of Australians—talk about the promises of politicians, let them for once talk about the 100 or so commitments in this budget that were given at the last election and which this government has now put into policy.

Those commitments include: the child-care cash rebate for working parents; reducing the excessive waiting times for elective surgery; the Commonwealth dental program for health card holders; palliative care funding; child-care initiatives for sick children; funding for play groups; national accreditation for child-care centres; extension of long day care child-care assistance fee relief to occasional child care; development and distribution of public patients hospital charter; Medicare rebate for bone densitometry; a catch-up immunisation program against HIB disease for children; dealing with overservicing and fraud in Medicare—now something on which the AMA is prepared to work with the government; expansion in work related child-care places; expansion of the women's health program; simplification of waiting period waiver provisions for social security; increased earned income allowance in income test free areas; earnings credits; reduced assets test withdrawal rate for pensioners; and on it goes. These are the things which mean something to Australians on a day-to-day basis. Australians want a strong health system. They want industrial relations which give them a role in a system in which they can have some security. Australians want growth with stability.

The opposition's attitude to the budget both here and in the other place is adding to this country's debt burden. The more that opposition members by their actions drive the dollar down and inhibit investment and confidence in this country, the more they add to the economic difficulties which we will subsequently have to overcome. If they are really serious, it is no good their coming in here everyday and talking about unemployment and the fact that one million people are unemployed. Those are things that everyone in this House is—and should be, justifiably—extremely concerned about. It is no good their coming in here and talking about it in a fit of pique, because of their dented egos. They all expected to be in the ministerial wing. Opposition members were all cruising around there a couple of days before the election, picking out the offices with the best view. They had organised all that well and truly before time. We saw that shortly afterwards.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—It is no use the honourable member for Bendigo shaking his head; perhaps he was not one of them, but the people on the opposition front bench all had their offices picked out. On Four Corners, I think, a week or so afterwards, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) was shown sitting in the back seat of a white limousine, quite impressed with what was going to happen on the Monday. Of course, that fell through. Those sorts of things are peripheral; but the point is that the opposition has to come to terms with the fact that it is increasing unemployment in this country. It might be a hard thing for it to swallow, but by its actions in this House and the other place, it is in fact increasing unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The government has done a lot to minimise the impact of the recession regarding unemployment, and set Australia up for the growth which is already shown to be higher than in other OECD countries. We have record low inflation—the lowest for 30 years. We have one of the highest growth rate prospects in the OECD, which I have already highlighted. We have record low interest rates. We have a world competitive business tax system, with a fall in the company tax rate from 39c to 33c in the dollar, whereas the opposition would put it up to 42c in the dollar. We have a reduction in personal income taxes, which the opposition is now trying to stymie. We have special incentives to invest. We have industrial stability—again, we have the lowest number of industrial disputes for 30 years. We have improved international competitiveness. We have low levels of public sector debt by any international standard, and high and increasing levels of profit share.

There are new measures in this budget which go to stimulating investment and employment in this country, which the opposition, by its tactics and by its dented egos, is seeking to inhibit. We have new measures which bring forward the tax cuts; a strategy which builds on the savings of the nation; a strategy to reduce the public sector's call on national savings by reducing the budget deficit. Indeed, $94 million is allocated to encourage more small to medium sized firms to commence or intensify exports. I have any number of classic examples of companies that are not McKinsey sized, but at a smaller level, which will be the driving force not only of employment, but of innovation and growth, and which will affect Australia's stance in a very important part of the world.

I believe that the government's white paper on employment will be something which all Australians need to understand and participate in. I commend the work of the caucus committees in terms of employment, and in terms of regional development, where employment really will be the force and where opportunities will exist for creating growth with stability, which the opposition will deny this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to follow the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples) in this appropriation debate because he was talking about jobs and emerging export industries. Those are the very strategies on which the government claimed it was building this budget. I will read briefly from a letter which appeared in my local newspaper, the Bendigo Advertiser, this morning. The letter came from Ethel Watson of Kangaroo Flat, which is a suburb of Bendigo. The letter states:

PARA.TAB: The policies of the Keating Labor Government during the past decade have been a disaster for this country. The mess we find ourselves in now is, of course, in the great tradition of the Master himself!
Here is a short summary of the Keating debacle:

1983 Budget—Keating: "Obviously, the economic policies of the Fraser Government have failed to come to terms with Australia's deep-seated problems; 1983-84 holds promise of considerable improvement". Foreign debt was $23 billion.
1986 Budget—foreign debt spiralled out to $75 billion.
1988 Budget—"The one that brings home the bacon." Foreign debt stood at $92.8 billion.
1990 Budget—Keating: "This year the current account will markedly improve and employment will pick up".

SPEECH.PARA: This is in 1990. We have seen no signs of that employment pick-up. In fact, we have seen a rapid increase in unemployment. The letter continues:
Foreign debt spiralled out to $124 billion.

PARA.TAB: 1993 Budget—Keating: "The Government economic strategy is to accelerate recovery from recession and at the same time build a stronger Australia. It is a four year plan which begins now with an immediate boost to spending and employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, you must remember it is saying that the four-year plan is starting now. Labor has already been in government for over 10 years and it is now starting another four-year plan. The letter goes on:
It ends in 1995-96 with the Budget back in surplus and dramatically reduced marginal income tax rates for most Australians".

PARA.TAB: Foreign debt has now risen to $190 billion with no reduction in sight.

Keating's One Nation statement is now in tatters and all we have heard since the last election is MABO, MABO—nothing about the one million who cannot find a job, my own two sons with university degrees among them!
Labor's record speaks for itself. The spiralling foreign debt is the government's own creation.
One can only hope that as the vast majority of Australians survey the ruins of their economic hopes, they will empty the Parliament of these self-serving parasites at the next Federal election!

SPEECH.PARA: ETHEL WATSON,
Kangaroo Flat.

That says it all. The government claims to have embarked on a strategy for creating jobs; it is all about jobs. But I took the time and trouble to write to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) to find out what the government was going to do about unemployment. The response was quite staggering. In my electorate I have 7,500 people receiving unemployment benefits. The government, through the minister, wrote back and said that it was going to appoint yet another committee to look at unemployment, and that the committee would be set up and come back with a white paper in the first half of 1994. We are talking about a budget which was introduced early in August, and we are now looking at having a white paper prepared by some time in 1994. That means that for at least six months the government will have taken no action at all on unemployment queues. More likely than not, it will be 12 months before we see that white paper and any implementation of any action on unemployment in this country. So we are looking almost at August-September, maybe October-November, of 1994 before we see any action at all on jobs.

PARA.TAB: The Keating government felt that there were opportunities for employment in encouraging emerging export industries. I will tell the House of just one emerging export industry—the wine industry. The wine industry has been developing in Australia over some years, building a solid foundation from which to launch a major export assault into a whole range of countries.It started to get a toehold in the United Kingdom, Europe and the United States. But what did the government do? It decided in this year's budget to increase the tax on wine from 20 per cent to 31 per cent—a 55 per cent increase—on what is one of this nation's emerging export industries.

We have to put that decision in the context of the government's 1993 election promises. The government promised that there would be no GST and more jobs—I can still hear that theme ringing out—but we ended up with wholesale sales tax increases and fewer jobs. There was not even a genuine attempt by the government to address the unemployment situation for at least 12 months. So there has been no attempt at all to address the question of about 11 per cent national unemployment. Certainly the minister for employment has done nothing except appoint another committee which will report back to him with a green paper some time late in 1994. That really is an indictment on this government.

It is no wonder that the backbench members of caucus staged a revolt over this budget because, as we were told, the main focal point of the budget bill was jobs and where those jobs would emerge from. The government said it could do that without increasing taxes and without a GST, but it increased the wholesale sales tax and the result of that will be fewer jobs.

One of Australia's most important export industries is primary production. What did the government do to primary producers? In this budget it increased the excise on petroleum products by a flat 3c a litre from the night of the budget to be followed by an extra 2c a litre in a year's time, applying an additional increase of 1c per litre on leaded fuel, rising 5c a litre in a year's time. The government's response will be that the farmers get a rebate on their diesel fuel, but the government is still not missing out because it has established a rebate administration fee which will raise $10 million purely and simply to administer the rebate scheme.

From figures I have been given I understand that the administration cost of that diesel rebate scheme will be something less than $5 million, so the government will reap a very healthy profit. It will raise $10 million in administration fees from an industry of the very type that it is supposedly encouraging—an export industry—and from people who are producing primary produce for world markets.

All the government has done for the industry is to increase the cost of transport in every form by imposing an increased fuel excise. That increase will flow on to all of the industries that service the rural community and the primary producers in this land. All transport costs will go up and the flow-on effect to the primary industry sector will be enormous. That only serves to make our primary produce less competitive in world markets.

We have some very good markets overseas—or we did have. We are having some battles to retain them now because of the influence of things such as the export enhancement program of the United States. Australia has always produced good clean food at a very competitive price, but the government has now saddled the industry with these increased excises on petroleum products, and that adds a cost to every item of equipment and every service that touches on the rural community.

I mentioned earlier that the back bench and the caucus of the government had had great difficulties with this budget as well. They went back to the electorates, and they heard the same message as I heard, and obviously came across the same feelings as Ethel Watson from Kangaroo Flat has expressed in the Bendigo Advertiser this morning. She recognises the problems that this budget is creating. I do not know how the backbench members of the Labor Party could have gone back and faced their electorates. Obviously they received a tremendous caning in their electorates, because they had to come back here and there was an unholy squabble. The backbench members turned up at the expenditure review committee meeting and they got some minor concessions, but they did not really address the real problems.

The real problems are the one million people who are unemployed in this country, and the encouragement of Australian export industries to enable them to get into a situation where they can compete overseas, because that is where the growth will come from. There has to be encouragement of the private sector, and encouragement of firms who are prepared to have a go on world export markets. They must be encouraged to employ people and push into South-East Asia and other areas where they can get export industries going.

One of the things that came out of the budget was the arrogance and lack of consultation shown by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) towards people in their own party. It is quite obvious from this side of the chamber that there was no consultation with the government's backbench members. The backbench members did not have any input at all into the budget processes. When the budget was released, the backbench members were placed in the very embarrassing situation of having to go back to their electorates and try to explain it.

There is no possible way it could be explained to the wine industry; an industry that is developing rapidly and that has great potential for Australia. The backbench members of the Labor Party obviously were not able to explain the budget to their own constituents, so they had to come back and try to wring out some tiny little concessions. They did not have a great deal of success.

I want to give the House some figures to illustrate how this budget will affect people in my electorate. More than 80 per cent of Bendigo families will be worse off under this budget. The figures produced by the Department of the Treasury—they are not my figures—reveal that a family earning $25,000 a year will be 1.5 per cent worse off, while Australians earning between $45,000 to $60,000 per year are the big winners from this budget. A single person earning $25,000 a year will be 1.1 per cent worse off following the tax increases which the Treasurer announced in the budget. According to the Treasury figures, pensioners and the one million people who are unemployed will be 0.8 per cent worse off.

The budget strikes right at the heart of the Bendigo electorate. The 1991 census statistics reveal that the median family income in the electorate of Bendigo is $27,640 per year. In the Labor held electorate of Canberra the median income is $50,302 per annum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nearly twice as much.

—It is almost twice as much, as the honourable member for Parkes has indicated. The backbench Labor Party members have been told about these problems by their constituencies. Did they get any major concessions out of the government? No, there were no major concessions at all. In the Bendigo region almost 60 per cent of families earn less than $40,000 a year. They are the people who are going to be most severely affected by the budget changes being introduced by this government.

PARA.TAB: That does not include the second stage of the sales tax rises due on 1 July 1995. That will include increases in the sales tax on bed linen, furniture, floor coverings, flavoured milk, biscuits, ice-cream, confectionary, bathroom fittings, water heaters, matches and sanitary ware. They will all come in on 1 July 1995. After seeing this budget, we decided that we should oppose four important measures.

The first tax measure that we are opposing is the retrospective increase in tax on unused accrued annual leave. I bet my bottom dollar that Labor Party members cop plenty of flak over that. Yet the government is still not backing away from it. The second is the increase in wholesale sales taxes. We see it as being to the detriment of the economic recovery of Australia. It is a massive increase in wholesale sales tax over a range of hundreds, maybe thousands, of products, as proposed in the measures outlined by the government.

The third measure is the increase in the tax on wine. The Australian wine industry is emerging as a very good export dollar earner and should be encouraged. The fourth decision was to oppose the increase in tax on petrol, diesel and other fuels, as that affects another very substantial export earner in the primary industry sector. The flow-on impact from that on the whole transport industry would act against the best interests of exporters.

We have noticed that the government is trying to shy away from its terrible budget and push the blame for it onto the coalition and other parties. The government is bogged down by the most dreadful decisions that it has taken as a result of these budget measures. Members on the Labor side of the House must have great difficulty in explaining to their constituents—particularly people who are still driving vehicles that use leaded fuel and people in the transport industry who are transporting goods from one part of the country to another—how they could agree to impose that increased excise on fuel. It is fine for people to talk about the replacement of vehicles that use leaded fuel, but that is well beyond many people. They cannot find the $10,000 or $15,000 necessary to change that vehicle over and they are really feeling the effects of this budget.

In summary, it is a mean, arrogant budget. It is arrogant in the fact that it did not even consult its own people or give any consideration to low income earners. It does nothing for jobs—yet that is what the strategy was said to be all about—and it does very little for emerging export industries. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall The Hon R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is reaping a bitter harvest of its own making because it has failed in reform. It is loading a traditional, old-style means of collecting money in this budget with all the exigencies and demands of a society that has moved on since the government has been in office. We can look back to the real problem of this administration, which rests with the failure of the then Treasurer, now the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), to carry his reforms—in regard to a general GST—in the early days of the Hawke administration. With that failure, the government has been left with an old-fashioned budget structure.

PARA.TAB: It is trying to meet the demands of controlling a growing deficit and is paying for its tax cuts by loading expenditures in the community with increased budget charges. So instead of helping members of the community, it is depriving them of further productive capacity by raising costs. Its problems with the Senate are of its own making. It was adequately warned, when it reformed the method of electing senators, of what the consequences would be for the government of the day. When it raised the numbers in the Senate from 10 to 12, it created an election for even numbers in the Senate. It consolidated the inevitability that the government of the day would not carry the numbers or have a majority to approve its programs in the Senate.

So the government is a victim of its own stupidity and its past failure to manage, firstly, the financial affairs of the community and, secondly, the means of election to the Senate. Who would have sympathy for it? The problem is that it is the community that has suffered as the government has moved its reforms—as far as they went in the 1980s—to get alongside the great names of the developers of this community who have played such a significant part in the subsequent crash of the economy. In this sense, the world has imploded on this government—and the opinion polls have showed how much it is rejected by people in every state of the Commonwealth.

I would like to speak about my own state of South Australia which, too, is going through an enormous amount of suffering because of the failure of the state Labor government to manage its affairs. The biggest question facing Premier Arnold in South Australia, it would seem, is when should he fix the election date to maximise his possibility of return? When the election will be called interests members of the South Australian public. They want it to occur at the earliest possible time. We are watching this fiasco of a premier, transfixed by the failure of his own actions, trying to run from the consequences of the ballot box.

He said magnanimously—I do not think—that he will have an election at the end of this year or early next year. He is trying to get away from the point that his four years are up in November. Clearly he is thinking of running into his fifth year, despite the failures of Labor in South Australia. How dare he run from the judgment of the people and into his fifth year. How dare he consider it.

Only yesterday, the state Leader of the Opposition drew the attention of the South Australian community to the fact that the whole of the ministry would benefit personally on a grand scale in increased salaries and superannuation by staying on for another four or five months. Is this to be the measure of Premier Arnold's attention to the problems of my state? I hope he is cornered and will be deterred from such a fatal mistake for him and such a damaging course for the South Australian economy.

We can never forget the failure of the state Labor government to manage the affairs of the State Bank. A lot has been written about this since the revelations were made. That judgment is in print; and word goes on. I quote from the September Adelaide Review about the present government's attitude. The excerpt stated:
The concept—

SPEECH.PARA: as far as the Arnold government is concerned—
is the "year zero".

PARA.TAB: For the Arnold camp, history began on the first day of Spring 1992 when Mr Bannon belatedly made way for Mr Arnold. The minders will discuss, debate and defend only what has happened in the past twelve months . . . the political pragmatist of the nineties who hopes that launching a submarine will win him a few votes. The election version of Mr Arnold's biography would have him doing nothing in between—that's easier than explaining his role in the Marineland fiasco, the A.D. Little report's indictment of his term as Industry Minister and exactly what he was doing as a senior member of cabinet while the government's economy strategy was falling apart despite cries of warning from the opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Peter Ward, a highly regarded writer in South Australia, recently published an article under the heading `Bonfire of the Vanities'. His original article states:

PARA.TAB: By State per capita, the debacle is the largest in Australian banking history. When the Victorian State Bank went down in 1990, crippled by an estimated $3 billion loss and the collapse of its Tricontinental finance arm, the cost was in the order of $907 for every Victorian. In South Australia, the State Bank's $3.15 billion shortfall is $2085 a head.

SPEECH.PARA: The question was posed: why did this occur? The public and all of us want to know why. I refer to an article about the deal of the Remm project in Rundle Street in Adelaide, where finance of $550 million went into a now drastically revalued property deal. It states:

PARA.TAB: About this deal and Bannon's participation the royal commission was particularly crisp. "The treasurer, still living in splendid indifference to other evidence that the bank's commercial judgment was questionable and very likely flawed, himself put the final and vital seal on the financial package by authorising and approving the participation of SAFA" . . .

SPEECH.PARA: But after all these problems, and after the bank was revealed for what it was—the adventurous piratical organisation—an article states:
John Bannon went to a party. It was held on the Friday after Black Sunday—
after the revelations—
on the 6th floor of the QBE Building in downtown King William Street, Adelaide, where the State Treasury has its headquarters.

PARA.TAB: The host was the under-treasurer, Peter Emery, and 230 of South Australia's top mandarins attended, including those who had burned the midnight oil putting together the rescue package for the bank.

And so it was in the outer court of premier and treasurer John Bannon in February 1991, as 230 of the State's most distinguished Public Servants watched and sang and looked on the brighter side of the life, and laughed and laughed until they almost cried.

SPEECH.PARA: They had a magnificent party after the news was broken about the bank. The Treasury has been mentioned. It has not been mentioned enough. We know of the deficiencies of ex-Premier Bannon, his total incapacity to grasp the situation and to manage. We know of current Premier Arnold's participation as a full-blown cabinet minister right throughout this failure to manage, and we also know of the enormous time put in by the royal commission and by the Auditor-General to find out, at the cost of many of millions of dollars, what went wrong.

PARA.TAB: I believe the blame has been fairly sheeted home, as far it ought to, to the government, but not enough has been said about Treasury. How on earth could it be that the Treasury of a state was so out of touch with the financial management of the great arm of the State Bank of South Australia as not to know that it was in trouble? Let me say, its ignorance smacks of incompetence on a grand scale.

Those of us who have been in state administration in past years know of the diligence of the state Treasury. In the 1960s, the 1970s and before, the state Treasury in South Australia held the supreme position in regard to integrity among all of the state treasuries of Australia. Yet, in the latter 1980s and in the early 1990s, the state Treasury was ignorant of the depletion of the prospects of the State Bank. It did not know what was going on and, if it did, it would be utterly culpable in not making sure that the premier of the day knew about it.

The state Treasury, through all of this grand debacle and disaster, which has struck my state and which will inhibit its capacity to develop for years to come, was culpable in some way of negligence on a grand scale of not knowing what was happening to the greatest financial institution in my state. I hope that the incoming government will get to the bottom, not now by pursuing further the subjects of the royal commission, but by examining state Treasury to find the fault and root it out, because my state can never again withstand the negligence of state Treasury as it has experienced it in the past several years.

This state government, of course, is not only deficient in South Australia in relation to the State Bank—that would overshadow almost every other deficiency—but it is irresponsible also on a very wide front. Right now it is involved in giving jobs to the boys before its defeat. One in particular which is very aggravating to South Australian electors is the support for Mr Bruce Guerin to be head of a new department at Flinders University. An article in the Adelaide Advertiser states:

University Vice-Chancellor Professor John Lovering rejected yesterday claims the former head of the Department of Premier and Cabinet, Mr Bruce Guerin, was being put "out of the way" in his appointment as the head of the institute.
Professor Lovering said the institute was planned as a world-class training facility for public servants and service sector organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the record of Mr Guerin? He was head of the Premier's department and chief adviser to the government through all of the failure of the State Bank. After the State Bank failed, and the board and the managers fell around, Mr Guerin jumped ship, and where did he go? He went to be the chief executive of the multi-function polis of which, I must say, I have always been a strong supporter. Now it is a matter of salvaging something from the wreckage, but Mr Guerin went and spent a year or so at the MFP and a new head of the MFP was appointed back mid-year. What did he say about what he found. An article from the Adelaide Advertiser states:

PARA.TAB: The new head of Adelaide's proposed multi-function polis has condemned the project's past direction and foreshadowed a dramatic shift in its future.
Mr Ross Kennan admitted yesterday he was "absolutely dismayed" by what he found when he took up his $300,000-a-year appointment as chief executive officer on June 1.
Breaking his self-imposed three-month media silence after sizing up this task, Mr Kennan described some earlier MFP-inspired proposals as "in a word, desperate".
"There was so much ethereal thinking . . . God, bloody poppycock", he said.

SPEECH.PARA: So the man who went through as the chief adviser to the Premier when the State Bank collapsed left the MFP in that state. The state government is now providing for a large segment of his salary, to put him in charge of a department to teach public servants how to plan and others how to run industry and business. What are we to think of all this? It begs imagination. There will be a time to pay for all of this, and it will be at the state election.

PARA.TAB: I just want to mention in my last segment today the matter of ambit claims, which again has a strong connection with the Labor governments. It is part of the administration of Labor that it supports this form of extortion in the community of pervading fear within small industries. One of my constituent industries has written to me and has included this ambit claim. It has asked me of course not to reveal its name because it fears reprisal. It gives very good reason in its letter as to why it should fear reprisal, and I will observe its claim to anonymity on this question.

Are we living in a sane society when law makers will allow this sort of claim to be made? Are we a sane society if we allow this form of extortion and fear? I went through this claim briefly without analysing all the bits and pieces. It is a claim by the Construction Forestry Mining Energy Union against a small industry, entitled `Letter of Demand'. It ends its preamble by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: We shall be glad to have your answer within seven (7) days from the date hereof, as failing adoption of the log of claims within this time, this Union will apply in accordance with the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act 1988, to obtain an Award under the said Act in settlement of the industrial dispute existing or probable between you and the said Union in regard to matters referred to in the said log.
Despite the ridiculous aspect of the demand, the industry imposed upon must answer under the act or else it will be involved in a dispute. Of course, the whole objective is to establish a dispute.

PARA.TAB: One of the ironies of the claim is that there are hardly enough working days in the year to provide for the holidays it seeks. The claim seeks to establish a 30-hour week and holidays adding up to 21 weeks a year. Per year there are six weeks annual leave; four weeks public holidays; two weeks sick leave; two weeks compassionate leave; two weeks first aid study; two weeks school requirements; and three weeks annual service leave. That adds up to 21 weeks. There is, however, a way to get around that because, under this claim, union delegates can take 40 hours a week off from their 30-hour working week—and be paid for it! There is no limit.

This little industry in my district, operating in these very difficult economic times, has opened its mail and suddenly found this letter of demand, sanctioned in some form by the arbitration act. It would be nice to whiz it away, but it cannot. It is hooked. It ought to be a criminal offence to send this rubbish to people in a day and age when we are supposed to act intelligently in these matters. But under this claim the union is asking for all sorts of ridiculous things—two years paid maternity leave, 60 minutes washing time per day out of a six-hour day, $2,000 a week and, to top it all off, 100 per cent of the profits.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you and I are sane enough to know what nonsense that is, but why do we as a parliament allow it to happen? Are we not out to help industry? Are we not out to say to people that they can have jobs? This claim is starting a process that would take jobs away. Even a small portion of that claim, if successful, would diminish jobs in Australia, yet it is sanctioned by those opposite, those great brilliant administrators!

As I said when I began this speech, the government has talked and reformed itself into the greatest mess that a government has been in for a couple of decades. It reformed the Senate so that the Senate would be against it—and we told those opposite that that would happen. They just thumbed their noses at us and look what they have now. It serves them right.

The government's then Treasurer, now Prime Minister, tried to reform the taxation system of Australia to provide an equitable base that would have got it out of the hole it is in today, but it knocked him back. It serves the government right. The trouble is that it does not serve the Australian people right. They are the victims of this nonsense.

Members of the government have come out of the 1980s alongside the Bonds and the Skases—people that many of them personally assisted in their depredations—and, unfortunately for the rest of Australia, they are now paying for that policy. My state of South Australia has had a double whammy with Arnold and Keating. We can get away from Arnold shortly, and the sooner we can get away from those opposite the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Mr H.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the previous speaker, the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), of the praise lavished on Skase and Bond by the opposition's present leader. There was no greater supporter of those people than the Liberal Party and its present leader.

PARA.TAB: In the six weeks since the budget was delivered we have seen many opposition members standing up in their benches, crying crocodile tears and bemoaning the revenue raising measures of the budget. Their mock concern allegedly stems from a heartfelt feeling for the less well off in society. But when I look across at those benches, I see exactly the same faces that I saw prior to the last election, maybe just a few less. They are the same faces, the same people who went out into their electorates day after day to champion the cause for the single most regressive and repugnant set of policies ever adopted by any Australian political party, namely Fightback.

That policy document was soundly rejected by the Australian electorate as a cynical exercise. It was designed to squeeze the unemployed, the low income earners, women, pensioners and middle Australia with a $28 billion goods and services tax. It was a policy that would dismantle Medicare, bring in draconian industrial relations legislation and force the unemployed to become cheap labour fodder for the body hire agents. It all sounds a bit rich when they now strut and swagger with bleeding hearts, drawing attention to the plight of the less well off in society.

It appears that all their secret sessions with senators Chamarette and Margetts are having a profound change on their consciousness. I do not pretend that there were no unpalatable aspects to the budget when it was first handed down. Clearly there were. Perhaps the words spoken the other day, that good budgets are not always popular, are true.

The government has addressed the concerns of the removal of optometrical services from Medicare, taxation on untaken long service leave and a rise in excise levels in unleaded petrol. Since those changes were made I have not had any complaints in my office about the focus or the strategy of the budget. So when honourable members opposite come in here saying that they are acting on a call from the community to block aspects of the budget, I really think they are carrying on with a lot of humbug.

The budget is a budget of balance. It is a budget which recognises the difficult financial position of a small trading nation like Australia when dealing with a flat world economy, an economy corrupted by the practices of some of our closest trading nations. The priority of this budget is firmly focused on creating employment, reducing the deficit and establishing a sound economic basis for sustainable growth through the 1990s. The budget provides substantial support for business investment through investment allowances, lowering the company tax rate from 39c in the dollar to 33c and extending the depreciation and development allowances announced in the One Nation package.

This will provide a healthy climate for investment confidence, business growth and employment opportunities. These measures should result in an increase in business investment of close to 11 per cent, with an employment increase of about 100,000 in the coming year. Next year the employment growth is forecast at 2 1/2 per cent and the following year, 1994-95, it is forecast to be 2 3/4 per cent.

Expansion of labour market programs means that an extra 66,000 people in 1993-94 will gain vital assistance to enter the work force. There is a $6 a fortnight increase in the unemployment allowance from next March, and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has indicated that a further $6 rise on top of the normal CPI increase could be a priority for next year's budget.

We have relaxed the income test for unemployed people so that they can earn a higher supporting income without having their benefits impaired, and we have eased the waiting period for people who are employed for only a short time and who may become unemployed again. The government is also providing pension-type benefits for unemployed people over 60 years of age in recognition of the difficulty that this group faces in getting full-time employment. These initiatives demonstrate that this government has a real concern for the unemployed and will not let them fall by the wayside to become a mass underclass, as proposed by the coalition's social welfare policies.

At the other end of the scale we are providing significant improvements in child care. Over the life of this government we have increased the number of child-care places from 46,000 to more than 200,000, with an increase in the expenditure commitment from $65 million to $640 million. The government has made a commitment to fully meet the demand for work related child care by the year 2001 with an interim target of 300,000 places by 1996-97. This budget provides funding for an estimated 29,000 additional places in 1993-94.

The budget has committed increased funding for regional tourism, backpacker tourism, ecotourism, flood mitigation, land care and the development of alternative energy and support measures for our primary industries. We are providing dental care for all pensioners, and extending to them the full range of fringe benefits. They are all progressive measures in line with the government's commitment to social justice policy.

This budget will deliver on the government's promise to provide tax relief for middle income earners with $300 million worth of income tax cuts for Australia's taxpayers before Christmas. For individual taxpayers these measures mean that someone on $520 a week will get $32 before Christmas; someone on $610 a week will get $55 and someone on $710 a week will get $91 before Christmas.

What do we see from the opposition on these issues? We see absolute intransigence, absolute contempt for the average families of Australia and absolute contempt for the wellbeing of the Australian economy. It is what we have come to expect from the opposition under the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). He has no interest in people, but only an interest in playing those low political games, regardless of whom it hurts or how much damage it does to the Australian economy. I know what the result of budget intransigence from the opposition could mean, and we have heard this from the Governor of the Reserve Bank; it could mean a lower dollar and higher interest rates, interest rate increases that would be a much bigger blow to the battlers of the country and to business in the country than any of the revenue raising measures in the budget.

We can see that the Leader of the Opposition and his cohorts in the Senate do not care about the economy. They do not care about interest rates, the possibility of those rates rising, and they do not care about the low income earners who would be affected by those rises. They do not care that the tax cuts would be delayed. The Leader of the Opposition cares only about his own political game to shore up what is a very shaky leadership.

As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) rightly pointed out in question time yesterday and on Tuesday, some of the luminary figures to the coalition, such as the President of the National Farmers Federation and even a former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, have highlighted the folly of the current opposition position. What they said amounted to a veiled warning: `If you do not pass the budget bills you will be facing retribution from the electorate, that same retribution you have felt many times over recent years'.
On 19 August in this House the Leader of the Opposition said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are concerned to raise parliamentary standards . . . We want to make sure that this parliament does perform the role it should perform—

The Leader of the Opposition has reached a new depth in hypocrisy by threatening the legitimate mandate of this democratically elected government to formulate a budget. Has he considered that one of the primary functions of this parliament is to pass budget legislation in the best interests of the Australian economy?

PARA.TAB: Extraordinarily, now it seems we have the opposition consorting in a dangerous alliance with the Greens of Western Australia to destabilise the political process. The Western Australian Green senators are now embroiled in what appears to be a conspiracy with the conservatives—the same people who would mine Coronation Hill, who would dam the Franklin, fast-track 13 new uranium mines, five pulp mills, three rare earth plants and the Cape York space station, and throw out environmental controls in the process. It is coalition policy to support the setting up of a domestic private nuclear power industry.

It is astonishing that people, particularly the constituency of the Greens, are copping the tripe that the conservatives are handing out to those Green senators. Has anyone heard anything from those Green senators about land care, forest issues, water quality and the protection of endangered flora and fauna? Why do the Greens not recognise these issues? Why are they so small-thinking that they see so narrowly that they can only use their balance of power to become lackeys of the conservatives? Instead, they are talking on the issues that the conservatives find political advantage in: obstructing and vandalising national consensus by wreaking havoc on the economy.

Why are the Greens joining the conservatives in opposition to wholesale sales tax rises, the tax on accrued leave and rises in sales tax, and ignoring the opportunity to install an environmental agenda in partnership with the government? Is it that they are simply so naive that they are unable to see that some of the smarties on the other side, such as the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), known as Ironbar, are simply using them up? Are the Greens also going to take advice from the honourable member for O'Connor on Mabo and on social justice issues?

Are the Greens getting any undertakings on environmental issues from the other side? I think not. Even so, they would be fools to believe them, given the record of the other side. Rather, I believe there is a sinister influence on the Western Australian Greens to run a conservative platform and not to seize genuine opportunities that the government can offer. Sooner or later the grassroots support will see through this. Many on the other side of this House believe, incorrectly, that protection of the environment is anathema to economic prosperity. The underlying notion is entrenched in their minds that in order to prosper economically we need development at all costs, regardless of consequences; that we need to extract more and more from our finite resources. There is always a failure by the opposition to recognise that resources are finite and that, if we continue to plunder these resources in the hope of gaining economic prosperity, there will be nothing left.

May I emphasise that the government has taken on many of the budget concerns raised by the Western Australian Green senators, as well as the Democrats and the Labor caucus, in a spirit of cooperation and negotiation. This budget provides incentive for a solid economic foundation to provide ecologically sustainable industries and development.

We have to take advantage of our relative environmental cleanliness. For example, there is an enormous opportunity for Australia to succeed in the production of clean green foodstuffs. The world is increasingly demanding these quality products and we are recognised worldwide as a producer of clean green agricultural commodities. This is a reputation that we need to maintain and enhance. If Australia can, through imaginative policies, satisfy what will be enormous world demand for food that is perceived and can be demonstrated to be clean and green, the world will demand those products. The world is becoming health conscious and will pay a premium for products produced in a non-polluting, environmentally conscious way.

Another major feature of the budget has been the adoption of an active labour market strategy. The jobskills program offers six months work experience and training places to the long-term unemployed and is targeted to the regions of highest unemployment. In my electorate the Greening Australia program has made provision for 260 jobskills placements. They will provide on-the-ground land management training in conjunction with a reafforestation program which will form the basis for a sustainable timber production industry on the New South Wales north coast. This is where long-term job security in the Australian forest industry lies; not with the idea of clear-felling the last old-growth forests.

It was tragic to watch on television the other day an Aussie worker being incited by extremists to commit violence on protesters. The attitude of the representatives of the forest industry apparently takes no consideration of the fundamental democratic principles and the rule of law that Australian citizens are entitled to. This government should not be party to a forest agreement that is driven by greed, violence and intimidation. I am disgusted that the forest policy is being used as an excuse to allow intimidation and violence on young Australians.

During the election campaign, in the electorate of Page, both the Prime Minister and I were subjected to an orchestrated smear campaign by the same representatives of the forest industry who now want and demand from the government the green light to do as they like in the forests of Australia. Why should the taxpayer foot the bill to have the world heritage forests in Tasmania chipped for export?

The federal government is shortly to make a decision on whether certain national estate forests in South-West Tasmania are to be logged. The government is also being strongly lobbied to nominate world heritage areas in the Tarkine wilderness and the north-west of Tasmania. The Greens must press for favourable decisions and they will find that there is a lot of support within the government to achieve a favourable outcome.

How much longer can wetlands disappear without our fishing and coastal resources becoming depleted? Some of our rivers are becoming toxic, polluted waterways and our prime agricultural land has been degraded to a large extent. The government has made a commitment in the budget to increase funding for land care and the healthy rivers program but we need input and support from the Greens to make these programs effective and ongoing.

On the north coast of New South Wales in my electorate every koala habitat is now targeted for development. I call on the Western Australian Greens senators to represent their mandate in the strongest possible terms. They must not abrogate this responsibility. The government must be presented with the means to implement an environmental agenda. Never has there been a more urgent need for the Greens to participate in the governing process. The government will listen, consult, negotiate and come to agreements.

At this very moment, while the Greens senators are enmeshed in political manipulation with the coalition over wine taxes and over the one per cent wholesale sales tax, forests are coming down, the habitats of endangered species are being destroyed and grassroots Greens supporters are being subjected to harassment. Where is the imagination, the forward thinking and the proactive approach in these Greens Western Australian senators that have been the hallmark of the green movement.

If the Greens refuse to take on the environmental issues in federal parliament then it must be the Keating Labor government that must turn its mind and gain public support and profile as the only real party that will take on board a vision of Australia based on the principles of environmental protection, social equity and economic justice.

Are the Greens going to lose this opportunity to put environmental issues on the government agenda as many of its supporters think they are? I quote from a letter from a group called Australians for Animals written to Senator Chamarette:

SPEECH.PARA: This organisation, along with many other groups, is growing deeply concerned by the actions of the two Green Senators in Canberra.
Why aren't environmental issues being negotiated by the WA Greens?
Why aren't you using this opportunity to force an EIS or a public enquiry on the Uruguay Round?
Why aren't you raising the issue of the export woodchip licences and the destruction of native forests in NSW, Victoria?
Why aren't you using this opportunity to put the environment on the public agenda?
Are you Greens or something else?

I have seen the honourable member for Page in this chamber in a state of some disrepair in the past but I thought that his elocution was better today. —I am sure the honourable member for O'Connor would have been flattered had the other word been used. PARA.TAB: I wish to concentrate on one aspect of these matters in this Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1993-94 this afternoon and that is the aspect of the effect of increased taxes on the wine industry. This government in this budget has put up its own government expenditure and put taxes on other industries to pay for it. Therefore, for government members to come in here, as has been going on in the last few days, and protest about the savage and unfortunate Christmases that Australians will have, when the government in fact is guilty of the very reason for that coming to pass, is nothing less than hypocrisy.

On the subject of wine, the question is, `What would you do in Australia if you were a government which professes to want to promote industry?'. We have heard the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) in this place again today saying that exports are the name of the game; that what we have to do is get out there and become part of the world scene in a way that makes sure that Australia can go forward.

The government looks around for an industry and finds one which has been struggling along for 100 years. It finds one that is starting to improve—that is starting to make not only an acceptable product for home consumption, which it did for a number of years, but one which is now acceptable to the rest of the world. It has had some local product success and it is an expanding industry. It has dared to venture out into the world, which I might say many of our industries until recently have not. It has lots of small business entrepreneurs involved in it. It has some 6,000 grape growers, and many employees involved in it. The government finds out whether the industry has succeeded and whether it is making market penetration. It finds out whether the technology in that industry is now acceptable to the rest of the world. It finds an industry which people, even French wine makers, are now saying has technology as good as that anywhere else in the world, if not the best technology in the world. When it has found out all of those things and made sure that that industry is rapidly expanding its exports then it taxes it.

The wine industry had no sales tax until 1984. On 21 August 1984, with the exception of wine with a low alcoholic content, a 10 per cent sales tax was applied to wine. That caused great consternation around Australia because at that stage the wine industry was not exactly in its infancy but it was an industry that was still learning and had a long way to go to get to world standards. In 1986, the wholesale sales tax went up to 20 per cent, and in 1993 this government is trying to take the wholesale sales tax to 31 per cent on wine and then subsequently to 32 per cent.

I have had a great interest in this industry because I have seen the development of it, not only in my electorate but also in my state and in the Hunter River, and of latter days in rather newer areas in Victoria. I have watched the sorts of people who have taken the trouble to train themselves, who have taken the trouble to attend schools of oenology and other places and taken the trouble to go to the nether ends of the earth to become technically expert. I have watched them struggle with their small plots of land, I have watched some of them expand and I have watched those people succeed.

I was absolutely horrified when I heard the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) say on budget night that the government was going to increase the tax on the wine industry. Not only was I horrified but I found that I was in keeping with a whole lot of other people in Australia. The coalition decided that this budget was so outrageous that it had to pick a number of taxes with which it totally disapproved, object to them and vote against them. This was one of the taxes which we chose to object to for the very best of reasons.

I am glad that the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) has come to the table because he knows these only too well, not only because he enjoys the product but also because lots of people produce it in his own electorate. I am absolutely staggered that the minister did not have some influence on this decision before it was made. Of course, the reason he had no influence on the decision before it was made was that he did not know it was going to be made. He did not know it was going to be made in the same way as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) did not know until, I understand, 6.30 on budget night that the decision was going to be made to increase the sales tax on wine.

It is a great way, is it not, Mr Deputy Speaker, to encourage industries when the minister responsible for that industry has no idea that the taxes are going to be increased. One can imagine how well thought out the whole matter was. In the same way, the same minister did not even know that there was going to be an increased levy on wool in the budget papers to begin on 1 July 1994. So there are a lot of things that these ministers do not seem to know about.

But one of the things that is absolutely sure is that development and investment in that industry will slow down—but not stop—as a result of an increase of this sort in the wine tax. So I cannot for the life of me understand how that was allowed to come to pass. Of course, there is no logic in it. It has been allowed to come to pass because the government needed the money from somewhere and it may as well go out and get it from an industry which looks to be successful.

I know the other argument in this matter is that the beer industry is heavily taxed. There is no doubt it is heavily taxed; it has been heavily taxed for years. Having been involved in that industry on the board of a company, I had listened for years to that industry putting submissions to government about the fact that there should be more wine taxes. I disagreed with those submissions every time because my argument used to be that if there were a tax on beer and then a tax on wine, one would be ramped by some government or another and it would be used as a series of step ladders.

That is exactly what happened. We had the beer lobby up here in Canberra, twisting everybody's arm, saying, `Look how much money we are paying. Why don't you make other people pay the same sort of offering?'. But it is nonsense. Just because one industry is used as a general taxing method for revenue, that does not mean to say that other industries should be taxed also.

The wine industry has long lead times in which, depending on the particular geographical area, the plantings take three, four or even five years, on some occasions, to come to reasonable fruition and it takes at least a couple of years to get it into the bottle for export. It is quite unreasonable to tax those sorts of industries which have those sorts of lead times—and, I might say, which involve those sorts of entrepreneurial activities—in the same way as one taxes an industry that puts various ingredients in one side of a machine which come out the other end a few days or weeks later.

So I found it an unbelievable circumstance that all of those people who had got so enthusiastic about an industry that was starting to succeed should be taxed. And I say advisedly `starting to succeed', because all the hyperbole about the fact that this is a very successful and financially rewarding industry is complete nonsense. One has only to read the annual general reports of the larger companies, and of some of the smaller ones, and talk to the wine growing fraternity itself to know that that has not been the case.

If we are to encourage people in this country to create jobs, we will have to make sure that they feel confident that the future of the industry in which they partake will give them a reward. We know that jobs are created by small industries; they are not created, in the main, by the BHPs or the Mount Isa Mines. What is tending to happen in those bigger organisations these days is that they can produce the same quantity of goods with a lesser number of people. The reason for that is quite obvious. The technological improvements enable them to spend money on capital equipment which does the same thing as people used to do before it.

But this expanding industry requires people. It requires people to plant. It requires people to graft. It requires people to harvest the posts. It requires people to grow the posts. It requires people to treat the posts. It requires people to do all sorts of things that require labour. It requires people to harvest. It requires people to spray. It requires people to design the wineries. It requires people to design the restaurants that grow out of the wineries. It requires people to do all sorts of things which create jobs. It also creates new areas of tourism for national and international tourists. One has only to take perhaps the most internationally famous area of Australian grape growing, Coonawarra—more famous, I have to say, than McLaren Vale at the present time—

TALK.START.PARA: —But not better wine.
—And better wine.
—I didn't say that.
—I did.
—I said `not better wine'.
—I said it was better wine. It matters not, because all the wine from both of those areas is better than the wine from New South Wales or Victoria.

PARA.TAB: In the last 15 years, that area has changed from being simply a grape growing strip of terra rossa soil to having restaurants, hotels and international visitors coming from all over the world, including places like Sweden, to buy their main Australian wine requirements. Sweden is second only to the UK as the biggest receiver of Australian wine in the world. Tourists come to those places and new industries are created.

I cannot imagine an industry that is better at creating small business and small jobs than the wine industry. It creates other industries. Therefore, to tax it is an act of madness which is second to none. The minister ought to know that better than anyone else. In fact, he ought to be more embarrassed about this than anybody in the whole country on the government side of politics, and I am sure he is.

So we have got to a situation now where we are seeing a monumental battle between the government and the wine industry on the matter of tax. We read in the paper about deals on the side. The growers have said, as we have said, `We will oppose this tax all the way to the vote'. We will oppose it here in this House, we will oppose it in the Senate and we will oppose it in whatever form for however long it takes to turn up.

I want to raise this issue because it is an example of a particularly bad decision made by the Treasurer when at the last minute he found he had a shortfall. It was made without consultation with the local members who might have been affected, even on his own side—he certainly would not consult us—without consultation with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who knew nothing about it, and without consultation with the industry, or if he did consult the industry he did something quite different from the understandings that the industry had some months before. It is an example of exactly how investment can be can slowed down in an area where one does not want to slow down investment at all.

I chose this example because it had all the ingredients of a wealth making, job making, entrepreneurial activity which actually created other industries, and the government slowed it down. That is a ridiculous solution in order to raise $79 million a year. I understand that the Managing Director of the South Australian Brewing Co. has said in the past that we need $1 billion of new investment within the foreseeable future. That means that, for the lower south-east area of my state to fulfil its portion of that investment, there must be somewhere between 10,000 and 15,000 acres of new plantings every three or four years, at $12,000 an acre—and that is without the land cost. It will take three or four years for the plantings to come to early fruition and another couple of years to produce the wine. It is no exaggeration to say that, as I drive down the road to the bottom end of South Australia, it seems to me that some of that investment has gone on hold. It seems to me from the conversations I have had that those people who were putting together investment money have been told to cool it until we see what happens to this tax.

If that is the result of the thinking process of a government that is trying to create jobs, with a 10 or 11 per cent unemployment rate, what hope do we have in this country? We have only to look at this industry to get an idea of the lack of thinking that takes place when the government is preparing its budgets. We have reached a point where our international reputation is such that one of the top winegrowers in France said, `We have two problems left in France: one is the bloody weather and the other is the bloody Australians'. That is a flattering position to be in. We have reached a position where, in markets other than France, even the French are very worried. What do we do? We make sure that investment slows down. We make sure that all of the confidence that those people have got into their heads in the last few years—and it has only risen in the last few years—is slowing down.

I cannot for the life of me understand the logic in it; I cannot for the life of me understand why people like the Minister at the table could possibly have allowed it to happen, had he known it was going to happen. As he did not know it was going to happen, and as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy did not know it was going to happen, we now have a stand-off by a government simply saying, `Yes, it wasn't a very good idea, but we want to win the debate'.

I suggest to government members that they give up that puerile view, walk away from the wine tax and stop threatening the wine industry with excises and all the rest of the things that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) and others say on the telephone. The government should stop all of that and say, `We were wrong, and for $79 million, we're not going to put these taxes back on and the investment will go straight back in'. That is the reason why it makes me so cross to have to get up here and talk about a subject which should never have arisen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1993-94. On 24 February 1993, in Building on strength, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) emphasised our commitment to an Australia based on practical, sensible policies to stimulate private investment, strengthen economic recovery and increase employment, while at the same time building a fairer Australia. The pursuit of greater social equality, good health care, good education and a good environment for all Australians, remain the policy foundations for the Labor government. These involve measures to stimulate growth by encouraging investment and innovation, increasing women's participation in the work force, improving and extending access to child care, improving health care, assisting older Australians, improving and expanding our education system, and reducing marginal tax rates for middle Australia. These policy foundations were incorporated in the budget.

PARA.TAB: It is pleasing to see that the primary objective of the 1993 budget is jobs. This is built on a recovery based on low interest rates, continuing low inflation, reduced company tax and generous business investment incentives, designed to cut the deficit by $9 billion in four years, contribute some $17 billion to the national savings over three years and provide extra help to families with children, extra assistance to those out of work, improved health services, and a range of other initiatives.

There will be 500,000 labour market places available this financial year, two-thirds of which will go to people who have been unemployed for 12 months or more. Further, the newstart allowance will be increased by $6 per fortnight for single adult people without children who have been unemployed for more than 12 months.

The budget recognised that in 1990-91, $8 billion in export earnings was achieved from 700 small to medium sized manufacturers. More than 6,000 businesses are not yet exporting. A total of $94 million will be provided over the next three years to enable them to provide more jobs by gaining access to export markets.

The budget provides relief for middle and low income Australians by delivering tax cuts early, commencing when the opposition stops its constitutional vandalism. Those on incomes below $23,200 will receive a new rebate on assessment. These tax initiatives will stimulate the economy by $2 billion. The seniors health card will be provided from 1 July 1994 to low income retirees not currently receiving the pension. The pensions assets test will be eased from September 1993—this month. Commitment to child care, a major strategy in our election campaign, will be delivered. Overall, this budget is a responsible document by a responsible government committed to social justice and jobs within our community.

The budget goes further than just being a responsible document for Australia's future. Let me be specific and list for the record the promises kept, because this budget is all about being honest and being strong in keeping commitments. The opposition made outrageous claims about its so-called Fightback mark 3 package—the unchangeable. What is it now called: slink-off mark 12—the impossible?
