The opposition knows that if it had got into government, it would have done a Jeff Kennett, cried foul on how bad the books really were, and gone back to Fightback mark 1. When that proved to be disastrous, who knows who it would have then blamed. Those opposite know that that was what was planned. Privately, the more honest of them admit it over a few beers. The government made promises and has delivered, and the opposition does not like it.

For the record, let me detail the promises kept: establishment of a cultural heritage protection program for Aboriginal rock art; an education and monitoring program concerning taxation incentives for the arts; protection and return of significant cultural property to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people; establishment of a festival of youth arts; development of the National Museum of Australia—design and documentation work for the development of the Yarramundi site; improved access to the distributed national heritage collection; a film script development and producer support program; enhancement of the role of the Australian Youth Orchestra; improvement of children's media; establishment of the Foundation for Australian Cultural Development; national touring of visual arts, crafts and heritage exhibitions; expansion of cultural industry development schemes; a Commonwealth cultural policy statement; and a review of the Australian honours system.

The list also includes outlays for a taxation incentive scheme for approved heritage conservation works; the establishment of a fund for higher education institutions to utilise spare capacity; resource allocation for higher education research infrastructure funding; provision of a deferred payment facility for students of the open learning initiative; additional funding for group employment and training companies; grants for hostels for rural school students; and the abolition of the assets test for the supplementary boarding allowance under the assistance for isolated children's scheme.

There is also the establishment of a grasslands ecology unit; a national strategy for rangelands rescue; an inquiry into the environmental and economic values and potential of the Shoalwater Bay training area; the abatement of lead levels in the environment; the development of a world heritage nomination for the Sydney Opera House; funding of Altone Park Community Recreation Centre; review of nursing staff in hostels; a restoration and replacement program for the Commonwealth's assets in the national capital; the development of a youth housing strategy; best practice in the health sector program; a child-care cash rebate for working parents; the reduction of clinically excessive waiting times for elective surgery; and a national review of nurse education in the higher education sector.

Included in the list is the Commonwealth dental program for health cardholders; palliative care funding; child-care initiatives for sick children; funding for playgroups; national accreditation for child-care centres eligible for child-care assistance, or fee relief; extension of long day care child-care assistance, or fee relief, to occasional care; the development and distribution of a public patients' hospital charter; a public health education and research program—consolidation and enhancement; a Medicare rebate for bone densitometry; and a catch-up immunisation program against HIB disease for children. These are the things that those opposite put in jeopardy.

There are optional postal income assessments for child-care assistance; reduced overservicing and fraud of Medicare; referral services for women escaping domestic violence in rural and remote areas; expansion in work related child-care places; the second national AIDS program strategy; a women's health program; establishment of working women's centres; industrial relations legislation reform and an information campaign; funding for workplace reform and a best practice program; and the implementation of ILO Convention No. 156, involving workers with family responsibilities. These are the things that those people over there put in jeopardy.

There are changes in shipbuilding and bounty rates; a regional development task force; and a safety officer for NSW forests. After what the minister in New South Wales is doing, it is no wonder that they need one. Further commitments include encouraging the use of solar water heaters; New South Wales flood mitigation; a review of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation; a review of the wool industry; community based models for rural area development; a rural counselling program; and telecentres for rural communities. The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) thinks that this is all ridiculous, and it is ridiculous that he should think it funny that these things will be stopped for his rural voters.

There is additional funding for clean food export strategies; funding for horticulture; a rural enterprise network program; upgrading of rural telecommunications services; a rural development incentive scheme; a world best practice incentive scheme; cooperative research centres; establishment of a republic advisory committee and constitutional reform unit; and continuation of the National Committee on Violence Against Women. Some of the female members of the opposition should think very hard about what that means.

There is the additional funding of the operational grants component of the national agenda for women; the simplification of waiting period waiver provisions; increased earned income allowance in the income test free area; earnings credit for allowance recipients; the transfer of newstart allowance recipients to a mature age allowance for long-term unemployed aged 60 and over but who are under the age to qualify for an age pension; an indexed, non-taxable home child-care allowance in the social security system; a reduced assets test withdrawal rate for pensioners; and a seniors health card. These are the things which the opposition wants to jeopardise.

There is the completion of the survey work on the Alice Springs-Darwin rail link; establishment of a national transport planning task force; an inquiry into the provision of broadband services to customer premises with optic fibre; extension of the ABC's Triple J; development of a national ecotourism strategy and the implementation of an ecotourism program; implementation of a regional tourism development program; development of a special interest tourism program; establishment of a tourism forecasting council; assistance to residents of contaminated sites at the Martin Street subdivision, Armidale; and Commonwealth financial assistance to South Australia—and the last speaker, the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), should think about that.

Other measures include the establishment of a national investment council; an expanded role for the Commonwealth Development Bank; a national Aboriginal and Islander skills development association; the Asia-Pacific biennale of indigenous arts and sciences; a review of copyright collecting agencies; improvements to the Australian academic and research network to permit broader access; resource levels for government primary schools; upgrading the CES to improve services to clients; and establishing a network of over 300 open learning access centres. These measures are in jeopardy.

There are refinements to the training guarantee; purchase of properties by skillshare; establish a special consultative group on training with non-English speaking background people; a long-term unemployed entitlement to program assistance; the establishment of a teaching accord; industry, enterprise and community involvement in training reform; Cairns campus development of the James Cook University; national strategy on the status of vocational education and training; provision of mature workers centres under the skillshare program; internationalisation of Australian education and training; and sports traineeships. Honourable members opposite whinge about the Olympics, but they will put those things in jeopardy.

Other commitments involve strengthening consumer protection for renters in the private tenure; an export strategy for the housing and related industries sector; AIDC Ltd's star product; removal of developing country tariff preferences; extension of patent life for pharmaceuticals; and a centre for furniture design in Hobart—these measures are all in jeopardy because of the opposition's irresponsible behaviour.

I would like to look in some detail at what some of these promises that we have delivered mean to ordinary Australians. In education and training the government will maintain and upgrade the CES, introduce new computerised vacancy display technology, enhance off-site facilities and telephone based client servicing. The provision of a deferred payment facility for students of the open learning initiative will allow students wishing to undertake a minimum of 75 per cent of the full-time study load to do so free of the immediate requirement to meet the cost of their study. Such a provision will increase access and ensure equity in the provision of education under the open learning initiative.

Additional funding for group employment and training companies will provide start-up funds and expertise to assist existing group employment and training companies to further match up skills and facilitate restructuring and employment growth in that part of the Labor market not accessible to the CES. A national health policy will reduce clinically excessive waiting times for elective surgery. The opposition wants to stop this. The government has provided funds in the budget to fulfil the commitment of $25 million per year which will be available to reduce waiting times for elective surgery, particularly for the treatment of public patients in private hospitals.

The Commonwealth dental program for health card holders will provide access to subsidised emergency dental care and basic dental services to health card holders. The budget outlays $19.2 million in 1993-94. This outlay will be tripled in the following year and doubled again the next year. Those opposite have put this in jeopardy. The seniors health card will allow people of pension age who do not receive age or veterans pensions to gain access to concessional pharmaceutical, hearing, dental and optometry services. Under the second national AIDS program strategy funding for the prevention and treatment of people living with HIV or AIDS will be doubled, totalling $104 million in 1993-94.

A reduction in medical overservicing and fraud will save the health budget an expected $25 million in this fiscal year and an approximated $60 million in the following year. We have a catch-up immunisation program against HIB disease for children. The opposition wants to jeopardise that measure. More than $10 million over the next two years will be made available to enable the implementation of the program to provide immunisation against HIB disease for children born after 1 April 1988.

We will review the adequacy of quality nursing care in aged care hostels. Those opposite want to put that in jeopardy. We have a national housing policy to provide funding to facilitate access to information for private sector renters about their rights. There is the development of a youth housing strategy, and the funding commitment for that is $0.6 million over two years. The aim of the strategy is to improve housing options for independent young people on low incomes.

Under the investing in the nation child-care policy there will be a child-care cash rebate for working parents of up to $28.20 a week—$1,446 a year—for one child and $61.20 a week—$3,182 a year—for two or more children. This will apply to work-related child-care expenses for children up to 12 years of age. Child-care initiatives for sick children will assist families with working parents. Increased funding for playgroups will assist parents caring for children at home. National accreditation for child-care centres eligible for fee relief aims to ensure good quality affordable care in child-care centres. Opposition members have put these measures in jeopardy. Where is their responsibility? Then there is the extension of long day care child-care assistance to occasional care, and expansion in work related child-care places to meet a target of 300,000 places by 1996-97.

TALK.START.PARA: —And in your electorate, too.
—In my electorate also. Working men and women in my electorate have taken great advantage of this. The irresponsible attitude of the wreckers opposite has put all of this out.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! The honourable member, my friend and colleague, should direct his comments through the chair and not directly at the opposition side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will do so. It does become a little hard, though, because it is obviously a case of complete irresponsibility. The company tax rate has been reduced from 39 per cent to 33 per cent, yet those opposite who would stand up for the business community are putting that measure in jeopardy. Where do these people stand? Where do they get off? They are irresponsibly attacking women, children, families and businesses.

PARA.TAB: As in all democratic parties, there are at times disagreements. The great Australian Labor Party, of which I am still a member, is no exception. Let us contrast the two main parties. `Dr Dull' was told by all of his backbench to drop the GST. Even some of his frontbench told him to drop the GST or at least to change it. `I'll resign first', `Dr Dull' said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the honourable member is referring to a member of parliament, he must use his correct title. There is no such title in this parliament. If he is going to follow that train, he must use the honourable member's correct title.
—I am not sure of his—
—Just use the correct title or do not say anything.

—Did he keep his word and give the Liberal Party a chance? No. He changed it and stayed. I thank him for that because by the time the election came nobody believed him, not even those elements of the Liberal controlled press. Did he listen to his backbench? No. Did he keep his word? No. In contrast, our fearless leader kept all his election promises. Even under severe pressure to break them, he stood his ground and kept his word. When criticism was heard on the budget, he and the Treasurer confronted members on the back bench, listened to their concerns on behalf of their constituents but, more than that, understood and acted. This is the party that I belong to—a party where a humble backbencher such as I can make a difference.

PARA.TAB: I intend to continue to press my colleagues in the government to exempt country people from the leaded petrol excise increases because we have no public transport options. We already pay on average 5c to 6c more per litre. Income levels tend to be lower in the country due to lower union participation. Our services are wider spread, our goods all have higher freight components as part of price, and lead is predominantly a major problem in the metropolitan areas.

I also intend to press my colleagues on a number of measures concerning mature Australians. Firstly, I intend to show that the retirement age for both sexes should be reduced—not on moral grounds, equity grounds or social justice grounds but on economic grounds, as I believe the research from my office shows us that it is cheaper to do so. Further, I intend to ask that voluntary retirement with fringe benefit card access be available at the age of 55 for self-funded retirees and superannuants. I suggest that the income tax threshold for these people and pensioners should be $10,000. I will continue to press for these reforms and ultimately we will achieve these goals.

I intend to press for exemptions for credit unions to be re-established. I strongly support credit unions because the banks are ripping us off with collusive market behaviour. The margins the banks are making on home loans are higher than at any recent time—since well before 1970. The margins on commercial loans are also higher than they traditionally have been. There is almost a four per cent difference between the commercial bank bill rate and the housing rate, which is 8.75 per cent. This margin has been too high since 1992. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House has just heard a rather humorous address from the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott). Perhaps he is practising to be the next Treasurer for the government because he has given us quite a run-down on what is in the budget. He even came in here with a bow tie. Perhaps he is much closer to being the next Treasurer after the comments of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) who said that he is very tired when he gets on the plane in Perth and thinks about going fishing at Fremantle.
—The next Placido Domingo.

—Perhaps we have a Placido Domingo here in the House tonight. I did notice towards the end of his tirade that he started to talk about issues that he disagreed with that are measures in this budget, such as the increase in fuel tax, which he will be urging the government to drop. He also mentioned credit union legislation that the government is committed to as well. It is quite interesting that, whilst he went on at great length to say what was in the budget, as he got towards the last two or three minutes of his speech he started to talk about things he did not like in it, and the honesty started to show through.

PARA.TAB: When the Treasurer came into the House on 17 August he said he had a vision, competence, and trust in his budget to deliver the goods. Those three ingredients were certainly missing from this year's budget because it was really a `big bang or bust' budget. The budget is all of those things. It is certainly big. It is going to glean or gain $99 billion of revenue from the Australian people. It is going to go bust because the government is going to spend more than it will earn, to the tune of about $16 billion. It will certainly bust because, when we look at the comments from every lobby group around Australia, we do not find any of them saying that this is a good budget.

One of the comments that come to mind is from the trade union movement, the great supporter of the Australian Labor Party, which says that the budget is `an act of bastardry'. Right across Australia all lobby groups have been coming to see us on this side of the House asking what we can do to get this budget to a position where it will benefit Australia, where it will start to create jobs and address the real problems of this nation—unemployment, high debt, and the massive balance of payments problems that we have got in this nation.

In this budget the government has treated regional and rural Australians with complete disregard and contempt. This disregard and contempt are attributed to a constituency in decline. Under this government this will accelerate. We have only got to look at research that is coming in from regional, rural and remote parts of Australia to see that the population is drifting from these areas to the cities. Worse still, the population is ageing. This budget will only hasten the decline in populations in regional and rural Australia.

The Treasurer may argue that this budget did not come without some warning because for many days—in fact, weeks—prior to bringing down the budget he was telling all in the nation who would listen that Australia was one of the lowest taxed countries in the OECD. This somewhat obscure announcement was in preparation for the huge tax slugs announced in the budget. It was the softening up approach—the progressive leaks; the controlled leaks from his office—so that people would think on the night of the budget, `We thought we were going to get worse, so it is not so bad. We are going to have to pay more tax but it is not as bad as we were led to believe in some of the leaks'. Clearly the Treasurer was saying that we are amongst the lowest taxed nations in the OECD. However, this analogy is quite irrelevant. Of the 24 OECD countries, 19 are in Europe. Included in the list are Belgium, Luxembourg and Spain—countries which are of only marginal importance to Australia. So he should not draw that analogy that we are amongst the lowest taxed nations in the OECD using those countries as an example.

So often we hear the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) talk in the House in glowing terms about the opportunities in Asia. I agree that there are enormous opportunities in Asia. Prior to bringing down the budget and during the budget process the Treasurer and the Prime Minister should have been talking about how we compare with the nations in the Asian area.

We must compare our performance with that of the Asian nations. We are geographically closer to them. The economies of the Asian nations are booming, and their figures in relation to economic growth, levels of unemployment and balance of trade make our figures look as though we are not just terminally ill but dead.

Whilst the Treasurer might think that he can sell this budget, the Australian people will not cop it. I have just listened to the tail end of the speech by the honourable member for Gilmore, and it is obvious that the caucus will not cop it. Every day when the Treasurer is up here at the dispatch boxes during question time, trying to sell the budget, the backbenchers are strangely quiet.

One of the most despicable aspects of this budget is the increases in the fuel tax. The implications of those increases on regional and rural Australians have to be measured against the capacity of those people to pay. The great wealth of this nation is generated in regional and rural Australia, and this tax impost is going to fall heavily on the people who live in those areas and the industries located there. The tyranny of distance is as evident as ever. This government has done nothing at all to break down the great tyranny of distance in this country. The Queensland Farmers Federation said this about the tax measures announced in this budget:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federation is particularly concerned about the impact of the proposed fuel tax increases on rural people who have to travel further for goods and services than their urban counterparts. These people have no alternative means of transport—
as the honourable member for Gilmore quite rightly pointed out—

and they do not have the benefit of competition helping to keep the price of fuel down. Nationally the impact of the proposed excise changes will cost agriculture more than $70 million, and will reduce net farm income by 4%. In industries more dependent on transport the effect will be even more pronounced. On average it is expected that the excise increase will add $1000 to farm costs and reduce net farm profit by 10.4%.
The federation went on to say:

The Federation asks that you consider the following key statistics from the Farmfacts Lifestyle Survey which reveal how discriminatory and regressive is the impact of fuel based taxation of this kind.

I think that says it all. When a farm dweller has to access a supermarket, the average distance he has to travel is 30.2 kilometres; for someone in a capital city it is 1.9 kilometres. To access a hospital, the average distance that someone living in rural Australia has to travel is 34.2 kilometres; the average distance in a capital city is 5.9 kilometres. To access a child-care centre, the average distance that someone living in rural Australia has to travel is 39.5 kilometres; for someone in a city it is 2.7 kilometres. That clearly demonstrates how the tyranny of distance impacts on people living in rural Australia.

PARA.TAB: In answer to a question concerning the rural adjustment scheme during question time today, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) said he had been consulting the president of the Queensland Graingrowers Association on rural adjustment, and the amount of money that is needed in Queensland. The president of the Queensland Graingrowers Association Mr Ian Macfarlane had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . association would back anyone who intended to stop the introduction of increased fuel taxes.

He went on to say that rural people would remember who stood by them in their hour of need, and this issue would be taken into account when weighing up votes. The Queensland Graingrowers Association is certainly not on the government's side, and it is certainly not on the side of the minister, as he would have us believe, in this rural adjustment fiasco.

TALK.START.PARA: —Consulting is not agreeing.

—As the honourable member for Murray quite rightly says, consulting is not agreeing. Perhaps `consulting' should mean insulting the people of rural and regional Australia. That is what this budget does.

PARA.TAB: I would like to demonstrate another impact of increased fuel taxes and what they mean to regional and rural Australians. The impact of that 3c per litre on the cost of transport is going to add massively to the costs of moving freight across this nation. On a truck doing an average of 150,000 to 200,000 kilometres a year, the fuel increase of 3c a litre means an additional $6,000 per rig.

This fuel tax also impacts on the railways of the nation. In Queensland the Goss Labor government is talking about pulling up one-third of the Queensland railways. The people of Queensland started to pull the premier up when he went down this path, so he set up one of these committees. That is one of those things that the Labor Party is very good at. When the heat is put on the Labor Party it sets up a committee. The Labor Party creates a task force and it goes out and starts to consult, but we can bet our lives that the die has been cast in relation to the Queensland government railways while the Labor government is in power.

The increase in fuel tax is going to accelerate the decline of the railways. It does not apply only to the users of roads in this nation; it applies to the railways as well. It is going to be another cost to those many regional railway lines in Queensland that are desperately trying to show a profit at a time when the Queensland government is talking about pulling them up.

The add-on cost of the fuel tax on many properties which use helicopters and aeroplanes for mustering their livestock is going to be $6 an hour for running each aircraft. These aeroplanes and helicopters are an efficiency measure. It is much better and much quicker to muster livestock in the remote parts of Australia with helicopters and aeroplanes than it is with horses, as used to happen many years ago. In order to drive efficiency and get costs down, people in rural Australia have modernised and have gone to the most efficient ways of handling their operations. What has this government done? This government has added another cost to the operation of those properties. It is going to cost another $6 an hour to run the average size aeroplane used in mustering operations.

It was announced in the budget that we are going to see an increase of up to 12 per cent in wool taxes next year. Tonight we are going to see some wool legislation introduced into the House, and we will be watching with interest to see what has happened to that little proposal. No matter how he tries to squirm out of it, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy was obviously not even aware of that proposal. He was clearly caught out by his own department. That indicates who is in charge of the primary industries portfolio—certainly not the minister. We will be watching tonight to see whether the 12 per cent tax is still in the legislation.

I want to touch on a couple of other aspects. In the budget the government has gutted what has been known as the country areas program. In Queensland that program is known as PCAP. In Victoria it is known as the country areas program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Country education project.

—It is the country education project. This country areas program, as it is known in this place, has been a most successful targeted funding initiative in bringing some equity into the education of the many students who live in rural and remote Australia. This budget subsumes the country areas program funding and broadbands it into other programs. So no longer do we have the identified approach that would make this government—or any future government—accountable to the many thousands of students who live in regional and rural Australia.

PARA.TAB: It can be seen from the government's actions of gutting the country areas program in the budget that it has given away the kids of the bush. The Treasurer might say that it will still be identified and will be up to the states. The fact is that it will no longer appear as a federal budget item. The federal government will no longer be accountable for what has been its most effective and targeted initiative in education for many disadvantaged students in rural Australia.

Today at question time, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy was asked a question by the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) about the rural adjustment package, or RAS, and the minister's recent announcement in Queensland—but he did not answer it. A fortnight ago, in Queensland, he said that he would make an additional $3.1 million available to Queensland farmers. He has been caught out because the funding that the minister announced is not additional—as we have identified in the last few days—but the reallocation of the RAS budget allocation to Queensland.

This means that the $3.1 million that the minister for primary industry would have the Queensland farmers believe is additional, is funding that has already been allocated. It will come out of other rural adjustment scheme packages and go into the exceptional circumstance provision. Given the minister's answer today, it seems that he has no intention of making additional funds available to the desperate farmers in Queensland, whose properties have been drought stricken for more than three years and where numbers in Queensland—
Mr Dodd interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Leichhardt is interjecting from the back of the chamber, but he would surely understand—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! The honourable member will address the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member for Leichhardt clearly would understand, if he was in tune with his electorate—or any parts of Queensland—that since April, the numbers of drought stricken properties have increased from 8,000 to 15,700. And the situation is not getting any better. There is a desperate need for additional funds. It is not the time for the minister to announce in Queensland that he is making additional funds available, when all he is doing is reallocating funds which have already been allocated. He has given a false sense of security to many thousands of desperate families who are seeking support from the federal government in these desperate times.

PARA.TAB: This budget is one of the great betrayals of the Australian people. It betrays us all. During the last federal election campaign, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer—and senior ministers—went around Australia trying to sell a reason why they should form the next government. They mentioned nothing of increased taxes. They did not get a mandate to increase taxation. They certainly got a mandate for a few things but not for what we saw on 17 August. This budget will destroy the confidence of business to invest—and it is business that will create the jobs that are so desperately needed. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dodd Mr P.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Appropriation Bill (No. 1). I want to make some general remarks about honourable members opposite—who purport to be the opposition. I am going to address my remarks mainly to the Liberal Party. I guess that the National Party is dying, so I will not make many comments about it. The Liberal Party is obviously determining the coalition's strategy at the moment.
—You are certainly out of touch.

—I am not out of touch. I will get back to the honourable member for Maranoa in a minute. The Liberal Party has no policies or principles. We have heard comments recently about the federal coalition's policies from no less a person than the former leader of the Liberal Party, the Rt Hon. Malcolm Fraser, who has said that the coalition is too tied up with economic rationalism and has the wrong policies.

PARA.TAB: Just yesterday, Senator Amanda Vanstone told the opposition the same thing; that Malcolm Fraser was right and those opposite are wrong. But the funny thing is that Senator Vanstone is on the frontbench of the coalition, yet she is saying its policies are wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —She said that so are yours.

—She may have said that; I would expect it from Senator Vanstone. But is it not strange that a member of the frontbench would say that the current leader is wrong and a former Prime Minister is right? Malcolm Fraser has made his position very clear. The Liberal Party is in disarray. The honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) contributed to the debate earlier today. I submit that he is a very principled member of the coalition. He is not on the frontbench because he is a small `l' liberal. Unfortunately, he had nothing to say so he pulled out the last card in the pack and talked about ambit claims. It is an absolute disgrace. That is what the coalition does whenever it gets stuck. It pulls out an ambit claim. Honourable members know about the industrial relations system and ambit claims. But if those opposite have no policies, what else can they talk about?

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) talked about the rural adjustment scheme, but he clearly does not understand it. The rural adjustment scheme is an interest subsidy scheme. Although governments make budget allocations for interest subsidy schemes, they will only ever be an estimate of what is required over the next financial year. Governments regularly top up the RAS in times of economic difficulty in the rural sector. That is what the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) said in the House today. He said that, if necessary, the rural adjustment scheme funding would be topped up, that supplementation would be found. It is right and proper that there should be a reallocation within the rural adjustment scheme before that happens, to meet the emergency needs in drought areas in Queensland. What the honourable member said illustrates that his party has no policies.

The federal coalition's policies in the last election basically consisted of a GST and massive cuts to government expenditure. What does it have now? There is no GST but I presume there are still the massive cuts to government expenditure. That is the coalition's problem. The honourable member for Maranoa, who is also an opposition frontbencher, is telling us what is wrong with the petrol tax. I come from a remote rural region—one of the most remote electorates in Australia. No-one has to tell me about the effect of petrol prices. Honourable members should travel in such places as Coen, Weipa and Bamaga in my electorate. I do not want the opposition lecturing me about the price of petrol. The opposition will not face the problem of raising revenue. It has no principles. It had the GST. Now it does not have the GST and it has not come out with any other revenue raising policy.

What the opposition has to address, and what Australia is addressing, is the problem that the FitzGerald report has recently raised in relation to the decline in Australia's national savings. Dr FitzGerald talks about our need to raise those national savings, and one of the ways is taxation. The government has taken options in this budget, and certain revenue raising options have not been particularly popular. But no-one opposite has put forward any other solutions.

Dr FitzGerald has talked about solutions and on this side of the House there is some talk of unemployment links. That is not firm government policy; that is talk. We are facing the problems that face Australia. We are facing the issue of the decline in national savings. What does the coalition do? It is lining up with the Greens in the Senate simply to get short-term political advantage. Where is the principle there? I expect that from the back bench; but the honourable member for Maranoa is a frontbencher, and so is Senate Amanda Vanstone. Where is the consistency? Where is the consistent policy?

The honourable member for Maranoa and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) consistently tell us about Asia—what about Asia? Well, what about Asia? The honourable member for Maranoa did not tell us about the level of social security in Asia because there is not any—there is none. The honourable member did not talk about the industrial relations laws in Asia because they are draconian. One thing that those opposite will not talk about in regard to Asia, and the so-called Asian tigers, is the higher level of state intervention in the financial system in those countries that has promoted investment. The ideological hideboundness of the opposition has left it in a bind.

It is very interesting. We talk about economic policy. The opposition is also absolutely bereft of policies in any other area. I refer honourable members to an article by Judith Brett in the Melbourne Age on 17 July. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: When the Liberal Party weren't talking about economics in the election, they had nothing to say.
She goes on to say:

The Liberal Party in the 40s and 50s was based on people who were joiners; people active in the church and community service, charity organisations, who saw their party membership as one aspect of their obligation to contribute to this society. Duty, leadership, self-discipline, responsible work, independence were the core values of the Menzies individual—
the author is the author of a biography of Sir Robert Menzies—
not the free choice, competition evoked by a go-getter like Hewson.

That is the problem. The go-getters and the right wingers have taken over the Liberal Party. They offer nothing to the majority of the working Australians, those people who joined the Liberal Party in the 1950s. They owe nothing to those Australians who are unlucky enough to fall into the entrepreneurial class. They owe nothing to Aboriginal people; they owe nothing to the white leadership and the male leadership of the Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: Dr Brett refers to social groups such as women, Australians of non-English speaking backgrounds and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. She says that the Liberals continually insist that people are individuals before they are a part of the collective. No wonder those groups are sceptical about the Liberal Party. It offers them nothing. All it offers them is a role as individuals in society; they see nothing in their role as a collective force. That is why the Liberal Party has alienated women, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people, non-English speaking people and the arts community.

In the brief time that I have I want to talk a little about my electorate of Leichhardt and the effect the budget has on it. It is interesting to note that when we talk about the Liberal Party, it holds no seat outside the metropolitan area of Brisbane, the Gold Coast and the Sunshine Coast—south-east Queensland. The best that the opposition has is someone called Senator Ian Macdonald, who is the shadow minister for local government and the ACT. Before the budget, Senator Macdonald suggested to the media in Cairns that the Far North would be affected by the Labor budget, that the Cairns campus of James Cook University would not go ahead and that the funding would be cut by the federal government. Senator Macdonald was wrong about that and he just caused a great deal of distress to people who attend the Cairns campus of James Cook because in the 1993 budget, the government honoured the Prime Minister's election promise to provide $9.5 million during 1994-95 and it increased the Commonwealth's commitment to $15 million. Of course the state government has put in an additional $6 million. This shows the federal government's commitment to education in the Far North.

But Senator Macdonald keeps running around Far North Queensland trying to undermine that position. We do not hear him talking much about local government, and we certainly do not hear him talking about the ACT. I do not know how often he comes down here and talks about the ACT. I would not wish Senator Macdonald on the people of the ACT.

Also in the budget was a commitment to bring both Triple J radio and SBS to the Far North. This is very important to my electorate. This means that my electorate in the middle of next year when we have SBS and Triple J—we will have SBS at the end of this year and Triple J at the middle of next year—will have all the free-to-air services that the capital cities have. That is very important. One week ago Senator Macdonald was running around, again causing concern in the Far North, saying that SBS would not be targeted. I see we have the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services (Dr Theophanous) here who is obviously interested in ethnic groups. Ethnic groups in the community were concerned. But I have been assured by the Minister for Communications (Mr Beddall) that SBS will be on target for Cairns. Again Senator Macdonald does not seem to be doing his job on the front bench, but just causing concern in the Far North.

The tourism industry was also a big winner in the budget. The government has committed a $42 million package over four years to develop tourism in regional and rural Australia. Yesterday there was an announcement from the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee) that applications and forms of the guidelines for the $23 million regional tourism development program had been sent to local government and tourism bodies in my electorate. That will provide tourism and local government bodies in my electorate with an excellent opportunity to get funding for much needed tourism infrastructure. That shows real support for the tourism industry from this government; real support for the need for infrastructure in the Far North; real support for a commitment to regional Australia.

In the budget, my electorate did very well in terms of local provision for Far North Queensland. It shows the interest of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the electorate. The Prime Minister is a regular visitor to Far North Queensland. Last week, when the Prime Minister was overseas, I had the pleasure of accompanying the Acting Prime Minister, the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services (Mr Howe), to the electorate. The Acting Prime Minister went to the Torres Strait and he also spoke in Cairns about the need for the provision of tourism infrastructure and infrastructure for the whole community.

Cairns is a growth area. Some honourable members may ask, `What is the problem in Cairns?' The problem is that Cairns is a very high growth area, and that provides unintended consequences which affect people in the community. The fact is that there is a crisis in Cairns in relation to emergency accommodation. We took the Deputy Prime Minister to speak to housing groups and there was discussion in relation to the need for provision of emergency housing. That is not because there is no growth in Cairns, but because there is so much rapid growth in Cairns which puts pressure on existing housing. The promise of jobs and the climate brings people to the Far North and that creates a problem in relation to emergency housing. That problem was raised with the Deputy Prime Minister.

I hope that the government, through the Deputy Prime Minister's department and in conjunction with state and local governments, will set in place some sort of solution to that problem. These are the sorts of problems that this government is addressing. These are the sorts of things that the government is aware of and is doing something about.

We do not hear anything about these sorts of issues from the so-called shadow minister for local government, Senator Macdonald. He is not talking about the need for infrastructure. He is not talking to local councils. He just goes through the electorate creating scare campaigns about this government. Of course, Senator Macdonald was the one who let the cat out of the bag in the election campaign about the GST and rates. It is amazing that he was reappointed as shadow minister for local government. I suppose as long as Senator Macdonald is in that position local government will still have the fear of extra taxation from a coalition government.

In conclusion, the coalition has no policies. It has no policies nationally and it has no policies relevant to my electorate. All the coalition wants to do is cause a new election by any means, fair or foul. That is its real agenda; that is what it wants. The coalition figures that it can apply its unprincipled policies in this place when it has no revenue policies of its own. All it can do is oppose the government's budget strategy in the hope that somehow it will convince the Greens to line up with the coalition in the Senate and provide it with a new election. That is its real agenda. That is totally unprincipled and totally outside the principles that have been espoused previously by the Liberal Party. That is why Malcolm Fraser thinks the current coalition does not have the right policies and obviously that is why frontbencher Senator Vanstone thinks the same thing. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan Ms J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I listened earlier to the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott), I could not help thinking what else I would have to hear before my ears dropped off. This budget was born in arrogant stupidity and nurtured in mendacity and bluster, and it is becoming a symbol of ineptitude and cowardice. It is devoid of long-term economic sense and vision, of incentive for the private sector and of compassion for the victims of this government's mismanagement. It is, in short, the logical culmination of this government's policy. The government is trying to defy Abraham Lincoln's advice and fool all of the people all of the time by advancing the threadbare defence that it has put forward a painful but economically responsible budget that will promote economic recovery.

PARA.TAB: Australians are not fools, any more than the international markets that have driven down the dollar are. People in Pearce who did not vote for the coalition in the March election are telling me that this budget stinks. They are not saying this just because their families will be worse off. This is a budget of quick fixes, bribing perceived marginal voters with tax cuts while ignoring the deep-seated problems of this economy. It is the response of a government that deceived its way into office, that has lost the plot and lost its sense of purpose.

The dollar is not falling because the opposition is being obstructive and the future of the budget is in doubt. Financial markets have no particular attachment to the slipshod and regressive budget that is being brought down. Instead, they are reacting to the smell of death pervading this government and its failure to act against our national indebtedness. The tactic of blaming the opposition has about as much credibility as the drunk driver blaming the gatepost that supposedly jumped out at him as he ran off the road.

This budget fails the fundamental test of reducing Commonwealth expenditure. We are led to believe that a deficit increased from $14.5 billion to $16 billion, with spending in real terms up by 3.9 per cent, is decent and responsible. I ask: is that decent and responsible? If we are to achieve a budget deficit of one per cent of GDP by 1996-97, projected spending cuts will have to reach $9 billion. So far we are looking at only a $1.9 billion deficit reduction. Worse still, this will be offset by the $2 billion cost of 1993 election promises. We have a tax-and-spend Labor regime running true to form and running out of options.

This is a government which since winning office has raised its own revenue by 30 per cent and cut revenue share to other levels of government by 22 per cent. This is not merely profligate, but advances the Labor centralist agenda at the same time. This is a government that has presided over a rise in overseas debt from $2,300 per head to $12,000 for every Australian. This is a government that has let public sector debt per head increase 400 per cent from $1,000 to $5,000 per head, while for the first time the rate of national savings fell into the negative in 1991-92. The markets have now found out that a tin-pot emperor has no clothes. The post-budget fall in the dollar has the effect of adding another $5 billion to our accumulated foreign debt, rising an extra $275 per head.

In practical and immediate terms, this means increased business input costs through higher priced imports, costs that the government hopes business will absorb in these recessionary times without adding to inflation. Maybe this will indeed happen, but at the expense of business investment and jobs which this country critically needs. Company tax cuts for business must now be offset against the fact that half of the $3.6 billion extra taken in sales tax will be levied on business inputs. When we add this to the fact that half the $4 billion grabbed in the new fuel levy will fall on businesses, we can be assured that this Labor government has already substantially clawed back its $5.6 billion company tax concession.

This is the workers' Labor government that has taken the public sector share of outlays to 39 per cent in 1991, up from 34 per cent in 1980 and 25 per cent in 1970. A government sometimes criticised for being too deregulatory, in 1991 excelled itself by adding 6,905 pages of legislation in 2,116 acts to the statute books. This is almost as many pages of statute as the 7,544 pages passed in the decade 1960 to 1969. Perhaps legislative activity rises as national prosperity declines.

Business people trying to survive and prosper under this government find this claim extraordinary as they struggle in the straitjacket that gets tighter each year. Business bashing has become a reflex action for this government and its bureaucratic advisers. The proposed application of the fringe benefits tax to domestic business travel in excess of reasonable limits forces the private sector to conform with limits applying to public servants. Why should private sector executives whose jobs depend on their performance be forced to conform to the standards of their securely tenured public sector counterparts?

What does this government care about the increased compliance cost forced on firms to substantiate the reasonable limit? Why should such sordid, practical details intrude into the world of our Labor decision makers? The attitude of this Labor government towards business in general is clear to see. This budget has visited a special animus against one particular industry, composed generally of smaller family enterprises. Wine producers in the Pearce electorate are wondering why they are being penalised through a 55 per cent sales tax rise, a rise conservatively translating into a nine per cent retail price increase. It is a matter of conjecture as to why this government confuses apples with oranges and draws false comparisons between wine production and that of beer and spirits. It is sheer, simple-minded greed that if an industry is doing well it should pay more tax.

Whether the motivation was malice or stupidity, Australian wineries, 700 of them, and 15,000 employees of the industry, are set to pay the price. This is an industry where the number of small producers in the last decade has increased from 300 to 700, contributing their share of exports and more than their share of attracting tourism. This government does not know or care.

Inevitably the 25 per cent export component of the wine market will suffer along with the 75 per cent domestic share that has provided the floor under its past expansion. In this last financial year wine exports earned $290 million for Australia, with the volume of exports in real terms rising by 130 per cent in the last four years. The industry achieved excellence and carved out its two per cent share of the world trade, and must now be taxed at three times the rate of its main competitors in France and California.

This irresponsible government rhetoric does not match action to foster healthy export industries. If this government persists in its folly, then it remains for another place—denounced by this Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last year as `unrepresentative swill'—to make a stand for elementary justice and economic good sense.

While I have stated that this government is anti-business, it is equally uncaring as to the effects of its policies on ordinary Australians generally, those whose living standards have continued to fall. Since 1982-83 the cost of such basic items as food and clothing has risen ahead of the average weekly earnings. Real household disposable income has fallen, and the average of household mortgages has risen while real average earnings have declined.

While national indebtedness can seem remote from the needs and everyday concerns of people, it is a fact that the real personal debt in Labor's decade of power has risen from $70 billion to $120 billion. This reflects not only the cost of mortgages but also the fact that more and more Australians have gone into debt to survive. The household savings ratio has declined as well from 9.5 per cent to 6.5 per cent.

While all Australians are going to pay more tax at the petrol pump, this extra slug is the culmination of a 75 per cent rise in fuel prices in the last decade caused by a government thirsty for easy revenue from an inelastic source. Road transport in Australia is a necessity of life, making a nonsense of this government's boast that we have low prices by international standards. This is once again comparing apples with oranges. It is essential for the broadacre farms in the Pearce electorate, for private motor vehicle owners, for people in rural shires, and for those living in the outer suburbs of Forrestfield and Swan View who cannot possibly rely on public transport for work and family needs.

Despite the compromise forced on the government to reduce the punitive surcharge on leaded fuel used disproportionately by poorer Australians, we remain saddled with a destructive and essentially regressive tax hike. This government taxes petrol because it knows that businesses and families have no choice but to fill the tank, guaranteeing the instant revenue to pay for electoral bribes. The effect on such irrelevancies as export industries and household budgets need not concern them.

Elderly Australians, over 8,000 of whom live in Pearce, have received particularly cavalier treatment from this Labor government since its election. The pledge to remove all pensioners from the tax system, irresponsible as it may have been, was dropped without consultation, and now the promises for dental care and the seniors' health care card—that useful coalition initiative—have been deferred until next year.

It has taken the adverse post-budget reaction for the government to finally acknowledge the blatant injustice of treating unrealised capital gains on shares as income for aged pensioners. Making the change prospective is only a step in the right direction, but it is still upholding the fiction that paper fluctuations constitute income and effectively precludes retirees from a prudent and effective form of savings. The repentance of the government has come too late for those retired people in Pearce who felt that they could not take the risk of sudden income loss and sold their shares. Australia will miss these small investors, even if the government does not.

While in some areas since the budget the government has been forced to concede a measure of justice, in one vital area of social and economic life it is preparing to subvert business profitability and trample on the rights of employees. Projected changes in the field of industrial relations demonstrate economic irresponsibility, moral cowardice and total subservience to the ACTU. Perhaps it was too much to expect that a Labor government was capable of industrial relations reform, bearing in mind that much of our current economic dislocation is a direct consequence of the failure of the Hawke government to complement financial deregulation, including the floating of the Australian dollar, with freedom of choice in the labour market. This is, after all, the government that diverts $20 million of taxpayers' money to unions and is rewarded by the efforts of paid union officials in marginal seats at the last election.

We now have a Prime Minister who is prepared to spit on the 70 per cent of employees who are not union members by denying them their right to enterprise bargaining unless they become unionised. It remains to be seen whether this craven surrender to the ACTU will allow genuine enterprise unions or whether the quest for a small number of bureaucratic union conglomerates will continue.

Australian business, employees, the retired and the 400,000 long-term unemployed have gained nothing from this government's budget. It has to be recognised that we are not witnessing a few failures of judgment; we are witnessing the conclusion of a total failure of vision, commonsense and genuine compassion. For the life of me I cannot understand how the Prime Minister can get up and boast about this country's low inflation rate. He quite forgets to inform the Australian public that our near trading nation, Japan, has an inflation rate of 0.7 per cent and a business interest rate of 5.46 per cent.

I would like whoever is listening today to take note of the relativity between the inflation rate and the business interest rate because in Australia the same figures come out like this: yes, we do have an inflation rate of 1.4 per cent, but we are still charging our small business and micro-business sector, many of whom are run by families in this country, an interest rate of 11.25 per cent. It is the relativity that the Prime Minister forgets to tell the Australian people about.

But the Prime Minister boasts about many of his achievements, leaving the Australian electorate speechless. Let me quote some of the things we have all heard over the last few years. In March 1990 the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: We won't let there be a recession.
And in November 1990 he said:
This is a recession Australia had to have . . . I knew there had to be one but I didn't want to tell you.
In February 1992 he said:
. . . if we cannot make 4 per cent growth a year the whole lot of us ought to give it away.
I wonder why the government has not done that, quite frankly, because it has done nothing. In January 1990 he said:
In three years' time there will be no government debt, domestic or external. It's an enormous claim that I can make on behalf of the Government of Australia.
In 1987 he said:
This is the great coming of age of Australia. This is the golden age of economic change.
In 1988 he said:
This is the one which brings home the bacon.
In 1977 he said:
What a politician needs is shrewdness, cynicism, cunning—and a lot of nerve.
I am sure that a lot of Australian voters can really relate to that. He eclipsed it all in 1990 to tell the Australian people:
I am the Placido Domingo of Australian politics.

I think that is an insult to Placido Domingo. If the Prime Minister and the Treasurer had been born 100 years ago they may well have had a very different career. They would have made a great duo as a travelling medicine show—the snake oil salesmen that roll into town on their wagons filled with their cure oils and their placebos, offering it to the ordinary folk to cure all their ills. When they have sold their useless cargo they leave town laughing with their pockets lined with the hard-earned cash of the townsfolk. The next day the people realise they have been duped. The snake oil remedy not only does not cure their present ills but also has given them a dreadful pain in the stomach that they cannot get rid of.

PARA.TAB: The Australian public have been fed this useless rhetoric for too long. If this government has any conscious at all, it will take an honest, fresh look at the regressive budget measures it proposes to bring down. It will stop the nonsense of building egos and start the real work of rebuilding Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the dust settles on the debate which has raged on certain items in the budget in this House and in another place I believe it will become increasingly apparent to all Australians and, indeed, to the opposition that this is one of the most significant and important budgets that the government has delivered for the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The goals of the government are quite clearly stated in the budget documents. The government aims for sustained economic growth that will provide Australians with the jobs so desperately needed in the future. Alongside that, the government will pursue social equity considerations by providing good health, good education and a good environment for all Australians.

The budget is important for two reasons. The first and most important reason is that it sets a minimum term fiscal strategy that will provide the best framework for business investment, for long-term economic growth and the creation of full-time employment in Australia. Secondly, the budget delivers on over 100 promises made to the Australian population by the government in the course of the election campaign. This is certainly important to maintaining confidence in government and, indeed, in the political process.

In meeting its election commitments, the government has introduced measures to extend child care to Australians, to improve the health system, to reduce the taxation burden on middle Australians and to expand their access to education and training opportunities.

This budget is a landmark budget in the sense that it will have a positive impact on regional centres such as Geelong, the city that I represent in this parliament, and on regional development throughout Australia. It will do this because it provides an overall economic framework in which small, medium and large business can expand and grow. It will provide in the regions an important short-term stimulus to economic activity through the tax cuts and it will continue to provide training and infrastructure expenditure to build the economic base of the regions.

The honourable member for Pearce (Ms Moylan), who preceded me in this debate, talked about relativities. She compared the Australian economy with that of Japan. She should have mentioned the word `selective', because that is exactly what she has been. She omitted to compare Australia across the board with its major trading partners to get a more accurate picture of how Australia is situated in the world trading community.

The economic factors have been canvassed significantly by previous speakers in the appropriations debate. Interest rates are an important cost to business and we have seen them plummet over the last five years. In the housing sector, which is one of the motor sectors in the Australian economy, we have the lowest interest rates for years. The housing affordability index is strategically situated for low and middle income earning families.

We have a favourable climate for interest rates. That applies as well to the inflation rate. It is projected to be some 3 1/2 per cent in 1993-94—it is the lowest that it has been in three decades—providing a significant competitive advantage to Australian business. The inflation rate is also among the lowest in the OECD countries. This government can take great pride in that. This government has been the only government in the postwar era that has been able to achieve the low levels of inflation that are now locked in and will sustain businesses in their competitive position throughout the rest of this century.

Economic growth is not as high as we would like it to be, but it is projected to exceed some three per cent in the second half of the year. Honourable members opposite ought to appreciate that growth in the Australian economy has fared extremely well in a very competitive international environment. The Australian economy is projected to be one of the leaders in the economic growth stakes in the next three years.

For business, we have lowered the corporate tax rate to 33c in the dollar, and we have provided to research and development a range of investment allowances and incentives that will be critical to the development of new products and innovative technology that will form the backbone of business development in years to come.

Overall, the tax burden as a percentage of GDP is among the lowest in the OECD countries. That is the sort of relativity that we ought to be looking at, not a selective relativity. We should not compare Australia selectively with one country such as Japan but with those nations in the world that are our trading competitors. When we do that, Australia comes out extremely well.

Industrial disputation is the lowest it has been for years. We have provided a flexible industrial relations structure in which genuine enterprise bargaining can take place. We have not ripped apart the fabric of Australia's industrial structure. That would have happened had the coalition been sitting on this side of the House instead of remaining in opposition.

There has been a virtual revolution in the export of elaborately transformed manufactures and that is set to continue during this decade. Many words have been spoken in this House about the developments in that export area, especially the development in the export of elaborately transformed manufactures. A virtual revolution has taken place and it is not understood enough by other governments at local and state level, in the business community and in the Australian community at large. However, as a government, we have been able to engineer a substantial reorientation of the Australian economy, with compassion and without the severe disruption that has beset other comparable economies.

With regard to personal taxation, the government has continued to provide tax relief for middle Australia. The $2 billion stimulus in tax cuts in this budget will certainly provide a much needed stimulus to small and medium businesses in regional and metropolitan communities. We have also seen a return of company profitability to the levels that were enjoyed in 1989.

All of these economic factors are significant. The presence of high unemployment or a high deficit current account are not burdens that should weigh us down unduly. While they are problems to be tackled with all the resourcefulness and ingenuity that we can bring to bear, we should look to the positive developments in the structure of the Australian economy and how well it is situated to create jobs over the course of this century.

I have outlined the overall economic framework in which regional businesses will operate over the next year or so. I turn my attention now to the positive way in which the budget will impact on regional economies because the expansion of existing small and medium businesses, the growth of new enterprises and the development of new innovative technology on the back of the comparative strength of these regions will be critical to job creation in the future.

In my electorate, whenever I talk about the great developments that have occurred in the Australian economy, I am asked some legitimate questions, such as where the new jobs will come from. If we analyse the economic structure of some of our regional communities, the answer is self-evident. I am pleased to say that in this budget the government has recognised that and targeted its programs extremely well in order to meet the needs of the sector that will carry our economy into the year 2000.

I suggest to honourable members that large job growth will not be found in the larger firms and businesses because they have become extremely efficient and have improved their productive capacity without taking on additional units of labour. The job growth will not really come from the public sector either.In my own community local government amalgamation will see some 350 jobs disappear. At the state government level—in Geelong, for instance—the Kennett government has really ripped the guts out of the state public sector. We cannot hope for a return to any sort of job growth there.

As far as the federal government is concerned, we have done what we can with our available resources to improve job opportunities in Geelong. The location of the teleline facility, which belongs to the Department of Social Security, and the expansion of the Australian Taxation Office have both provided public sector employment via the federal government. We have pumped money into infrastructure development. We have continued to provide training and education expenditure to improve the skills of the local work force and expand its participation in the economy.

So where will the jobs come from? They will come from the small and medium enterprises that are already in existence and from the innovative technology that will form the backbone of the new businesses that will be created. Recently in my electorate two very innovative products came to my attention. While the businesses involved in those products are struggling to meet the point of commercialisation, they offer great opportunities for Geelong. I refer to the Gearing Dynamics oil immersed braking system, which is a revolutionary brake technology with widespread application to the motor vehicle and other industries.

Recently, a young gentleman walked through my door with an innovative piece of software which he had successfully sold in the United Kingdom. He wants to establish his particular business in the great regional centre of Geelong, developing the software technology, and managing production and distribution of the product. He is having some difficulty doing that, even though not a large amount of capital is required to bounce the ball. That points to one of the problems that small enterprises have in these regions, namely, getting access to capital to develop their businesses. Both of the enterprises I have referred to offer great prospects for the development of job opportunities in the region. It must be the resolve and objective of the community to ensure that all the necessary support is provided to make sure that these enterprises see the light of day.

In recent years many factors have affected the development of the Geelong economy. Firstly, the Geelong economy has seen massive restructuring not only in its key industries—the textile, clothing and footwear industry and the motor vehicle industry—but in the manufacturing sector generally. I am pleased to say that some of the larger firms in those sectors recently increased the number of people they employ. Godfrey Hirst has been actively involved in developing export opportunities in Asia and elsewhere in the world, and over 150 employees have been taken on over a period of months. That company is successfully doing what the government set out as an objective for that particular industry.

Only last week in the motor vehicle industry Ford announced the creation of 50 additional jobs. Another factor which has affected the growth of the Geelong economy has been the lack of domestic demand, which has impacted fairly significantly on small and medium business. We have seen the effects of the international recession and the collapse of financial institutions, the problems associated with capital formation in this particular city and the declining confidence which is very similar to that which has occurred in other regional economies.

However, in this budget the government has crafted a very neat and well targeted set of programs to stimulate more small and medium enterprises into entering the export ring. There are enormous spin-offs for those firms that seek to expand their activities—the prospect of greater production runs; the achievement of economies of scale; greater productive capacity utilisation—which all lead to the lowering of costs, which in turn improves the competitive position of those enterprises. In addition, there is the discipline of producing quality products for demanding export markets which will stand those companies in good stead in the domestic markets into which they currently sell. Also, the energy and commitment of employees is unleashed when a company involves itself beyond its region, state and nation and successfully climbs into the global export ring.

The initiatives announced in the budget focus on three specific areas. They provide coordinated services to strengthen the skill and the knowledge base of the small and medium enterprises. I am pleased that the government has provided in the budget for a significant expansion of NEIS. I agree wholeheartedly with the concept of the first stop shops and I congratulate the minister concerned for this particular innovation.

It is very important that small and medium enterprises gain access to relevant and correct information and that a range of services be available in that one locality. That way time and effort are not consumed by enterprises doing the rounds of the bureaucracy, trying to discover which program fits their particular circumstance. I am particularly pleased that the government has provided for a national exporter education centre. We should not underestimate the value of export education in changing the culture of business in this community.

I am also pleased that the government has provided assistance to exporters. We will see faster payments occurring under the export market development grants scheme, increased funding for the international trade enhancement scheme and the expansion of the export access program. The strategic measures that have been taken also relate to a more aggressive market Australia campaign in these areas. The budget has provided a very significant amount of $94 million to assist small and medium enterprises over the next three years get into the export ring, strengthen the backbones of their business and provide and create greater job opportunities.

In conclusion, I make some comments on the developments taking place in the regional policy development area. Quite recently, we had the publication of the draft report of the Industry Commission. As a general overview, there are some worthwhile recommendations in that report. However, I am critical of the report for several reasons: the weakness of its system of public consultation is very much exposed in the nature of the recommendations that the commission has made. Indeed, when people from the commission came to Geelong, they visited the Gordon Technical College, the Geelong Regional Commission and the Vehicle Builders Union. That is hardly going to give them an accurate impression of what is happening on the ground in Geelong.

I see that the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) has walked into the chamber. I believe he made a constructive submission to that particular inquiry; dry as it may well have been, he did make a contribution. I know he is interested in getting the Geelong economy moving, as I am.

The Industry Commission draft report has several limitations. I think one of the great limitations of this draft report is the undue emphasis in its recommendations on labour market adjustment as a significant and central impediment to regional adjustment and its failure to really address some of the fundamental impediments to adjustments and growth in regional areas. I refer to some of the cultural obstacles in these regional communities that impede the development process and also the issue of the availability of capital. I think that there were only two pages in the report devoted to the critical issue of the expansion of existing business and the development of new business in our locality. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been an interesting six weeks since the budget was first introduced into the House by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). We have seen an enormous number of changes. We have not seen the changes that the people of Australia are crying out for and demanding. They are not just crying out for them and demanding them in the electorates that are represented by coalition members, they are also crying out and demanding these changes within the electorates of government members. Government members know that. It was interesting to listen to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor), touch on regional development and what government can and is doing to encourage regional development. I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, this 1993 budget of betrayal is going to do nothing for regional development in my electorate.

PARA.TAB: My electorate is one based on a large retired population, primary industry and the tourism industry. Tourism revolves around domestic travel by cars that use fuel, both unleaded and leaded, of which the budget is going to increase the cost. My electorate also revolves around the accommodation industry which will be affected by the increase in the FBT contained in the budget. A boutique winery in my electorate is going to be seriously affected by the wine tax in this budget.

If the Treasurer really thinks that the economy is ticking along, he should hop in his car and drive up to the mid-north coast of New South Wales, having paid an inflated price for petrol following the introduction of the budget on 17 August. I might add that it is not known whether or not that is legal yet, because the bills have not been passed and have not gained royal assent. When he gets to the mid-north coast, he might stay in hotel or motel accommodation and pay the extra tariffs resulting from the new taxation measures. He might go and buy some wine at the local winery and pay the increased cost on that.

I noticed even in the parliamentary shop that we are paying increased tax. We should not be exempt, but that was something that I noticed this afternoon when I was buying some parliamentary label wine for my constituents. The increased tax is on now. The bill has not gone through the Senate, it does not have the Governor-General's signature; is it legal? I put that before the House.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I put it to you that the Treasurer does not know what is happening in the real world. He and his Canberra bureaucrats walk out of this place in the evening, drive down the wide, leafy streets to their perfectly planned suburbia and think that Australia is going along nicely, thank you. I have some statistics here that may open the Treasurer's eyes a little. This is a brief comparison between some of the demographic changes that have taken place in Canberra and my electorate of Lyne. The median family income in Canberra is $50,300; in Lyne, it is $23,690. Families with an annual income below $16,000 in Canberra—bearing in mind that Canberra is a much bigger place than my electorate of Lyne—total 2,018; in Lyne, there are 8,000 families with incomes below $16,000.
