Families with an annual income above $60,000 total 10,482 in Canberra; in the electorate of Lyne, there are 1,977.

The most interesting, damning and indictable statistic of this government, which has been in power in excess of 10 years, is the unemployment rate. In Canberra, it is 6.2 per cent; in the electorate of Lyne, it is 15.9 per cent. I will refer later in my address to the opening comments the Treasurer made on the night that he tabled his budget for 1993 in this House.It is appalling to think that a Labor government, supposedly founded on the basis of equality for all, can create such an uneven and inequitable balance between two areas only eight hours apart by car. I speak of the cocoon of Canberra and my electorate in regional Australia.

It is now six weeks since the budget was delivered on 17 August by the Treasurer. It remains entangled in controversy and turmoil. This is all of the government's own making. It can blame opposition members all it likes about what we are doing to oppose those tax increases, but the government can very easily fix it by unlinking those tax measures from the rest of the deficit reduction bills. The tax breaks that have been promised to the people of Australia will be passed immediately; the new tax implementation measures will not be. We are going to oppose those. The people of Australia did not vote for those tax increases in the election in March this year and they demand that they be opposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —They've got no mandate.

—They have absolutely no mandate. The people of Australia know that there is no point in the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) standing at the dispatch box, day in and day out, claiming they have the mandate; playing the Australian people like fools. The Australian people are not fools; they did not give the government a mandate to introduce these measures; they know it and the government will not convince them.

PARA.TAB: The Treasurer asserted that the budget was non-negotiable. The Treasurer asserted that the legality of the omnibus bill was beyond question. The Treasurer has not had a very good seven weeks. The legality of the omnibus bill has already been shown to be questionable—not by opposition senators, but by government senators. They did not agree that it was constitutional. They said that it was questionable. That is why the government has changed its taxation bills to create the eight bills now before the Senate.

In an attempt to play political bullyboy, the Treasurer remains pig-headed in linking bills with the new bills, Nos 1 and 2, which also look to be unconstitutional under section 55 of the constitution. The budget has also proven to be negotiable. The Treasurer said it was non-negotiable. The coalition parties are the only parties to make clear their position publicly in blocking certain unfair measures of the government.

The Treasurer has been forced behind closed doors to wine, dine—but still call asinine—three ladies of the Senate: Senators Kernot, Chamarette and Margetts. So we have seen the Treasurer back down and show us that, despite all of his hot air, the budget is negotiable. To top it all off, the Treasurer's budget has also been universally labelled as an unfair budget. That is something that I would have expected the Labor Party to pride itself on never being labelled. Yet hundreds of people have come out of the Labor Party closet and damned this budget as a joke. I want to put a few of these people on the record. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later hour.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Motion (by Mr Crean) agreed to:
That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Tuesday, 5 October 1993, at 2 p.m.
Bill presented by Mr Crean, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: There are eight bills in the Government's package of wool industry legislation. In introducing these bills to the House, I am confident that they will provide the statutory framework for a much stronger and commercially driven Australian wool industry. I believe the wool industry's long-term future as the supplier of a high quality premier textile fibre to world markets will be secured only if we fundamentally change the industry's structures to provide a more market driven approach that is more closely attuned to the needs of its customers and its end users.

PARA.TAB: I consider both the food and natural fibre industries as presenting the most exciting development opportunities for this country, with the potential to substantially increase value adding exports and the jobs that go with such developments. We already have in place a strategy for development of the food industries through the work of the Agrifood Council, and the legislation I am introducing today will also provide the foundation for the wool industry to also grow and prosper.

In March 1993, I made an election commitment that I would commission an independent review of the role of the wool industry structures. One of my first actions upon being returned to government was to establish a review committee to achieve this. The committee, comprising Professor Ross Garnaut, Mr Rodney Price and Mr Stephen Bennett, brought an extensive background in wool industry, economics, trade, business, finance and marketing expertise to the review and presented a comprehensive blueprint for securing the future of the wool industry. It reported in August of this year.

Upon receiving the Wool Industry Review Committee's report, I initiated wide ranging consultations with all sectors of the industry and modified the committee's recommendations to account for some legitimate industry concerns. I have, however, maintained the integrity of the committee's package in the legislation which I am presenting tonight.

The Wool International Bill 1993 establishes a new, strongly commercially oriented organisation called Wool International, which will assume responsibility for discharging the $2.28 billion debt and disposing of the 3.9 million bale stockpile which is currently held by the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. It will also be responsible for the development for the industry of a range of forward selling, marketing and risk management mechanisms to provide a broader range of options for wool producers and others in the industry to market their product and to manage risk.

The Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Bill 1993 will establish a new Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation which will be responsible for generic wool promotion and wool research and development.The Wool Legislation (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1993 will repeal the three acts—namely, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991, the Australian Wool Corporation Act 1991 and the Australian Wool Industry Council Act 1991—on which the current wool industry arrangements are based. It amends the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 to remove provisions relating to wool research and development, which will now be encompassed within this new package of legislation. It also amends the Wool Tax (Administration) Act 1964 to require the provision of additional information concerning wool which is tax paid.
The last five bills in the package each amend one of the five wool tax acts to reflect changes in setting wool tax rates necessary with the new industry structures.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation reflects an integrated package of measures, and essentially these provide a three-pronged strategy for the wool industry, which are designed to:
.establish industry bodies with a clear commercial focus;

PARA.TAB: .establish new mechanisms for marketing wool; and

SPEECH.PARA: .expand international trade in wool and wool products through the establishment of an Australian trade and investment package.

This new approach gives a greater emphasis on building demand, promoting quality and reliability to our customers and providing new marketing tools to spread market risk and to develop new markets, not only in the growing markets of Asia, but also in our more traditional European markets.

PARA.TAB: This package represents a watershed in the development of the Australian wool industry because it establishes the means for enabling the industry to take more direct control over its own destiny. As such, it represents a critical step forward towards self-determination and independence for the future. It will see wool producers becoming key shareholders in their own wool marketing company—Wool International—supported by a professionally and commercially oriented generic promotion and research organisation, whose activities will be closely linked to those of Wool International to ensure complementarity and full exploitation of market opportunities.

The structures embodied in this package reflect, on the one hand, the commercial thrust the government sees for the industry in the future and, on the other hand, the package reflects the government's continuing commitments to wool industry research and development and, through its maintenance of wool tax legislation, the funding of promotion.

Perhaps the most exciting element of the government's proposed measures is the establishment of Wool International. Within it is embodied a mechanism for effectively reducing the wool stockpile to commercial levels—giving producers equity in any residual value, including all wool and non-wool assets once the associated debt has been acquitted—and largely removing the government from much of its involvement in industry affairs.

Wool International is established at the outset as a statutory authority with the intention that it be first corporatised and then privatised by a target date of 1 July 1997. This is a departure from the recommendations of the Wool Industry Review Committee, which were that Wool International be established as a 100 per cent government-owned company until privatisation.

The reason that the government has decided on a three-phased approach rather than two is because it received legal advice that it would be difficult to move directly to a government-owned corporation. Relevant considerations included the extent of the debt that Wool International would have to initially take on and the practical difficulties of achieving corporatisation within a reasonable time frame. However, in framing the legislation for Wool International, particular care has been taken to reflect as far as possible the model for government business enterprises so as to ensure that the commerciality of such bodies is a feature of Wool International.

The Wool International Bill provides, at this stage, only the framework for the second phase in Wool International's life corporatisation. Legal advice on the complexity of these processes means that it is better to leave the detail relating to corporatisation and privatisation until closer to 1997. This represents, in the government's view, the more responsible approach. At the same time, by providing the framework, we are clearly signalling our broad intentions and our commitment to privatising Wool International.

Wool International's functions will include the development of alternative forward selling, marketing and risk management mechanisms to better enable industry participants to market their product, manage their cash flows and their risks. In the period leading up to privatisation, a key activity of Wool International will be to effectively manage and market the wool stockpile and to reduce the debt.

Because of the decisions taken in April this year by the government, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission is in a position where it is not required to sell any more wool during 1993-94 to meet its debt reduction schedule. It may however sell further wool if there is sufficient demand. A central element of the marketing of the stockpile under Wool International will be the imposition of a fixed sales schedule. This is central to the development of forward selling mechanisms and the establishment of wool futures and other commercial risk management tools. The government has decided, however, that the fixed schedule will not commence until 1 July 1994. Until that time, Wool International will be required to manage the stockpile in accordance with current policy.

I have indicated previously that the process of stockpile disposal will be a transparent one. The legislation clearly sets out, for all in the industry, exactly how much wool must be sold in any month or quarter. Although the Wool Industry Review Committee recommended that Wool International be required to release five kilotons per month a fixed quantity of wool between 1 November 1993 to 30 June 1994 and then 33 kilotons per quarter from 1 July 1994 to 30 June 1997, the government has delayed the introduction of the fixed schedule to 1 July 1994.

In deciding to delay the introduction of the fixed schedule to 1 July 1994, the government was concerned to honour its existing commitments regarding stockpile disposal, which apply until 1 July 1994, and to allow more time for the development of forward selling and risk management tools by Wool International. The introduction of a fixed schedule is central to the development of such tools and it is prudent to allow the additional time for this to occur.

From July 1994 until December 1994, the fixed disposal rate is to be within a narrow range around five kilotons per month. In commercial terms, this translates into the range of 27,700 to 29,100 bales per month. The narrow range has been introduced purely for practical reasons. From 1 January 1995, the disposal rate is to be in the narrow range around 33 kilotons per quarter, or 182,000 to 192,000 bales. These ranges represent around five per cent of each of the relevant target rates of 28,400 per month and 187,000 per quarter.

Wool International will be required to make a public statement monthly and then quarterly on its compliance against the disposal schedule for that month or quarter. This is expected to be a very simple statement although Wool International will have the opportunity to report more fully to industry should it decide on commercial grounds that it should do so. Wool International will not be required to report in detail on its activities in relation to stockpile management. It is intended to be a commercially oriented body and its commercial activities will be treated accordingly. Nonetheless, a confidential and regular reporting process will be required of Wool International by government on its disposal activities and its debt management activities generally while ever the government guarantee is in place. These reports will set out how the disposal schedule has been achieved in the relevant period and how revenue has been utilised. This will also provide government with an ongoing view of the body's debt profile and ensure its operations accord with its charter.

During the period between now and July 1994, the government expects Wool International to make significant progress in setting up forward selling and risk management mechanisms for the industry. We appreciate that this will take time; however, the government believes that Wool International should be well advanced in this process by the time the fixed disposal schedule commences. During this period also, Wool International will be able to undertake other activities on a commercial basis. In this context, the government is well aware of the importance of market intelligence and reporting to the industry and, having yet to settle how industry can best undertake these activities in the future, a savings provision has been included in this bill to enable Wool International to continue to perform this Australian Wool Corporation function until 30 June 1994.

Prior to privatisation, Wool International will primarily be a selling organisation. The government does not intend that it be a day-to-day trader in the marketplace. Neither is it to be a speculator. I will be issuing instructions to the board of Wool International that it develops Wool International's selling strategies specifically to meet its requirements under the fixed disposal schedule. The buy-in power would only be used in specific circumstances to meet the legislative requirements of the disposal schedule set out in the act.

With regard to the non-wool assets of the industry, the new board of Wool International will have the power to dispose of these should it decide it commercially prudent to do so. On the same basis, such assets may well be retained so that on privatisation, a portfolio of non-wool assets complements the wool assets and the overall net worth of the organisation. In the interim, Wool International will be able to use the revenue stream from these non-wool assets for its commercial activities. This will potentially generate around $25 million per annum of seed capital for its developmental work. However the government expects that as Wool International develops its own revenues from its other commercial activities, the need to draw on these funds will be reduced. The government intends to review Wool International's use of the seed capital in two years time to determine the need for continued access to these funds. Wool International will be required to maintain and report to government on this funding separately.

The government will continue to guarantee the borrowings but will include the hedging activities of Wool International as these are related directly to the financial management of the stockpile. This arrangement will be through a statutory guarantee. The guarantee will not apply to any activities outside the stockpile management.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Determination of equity in Wool International

PARA.TAB: Producers' payment of the debt component of the wool tax from 1 July 1993 onwards will give them their equity entitlement in Wool International on privatisation. However, provision will also be made for producers to increase their debt repayment contribution up to a maximum 10 per cent should they wish to acquire additional equity in Wool International.

To establish the equity rights of producers to shares in Wool International, it will be required to keep a register of wool taxpayers. The register will become the share register of Wool International on privatisation. The register will record the details needed to assign such rights, and in future, wool tax payments will need to be accompanied by information on the wool taxpayer. Any unclaimed shares will be re-allocated proportionately to all eligible wool producers.

On privatisation, shares will be issued to wool taxpayers at zero value. Should they subsequently dispose of them they will be liable for capital gains tax. The rationale for this is that the initial tax payment is tax deductible. To allocate shares with an imputed market value would effectively confer on wool taxpayers a double taxation benefit. In respect of voluntary contributions up to 10 per cent of the sale value of wool, the expectation is that they would not be tax deductible and the value of the shares for capital gains tax purposes would be based on the value of the contributions made.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation

PARA.TAB: I will also be shortly introducing the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Bill 1993. This bill will implement the merger of research and promotion that wool producers agreed to at their last AGM and will continue Australia's close involvement in the generic promotion of wool.

I recognise that there may at times be slightly grey areas where the activities of Wool International and AWRAP may impinge on each other. However, I will be relying on the commonsense and business acumen of the boards. The majority of membership of each board will overlap to ensure that, while they each have quite distinct roles to fulfil, there is a close linkage between the two functions. In resolving any potential areas of conflict over functions I will be relying on the chairpersons to be guided by the underlying philosophy of the proposed new structures that as much as possible of the current functions of the Wool Corporation should be transferred to the private sector.

The members of the boards of Wool International and AWRAP will be the key to the success of this package. In my view it is important that the boards not be selected on the basis of representation but on the calibre of their expertise.

As I have already mentioned, the boards of AWRAP and Wool International will have a majority of common members. AWRAP will have nine members while Wool International will have 11 members. Consistent with the wool industry review committee's recommendation, there will be a commercial approach to the selection and appointment of the Wool International board and, because of the need for overlap in the boards and the need for appointments to be expertise based, there will no longer be a selection committee process for AWRAP. It is intended that the minister will appoint members after wide consultation with the business community and with industry groups, including the Wool Council of Australia.

Staff in the AWC and the AWRC will, in the first instance, become the staff of either AWRAP or Wool International on the establishment of those bodies. This will allow for some staff to be transferred between the two bodies if necessary to ensure the continuation of particular activities. Staff transferred over to the new bodies will be transferred on no lesser terms and conditions than existed prior to the restructuring. Thereafter, staffing matters will be the responsibility of the incoming boards.

The wool tax rate for debt management purposes is set out in the Wool International bill at 4.5 per cent and this rate will remain in place until privatisation. This will provide for Wool International to establish a net worth prior to privatisation. The rate cannot now be changed without amending the act.

Wool tax rates for promotion and research and development will be 3.5 per cent and 0.5 per cent respectively and will apply for three-year periods rather than the current single year. These rates will therefore apply for the period July 1994 to June 1997 unless changed by grower ballot during that period.

The maximum rate of wool tax will remain at 15 per cent to allow flexibility to increase the promotion and research and development components if the industry wishes to do so, and thereby not constrain the ability of growers in establishing appropriate rates for promotion and R&D through grower ballot.

In the process of making consequential amendments of an administrative nature to the wool tax acts, the government is tightening up on the collection process by requiring that all collectors of wool tax be registered in future. This will ensure that wool tax can only be paid on behalf of Australian wool producers by a registered collector. The change is an important one for the industry, particularly in the area of future individual equity rights in Wool International. Such equity rights are to accrue in proportion to wool tax paid for debt management and the process for assigning such rights will need to be as tight as possible.

The Australian Wool Industry Council was established to provide a forum for the provision of representative industry advice to the government. The need for such a body will be substantially diminished with the implementation of the proposed new arrangements. The new structures will provide the right communication linkages for the wool industry. Consistent with the Wool Industry Committee's recommendation, the Australian Wool Industry Council is therefore to be abolished.

This package of measures represents an exciting shift in wool industry arrangements and I am confident that it has within it the potential to revolutionise the way we regard our wool industry and the way it manages itself. I commend this bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ronaldson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN WOOL RESEARCH AND PROMOTION ORGANISATION BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Crean, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill establishes the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, AWRAP. I have already outlined how this particular bill fits into the total package of legislation for the wool industry. AWRAP will play a critical part in improving the performance of the Australian wool industry by encouraging the maximum possible coordination of the generic promotion of wool and wool products with research and development activities.

PARA.TAB: I have long held the view that R&D and promotion should be closely linked in order to get proper targeting of the R&D effort and promotion activity. This view is also supported by the wool industry at its last AGM and was subsequently endorsed by the Wool Industry Review Committee. The aim is to get a more commercially driven and consumer responsive approach to these activities and this legislation will give effect to this objective.

The legislation makes it quite clear that AWRAP's role is to direct the generic promotion dollar to where it will be most effective, including promoting the use of wool and wool products in Australia and overseas through consumer advertising coupled with the provision of technical advisory services in those markets which require assistance to develop and expand their wool processing industry, using Australian wool.

As well, it will assess research and development needs in relation to the wool industry, and provide funding for this purpose, and will disseminate and encourage the adoption of the results. There is clearly a strong link between the R&D and the promotion activities, and the government is pleased to be able to respond to the industry's request that the two functions should be merged.

Generic promotion for AWRAP is envisaged as promotion in its broadest sense and encompassing such activities as consumer advertising, the provision of technical advice and assistance to wool processors, manufacturers and retailers to encourage wool and wool blend product processing and innovation to meet consumer needs, and supporting wool trade marks such as the woolmark. Generic promotion will also encompass a range of international market development activities both of wool generally and Australian wool in particular where these latter activities are directly related to promotion and are directed to encouraging processors in developing markets to opt for Australian wool rather than other fibres.

In summary, AWRAP's activities might be defined as those which promote the use of wool over other fibres but do not extend to direct marketing or sale of wool. Selling wool will be clearly the function of Wool International and other commercial suppliers.

While the role of AWRAP is clearly focused on generic promotion, there is a need for this activity to be closely integrated with the advertising and brand promotion of companies promoting wool products. In the past, wool promotion funding has depended heavily on funds provided by woolgrowers and the government. This needs to change, and one of the principal goals of the new organisation will be to actively seek additional funding from commercial sources, principally wool processors and companies producing consumer wool products. I have made commitments to the industry that wool promotion will be adequately funded and the new structures provide the opportunity for this to be secured from commercial sources. For example, discussions are continuing with the International Wool Textile Organisation to assess its role in promotion funding.

AWRAP will be able to continue its participation in and fund international promotion activities of bodies such as the International Wool Secretariat, the IWS. The nature of, and level of funding for, such activities will be a matter for the AWRAP board, but the expectation is that Australia will continue to play a major role in influencing the policies and strategies of bodies such as the IWS.

While the activities of the Wool Research and Development Corporation will be transferred to AWRAP, the government recognises the success of the operational arrangements of that corporation. Therefore, the substructure of advisory and technical committees is expected to be maintained in the short term, although in the longer term this will be a matter for the AWRAP board to determine. The government will continue its matching of the research effort, the funding of which will be separately accounted for as part of the accountability arrangements to apply to the new organisation.

The government is also aware that, with the downturn in the wool industry and the reduced revenue base derived from the wool tax, it has been difficult to maintain the funding base for both R&D and promotion. In this context, the government is well aware of the difficulties faced by the research and development corporation in trying to accommodate the fluctuating revenue base whilst continuing to provide for ongoing research programs.

The creation of AWRAP will provide some relief in this respect. AWRAP will have borrowing powers which, should the AWRAP board choose, could be used as a short-term smoothing mechanism to alleviate some of the impact of wool tax income variability on suppliers of research services. The government has been encouraging greater commercialisation and comprehensive uptake of new technology and innovation by wool producers and processors. Increased commercialisation of R&D will not only assist in supporting the competitiveness of wool in the world's fibre markets; it will also provide a means of generating additional income for research and development purposes.

The promotion and research and development components of the wool tax will be determined through a ballot of producers, which may be conducted either independently of AWRAP annual general meetings, or in conjunction with them. The timing will be a matter for the board of AWRAP to determine. Provision has been made for the AWRAP board to formally consult the Wool Council of Australia regarding the appropriate rates of the promotion and research and development components of the wool tax to be put to a ballot of producers.

Annual general meetings will be continued for AWRAP only, although Wool International will be able to hold such meetings if decided by its board. The AWRAP AGM will provide the opportunity for wool producers to question the board of the organisation about the performance of its functions and, in the ultimate, provides the sanction of a vote of no confidence in the board. However, no provision has been made to take general motions from the floor of the meeting. There is no sense in such a process unless the outcome was to be binding on the board and that could, on occasions, be in clear conflict with the board's responsibilities under the act for the day-to-day direction of the organisation. Similar arrangements to those currently in place for the determination of voting rights will apply. However, the information needed to determine voting entitlements will, in future, be drawn by AWRAP from the share register to be maintained by Wool International. Upon privatisation of Wool International the register of wool tax payers will be passed to AWRAP.

AWRAP will be required to prepare both corporate and operational plans each year and is expected to widely consult with industry in doing so. The corporate plan will define principal goals, outline strategies and nominate performance indicators and must receive ministerial endorsement before coming into effect. The annual operational plan will detail the activities required to give effect to the matters set out in the corporate plan and must also be submitted to the minister.

Most of the proposed changes encompassed within the bills before the House can be implemented immediately. There are, however, two particular areas concerning the transfer of functions which have yet to be settled. These are quality assurance and shearer training. AWRAP is expected to have a very focused and concentrated approach to generic promotion and not be distracted by a wide range of other activities. It will therefore be an immediate task of the new AWRAP board to drive the process that will ensure the earliest and successful divestment of functions, particularly those concerning quality management.

To ensure that the transition is effectively made, and that there is no break in continuity in the performance of those functions, the legislation includes savings provisions, the effect of which is to enable AWRAP to continue to perform this function until an orderly transfer can be achieved. The savings provision will apply for no longer than the period to 31 December 1994.

The government is well aware of the importance of quality assurance to the future of the wool industry. Indeed it has been a strong advocate of the adoption by the industry of a quality management approach to marketing. It therefore has no intention of having the function taken from the Australian Wool Corporation without ensuring that there is a workable, effective arrangement in place for the function to be performed by other bodies.

The intention is to progressively hand over those functions identified for transfer from AWRAP to other bodies which the government, in consultation with AWRAP, deems can effectively take up particular responsibilities. This means we can ensure a smooth process of divestment from AWRAP, without dislocation of quality assurance, and our customers' ability to be reassured about the quality of our product.

The various alternatives will be carefully examined over the coming months during the transfer process. Without being definitive, the divestment process might include a role for the Australian Wool Exchange and the Australian Wool Testing Authority. It might also be possible, given the extent of standards already developed, that an Australian standard could be developed for woolpacks and that this be reflected in customs regulations replacing the current reference to the Wool Corporation's involvement.

I am confident that the wool industry can, utilising the standards currently in place and developing new ones, bring an industry wide response to building on and further developing Australia's already high global reputation for premium quality wool. Wool quality is an industry wide challenge and there are already examples of innovative responses which demonstrate that different sectors are prepared to meet quality goals to better differentiate their product in the marketplace and so attract buyer premiums.

Wool broking companies are already encouraging producers to distinguish their product by meeting predetermined quality standards in the shearing shed and I am aware of the work being done on this by Dalgety and Elders for example. Systems for wool testing in Australia are already regarded as the world's best. Shearer training has long been organised and funded by the Wool Corporation through the wool tax. The government is already working with the Wool Corporation and relevant training agencies to determine the most cost-effective approach for the future, given the particular nature of shearer training. There is the opportunity to bring shearer training into mainstream technical training approaches, such as through TAFEs, and to link it in an integrated way to quality assurance systems involving a better understanding of clip preparation for fine wools. I expect the industry to actively pursue these opportunities.

Finally, a savings provision has also been included to provide for the continuation of funding for exotic animal disease eradication programs which is to run through until mid-1995. In conclusion, with the creation of AWRAP there is the opportunity to better coordinate and commercially focus wool promotion and the R&D effort. The wool industry is facing a period where industry funds for promotion and R&D are at their lowest levels for some time. The more streamlined approach which AWRAP will bring to the industry will allow a better focus on achieving returns for the industry for the benefit of all participants. I commend this bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ronaldson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: WOOL LEGISLATION (REPEALS AND CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Crean, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to remove or amend existing wool legislation to allow for the introduction of new legislation to establish Wool International and the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation. This bill repeals the Australian Wool Corporation Act 1991, the Australian Wool Industry Council Act 1991 and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991 and sections of the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 relating to the Wool Research and Development Corporation.

PARA.TAB: The bill also provides for arrangements to cover the transitional period between the existing arrangements and the new arrangements, in particular to ensure that staff employed under the current structure retain their terms and conditions of employment, and benefits, under the new structure. I have indicated previously that a significant part of the move towards the wool industry commercialisation is the inclusion of a provision to give producers equity in Wool International. The mechanism for establishing the entitlements of producers to shares in Wool International on privatisation will require amendments to the Wool Tax Administration Act 1964. Wool brokers, dealers, exporters and manufacturers will be required within 6 months to provide details of tax payers to the Tax Commissioner who will be in turn required to pass these onto Wool International covering the period from 1 July 1993.

Other minor amendments to the Administration Act which have been made provide for greater uniformity in penalties and registration of wool tax collectors, and reduce the penalty for unpaid tax in line with reductions in tax related penalties in other Commonwealth legislation. I commend this bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum.

Bill presented by Mr Crean, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of these bills is to amend the existing wool tax acts to reflect changes to the wool tax arrangements flowing from changes to the statutory arrangements for the wool industry. Under the current arrangements, in determining the debt repayment component of the wool tax, the views of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission must be taken into account, together with any views expressed by the Wool Council of Australia. Similarly, in determining the wool tax rates to apply for promotion and research and development purposes, account must be taken of the recommendations of the annual general meetings of the Australian Wool Corporation and of the Wool Research and Development Corporation.

PARA.TAB: Under the new arrangements, the debt component of wool tax is a fixed rate of 4.5 per cent and is included in the Wool International Bill 1993. This will terminate when Wool International is privatised. For promotion and research and development tax rates, provision has been made in the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Bill 1993 that the wool tax rates will remain at their current level of 3.5 per cent and 0.5 per cent respectively unless a ballot of wool producers recommends a change. I commend these bills to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: ARTS, ENVIRONMENT AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of the Arts, Environment and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 is to make various minor improvements to the ACT self-government legislation, which are the result of a review of the legislation conducted by the ACT administration and my department in 1992, three years after selfgovernment. Possible more important changes are being examined and would be included in a separate bill at a later date.

PARA.TAB: The bill removes from the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 limitations on the powers of the Legislative Assembly and the executive of the territory that are no longer considered appropriate. For example, the assembly will be given power to decide how frequently it will meet; how laws passed by it will be notified to the public; and the level of remuneration of its members and the ministers and senior officers of the ACT government. This brings the ACT's degree of self-government closer to that of the Northern Territory.

The government had intended that the assembly should also be given power to determine the number of its members. However as the opposition and Democrats did not support this position and the bill needs to pass as soon as possible, the government agreed to an amendment in the Senate to remove this amendment from the bill. The government intends to continue negotiating towards a more acceptable solution at a later date.

The bill also amends the ACT self-government legislation to ensure that, during the transitional period before the ACT establishes its own public service, the Commonwealth's Comcare system applies to the ACT Fire Brigade and to Legislative Assembly members' staff, as well as other ACT government employees. The bill ensures that an eligible judge, when exercising the power issue search warrants under the enforcement provisions of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983, has the same immunity from legal action as a justice of the High Court has in proceedings in that court, and it makes various minor corrections and drafting improvements to other legislation.I present the revised explanatory memorandum to the bill and commend the bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH LEGISLATION (PROFESSIONAL SERVICES REVIEW) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Dr Theophanous, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill gives effect to the undertaking given in the budget to introduce new measures to combat overservicing in the Medicare program, including pharmaceutical benefits. The bill represents the first instalment in a series of measures that will be taken by the government to minimise abuse of Medicare. Further measures to deal with fraud and with audits, and to prevent double dipping by visiting medical officers against public hospitals and Medicare benefits, will be implemented progressively. Legislation for new fraud measures is expected to be introduced into the parliament by the end of the budget session.

PARA.TAB: The amendments to the Health Insurance Act outlined in this bill reflect the outcome of a close consultative process with the Australian Medical Association. The AMA has played a key role in the development of the new measures and, in so doing, has demonstrated that it takes seriously its expressed belief that it has a duty to cooperate in ensuring that the public resources earmarked for health care are appropriately utilised.

The new measures in this bill are necessary because the existing mechanisms for dealing with overservicing have come under question and have not been shown to be effective. The strengthened professional review process in this legislation should not concern the vast majority of practitioners. However, it should cause those practitioners who misuse or deliberately abuse the current benefits arrangements to reflect on their activities.

The review process is not to be invoked lightly. It is the government's intention that no practitioner will be subjected to the review process until he or she has been seen by a medical adviser of the Health Insurance Commission. The practitioner is to be advised of the commission's concerns about the practitioner's practice and given a chance to consider his or her position, which could include seeking the advice of his or her professional colleagues. Only if the practitioner's practice continues to cause concern will he or she be referred for review.

The Australian National Audit Office found in its Audit Report No. 17 1992-93, entitled Medifraud and excessive servicing: Health Insurance Commission, that medical services committees of inquiry, the current bodies responsible for dealing with excessive servicing, were not operating satisfactorily and needed to be strengthened. The ANAO concluded that specific action needed to be taken to deal adequately with gross levels of overservicing. One of the principal complaints about the existing mechanisms for dealing with overservicing has been that they do little to discourage the provision or initiation of excessive services. They are not effective deterrents because, in many instances, the level of benefits recovered from practitioners has been totally eclipsed by the level of overservicing actually engaged in.

A major factor in the inability to impose penalties commensurate with the extent of a practitioner's overservicing is the current lack of power to make decisions on the extent of overservicing on the basis of generalised evidence. At present judgments about overservicing can only be made on the basis of individual services, that is, recovery of benefits and the imposition of penalties can only be made in respect of each service separately determined to have been excessive. A further criticism of the current overservicing detection arrangements relates to delays in finalising cases, including delays occasioned by practitioners under review declining to appear at hearings because existing penalties for non-attendance are insufficient to ensure attendance.
The audit office report suggests that the minimum requirement to make medical services committees of inquiry more effective are:

SPEECH.PARA: .increasing the amount of repayment, and/or penalty, required to be paid by practitioners found to have engaged in excessive servicing to reflect more closely the actual extent of moneys involved;
.power for the committees to access medical records;
.appointment of additional committees to help reduce time delays;
.follow-up counselling to be taken by the chairpersons of the committees; and
.appointment of a full-time manager to oversee the operations of committees.

While the provisions contained in this bill do not provide a continuing role for medical services committees of inquiry, they do address the audit office's views on what is required to make dealing with excessive servicing more effective.

PARA.TAB: The bill provides for the replacement of medical services committees of inquiry by professional services review committees. Whereas the basic composition of committees of inquiry remains constant regardless of the nature of the services that are subject to examination, the composition of the professional services review committees will vary according to types of services that are subject to review. For example, the empanelling of a committee to review the rendering or initiation of services by a specialist in a particular specialty would be on the basis that the majority of the committee would be specialists in the same specialty. This means that there should be little cause for a practitioner to question the committee's competence to deal with the matters referred to it.

A significant change in the bill is the replacement of the concept of excessive servicing with one of inappropriate practice. Whereas excessive servicing is currently defined as the rendering or initiation of services not reasonably necessary for the adequate care of the patient, the concept of inappropriate practice goes further. It covers a practitioner engaging in conduct in connection with the rendering or initiating of services that is unacceptable to his or her professional colleagues generally.

Another significant change is that the bill provides for the application by professional services review committees of the findings from a statistically valid sample of services rendered or initiated by the practitioner under review to the whole class of services that are of concern. This will constitute a far greater deterrent than the application of the current excessive servicing benefits repayments and penalties. The statistical procedure for making the necessary calculations has been developed on advice from the Australian Bureau of Statistics and protects adequately the rights of the practitioner under review.

A further important change lies in the penalty that will result from the refusal of a practitioner to attend a hearing or to produce documents when required to appear before a professional services review committee. If a practitioner refuses twice to comply with the requirements of a written notice of hearing, that practitioner will be fully disqualified from Medicare until such time as he or she agrees to comply. The inclusion of this provision reflects a view shared by the government and the AMA that a practitioner whose conduct in the rendering or initiating of publicly funded services is open to question should be required to participate in a professionally oriented process of review.

The bill provides for the creation of an independent director of professional services review. The occupant of this position will be responsible for considering referrals for review from the Health Insurance Commission and deciding whether to empanel a professional services review committee from members of a professional services review panel drawn from the relevant fields of professional practice. The director will also have the power to dismiss a referral or to impose, but only with the consent of the practitioner who is the subject of a referral for review, a partial disqualification from Medicare. The director, who will be in effect the manager of the entire review process, will be required to report annually to the parliament.

The Health Insurance Commission will no longer be responsible for providing the secretariat. However, the director may make an arrangement with the Health Insurance Commission or another Commonwealth authority for officers of the authority to be made available to assist the director in the performance of his or her duties.

The bill gives the profession substantial autonomy in examining and reaching findings on inappropriate practices. At the same time, proper care has been taken to ensure that the practitioner under review receives natural justice. At every major point in the review process the practitioner is given the opportunity to make submissions that could influence the review process and outcome. The bill provides for the separation of the three elements of the decision making processes which are:

SPEECH.PARA: .the referral for review;
.the review hearings and findings; and
.the determination of any penalty.

The Health Insurance Commission prepares and refers a case for review to the director of the professional services review who decides whether to empanel a professional services review committee. The review committee reports on its findings and, if the findings are adverse to the practitioner under review, a determining officer, who must be a person holding an office or appointment under the Public Service Act, must determine one or more of the following courses of action:
.a reprimand;
.counselling;
.repayment of benefits to the Commonwealth;
.payment of a penalty to the Commonwealth; and
.complete or partial disqualification from the Medicare scheme.

The determining officer will be required to provide the practitioner under review with a draft determination on which the practitioner will have the opportunity to make submissions before it becomes final.

PARA.TAB: The bill retains the current appeals mechanisms with an appeal to the professional services review tribunal, which will replace the medical services review tribunals and the optometrical services review tribunals. The new tribunals will function in the same manner as the existing tribunals, and there will continue to be provision for appeals on questions of law to the Federal Court. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ronaldson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROTECTION OF THE SEA (SHIPPING LEVY) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe The Hon N.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Amendment Bill is to amend the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Act 1981 to raise the maximum rate of oil pollution levy which can be applied to commercial shipping using Australian ports. The levy, which was introduced in 1973, provides funds towards the costs associated with operation of Australia's national plan to combat pollution of the sea by oil.

PARA.TAB: The national plan brings together Commonwealth, state and territory and industry expertise and combat capacity under one national contingency plan. Since 1 January 1991, it has been administered by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, AMSA. The levy funds the administration of the national plan, including equipment acquisition, maintenance and training. It also provides a contingency fund to cover costs incurred in responding to marine pollution incidents.

The act currently provides that the rate of levy, per quarter, is such rate, not exceeding 4c per tonne of the tonnage of the ship, as is prescribed. The rate of levy at present prescribed by regulation is 2.2c per tonne. However, it is intended that this rate be raised to 4c per tonne from 1 October 1993. This increase will enable AMSA to implement the recent decisions of Commonwealth and state transport ministers aimed at enhancing the effectiveness of the plan.

These decisions flowed from consideration of a high level review of the national plan by a Commonwealth-state-industry working party. Additional funds are required to purchase additional response equipment to enhance response capability in the event of major spills and put in place contractual arrangements to enhance fixed wing dispersant delivery capability.

The increase in the prescribed rate of levy to meet these additional funding demands will, however, remove the leeway that has previously existed between the rate of levy prescribed by regulation and the limit on the levy set by the act. This leeway is essential to allow AMSA to react speedily to a large funding requirement that might arise in the case of a major incident. While in almost all cases costs of responding to oil pollution incidents are recovered from the polluter, there is an immediate call on funds, and it may be some time before these can be recovered.

In such cases the ability to increase the levy by regulation will allow AMSA to borrow funds at short notice by giving it the financial capacity to service and repay such a loan from the levy. The increase in the maximum rate of levy that can be prescribed to 6c per tonne as proposed in this legislation maintains the current relationship between the rate of levy prescribed by regulation and the maximum rate capable of being prescribed.

The government hopes of course that we will never need to raise the rate of levy to pay for the clean-up of a major spill. The government believes, however, that it is essential for AMSA to have the capability to respond quickly should such an unfortunate event occur. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Bruce Scott) adjourned.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was halfway through my presentation on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) before I was so rudely interrupted by the dinner break. At that point I was presenting to the House a few quotes that were made immediately following the presentation of the budget on 17 August. I will continue to read a few. The President of the ACTU, Mr Martin Ferguson, said:

SPEECH.PARA: How do you defend the indefensible?
Mrs Merle Mitchell, President of the Australian Council of Social Service, said:
I am extremely disappointed with the tax changes, a lack of action to bring down unemployment and a failure to implement recommendations on national savings.
Ken Fowlie, the National President of the National Union of Students, said:
The government has slugged students to help to overcome its financial problems. Continuing education, which the government had pledged to support, would become the domain of the rich.
Mr Michael Easson from New South Wales said that the budget was `an act of bastardry'. Bishop Patrick Power, Chairman of the Bishops Committee for Social Welfare, said:
In the aftermath of the 1993 federal budget, one of the greatest concerns is its adverse impact on the poorest members of our society.

That is exactly what this budget has done, notwithstanding the lengthy rhetoric we have heard from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) with regard to the opposition's actions to oppose the tax increases.

PARA.TAB: This government is on the nose, and it was clearly in evidence at the last federal election when all those Labor promises have now been turned into Labor lies. Do honourable members remember the following comments amongst the March 1993 election promises by Labor? On 19 November 1992, the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: What I am promising is not to put up tax.
Again on 19 November, 1992 the Prime Minister said:
I don't think the incidence of tax should rise.
Then there was that now famous statement by the Prime Minister on 9 February 1993:
They—
that is, the promised tax cuts—
are not a promise, they are law, l-a-w.
On 19 August 1992 the Treasurer said:
We will not be introducing new taxes.
On 15 September 1992 the Treasurer said:
We can pay for our personal tax cuts.
These have all since been proven to be one big joke, but I would like to emphasise the last comment of the Treasurer:
We can pay for our personal tax cuts.
If that is the case, why do we read comments in the newspapers today of Senator McMullan, the Treasurer's counterpart in the Senate? He said:
The government will not pay the tax cuts to people, we will not give royal assent to the bill . . . until the compensating revenue measures satisfactory to us are passed.

Why, after the Treasurer said that he could pay for the tax cuts, are those tax cuts now linked to tax increases with the government trying to blame the opposition for it when the people of Australia know full well it is the government's fault and the government can provide those tax cuts prior to Christmas by unlinking, untying those tax cuts from the tax increases? Who is off the track here—is it Senator McMullan or is it the Treasurer? I now understand why the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) said of this government in his reply to this budget some six weeks ago:
Were you lying then, or are you lying now, or are you not chronic and habitual liars?
In the budget speech that the Treasurer presented to the House on 17 August, after he had moved the motion that the bill be now read a second time his opening sentences were:

PARA.TAB: The greatest issue facing our nation is how to provide jobs for our fellow Australians. Too many are now out of work. Too many have been out of work for too long.
The primary objective of this budget is jobs . . .

On the night of 17 August, the unemployment rate in Australia stood at 10.7 per cent. Buried deep in the budget documents was the government's forecast that 12 months hence the unemployment level would be 10.75 per cent. So who was the Treasurer trying to kid when he said that the budget was about producing jobs? The government has no intention of producing jobs. It is telling us that the unemployment level is going to be the same in 12 months time as it was on the night of the budget. That is an absolute joke.

That is why we saw Australians react to this budget with outrage. I am a new member of this House but it frightened me to see the people in the public gallery during the weeks following the delivery of the budget stand up and abuse the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. I am sure that they were true believers who felt absolutely and totally betrayed by the government.

The government's argument that it will be the fault of the coalition if we do not see tax cuts by Christmas is wrong. If the government supported the coalition amendments, the tax cuts would sail through. We are opposing 1.5 per cent of revenue; that is all the coalition is trying to amend. It is not the opposition that is being irresponsible. It is our job to oppose and to try to amend areas of legislation that need improvement. That is what we have been elected to do. The people of Australia are demanding that we take a stand on this issue.

It is the government's own action in linking bills, not once but twice, that is unbelievable. The first group of budget deficit reduction bills introduced into this House were found to be unconstitutional. The Treasurer could not help himself, and in the second group of budget bills—the eight that were passed through from this House to the Senate under the guillotine this week—he linked two items pertaining to tax increase. Whether those items are constitutional or not is still questionable. If the government was fair dinkum about providing these tax cuts by Christmas it would not have linked these measures; it would have kept them separate. The government knew what our stand was. It knew that those measures would have gone sailing through and have been passed in the Senate by now.

We all remember the night of 30 August, the night of the infamous caucus meeting that blew up on the Treasurer and the Prime Minister. For some time now, the opposition has been berated in this House by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer for being economic vandals, for being wreckers and for pulling the budget apart. At this stage, we have said only that we are going to oppose certain tax increases. We are on to the third draft of the budget and who has done all the amending? The government backbench—the caucus. It has done the amending because it has been put under the same amount of pressure from the people around Australia as opposition members have. The caucus knows that the people feel betrayed. It knows that the government had to do something about the situation. The government backbenchers in that caucus meeting gave that message quite clearly to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are still saying it in the House today.

—That is true. After that meeting, it was interesting to read a quotation of the Prime Minister's words when he read the riot act to his backbenchers. During the election campaign, when nobody else in the Labor Party believed that they could win, the Prime Minister was standing on the burning deck all by himself, leading the way for the Labor Party. It reminded me of a little ditty that I knew when I was going to school about the little boy standing on the burning deck with a pocketful of crackers. We all know what happened when the spark flew up his trouser leg. I think that may have happened to the Prime Minister in that caucus meeting on 30 August.
—It might have been a double bunger.

—It might have been a double bunger; that is for sure. I would like to remind the House of some things that we all need to remember. On 31 March 1992, when the Prime Minister spoke about budget forecasts, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if we cannot make 4 per cent growth a year, the whole lot of us ought to give it away.
This budget forecasts growth of 2 3/4 per cent. When is the Prime Minister, and more particularly the Treasurer, going to give it away? On 13 May 1987, the Prime Minister said:

Australia now stands on the verge of breaking away from its precarious dependence on a narrow range of primary exports. In doing so, we will free ourselves from the dictates of the international financial markets.

When the Prime Minister made that claim, in May 1987, net foreign debt stood at about $86 billion. In the six years that have followed it has more than doubled. On 24 January 1990, the Prime Minister said:
In three years' time there will be no government debt . . .
That was in January 1990. Here we are in September 1993 and look at the massive debt we have. He said:

In three years' time there will be no government debt, domestic or external. It's an enormous claim that I can make on behalf of the government of Australia. The government's debt for this year will rise to approximately $85 billion.

We should remember what the Labor Party promised the people of Australia during its election campaign in March this year: no tax increases, no GST, and Medicare to remain intact. In my electorate, the ALP booth workers at every single booth handed out how-to-vote leaflets which said, `Vote for the ALP. Vote against GST. Vote for Medicare.' What was one of the immediate measures proposed in the budget, not even six months later? It was the removal of optometrical services from the Medicare rebate scheme. No wonder people were outraged. No wonder there were so many people contacting my office and the office of every other member of this House. They felt totally betrayed by the fact that the promises made in March were so very quickly broken.

PARA.TAB: The sad indictment on the government is that it was its own backbench—nobody else—who forced the change of heart on optometrical services before it got any further. The backbench knew—it had a heart—that it had to honour promises from 13 March 1993 otherwise the government would be totally discredited.

The taxes that are proposed to be introduced in these budget bills are taxes on regional development. Today we heard many speakers in this House talking about the importance of regional development and what the government can and cannot do. The very first thing the government should do is become far more equitable with its taxes as far as regional Australia is concerned. The fuel tax is a tax on regional development. The wholesale sales tax is a tax on regional development. The wine tax is a tax on regional development.

These taxes are an insult to businesses in this country, businesses that the government is expecting to get the country going again. Yet it continues to burden these businesses with more taxes. There is an ever narrowing base of productive tax paying people in this country but still the government is burdening them with more and more taxation. No wonder we are struggling at the moment.

It is government—not the public sector—that should ultimately be poor, small, but honest. Governments should not be about raising wealth; they should simply be an avenue for redirecting spending. The private sector is this country's future. I think the words of Ian Spicer, chief executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, summed up what the business community thinks of this budget, and I shall finish with his words. Whilst commenting on the budget, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In its pre-budget submissions, the business community sought reductions—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) for his excellent speech. If he would like to hand me the words of Mr Spicer with which he was about to finish, perhaps I could start with them. I take it that if I am speaking after my National Party colleague the government has given up and finally lost interest in the debate completely. It will not be evident to the people listening to the debate but, except for the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Punch) at the table, there is not one person on the government's side of the parliament tonight. One can only imagine what they might be up to. I think this probably indicates their disinterest.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps they have lost hope. I suppose it has been a fairly traumatic few weeks for the government, as it has been for all the people of Australia who have watched this budget fiasco lurch from crisis to crisis. Here we are at the end of another week of sitting in this place and I do not think any of us are very much the wiser about where we will end up with the budget.

The budget is like a moveable feast. It is a bit hard to get a handle on the latest situation in any aspect of it. While the honourable member for Lyne might not have been in this place very long, I congratulate him on the fact that it has not taken him very long at all to actually get the gist of the situation—the complete hopelessness of the government in managing this economy.

In the whole 10 or 11 years that the government has been in control of this place, it has failed consistently to achieve anything. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has stumbled across the few gains that he has managed to get up and talk about. He accidentally achieved a low inflation result, but not by good management. That was simply a product of the circumstances in which the government found itself. With the mismanagement that the government has actually inflicted upon us it is a wonder that we do not have deflation in this economy. The government deserves no credit at all for low inflation; it was purely an accident. Although in many respects low inflation may be fortuitous, the government can claim little credit for it.

I am not sure whether in real terms interest rates are that low at all. In absolute terms, real interest rates have come down, but they did so from historically high levels. It was this government that inflicted upon this economy the highest interest rates that we had just about ever had. During the years of mismanagement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when he was Treasurer, businesses were consistently going to the wall as they laboured through years of horrifically high interest rates. So the government can claim very little credit at all.

After 11 years of being in government what does the Australian Labor Party really have to show? One million unemployed and an enormous debt. Those are the two huge, outstanding economic matters on the agenda of this country, neither of which this government has any answer for. This government has no answer to the unemployment problem and no answer, that I can see, to the ongoing problem of the deficit.
The time of the honourable member for Lyne expired before he was able to put on the record what Mr Spicer had to say about the budget. But I will correct that situation. Mr Spicer said:

SPEECH.PARA: In its pre-Budget submissions, the business community sought reductions in government spending, reductions in the deficit and reductions in taxes on business inputs.
Instead, the Government has seen fit to raise all three.

It is therefore a Budget which has damaged business confidence. It has raised concerns about the sustainability of recovery and made the business community even more wary about the future than it already was.

Undoubtedly that is a commonly held view about this budget. The business community has absolutely no confidence in the direction in which this economy is going, and no confidence in this government. The Australian people may have finally got to the point where, if an election were held tomorrow, they would get rid of the government. I do not know how the Labor Party won the last election. We have spoken about that. It stumbled across the line. To a large extent, I suppose it was our fault that it did, but it did. We were all amazed, but probably the government was even more amazed than we were.

PARA.TAB: Hopefully, the Australian people now recognise that they made a dreadful mistake on 13 March—and they did make a terrible mistake. We just wonder how long we have to suffer. Every day people ask me, `Can't you get rid of them?'. I cannot find anyone who voted for the government. It seems that, ultimately, almost half the people in Australia through their first, second, third or umpteenth preference voted for the government, but, amazingly, even in my electorate I cannot find anyone who did. Perhaps the people who did vote for the government are hiding. Although the government did stumble across the line, the people of Australia hopefully now recognise that they did make a mistake.

We now have a budget fiasco, with negotiations going on somewhere in the corridors of power in this place tonight I suppose. One wonders what the final outcome might be. I am sure that, if it could be arranged, the Australian people would support any action the opposition could take to bring about a double dissolution of this place. The people of Australia are telling me that they want another election and maybe that is possible, although unfortunately I do not think it will be that easy. It seems that we will have to suffer for another couple of years before we can finally have a change of government.

Hopefully by then, if the country has not been completely destroyed, people will be ready for the sorts of fundamental changes that really need to be made rather than bandaid solutions. We are constantly subjected to this government coming up with all sorts of schemes, programs, incentives and initiatives—that is the latest word—to solve the very problems that it created. The government keeps coming up with all these mickey mouse schemes one after another.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fairyland stuff.

—All these job creation schemes are fairyland stuff. In my electorate I have the best qualified unemployed people of all time. They come into me with six or seven certificates saying that they have done a course for this and that. Through all of these schemes, all that the government does ultimately is shuffle the one million unemployed around on the queue; they just move from one end of the queue to the other. The government takes them off the back of the queue and puts them through some sort of training scheme.

PARA.TAB: The other day a constituent came to see me and told me how she had been through one of these schemes. She had to undertake the scheme—apparently the deal is that one has to be retrained otherwise one is liable to have one's benefit threatened. This lady is quite genuine, she wants to work but she cannot find a job. She went through a scheme and she came to tell me that she had not actually been retrained; she had been detrained in this particular scheme. The computer course that she was subjected to was such that she said she could have taught the instructor. She said that everyone else on the course felt the same way—they all knew it backwards. But they were all subjected to this two-week course or whatever it was, after which they had to go out and get back on the queue, which is where they came from in the first place.

There are fundamental answers—the honourable member for Lyne mentioned some—which this government is completely incapable of coming to grips with. Most people in Australia to whom I talk know the solutions; they are not that difficult. But this government is completely hamstrung by an outdated and discredited ideology and therefore cannot come to grips with the problems. Regardless of whether the area is education, health or similar key areas, the government cannot get its mind around the very obvious solutions to a lot of the problems we are facing today in this country.

As the honourable member for Lyne mentioned, the government's absolute achilles heel is its relationship with the trade union movement. When I talk about the trade union movement, as I do from time to time in this place, I do not mean the rank and file trade unionist. Many people are union members because they have to be. These days people do not really choose to join unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're bludgeoned.

—That is a very good word. In lots of cases they are bludgeoned into joining unions. In the private sector work force now only about 30 per cent of people are in unions, but in the public sector union membership is still around 70 per cent. The Labor Party is controlled by its union mates. When Mr Kelty comes along to give those opposite their marching orders, it is really only a matter of how high they jump.

PARA.TAB: The recent report of the Industry Commission gave the government some clues about how to reduce unemployment. But the government immediately rejected many of those very valid points on the need to bring wages into line with what the market can afford, and ultimately that is a very real part of the solution. In this country, the Labor Party has created a whole system of wages way beyond what people should be entitled to—unless they deliver on a productivity level, but they have not done that. That is protected by a centralised wage fixing system and it has often happened behind tariff walls of protection and so on.

Now businesses cannot afford to pay those award wages, which has resulted in unemployment. The government has then picked up the other side of the equation, which is all the unemployed people to whom the government has had to pay welfare through unemployment benefits. Rather than create a system whereby people can actually go out and work, the government has put them on welfare.

At the same time, there are fewer people in the work force paying taxes to pay the welfare. There is an ever diminishing number of people who are silly enough to be out there working, rather than choosing paid leisure, which means that the demands on the taxpayers are ever increasing. No amount of obfuscation on the part of the Prime Minister or the Treasurer can disguise the fact that the government has lost total control of the economic management of this country. No diversion, whether it be the republic, the flag or—dare I say it—even the Olympic Games, can lessen the government's culpability in respect of its massive mishandling of the Australian economy. The Treasurer, in his budget speech—it seems like years ago now; it is only a short time ago—made, almost as his opening gambit, the incredible claim that has been repeated in this place many times that `this budget is about jobs'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are they?
—Where are they? Not one has been created since budget night. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The greatest issue facing our nation is how to provide jobs for our fellow Australians . . . The primary objective of this budget is jobs.
