Yet, when we read the budget papers, we find very quickly that the whole budget is based on the assumption that unemployment will be virtually unchanged. The unemployment rate on budget night was around 11 per cent. When we read the budget papers, we find that it is going to be about the same, at 10.75 per cent—close enough to 11 per cent—at the end of 1993-94. The only difference is because the participation rate comes down a little, so the government has fiddled with the participation rates fractionally to achieve that slight reduction in the unemployment rate. The budget papers go on to state:
While some reduction in the unemployment rate is expected by mid 1994, progress on reducing unemployment fundamentally depends on achieving faster rates of economic growth.

There is no evidence in the budget that these faster rates will be achieved. The growth rate in the Australian gross domestic product in 1992-93 was 2 1/2 per cent. The Treasurer likes to think that is pretty good. He likes to compare that with rates of growth in the OECD—the developed countries. It may well be that, compared with Japan, Europe and perhaps even the United States, 2 1/2 per cent in 1992-93 was not too bad. What he and the Prime Minister fail to do when it suits them is to not compare us with our Asian neighbours. Our Asian neighbours are achieving rates of growth well in excess of 2 1/2 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister likes to tell us that Asia is our part of the world. He tells us that when it suits him, but day after day when government members get up in here and try to tell us that 2 1/2 per cent growth is good, they compare us with parts of the world which are not directly comparable with us at all.

The budget forecast growth rate for 1993-94 is 2.75 per cent. However, the other underlying flaw in the whole of this argument is that most of that growth rate is in the public sector. Once again, it underlines how wrong this government has got it. The budget papers state:

SPEECH.PARA: Public investment is expected to grow strongly as spending on One Nation and other infrastructure projects reach a peak and investment by the Commonwealth Public Trading Enterprise increases.

Without this huge government spending or stimulus—that is the word these days: stimulus—that the government is putting into the economy, growth would be very limited indeed. In fact, there is still a lot of evidence around that the private sector remains stalled or worse.

PARA.TAB: This really begs another fundamental question besides the question about the unemployed for which the government admits, in effect, that it has no answer in this budget, because we had one million unemployed at the beginning, and we have one million unemployed at the end. The other important question is: how long can the government keep propping things up with government expenditure? Last year we had a deficit of $15 billion-odd. This year it is projected to be $16 billion. Even that is an underestimate. If we add back all the tricks and creative accounting that the government uses, the actual deficit for this year could be as high as $25 billion. How long can we continue to live on the never-never?

Not only is this deficit the public deficit, but each month we fall behind in terms of our gross national debt. There is no suggestion that we will ever get that under control. The best hope the government can give us is that by 1996 it might get the deficit down to $6 billion. That is, by 1996, if we accept the government's target of one per cent of gross domestic product, we might have a budget deficit of $6 billion.

We are going to continue to live on the never-never. We must get hold, the same way as any individual household would have to, of the fact that we cannot continue to spend more than we are earning. Yet the government suggests, and its budget papers confirm, that that is exactly what it intends to do. The proposed measures that it outlines to cut the deficit are completely unconvincing as well. There is nothing in this budget which guarantees that the deficit will fall to one per cent of GDP, even if that were a worthwhile objective.

The bottom line really is that this government is incapable of managing this country. It has no plan at all. I believe that the Labor Party simply takes the view that the government ought to solve all of our problems. As I said before, it is great at coming up with all sorts of programs. I still think it believes that people like to get a knock on the door, open it and find that the person outside says, `I am from the government and I am here to help you'. That attitude is pervasive. It applies to business, families and just about every aspect of Australian life. This Labor government still takes the view that it can solve things better than individuals can for themselves. It is just not the case. Until it gets that message right, until it understands that, it will never get anything right.

Most people, including the many small business people I talk to, understand that what they really want is for the government to get out of the way. The last thing they want is any help from the government. What it has inflicted on the business sector is more taxes, more levies, more charges, more schemes, more licences and more interference to the point where business cannot survive. The government wonders why business is not employing anybody.

If we wanted to be terribly simplistic about it, the point is that if we take these burdens off business, instead of putting them on, then business can start to talk about employing more people. That is the sort of employment growth we want in this country—real jobs; not jobs created by spending of the type that is envisaged in the One Nation statement. We can have people building roads, bridges, railway lines or whatever, but those jobs come and go. They are not real jobs in that sense.

The only way that we will solve the unemployment problem in this country is to get the private sector moving; to get off the back of business, particularly small business, and let it get on with the job of employing more people. It seems so simple that I cannot understand why government members cannot understand it.

Let us look at the government's treatment of the wine industry in this budget. Here is one industry that seems to be working. It is exporting. So what does the government do? It puts a tax on it. It increases the wholesale sales tax on wine by about 50 per cent. What sort of thinking is that? In my electorate, I have a very strong tourism sector. What does the government do with the tourism industry? It looks around and says, `Here is an industry which is doing well, let's increase the tax on it'. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder what one must do these days to qualify to be a true believer—a term which has been bandied around in this House and abused appallingly. I decided to profile what a true believer was in the days of Curtin and Chifley and what one is during the days of Hawke and Keating and—excuse the fact that I am from Western Australia—Burke, Dowding and Lawrence. If government members were in the chamber tonight, they would probably prefer to forget—or at least cringe horribly when some of those names were mentioned.

PARA.TAB: I would imagine a Curtin or Chifley true believer was a real true believer—one who most likely was a blue-collar worker; took his lunch in a lunch box and a thermos to work each day and who enjoyed a beer with his mates after work. I am sure honourable members can imagine the sort of true believer that I am describing and referring to—the salt of the earth sort of person this budget kicks soundly in the guts. That sort of person, the true believer of days gone by, does not exist in the eyes of the Labor Party. Instead of being its true believer, this person is Labor's forgotten person—along with the rest of the populace of Australia.

Today, Labor's true believers are vastly different people. They are white-collar workers; probably went to private schools; they have lunch at expensive restaurants; they drive the expensive imported cars which use unleaded petrol; drink champagne with their peers; and wear Zegna suits—indeed, the sorts of people this budget was made for.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as you are aware, I am new to this place. I come to this place having successfully enunciated to the electors of Stirling a policy package of economic responsibility; a policy of honesty; a policy which took the hard decisions but also a policy which was to pull our wonderful country out of the decade of economic mismanagement under which we have suffered with the lack of leadership of Bob Hawke and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I went through the shopping centres of Stirling night after night, telling the people of my electorate about the advantages that we offered for Australia. I did not pull the wool over their eyes. I told them it was going to be tough, they had to face the hard decisions, and they proved by their overwhelming support for me at the election on 13 March that they were prepared to stomach it. They were lied to viciously by this government.

By contrast, my opponent—who was lined up for the job of Speaker in this House—and his party had very few policies. Indeed, as the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) said here two days ago, the Labor Party had four major promises: to lower company tax; to lower the budget deficit to one per cent of GDP; to deliver personal tax cuts; and to not introduce a goods and services tax. This is supposedly what Labor went to the election with. I found it difficult during the election campaign to find any policy at all that Labor went to the election with.

Indeed, at a rally at one of our local shopping centres, all of the candidates for the electorate of Stirling were invited to put the views of their parties and their particular viewpoint. When it came to my predecessor in this place, Mr Ron Edwards, to put the policies of the Labor Party, he was almost apologetic. When my turn came to put what our policies were, I could honestly say that I believed in everything that I was putting forward. I said to the people in that crowd, which numbered in excess of 2,000, `If anyone in this crowd today can show me the policies of the Labor Party I will give you $1,000 cash in hand because there are no policies'. We went to this election honestly and forthrightly and we were defeated by lies. That is something that the government has yet to come to terms with. But the chooks are coming home to roost in a big way.

The Labor Party also came out with a number of promises—all, of course, throwing money after votes. It made it perfectly clear that it would not increase taxes. If honourable members opposite want to suggest otherwise, I challenge them to tell me the date their party made it known the wholesale sales tax would increase. On what date did they settle that one? On what date did they make it known that the wine tax would increase? On what date did they make it known the tax exemption on credit unions would be repealed? On what date did they make it known they would change the HECS payment rules? On what date did they make it known they would increase the petrol tax on both leaded and unleaded petrol? Name the dates. They cannot. These tax hikes were all made known on 17 August—185 days after the 13 March poll. They were certainly not made known prior to 13 March. When Australians went into the polling booths on that dreadful day, those who put a `1' next to the names of Labor candidates did not know they were voting for tax hikes as it has turned out.

We have had some breathtaking comments coming from our ever so desperate Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). It makes me ashamed to be a West Australian knowing that he comes from the same state. But his classic in this place is that revenue as a proportion of GDP remains the same. The Treasurer says that, by having said that prior to the last election, Australians knew they were voting for tax increases. What absolute balderdash! People will not fill up their cars or buy some goods or have a glass of wine and think when they are charged more, `Oh, well, that does not particularly matter, at least revenue as a proportion of GDP remains the same'. Good God! What planet is this man from! If the Treasurer thinks people will accept that, then he is more foolish than I first thought. I assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I thought he was incredibly foolish to start with because I have known this man for a long time. I am afraid the silver spoon he had in his mouth since birth must be harming his brain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I submit that that is unparliamentary.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—It is a moot point, but the parliamentary secretary has drawn my attention to the fact that that could be regarded as unparliamentary and, as such, I would ask the honourable member for Stirling to withdraw that comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which particular comment?
—The honourable member knows which particular comment. Let us not play around. I would invite you to withdraw it.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will take your advice, being new here, but I am not quite sure what you are referring to.
—As long as you withdraw it, you can then proceed with your speech.
—I withdraw whatever it is you are referring to.
—No. You will withdraw the comment.

—I withdraw the comment. On 13 March the people did not vote for increased taxes. I admit they did vote for tax cuts; they voted for a cut in company taxes; and they voted for our deficit to fall to one per cent of GDP by 1995. But they did not vote for higher taxes and, for that reason, they should be opposed. Any honourable members opposite who support this budget will be stabbing their constituents fairly in the back because they could not look them in the eye whilst doing so.

PARA.TAB: There were some more foolish comments which the Treasurer; his acolyte, the Assistant Treasurer; and the Prime Minister have also made. They blame the coalition for the changes that have had to be made, yet what they fail to acknowledge is that 60 members of their own party shared our concerns. They led a caucus revolt opposing many of the budget measures. If members of the parliamentary Labor Party opposed certain budget measures in the caucus room, then it is obvious they of all people did not expect these measures to be introduced when they were running for office. It is therefore obvious that the government does not have a mandate to introduce many of these quite pernicious measures. It is therefore incumbent on us all to oppose this budget, a budget of deceit and betrayal. As I have heard from one of my colleagues in this place, who happens to be from the party opposite, going home to face their electorate is like facing a lynch mob—and they never expected this.

I will be directing my attention to a number of changes which were flagged on 17 August, some of which have since been removed by the government following public pressure, but measures which the Treasurer wanted; changes which would have hurt the people who are stereotyped as being the true believers. The most surprising and deceitful change would have to be the increase in the wholesale sales tax. This is to rise by one per cent this year and another percentage point on 1 July 1995. This is a change by a government which promised jobs, not GST. The coalition promised to abolish the wholesale sales tax; the Labor Party never said it would increase it. If it wanted to increase it, it should have sought a mandate. People who voted Labor on 13 March did not know they were voting for an increase in the wholesale sales tax. They did not give Labor a mandate to increase the tax. If democracy is to be upheld, we must all do the responsible thing and oppose this increase, which is but one tax hike we should be opposing.

Then there is the wine tax. I guess the Treasurer cannot get a glass of `Chateau de cardboard' to his lips because of the silver spoon that I have already mentioned this evening; that could get in the way. This is another dishonest tax. As I have said before, when people put a `1' next to the name of Labor candidates on 13 March, they were voting to keep the wine tax at 20 per cent, not increase it to 31 per cent. This increased tax will destroy an industry which has been developing ever since Western Australia's first days of settlement. It is now sad to see a Western Australian or supposedly so—our Treasurer—now ruining one of the oldest and most successful industries in our marvellous state of Western Australia.

Western Australia produces annually about $60 million worth of wine valued at wholesale prices. More than 70 per cent of that is sold outside the state. The Australian Wine Export Council aims to increase exports of wine to $1,000 million by the year 2000. It would be great if our Prime Minister had goals like this for the year 2000 other than his own personal political ambitions for that year. If Western Australia achieves only five per cent in wine sales in achieving this goal, our wine grape production will double and require an investment of more than $50 million; yet the Treasurer, whose loyalty to Western Australia has to be questionable, wishes to jeopardise this valuable industry and, in doing so, harm the jobs and livelihood of many Western Australians.

There are also the changes to the HECS, another revenue increasing measure which the government did not make known it would be implementing when it had ample opportunity to do so prior to the last election. These changes are blatantly dishonest and a stab in the back for more of Labor's so-called true believers. This measure is also quite interesting considering the support the Labor Party received from student unions at campuses right across Australia, and Lord knows I locked horns with a few of them during the campaign. I intend speaking on this measure in another debate and will elucidate on this measure then, but, again, the bottom line is that when students put a `1' in the box next to the names of Labor candidates, they were not voting for these changes to the higher education contribution scheme, and for that reason Labor does not have a mandate to implement them. These measures should also be rejected.

Another measure, or should I say deception, was the government's decision to repeal the section 23G partial taxation exemption for credit unions. I had intended talking on this when it came before the House, but the government, obviously ashamed of its dishonesty, guillotined the debate and refused to listen to the truth about this and its other dishonest taxation measures. The repealing of this section was totally unexpected by credit unions—unexpected because the government did not say that as part of its policy at the last election it would repeal this exemption. Indeed, this exemption, in the past, until this budget, has had bipartisan support.

Credit unions are quite dissimilar from banks in that they do not have liquidity support from the Reserve Bank. Banks are not required to fund their own supervision; banks have a trustee status and resultant access to a greater pool of deposit funds—in fact, the list goes on. There are vast differences between banks and credit societies, a fact which has previously been acknowledged by both sides of this House, and the reason we have supported this exemption on a bipartisan basis. Nothing has changed to warrant this exemption other than the fact that the government is desperate for funds and it has gone against logic in repealing this particular section. Yet again, when the 3.1 million Australians who are members of credit unions voted at the last election, those who voted Labor were voting to keep this exemption, and for that reason we must also oppose this measure. The coalition has sent it to a committee in the Senate; however, I am of the firm opinion that it should be opposed without waiting for any committee reports. It was not a Labor policy prior to 13 March and so the government does not have a mandate to implement this totally dishonest measure.

There were two more measures where the government either fully or partially backed down. The scrapping of the Medicare rebate for eye tests was a cruel decision, and I am glad that 60 of the Labor caucus members acknowledged this as being cruel and forced the government to back down. It is a pity they did not seek greater changes to Medicare to provide incentives for individuals to take out private health insurance and leave Medicare as a health insurance system for those at whom it was originally aimed: the low income earners, pensioners and the unemployed. I urged in my maiden speech the Prime Minister, the Assistant Treasurer and others opposite who had not taken out private health insurance to do so because people on incomes like those of us in this House do not need to be subsidised by the taxpayer for our health insurance.

It is a pity the government did not take the opportunity in this budget to reform our health system, as it so desperately needs. It means we will continue to see it crumbling, as it has, and the people who will suffer most, as always, are those who can least afford private health insurance or pay for surgery themselves: the low income earners, the unemployed and the pensioners in our society.

The last dishonest measure was the tax changes to unused annual and long service leave. Whilst I welcome the abandoning of the retrospectivity element, as one constituent pointed out to me, this retrospective element was akin to reducing the speeding limit, making it retrospective, and sending fines to people who had driven the speed limit. It should not have been put forward in the first place. Yet again this is but another measure which, when people voted Labor, they thought they were voting to keep the status quo. They were certainly not voting to increase the tax on unused long service leave and annual leave and making it retrospective. As I said before, there is no mandate to increase this tax and, therefore, it should be totally and utterly opposed.

Finally, and very briefly, considering I have spoken on this four times already, the government stands condemned for discriminating against pensioners by deeming shares held by them which increase in value is income, and therefore cut their pensions, when anyone else who owns shares which rise in value is not punished at all when those shares rise in value.

At the last election the coalition went into the election with a comprehensive policy package. On the contrary, Labor lacked any vision whatsoever or policies, as I have already mentioned tonight. Many of the measures announced on 17 August were not known about on 13 March, and therefore the government is not entitled to introduce them, and it has no mandate to. I would be totally ashamed if I were a new Labor member of this parliament, having been elected under those false pretences, to now have to put up with this ridiculous budget mark 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5, or whatever we get to.

I stand here tonight on behalf of the people of Stirling, the people of Balga, Mirrabooka, Balcatta, Nollamara, Dianella, Tuart Hill, Yokine and Karrinyup, and other areas which those members opposite used to call their true believers. These are the forgotten Australians—people who were duped by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister on 13 March. Boy, have they been had! And they are telling me in their droves. This is not just a budget of betrayal. It is a shameful, dishonest, illogical and discredited package of lies. It contains measures which the government has no mandate to introduce, and I have no qualms about opposing it, even if it means going to another poll. If it meant another poll, at least the people of Australia would know what Labor really stood for. They would not believe anything Labor said because this budget has exposed the Labor Party for its blatant dishonesty.

I do hope the Greens and the Democrats choose to oppose all the tax increases Labor has proposed because, as I said, when people voted Labor they voted for no new taxes and no tax increases. We must ensure that what the people of Australia voted for is what they get. It is not just Labor's mandate, it is ours, and we have every right to oppose all the tax increases proposed by the disgraced and dishonest Treasurer. I now challenge the members opposite—if there were any here—to uphold the mandate they were given, as they have been trying to behind closed doors, and oppose the increased tax hikes the Treasurer—the dishonest and discredited Treasurer—tried to unscrupulously introduce.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! I have been very lenient when listening very carefully to what the honourable member has been saying. I would ask him to withdraw the inference that the Treasurer as such is dishonest. The honourable member may say that in a broad policy sweep about policies, but when he becomes specific about the Treasurer, I think that that could be regarded as unparliamentary. I would ask him to rephrase that. Rather than directing that comment to the Treasurer in a personal way, I would accept that in a broader statement, not as a direct inference on the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take your advice, Mr Deputy Speaker, I withdraw that comment. I would say that the Labor Party has been extraordinarily dishonest coming up to this election. It promised there would be no new taxes and no tax increases. The challenge is for those opposite. They must now ask who they are beholden to, their party or the people they are elected to represent—the people who gave them the mandate to not introduce new taxes or, indeed, increase taxes. The true believers and the forgotten people are now one and the same and the government absolutely represents neither. On the contrary, we in the coalition will continue to battle for both.

—This week when budget mark 3 was rammed through this place without debate, we witnessed a continuation of what has become a drawn out and painful process of self-realisation for the government. For it is now beginning to dawn on honourable members opposite that this budget does nothing to address the fundamental economic problems which confront our nation today. Even in its latest form it is still a facade—nothing more than a cardboard cut-out, hastily glued together and erected by a government desperate to hide the policy void that exists after it lied and cheated its way into office.

PARA.TAB: As former Labor adviser Richard Farmer said recently of the Keating government, this is `a government that has no idea how it got us into this problem and no idea how it is going to get us out'. The constantly growing foreign debt, an inability to give work to all who seek it, the need to increase national savings, the prospect of a return to unacceptably high levels of inflation and to rising interest rates—all these problems have been left untouched by Labor's budget of betrayal, and all reflect Labor's enormous failure to implement the reforms which will enable Australians to compete more effectively in the global marketplace.

The 1980s were a tragically wasted decade for Australia. A decade which should have seen the implementation of an historic reform agenda, instead, saw an historic dereliction of responsibility; a hugely inefficient and costly public sector; some of the most expensive rail and shipping services in the world; a waterfront which still has a substantial distance to go to reach world best practice; a research and development performance which is one of the weakest in the developed world; a system of federal-state financial relations which encourages irresponsibility; a costly and chaotic tax system which is a deadly weight in the saddlebags of Australian business; and, above all, an industrial relations system that has been operated for a powerful few. All these problems should have been tackled by this government, and by this budget, and they were not.

The explanation of the failure of the Hawke-Keating governments is worth considering in some depth. Let us not be partisan about this. There are people of good will on both sides of this parliament. There are people on the other side of the House who know what has to be done; who know what should have been done. There was even a time—now receding into the distant past—when the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) seemed to have some understanding of the need for reform. But before the election he declared that the time for reform was finished. He said that the reforms were in place, and it was now just a matter of reaping the benefits.

No one believed it then, and no one believes it now, least of all those people whose task it is to provide the products and the jobs that will enable this country to begin to pay its way again in the world—the large and small businesses of Australia. They know that the reform process has barely begun; that they are still trying to compete on an un-level playing field; handicapped at every turn by procedures, regulations and institutions for which this government is responsible and which it wilfully refuses to change.

That is why at the last election it was the Liberal and National parties, which honestly faced up to these problems and these needs, which received the overwhelming backing of the business sector both large and small. They recognised that the coalition had done the work, had set out the policies which were best for Australia, and was honest and frank with the people about the task ahead.

The alliance with business which Bob Hawke had stitched together at his summit in 1983 had become frayed over the years, and was well and truly shattered by the 1993 election. The disillusion with Labor by business, large and small, was complete. This disillusion deepened after the election when, instead of showing that it had heard the message, the government—with the traditional vindictiveness of the New South Wales Labor Right—turned viciously on those business organisations which had the courage, indeed the patriotism, to support those policies which they knew were essential for the survival of this country. They were subjected to the classic politics of threat, which is the only kind of politics that the New South Wales Right and its fellow travellers understand, and as a result the demoralisation of the productive sector in this country deepened even further.

Business investment—the crucial missing link in our economic recovery—fell in the June quarter. Since 1989, business investment as a proportion of gross national product has fallen to its lowest level for at least 20 years, while investment in plant and equipment is lower than at any time during the past 40 years. So much for the Prime Minister's much vaunted investment `avalanche'. Without this investment there will be no boost to demand in the short term, no sustainable growth in the medium term, and thus no hope at all in the long term of reducing unemployment.

The Prime Minister is no novice in politics. He may be a bungler. He may be out of touch. But even he is able to spot a political problem when it hits him in the face, and he knows that Labor has a real problem in reviving business confidence. He also knows—or at least thinks as much—that by making the right noises and offering the right platitudes he can buy time. After all, this is the man who told the people that there would be no recession; that Australia was really in a golden age; and that everything was on track. By saying something to the private enterprise sector, he believed that he could give it some heart, some encouragement for the future.

So he hatched upon an idea for reform and decided to tell the business sector that he would extend enterprise bargaining to the non-unionised sector. Many were sceptical. I do not think private enterprise really believed that this would happen, but it welcomed the direction nonetheless. If the Prime Minister had meant it, this would certainly have been an historic event. Seventy per cent of the work force in private enterprise is non-unionised. This was a policy which the coalition had advocated for years, and in putting it forward the government would have received bipartisan support. In fact, pretty well all the reform ideas of the last decade have come from the coalition. The Liberal and National parties have been the parties of ideas in Australian politics for a long time now, and we have always been prepared to be bipartisan, to support reform and to not be dogs in the manger when the government has done something sensible.

Why then, with an opposition committed to reform in so many areas, has the government been unable to make the most of these windows of opportunity that the coalition has opened for it? Why has the opportunity for real reform of the labour market now been lost completely? In explaining why reform has not taken place, one fundamental point should be made very clear—it is not because we on this side of the House oppose it. The opposition has pushed for reform. It has promoted reform. It has said it would support the government in reform. But, no. There has been only token action.

The real reason lies in the government's relationship with the trade union movement, and the ACTU's privileged position when it comes to policy making. I am in no way disputing the ACTU's legitimate right to participate in policy debates. Through its affiliation with the Labor Party the union movement has, however, gained control of the levers of power to the point where it now exercises a veto over government policy. Witness the backdown of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) on enterprise bargaining following the first hint of union opposition.

It is no secret that the unions heavily financed Labor's election campaign and waged a war of lies against the coalition during the campaign itself. As Martin Ferguson, President of the ACTU, stated in February this year, the union movement `would do everything possible' to get Labor re-elected. Now, more than ever, it is payback time.

On reform of the labour market—the kind of reform that the Business Council of Australia said was essential to enable Australian enterprises to `bridge the gap with the best in the world'—the ACTU has pulled down the shutters. It has issued the orders and pronounced the veto. It has done to enterprise bargaining what it has done to tax reform, what it has done to shipping reform, waterfront reform, public sector reform, health, education and social security reform—used its powerful and privileged position to stop reform in its tracks wherever its interests have been threatened.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the government dances to its tune.

—And the government willingly, as the shadow parliamentary secretary says, has danced to the tune of the ACTU. We must never forget the ACTU's actions in this regard because they illustrate conclusively and without question the reasons for the deep distress that this country is in today, and why there is no business investment, no growth in business investment and no real confidence. There is, at the centre of our national life, a selfish concentration of power which exercises control over this government. No change of any kind which in any way might diminish the power of the ACTU and the trade union movement is acceptable.

PARA.TAB: It is now abundantly clear that the union movement would prefer to see this country sink beneath the oceans than to allow the reforms which would lift the spirits and morale of the Australian people and private enterprise. The Labor Party is structurally incapable of producing reform. It is without leadership. It threatens, blusters and deceives. It does everything to preserve itself and its mates. But it will not relax the grip it has around the throat of this country. It has this country on its knees today.

In state after state, the Labor Party has shown itself incapable of governing. The Wran, Burke, Bannon and Cain governments—all the glamorous new Labor governments of the early 1980s that were supposed to have learnt from Whitlam—have all collapsed, some from corruption. All have failed; incompetent betrayals of the people of their states. This budget simply epitomises Labor's inability to govern at the national level.

On the big issues—unemployment, the economy, Mabo, the republic, to name just a few—the government has shown a total lack of leadership. When the Prime Minister first promised to fight the battle of unemployment—in his inaugural prime ministerial press conference of December 1991—nearly 903,000 Australians were out of work. Today, with the job market still deteriorating, a further 60,000 have joined the jobless queues and many thousands of others have simply given up looking.

With a gross foreign debt of $195 billion, gross domestic product up a wobbly 1.2 per cent in the June quarter and inflation projected to rise well above the rate that would have resulted from the one-off impact of the GST, it is obvious that the government has crossed its fingers and is hoping for the best. In his handling of Mabo, the Prime Minister has delivered nothing but more uncertainty for the business community. He has alienated the states and raised the expectations of Aboriginal Australians to unrealistic levels.

Instead of encouraging united action to provide a realistic way of handling the High Court's decision, the Prime Minister has created deep divisions within his own government and confused the public at large. He has played the issue for his own personal political purposes and failed to provide the strong policy response needed to handle what is a complex issue of crucial national importance. Only this week there has been talk of further delays in the government's legislative response, following concerns expressed by two Labor backbench committees.

In relation to the republic, the Prime Minister has endeavoured to divide Australia once again to further his political agenda. Last week he even tried to link Sydney's magnificent success in winning the right to host the 2000 Olympics with his republican agenda—and used this to renew his call for a change to the Australian flag. But the public has seen through this grubby political ploy. A Newspoll published in the Australian yesterday showed that support for the Keating republic has slumped, with many more Australians now opposed to the idea than in favour of it.

So far the Prime Minister has been unable to explain precisely why we need constitutional change and how it will make Australia a more democratic, stable and united society than we are today. His so-called minimalist position is nothing more than a thinly veiled attempt to hide a broader agenda, including an attack on the states, abolishing the Senate, changing the flag and centralising power. Of one thing we can all be certain: none of the pressing problems facing Australia today arise from a defect in our Constitution.

In my portfolio area of science, technology and export development, the budget is a non-event. The absence of any significant budget initiatives in science and technology result from the government's bungled attempt to form a new national institute of marine science by dismembering the CSIRO and merging it with the Australian Institute of Marine Science. The Minister for Science and Small Business, Senator Schacht, in what was a remarkable display of political ineptitude, tried to bulldoze policy through without consultation and, in the process, alienated the entire science community, members of his own cabinet, the ACTU, the National Fishing Industry Council and a broad range of other industries. The end result was an embarrassing slap in the face for Senator Schacht, his cabinet calling for a complete review of his proposals.

If only the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) had taken more notice of what happens when normal political processes are arrogantly ignored and policy is created behind closed doors and without consultation, he may have avoided the need to consider resigning. The decline in university infrastructure, which makes a mockery of the notion that Australia can become the clever country, has been ignored in the budget. Contrary to the advice of the government's own national board of employment, education and training, which recommended an increase in funding, the status quo remains.

The reforms so urgently needed to encourage an upswing in private sector research and development, on which fundamentally our international competitiveness depends, are also sadly lacking. The Bureau of Industry Economics report released since the budget, has highlighted the fact that Australia has been stuck somewhere near the bottom of the OECD ladder since the mid-1980s, in terms of business expenditure on research and development. The report entitled R&D, innovation and competitiveness looked at the effectiveness of the 150 per cent tax concession for research and development and concluded that, since its inception, the scheme had not increased the stock of consistent R&D performance. Given the importance of innovation to Australia's economic development, this is cause for considerable alarm.

While some initiatives in the budget are aimed at improving our export performance, these fall far short of the recommendations in the McKinsey report. Just as importantly, the budget completely ignores the need to tackle the fundamental structural reforms to which I referred earlier. Without these reforms, Australian business will find it increasingly difficult to compete effectively in export markets. As a result, export growth will continue to fall short of the nation's needs.

During the past few months, this whole budget process has provided accurate insights into the contempt with which this government views the parliament and our democratic process. In a desperate bid to draw attention away from the massive fraud it has perpetrated on people, the Prime Minister and Treasurer have attempted to pin the blame for the budget debacle on anyone but themselves. They have tried to point the finger at the coalition, the Australian Democrats, the Greens and the Senate generally. Both have underestimated the intelligence of the electorate.

The people of Australia know that Labor has broken its promise of no increases in taxation, no new taxes and no increase in the tax burden. They know that the government does not have a mandate for the tax increases proposed in this budget and they know that these increases are only to pay for the tax cuts which were supposed to be l-a-w, law. They also welcome the fact that the coalition will stand firm in its determination to defend their rights and hold the government accountable for its election promises.

The coalition's actions are merely a response to—they merely voice—the anger and bitterness expressed by people. An overwhelming 74 per cent of Australians support the Senate in its refusal to pass the tax bills unless they are changed. The Treasurer will never recover from the debacle which has been in this budget. As the Australian Financial Review pointed out this week, and as even senior ministerial colleagues believe, he is `no longer politically or psychologically equipped to continue as Treasurer'. The paper went on to say that the Treasurer `will become a loose cannon, with potentially devastating effects on Keating's leadership'. It also says, `Already there is leadership discussion within the party'. The Australian people will never forgive the Prime Minister and the Treasurer for this debacle. This week, in this debate, let us simply take note of the betrayals, the backroom deals, the weak leadership and the division that have been the hallmark of this government and this Prime Minister. Let us remember this budget when people once more have the chance to exercise their vote and make their voice heard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address Appropriation Bill (No. 1) with some very stark memories of the week just past. I start with my recollection of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) coming into this parliament to do something that prime ministers must do frequently: deliver a written statement or speech. He has been taking what I believe to be something like 50 per cent more time than a normal person would take to deliver a document, almost stumbling over the words, following them with his finger and demonstrating practically an inability to read. The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) is smiling; he must not have been watching. It is about time that he and others started watching, if only because I am not citing an isolated incident. I am citing a situation that occurs nearly every time our Prime Minister goes into the public arena to do something on which nobody ever had to check on him before. Other than to read a budget speech, which he had written, and stand up here for a short period, our Prime Minister has never been seen in the public arena delivering a written speech. He has not been doing it with the expertise that one would expect—and that was certainly displayed by his predecessor.

PARA.TAB: The point that worried me was that I went out shaking my head and saying to people, `Look, this is not good enough for a Prime Minister. I am embarrassed by what I saw. I am embarrassed by the time that was taken', to have people say, `But don't you know? He never accepts a written brief from his officials. They have to come in and spell it out to him. He can't grasp the written word. Didn't you know that? It has been going on for years'.

I wonder why we are here today debating a budget which is a disaster, not only in terms of the words of members of the coalition. We have had questions raised again this week—stark in my mind—questioning the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) on whether he agreed with, for instance, the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), who went back to his electorate to save his own political hide, believing of course that the ANMLS would not report on him. He told his people he was embarrassed, and of course he was. Living even that little distance from a major population centre, he is aware of the increased burdens and the very foolish approach that this particular budget brings to the Australian people. It is all put in the wrong places.

It is an interesting point because, having had all that in my mind and having had a look at just some of the basic statistics of the budget, I was reminded of a document I read once. I read it at a Rotary meeting because its members had it on the wall. It is something that is very important to Rotary clubs. They call it the four-way test. It is a test they put to themselves, and it is a test that they believe in. Considering that Rotary in particular, as a service club, is oriented towards business and vocational activities, it is a test that its members put down upon themselves in the business arena. I thought it would not be a bad idea to have a few of those tests posted around the walls of this place.

Of course, there are four questions, as honourable members would imagine, in the four-way test of the things we think, say or do. These are the things we should ask ourselves before we do those things. The first of those questions is: is it the truth? The second is: is it fair to all concerned? The third—of some importance, I would think, to politicians—is: will it build goodwill and better friendships? The fourth is: will it be beneficial to all concerned?

I thought I might slide that test over the budget for a minute. Is it the truth? Clearly, it is not. We have had the Treasurer moralising here when we said to him today, `You are whingeing about people not getting their tax cuts for Christmas, but we will fix that for you today. Just ring them up in the Senate. Tell your people to vote for what is now Budget Deficit (Reduction) Bill'—or whatever they call it—`mark 3, and we will pass it. They will get their tax cuts even earlier'.

In fact, I predict that it will be passed on Tuesday anyway. I do not know whether the Treasurer will then come in here, crying his crocodile tears about the Christmas stocking—and I want to come back to that. But every time he gives us that lecture about economic and fiscal responsibility, I am tempted—I make the point `tempted' only—to interject upon him and say, `Why didn't you tell the people all these words before the election? Why didn't you say to them before the election that you couldn't have personal tax cuts unless you had a massive burden of indirect taxes dumped upon you?'. Why did not government members apply the first principle of that four-way test, and say to people, `Well, we don't like the approach of the Liberals to an indirect tax. We want to keep the old one, but you are going to have to live with the simple fact that, to give you those tax cuts we said we could deliver under One Nation and that we have put into l-a-w, you are going to have to cop some other taxes'. Why did they not do it? Why did they not take that first test: is it the truth?

Then of course we get down to the question: is it fair to all concerned? I think that is pretty important. Let us have a look at some of the aspects of fairness. The Treasurer, again, has been telling us how there is going to be all these magnificent presents for Christmas by way of personal tax cuts. I went and got hold of the statistics, as provided by the Treasurer in his budget papers, and I found the figure of $20,900. It is not $20,700 because the statistics do not happen to give me that figure. I also found that over 44 per cent of all taxpayers have a taxable income of less than $20,700. Of course, according to these wonderful new tax rules—and, might I add, the One Nation tax promise—they get nothing. They will get no personal tax cuts but, yes, they are to get a rebate. It was to be $100, but the government did a bit of a deal with the Democrats and gave them a lousy extra $1 a week. But when do they get the rebate? It will not be in time for Christmas. It is not to be provided for this Christmas, and some of them will still be waiting for it next Christmas. I tell honourable members, it will buy a lot of presents for the kids! It will not even pay, in that period, for the extra that people will pay for their petrol. So they are the first group.

When we look at those who earn less than $25,000, we find that a figure in excess of 57 per cent of taxpayers are in that category, and the best the entire 57 per cent can hope for, by way of a reduction in their income tax, is $3.30. That is for those right up near the $25,000 mark, and others get less. So I ask again: is it fair to all concerned that all those people will get no personal tax compensation or practically nothing? In fact, across the board, I suppose it will be $3.

There will be no dispute of the fact that it is these people who still have those motor cars with leaded engines that were inefficient, by modern day standards, when they were put in the cars. Of course, they are doubly inefficient today. We are not only talking about the type of fuel they use, but the fact that they use a lot more of it to travel a kilometre. Those people of course get no relief from the government's decision to increase fuel by 3c a litre and with the additional 2c a litre lined up for next year, just to toughen up the next Christmas a little bit more.

What a cynical exercise it is, considering the volatility of fuel prices, to bring those budget requirements from next year into this budget. We know why the government did it. It is just another way to deceive because, at the time when those taxes are applied, a person seeing petrol prices vary by 7c and 8c in a week will not know who gets the money. That is what this government was counting on with this long-term projection. It has nothing to do with long-term projection. One has only to have a look at the government's performance in terms of its deficits. I do not think it has got one budget outcome right in history. Some were better, some were worse. A couple of years ago, it was to be a $4.5 billion deficit and it came out $10 billion. It does not know where it is. It does not seem to be able to manage.

As I have told honourable members, we have a Prime Minister who cannot even read a written brief. He cannot sit down and absorb anything. He has to have it explained to him. He is rushed into the parliament and says it quickly, in case he forgets. Pump him up with J-curve, non-farm deflator and he will go for about five or six hours. After that, we would not know what he would do. He cannot manage. He is really and truly missing Bob Hawke.

These are the simple facts when we ask ourselves: is it fair to all concerned? Is it fair to families earning less than $25,000—50 per cent plus, nearly 60 per cent of Australia's taxpayers—to tell them that they get nothing by way of tax cuts? In fact, they must pay all this extra for their fuel when they have the most fuel-inefficient vehicles of the lot. What sort of a Christmas present is it to say to the kids, `I am sorry. I was going to take you to that lovely spot we know of a few hundred kilometres away but, because of the federal budget, our potential to travel has been reduced substantially and, I am sorry, we cannot go.'?

But it goes further than that because some of the families in that category are also small business people, people for whom I have a responsibility, and a substantial number of them own trucks. The Australian trucking industry is noted for the fact that many of its participants are owner-drivers, the epitome of a family small business.

What has this measure done for owner-drivers? The increased taxes have put up the average cost of operating a truck from $1,000 a week to $1,200. Truck drivers could try to negotiate an increased fee with their clients and, if they are lucky, the costs will shunt through. As the Road Transport Forum, a very reputable group in road transport circles, has told us, that will add about an extra $3 to the cost of a typical grocery basket. That is the sort of cost that will flow through from the decision to increase fuel charges.

A lot of people though are not that lucky. Government members have been telling us today how wonderful things will be in Victoria as a result of this budget. Victoria, more than any other state, is the manufacturing state. It is a state that is very vulnerable to import competition. The government—I am not particularly critical of this decision—has set the parameters for import competition. They get tougher every year as tariffs are lowered. But none of these taxes hit foreigners importing into Australia.

They send their goods in international ships, and where do they land them? On the very doorstep of the two great population centres of Australia—Melbourne and Sydney. All these people delivering food, clothing and commodities, be they Brazilian orange juice producers, Turkish dried fruit producers or Chinese manufacturers of clothing, just to name a few, are all coming into the country and competing, in particular with the people of Victoria. Yet we were told today by one government member that Victoria has never had it so good under a federal budget.

People have to absorb all these extra taxes.I remind you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that they are the taxes that people have to pay even when they are going broke. Numerous small businesses are not incorporated companies. Probably less than a quarter of the real mums and dads type of small businesses are incorporated. They do not get the benefit of the much lauded 6c in the dollar drop in company tax. That is for all the big boys who have been declaring such wonderful profits after tax in recent times. The little guys are not paying much tax because they are not making any profits in this recession we had to have. So where are they? There is an increase in all the taxes on the things they use and no offsetting tax personally and no offsetting tax in the corporate structure. How can that be fair to all concerned? How can that be right? It amazes me that these sorts of things happen.

We can read those opposite like a book. They all get together and put the words in place. I remember when they were first elected: they all trotted out the same words one after another. They are all given their lines and learn them like nursery rhymes. To a degree, it is very effective in a political sense, but we always know what they are up to. They have been running around moralising about whose fault it is that people are not getting tax cuts when the fault is clearly theirs.

They have also gone around spouting their lines on a few other subjects. The Prime Minister has been telling us that Graham Blight, the head of the NFF, does not like us any more. What the Prime Minister did not tell us is that Graham Blight does not like us because he believes we should also oppose the personal tax cuts. I have that in black and white. All the Prime Minister said was that Graham Blight does not like us anymore. The truth is that he does not like us because we have said yes. The government had a mandate to cut people's taxes. It did not have a mandate to increase the price of fuel, the price of all goods subject to sales tax and the price of wine. The simple fact is that the government will not get away with it.

Mr Blight's quite proper solution is the purely economic one of knocking off the taxes which he knows will kill his constituency—the farmers and others. How would honourable members like to be producing orange juice in Mildura and having to send it down to Melbourne to compete with the Brazilians. The Brazilians' costs have not increased a cent on account of this budget but, of course, the poor old Mildurians have to pay another $200 a week per semitrailer to get their product into the same market. What a joke!

The Prime Minister wants to quote us half of Mr Blight's remarks. I have Mr Blight's letter, so I know what he wants. I know why he is criticising, and he will have to keep on criticising. He would do a better job if he got on with representing the farmers instead of trying to run the country. I am fed up with paying him my dues. He seems to want to give all my money to economists. The National Farmers Federation seems to be more interested as an organisation in righting the budget than in representing the very legitimate interests of the individual farmers who are not going too well.

When we consider fairness and benefit, as laid down in the Rotary four-way test, the whole situation is amazing. Let us look at a few things straight out of the budget paper. It says inflation is to rise 3.5 per cent and unemployment is to stay at 10.75 per cent. The current account balance of payments is a mere $18 billion, of which this government proposes to borrow $16 billion. The minister is telling us about how his government will take on the responsibility for compensation claims resulting from the Mabo ruling. With what? Has he done a calculation under the fairness rule to decide who will lose a hospital or a school when he gives that money away? Or is he going to materialise it? Has it worked out a new system, or is he just one of those who believes two plus two equals six.

I do not mind how he does it, it is just that the budget papers tell us that the government proposes to borrow $16 billion this year and meanwhile the Prime Minister is saying, `I made the states a generous offer. I said I'll pick up the compensation'. What will he do—sell his pig farm? Of course he will not. He expects the Australian people to find that money even if it means losing hospitals or sacking school teachers—services which would be of better value to them. That is the sort of debt we are looking at. It is absolutely ridiculous and I cannot understand it.
Today, in a press release on national savings, the ANZ Bank told us about the superannuation scheme and how it will increase national savings. The report said:

SPEECH.PARA: The ANZ Saving Report shows that in trend terms, national saving fell by 1.2 per cent of gross domestic product or $1.2 billion in the June quarter, 1993.
This is the largest quarterly fall in national saving since the ANZ series commenced in 1974 and ends recent hopes that national savings had begun to stabilise.

The minister might want to tell us how that compensation money will be found in that situation. It appears the government will not rob the savings of Australians. They do not have savings. They are having to use it to pay for their petrol and the increased cost of buying their kids Christmas presents when in fact the government will not give most of them any tax cut anyway. The people who will get the cuts will probably be those who least need them. It is an outrageous situation.

PARA.TAB: This is a budget that does nothing for Australia's economic health and it is a farce for the Treasurer to suggest, as he did in his opening remarks, that it is a budget about jobs. It is about lost jobs, but not jobs. It is to be condemned in every form. Time prevents me from covering all the issues, but I close with the point that it is not the truth, it is not fair—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The motivation of the Labor Party during the Chifley era was the renunciation of unjust social programs which it said were in place in the Australian way of life. At that time, the worker, the fabric of Australia's economic future, was considered by the supporters of the party to be badly done by, not only by the capitalist bosses but all things authoritative. A revolution for justice was begun, which now has diminished.

PARA.TAB: Rather than accepting responsibility for our economic ills and developing improved policy, the Labor Party bosses have begun blaming: they blame the economy; they blame the world for not growing fast enough; they blame the fact that we are not a republic; they blame the Liberal Party, which has been in government only seven years out of the last 20; they blame employers; they blame investors; and they blame their mates. In fact, they blame everyone and everything. Yet Australia remains in a period of crisis which was artificially created by our Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

To understand why this Labor government has shifted from the roots of its past, one must study the autocratic nature of its leader who is a disciple of Jack Lang, that despotic leader of New South Wales in the 1930s who was so bad that he was sacked. The big fella despised Ben Chifley to the extent that he held a long-time grudge. And why was this the case? It was because Chifley had the strength of character to stand up to the tyrant, and this bitter man, Lang, wanted to repay his personal vendetta to Chifley and his policies by getting even. To the good fortune of Australia, Lang was given short shrift from public life and denied the opportunity of wreaking his revenge, but this poor, bitter man was so frustrated with his lack of worth that he told those who would listen of the correctness of his own policies—policies based on ego, poor management and disgrace.

The most eager of all listeners was a young Paul Keating, now our Prime Minister. This opinionated youngster was eager to hear of the leadership skills of Lang. He was Lang's protege and was trained to know that there is only one source of leadership, that is, one of an arrogant, despotic recreant. Look at how this man, this disgraced Jack Lang's man, has managed the country under the good faith provided by those still true-believing voters and supporters. The student would have received top marks from the big fella, but what would Lang know? We must all remember that he was sacked.

Our Jack Lang man, the misbegotten Prime Minister, has done to Australia what Jack did to New South Wales. In terms that our Labor colleagues will understand, he has wrecked it. Under our Prime Minister's reign we have seen the worst recession since Lang was in power; we have the highest unemployment since Lang was in power; the poorest class of people, the social class, since the days of Chifley.

We now have more crime, pay more tax, have more social problems and have the biggest family dilemma of increasingly frustrating breakdowns than ever before. Now the Prime Minister and his quite loopy Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) have delivered their budget of betrayal. This budget will go down in Australian political history as a lead weight around this government's neck. It is widely regarded with disdain by all sections of the Australian community.

We should remind ourselves, after almost seven weeks since the budget was delivered, of the headlines that greeted the budget of betrayal. The Sydney Morning Herald newspaper reported, `Hard hit faithful face more sacrifices' and `Reluctant government takes the wimp option'. The Australian newspaper reported that the budget was an `aimless display of little imagination'. The Canberra Times noted, `Government's tinkering will hurt low income earners'—the true believers. Finally the Age reported that there was `no long term vision in these regressive sums'.

Opposition to the budget has extended beyond the realms of the press gallery. Students and academics have protested against the budget. Doctors have doubted the government's predictions on Medicare savings, and the ACTU chief criticised the budget, saying that it would not be welcomed by the trade union movement. Then there is the rebellion of the Prime Minister's own backbench.

Many have gone so far as to say that this Keating-Dawkins budget is the worst budget since Whitlam was Prime Minister. The fact that Australia's level of real economic activity is at its lowest since the Depression should be of no comfort to those government backbenchers who sit sanguinely as they listen to the ravings of the Treasurer each question time.

This budget of betrayal has been received poorly across Australia, and no less than in my electorate of Cowan. Many of my constituents buy just the basics. They drink, smoke and drive. The Prime Minister told us that we would be worse off under the Liberal Party. I wonder now who would agree. Do honourable members remember the Labor Party pledge during the election campaign: jobs, not GST? Where are the jobs in this budget the Treasurer so proudly boasted of during his budget mark 1 speech? Instead of having a tax at 15 per cent, we now have increases to 21 per cent and 31 per cent.

The women our Prime Minister so proudly thanked on election night now have increases in most of their personal products which the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) today so proudly stated were luxury items. It just shows how out of touch these paternalistic socialist dinosaurs really are. They are really out of touch with Australia.

A point which has been neglected by the government and by many commentators is the poor attention given by this government to the urgent need for capital investment and infrastructure in this country. While we suffer with high levels of unemployment and poor micro-economic reform programs, unbeknown to many is the fact that Australia's infrastructure is fast approaching a state of terrible disrepair. Without a major overhaul and the injection of capital investment, recovery will continue to be a long way down the track, and high unemployment rates will continue to be a black spot on our economic landscape.

The Treasurer has developed an unsound budget in keeping with his unhealthy ravings about the performance of the economy. This quite daft Treasurer has impaired thinking when it comes to financial responsibility. This budget is defective in that it has not addressed the basic problem of Australia: living beyond our means in the hope that our assets will eventually increase so that we can cover our debts. A person can go broke earning $6,000 a week. Some people ask, `How can you go broke earning $6,000 a week?'. The answer is simple, `Spend $7,000'. That is what is happening to this country. We do not earn enough money. But what is the government doing about that?

I say to the Prime Minister, `Thank you, Paul Keating, our Prime Minister, for giving us the Treasurer. Thank you for your empathy to the Australian people. Thank you for being divisive and belligerent. Thank you for setting Australian against Australian. Thank you for sending so many Australians into bankruptcy, for denying many Australians a proper health system and for keeping most Australians not only poor in pocket but also poor in confidence about their future'.

Where are the leaders of the Labor Party to stand up to such a dilapidating wrecker of Australian hope, vision and values? Where is the leader to bring back the proper values within the Labor Party? Where is the principled Chifley? Are those opposite sucked in by electoral success so much as to compromise the values of their once proud true believers? Are they now so unprincipled that they do not care about the workers and are now the strumpets of the union bosses and their crazy social justice programs which defy normal financial responsibility? But there is no Ben Chifley, there is no John Curtin and, dare I say it, there is no Gough Whitlam to stand up to this oppressor of the workers' policies.

This traitor to the principles of the Labor Party has used ruses to convince his fellow travellers of his place in history. This deserter of Australian values detests all things Australian, from the clothes he wears and the clocks he collects to his loathing of our heritage. If his party lets him have his way, which it is weak enough to do, it will rue the day. Our Prime Minister is only concerned about one thing: his place in history.

Has the belligerence of our Prime Minister got to a level of hero worship status by the left of the party? Have they deserted their principles of social justice to accept the maniacal actions of our most narcissistic Prime Minister who is intent on gaining his precious place in history? Quite clearly this is the case, and the future of Australia and Australians, and the hopes of our children, lies not with the true believers, for they have disappeared into history.

The future of Australia lies with the leaders of the Liberal Party and their tolerance of the challenges we will be faced with. The Liberal Party and its members are the new future for the workers and every other Australian, and thank goodness. Hooray for those Labor lefties who have been victims of subterfuge and are no longer red in their thinking, for the rejection of their ideals will ultimately be the motivator for Australians to embrace the Liberal Party.

In conclusion, patriots are those who love their country so much that they are prepared to fight their own government. We on this side of politics are the patriots in Australia today, and all I can say is, `God bless Australia'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and to reflect what has been said by members on this side of the House about a budget, the receipt of which has been met with nothing but scorn from the people around Australia. No matter where we look for an opinion on the 1993 budget, we find people who are indignant about its impact on their lifestyle—not merely indignant from a selfish point of view, but indignant because they recognise that this budget fails to address the major problems faced by Australia and fails to provide the opportunity for some sort of renewal.

PARA.TAB: A lot of scorn has been heaped on members of the opposition by those opposite because of our decision to oppose just three sectors of the budget. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you will be aware from the speeches delivered, we chose to oppose the rise in wholesale sales tax, to oppose the changes in fuel excise, to oppose the changes in the sales tax on wine and to oppose the retrospective implications that the budget has in the areas of long service leave and holiday leave loading.

Such action affected in total barely two per cent of budget outlays. But the opposite side of the House has created the impression that would lead one to believe our intention was to block the budget and frustrate the government. Barely two per cent of budget outlays are affected by the changes proposed by the opposition. Why have we taken this bold and unprecedented, but responsible, step? Because the government cannot claim a mandate for the changes it proposed in the 1993 budget.

For telling it as it is, we, the opposition, lost an election. In that same election, the government failed to indicate to the people of Australia that it was the intention of the ALP to make these sorts of changes in a budget to be handed down within four months of the 13 March poll. The government gave no inkling to the people of Australia that it proposed the sorts of dramatic tax hikes that have been a part of this budget.

The government did indicate to the people of Australia that they could reasonably expect tax cuts—and we recognise that. Because the tax cuts had been legislated for, as the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) knows—l-a-w, law—we chose what for us was an uncomfortable, but responsible, course of allowing those tax cuts to go through. But those particular tax imposts which have been so unfair on Australians we chose to oppose without frustrating the direction the government was taking. So in the areas of fuel, wine, retrospective tax on long service leave and holiday leave loading, we, the opposition, have taken the principled stand of opposing these measures without frustrating the government because less than two per cent of the budget revenue is affected by these changes.

Much has been made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of the remarks uttered by the President of the NFF, Mr Graham Blight, in response to the opposition's stance on the budget. Mr Blight made these remarks at a conference convened by the Australian farm management society during the royal show in Adelaide. The one claim to fame that I, as a member of the House of Representatives, can make is that, unlike any other member of the House of Representatives, I was there. I heard Mr Blight say what he said about the opposition and naturally I stood up somewhat indignant and rebuffed his argument.

What I also heard from Mr Blight at the same conference, which was never acknowledged by the Prime Minister, was the criticism he levelled at the government. Certainly he was unhappy with the opposition, but not because we had chosen to oppose the sales tax increases, not because we had chosen to refuse to pass the increase in the wine tax, and not because we had chosen to refuse the changes in fuel excise; he was unhappy that we had not taken the additional step of opposing the tax cuts.

Imagine how indignant he was at a government that had proposed all of those increases and proposed the tax cuts. For the Prime Minister to claim any mandate from the President of the NFF is totally erroneous. The truth is that, while the President of the NFF may have been less than fulsome in his praise of the opposition, he was far more critical—not surprisingly—of the government over its budget direction.

He reflected what has been the universal criticism of the people of Australia. Mr Graham Blight's constituents and my constituents are largely the same people. They are also the constituents shared by the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb). They, of course, are indignant at the fuel impost and at the increased cost of production in rural Australia as a result of the changes to fuel excise.

These are the people who cannot afford the change to unleaded vehicles. These are the people from areas in which lead pollution has a minimal impact and these are the people who are being obliged by this government to pay the cost of what is largely an urban problem. More than that, they cannot make the change and so they are forced to change their already crippled lifestyle, as mentioned by the honourable member for Parkes, in order to accommodate what has been this government's budget obsession.

The fuel tax is clearly a regressive tax. It flows through the entire cost of production in Australia. I noted that, following the budget announcement, the Australian brought out an advertisement in which it made the point that shopping trolleys run on diesel, simply because the impact of the fuel excise on the price of goods in any shopping trolley was calculated, not by the opposition but by the Road Transport Forum, as being somewhere in the vicinity of $2 to $3. That average of $2 to $3 in additional costs is borne by every consumer in Australia, no matter what their task. So every consumer needs to take out of the Australian economy an additional $2 or $3. When we multiply that we appreciate just how regressive this tax is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Straight out of their Christmas stockings.

—As the honourable member for Parkes mentioned, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has been so anxious to create the impression that we are the people denying Australians the opportunity for a merry Christmas when effectively it has been his budget and his budget strategy which has made the delivery of these income tax cuts so difficult.

PARA.TAB: If there has been universal indignation about this budget and its impact, nowhere has it been spelt out more clearly than in the wine industry that is so much a part of my electorate. I make the point, which I made in response to the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) this morning, that if ALP members truly claimed to represent their electorates they would be standing up and saying what opposition members are saying about the impact of this tax.

I do not want to be unkind to the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), who is a charitable colleague of mine, but I gather that he has been much more outspoken in his electorate than he has been in the House. In fact, he has failed to represent the interests of his electors in spelling out just what this 55 per cent hike in wine tax will do to his electorate. I am acutely aware of what it is doing to his electorate because the same impact is being felt in mine. Why is it that the voices being raised in protest about this tax are solely those on this side of the House, echoing not some sort of prejudicial view expressed by the opposition but echoing instead what constituents right across Australia are saying to us all?

In the debate this morning the honourable member for Lilley was anxious to make much of what he saw as equity in the tax system as a result of changes to the wine tax and anxious to make much of what he saw as the failure of the wine industry to pay its share of taxation when compared to the brewers or the spirits manufacturers. Equity in tax! Is there any comparison to be made between the wine industry—which is in itself a labour intensive industry and, frankly, which is calculated to have more value adding built into it than any other primary industry; an industry which has become the benchmark for export development—and the spirits and brewing industries? Of course there is not.

What does it take to get into the wine industry? It takes a block of land, trellising, the planting of vines to a particular root stock and a delay of between five and 10 years to get into a production which is large enough to ensure that the debt incurred has been met. That is not the end. Having done all of that, the grapes are picked and processed in a labour intensive way, carefully blended and placed in a bottle to be matured for another three to five years, making a total delay of something like seven to 10 years before a real return can be felt in a quality wine product.
