How does that compare with the brewing industry which is nothing more than the annual crop of hops added to the annual crop of barley with a dose of water, probably on a monthly basis, to produce a product that can be brewed, or the spirits industry, the resource of which is frequently waste product? There ought to be no comparison for tax equity between the wine industry and the beer and spirits industries. After all, our major competitors in Europe make no such comparison. They deliberately favour the wine industries in their countries. Any quick glance at statistics will reveal that the major European wine producers are not taxing their wine at the level that Australian wine is currently being taxed, without the 55 per cent impost by this government in this budget.

It has been calculated that by the year 2000 the 55 per cent impost in wine tax proposed by the government in the August 1993 budget will raise something like $700 million. If one adds to it the tax revenue that the government is already scraping out of the wine industry, by the year 2000 the wine industry will have contributed the sum of $2 billion to the government coffers in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is more than the growers get.

—Not only is that more than the growers get, as the honourable member for Parkes quite rightly interjects, but more incredibly, the export target for the wine industry for the year 2000 is the export of $1 billion worth of product. So, if this government stays on its course, by the year 2000 the wine industry will have generated for the government twice as much as it will produce in export income.

PARA.TAB: I ask the honourable member for Lilley to think again just what tax equity is all about. Nor should he accuse the opposition, in his desperate desire for tax equity, of in some way falsely protecting the wine industry from the reality of meeting its responsibility in the community.

We are the people who went into opposition leaving behind a wine industry that had no sales tax and no excise. We went into opposition in the face of statements from a former Prime Minister, who said in Griffith in the electorate of the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks), `There will be no tax on wine'. As the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) knows, it did not take long for that promise to be reversed.

We took the responsible view of recognising that, if the wine industry was an industry with an alcohol base, it was not unreasonable for it to carry some tax. While we expressed our indignation at the rate at which this government overthrew its pre-election promise, nonetheless we tolerated a tax of up to 20 per cent, believing there was some equity in that. However, it is totally indefensible to lift the tax by 55 per cent from 20 per cent to 31 per cent in one fell swoop.

Earlier today the honourable member for Lilley went on to say that this tax rise would not affect the wine industry because the industry's principal growth area is exports and, after all, exports do not carry the sales tax. I could not believe that he could take such a blinkered view of an industry that is principally Australian and has become the benchmark for export development. On what does the honourable member imagine the wine industry has been built? It has been built on the quality of its domestic product.

Every time we make it difficult to build a domestic base we make it harder to make inroads into an export base. Every time we frustrate the development of quality wine in the domestic industry we reduce the base from which we have to export. We need quality wine in Australia to continue to fuel export development.

The impact of this budget will be to reduce the base of quality wine in Australia, to force up the cost of production in Australia and to make it more difficult for the industry to get into export markets. Is this rumour-mongering? Is this just a case of the opposition running around conveniently in South Australia making a difficult case? If it is, I ask the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley): why is it the case that is also being expressed by the ALP Premier of South Australia, Premier Arnold? Why is it that the wineries in South Australia and across Australia have since the budget faced a major downturn in wine sales?

Today I spoke to the representatives of two wineries in my electorate, expecting that perhaps there had been a 30 per cent downturn in wine sales, and found that, in one case, the downturn had been estimated at 50 per cent and, in the other case, at 60 per cent. The major winemaker whose sales had fallen by 60 per cent since the impact of the budget said to me, `Do you know what this is costing me?'. And consider this, Mr Deputy Speaker, in view of the location of your electorate: he said, `I employ over 30 people in my sales arm in Sydney. And, with sales falling by 60 per cent, every one of their jobs is at risk'.

The longer the government goes on delaying what is effectively a decision on the wine tax the longer it protracts this whole uncertainty about the wine industry. It is too easy for the government to simply blame the opposition for what it sees as the frustrated package of the wine tax measures. This opposition has not moved one iota on its opposition to wine tax and neither, so far as I am aware over the last week, have the Australian Democrats nor the Greens. There is nothing preventing the Treasurer, in the interests of the Australian wine industry, simply removing this legislation and so allowing certainty to return to the wine industry, the sales base to grow once again and the export base to grow as well.

As I said in some comments that I made in the House earlier today, if we are indignant at the impact of a 55 per cent increase in the sales tax base for wine, every Australian ought to join us in making an even louder noise about the little matter that has been largely forgotten in this parliament and largely overlooked. Given the influence that the Leader of the House has in government policy making, I bring directly to his attention the impact not only of a 55 per cent sales tax on wine but the astonishing impact of a decision by the government in the budget to raise the tax on dealcoholised wine from 10 per cent to 21 per cent.

That is a 110 per cent increase on a product that does absolutely no harm to the Australian community and is largely used as a healthy alternative for those who find that they are intolerant of alcohol. This 110 per cent increase applies to product with an alcohol rating of under 1.15 per cent. Most of that product has an alcohol rating of under .05 per cent. What is the reaction of the government? It raises the tax on that product by 110 per cent.

The most charitable view that could be taken is that this may have been an unintended consequence of the government's obsession with taxation. If I am going to be that charitable there is no reason why the government should not choose to reverse this decision because it generates little in income and frankly does nothing but frustrate what is a developing part of Australia's primary industry.

On behalf of the opposition I implore the government to pick up that two per cent of the budget that we have found so frustrating that it has deserved our indignation, to amend that two per cent and allow the budget's rapid passage in the interests of the people of Australia and the certainty of the Australian wine industry. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this late hour of 10 minutes past 11, it is interesting to observe that we have 41 people in the public gallery witnessing this debate. Since the dinner adjournment, we have had a total score on the government side of one minister, and no government members. At least at this late stage there are now three ministers in the House.
—That's because you are speaking.
—That is probably right, but it is fairly typical of the complete disregard that this government is taking towards this parliament—
—I have a great regard for you.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! The minister will keep quiet and stop interjecting.
An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —And so will the gallery.

—It is fairly typical of this government, the disrespect that it holds for this place and the complete and utter contempt it holds for the voters of Australia. I congratulate the previous speaker, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), on his speech because I think his speech exemplified one area which showed how that contempt has been put onto the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: It has been an amazing few weeks since the budget was delivered in the middle of August. It was an amazing budget inasmuch as within 24 hours it was rejected and members of the government were leaving the ships like rats down a drainpipe. My colleague made reference to two of those members and what they did: the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) and the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan). I think that was fairly typical of what was going on amongst the back bench of the Labor Party when it realised what an absolute disaster this particular budget was.

It was a fact that publications were going out in the electorate of Hunter completely disowning the budget. Like Eric the Red, he was ploughing the fields, telling them how he had stood up to this terrible government and fought those budget measures, but he is not here tonight. We had exactly the same thing in the electorate of Lilley in Brisbane. Like the little petal that he is, the honourable member for Lilley was prancing around the place saying that he had fought the good fight and had got all these changes in the budget. But when they come in here, of course, that bravado is not there because they are under the thumb of this government which is prepared to press on with what can only be described as draconian measures in this budget.

One really does wonder how much the government has thought it through. We heard the story of the wine industry just recently. We heard the story of the increased tax on fuel. We have heard the claims of government members, and from the Australian Democrats as to how they have saved the nation and people will not be paying as much for their fuel. But, in actual fact, all that those people have succeeded in doing is putting an extra 7c per litre on the price of fuel. As my colleague mentioned just a few minutes ago, the flow-on effect of that throughout industry in Australia is absolutely enormous.

It is true that when we look at these budget documents, we find there is to be no improvement in the unemployment rate and the debt is still going to be there. The only way Australia is going to get out of this trouble is to get into overseas markets, but the government obviously has no understanding at all of how exports work.

I am delighted to see the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) at the table tonight because there are a few matters that I would like to raise and I am sure that, after some of the verbal battles that we had prior to the last election, he must be flabbergasted at the moves that the government has made. He will remember those great debates in the tourism industry about the effects of a goods and services tax and how dreadful that was and that we were going to see the total and utter collapse of the tourist industry because of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You supported me. You opposed your own policy.
—Order! The minister will cease interjecting.

—What has the government done? We have seen the imposition of taxation regimes on about the only export industry that has the capacity to provide big numbers of jobs for Australians; that has the capacity to provide big numbers in terms of foreign income for Australians. Of course, it is doing everything it can to make sure that that industry cannot get off its back. It does so through the fuel tax, which is being passed on all the way down the line. Not only the transport operators, but the bus operators and the cruise ship operators are all paying more tax and that is going to be forwarded on.

PARA.TAB: The most outstanding debacle that has ever been put up was the imposition of the fringe benefits tax on business travel and what that is going to do to the industry. I really wonder which intellectual giant, if any, thought that one through. It is very interesting when one talks to government members that one cannot find where the idea came from. Did it come from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)? Apparently, in Monte Carlo, he was denying too much knowledge of it. Does it come from the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins)? Maybe; we will never know. Did it come from the bureaucracy?

It did not take too long for the industry to realise what a dreadful impact that was going to have. We look through those budget papers and see all these suggestions as to how public service rates were going to be applied. Nobody must have read the book, because when we went through that taxation ruling on the public service travel allowance, we found that there were literally dozens of permutations and combinations that could be applied in trying to calculate what the tax was going to be. That was pointed out to the government and, of course, it backed down on that.

It came up the other day—and this is how good it really is—with this brand new solution that we will have this flat rate across the board. It was implied that the rate may start at $300 a day. Of course, Access Economics did its homework on that and found that if that was applied in that manner, the most likely outcome would be that the government would get no income whatsoever under the fringe benefits tax arrangements. In fact, the revenue might decline. In the meantime, an industry has come to a stop when it realised that if this tax came in, it would be in big and desperate trouble.

More importantly than that, I believe that the young people of Australia are in deep and desperate trouble. I think it has been fairly well established through the official studies that there are going to be at least 10,000 jobs lost in the tourism and hospitality industry if this particular measure proceeds. That would mean 10,000 young people would be looking at losing their jobs. But what about the thousands—and there are now thousands—of young people in the tourism and hospitality colleges around Australia who are training with the hope that they will be able to get into this industry; that they will have a career path in a growth industry, in an industry that is full of fun—

TALK.START.PARA: —They will have.
—The minister says, `They will have'. Is that an indication that the government is going to throw out the fringe benefits tax provisions completely? I sincerely—
—We will break every inbound tourism record from now until—
—Order! The minister will not carry on a conversation.

—The minister is now making some fairly wild claims. The government may do that, but what it is going to do to the domestic industry is cripple it, because under this particular arrangement, one of the first things that is going to be shot to pieces is the whole convention market in Australia. If the government is going to apply all these taxes across the board, what is going to happen? The convention organisers are going to go offshore; they will take their business elsewhere. It would be a physical impossibility for this government to try to estimate exactly what the expenditure might be in such exotic locations as Bali, Singapore, Fiji or Thailand and it will lose that whole sector of the industry. Is that not crazy?

PARA.TAB: There has been enormous investment in convention centres in Melbourne and Sydney. The Queensland state government in its budget just a few weeks ago allocated $75 million for the construction of a convention centre in Brisbane and for assistance for a convention centre in Cairns. We build these crystal cathedrals on our shores and they will remain absolute tombs; nobody will go there, because the government is taxing them out of all creation. They have gone offshore; they have taken their money with them and run. Those buildings sit there derelict. More importantly, the young kids of Australia have not got a job. That is an appalling situation.

If we get those limits that are being proposed into the system, what do we see around Australia? One of the things that I think this government can be justly proud of over the last decade has been the construction of some world-class hotels. I defy anybody to say these days that we do not stack up with some of the major overseas destinations in the quality of the hotels and the service that we provide.

These major hotels, after all, are being used by the top end of the market; they are being used by international visitors. Their bread and butter is still coming out of business travel in Australia and their yields have been dreadful in recent times because of the economic downturn and the recession. What are they going to do? They are going to have to fit in with a price, so the prices come down.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a rule of thumb that the cost of a hotel room per night is about one per cent of the cost of the construction of the room. The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) knows as well as I do that the cost of room construction at one of the new hotels in Sydney was $850,000 per unit. He might also be aware that the overnight cost at the moment to try to get some business is about $180 a night. Honourable members should look at some of the older hotels in Australia where the rooms were costing $250,000 dollars to build. What returns are they getting now? In one of the big chains the government rate is $92 a night. They have come down as far as that. If we get this tax imposed on the system, we will see those rates pushed down and down.

PARA.TAB: To stay afloat, those hotels will have to make some very big adjustments. The first adjustment that they will make is to off-load staff. The estimates around Australia are that 10,000 jobs will go. Australia enjoys an enviable reputation in world terms as a tourist destination. At the moment I think our properties and the service that we provide stack up against almost anything around the world. But that level of service, because of what the government is doing, will have to decline. We will see those standards come down, the prices for those international visitors will come down, and that will flow all the way through the whole industry. The big losers will be the three-star hotels, and the other great losers will be the mum's and dad's hotels and motels. People do not realise in Australia that, while we talk about the tourist industry and while we pay due respect to the five-star properties at the top end of the market, the reality is that about 92 per cent of the tourist industry in Australia is made up of small business. They are the ones that we will hurt.

Honourable members can see what has happened around Australia in recent times. In places like Cairns, the Gold Coast or even Sydney, the high occupancy rates are in the top end of the market. The minister's reference to the number of overseas visitors is quite true. The possibility of getting a hotel room in Cairns these days at the top end of the market is pretty slim. Cairns probably needs another three five-star hotels over the next couple of years. Even the Gold Coast will need to require more properties. The lower end of the market—the mum's and dad's motels—has had the worst year on record. A lot of that is because of the economic downturn. The government will help that along even more because it has just whacked a bit more onto the fuel tax. We have seen, especially in the case of the Gold Coast and its Victorian market, which was an important one over the years, that the Victorians are not travelling much further north than the border. While places like Bega and Merimbula are doing quite well at the moment, the real reason is that people are not travelling as far. A lot of room stock will be crippled.

It is a crazy situation if the whole of Australia has to take a downturn in its standards because of the short-sighted stupidity evident in this government's imposition of those fringe benefits tax arrangements. It flows right the way through the industry. We have talked about the conventions; we have talked about the hotels. We saw what happened initially when fringe benefits were applied to restaurants. Nobody denies that all sorts of tricks were going on in terms of claiming for restaurant meals. The government, in its imitable style in the mid-1980s, knocked the whole thing on the head with a sledgehammer and we saw restaurants going out of business all over the place. It has taken a long time and a great restructure of those restaurants for them to come back. While we have some restaurants at the top end of the market, there are not as many there now as there usually were. The standard or nature of restaurants has gone down-market. What is euphemistically called the family restaurant is now picking up a great deal of the business. We have lost the tradition of the silver service restaurants that we had before.

With these provisions in the original proposal, people will be able to claim something like $50 a day for three meals if they are travelling interstate. That would see that industry decline even further. As one of my hoteliers told me, if people are trying to make a profit in this game in some of the luxury hotels in Australia, $50 would not even buy a sandwich. That is probably pretty right. I suppose it is all right for the government to think that the business travellers of Australia can stay at the YMCA and buy themselves a bowl of rice, if they are lucky, for lunch and another one for dinner. That is really what the government is talking about. We are losing all that tradition and investment that we have had in the hospitality industry. We have seen a decline in the number of the top of the market restaurants, but the government wants to go even further. Government members get up here and trumpet their huge successes in international tourism; they trumpet how they have been the only ones who have ever really made any effort to build the industry in Australia. But nobody thought this proposal through. All they are interested in is knocking this industry on the head and getting these stupid socialistic principles into place—principles at the end of the day which will see one thing happen, and that is the decline in the number of jobs.

It is not too late for the government to change its budget strategies. It is not too late for it to go out and say that the wine tax is absolutely stupid and it will get rid of that; we will really affect our export industries if we maintain this stupid arrangement with the increase in the fuel tax; and it really will be a crazy situation if we wreck the hotel and the hospitality industry through the fringe benefits taxes. If the government had any intestinal fortitude it would go in and make the hard decisions, realising that it has made some dreadful mistakes and should change the situation. How many versions of the budget have we had so far? Three or four. I am sure that mark 5 would be welcomed if it contained some sensible arrangements and was thought through, and these particular impositions which will have a disastrous effect on some sections of our industry were taken out altogether.

Australians are cynical about politicians at the moment. They are terribly cynical about what went on before the last election. They are terribly cynical about the implications of this particular budget. We cannot blame them. They were misled right the way through the election. The government went into the election on a fear campaign, and fear it was. The fear within the Australian community was generated in that budget just over six weeks ago. It is a disaster for Australia. The kindest thing that the government could possibly do would be to withdraw the budget altogether and try to start again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to bring to the attention of the House a copy of a letter I have received from a constituent in Selby which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr. Keating,

It is most unusual for me to write to an M.P. let alone a P.M. but I feel there are some comments I must make to you. Basically my concern is about what I would perceive as the bad example you are giving to the younger members of our community and in particular my children. My concerns cover a number of areas, namely:

1.Your language whilst in Parliament I believe is disgusting when our children can see you on the evening news using words like "scumbag". This word became part of the vocabulary of my then 7 year old last year and his defence when questioned was "that is what Mr. Keating says".
My question to you is do you believe you are setting a good example to the children of this country by using words like that?

2.All Australia saw before the election of your promise of tax cuts, it being "L.A.W." To have then broken a promise after such a short time, (and don't even try to defend to me that by advancing half the cuts by six months and deferring the other half by more than six months that the electorate is no worse off), I must again ask you other questions.
a). By telling a lie to the electorate just over five months ago what example is this setting to the children and teenagers of Australia?
b).Do you believe that by lying and getting away with it that it's acceptable?
c).If the economy was "on the improve" before the election what information do you now have that has changed your mind on the tax cuts that were " L.A.W."?
d).In light of the 1993 Budget, did you tell the electorate of the massive increases in indirect taxes before the March Federal election?
e).If your answer to the last question is negative, what justification do you now have to increase the costs of essential items?

f).How can you defend to my family your tax imposts on Super petrol. It will eventually cost this single income family an additional $400 p.a. and our taxable income is such that we just miss out on your tax cuts. My wife and I have two cars with a combined age of 33 years and 560,000 km's on the clock and public transport is virtually non-existent.

3. When Mr. Hawke was Prime Minister he continually spoke of "Equity, Fairness and Justice". Can you please explain to me how these key principles of Mr. Hawke and presumably the ALP relate to the 1993 Budget?
4. When you said "we brought home the bacon" who were the recipients of this feast?

5. I can clearly remember the 1990 Federal Election Campaign and Gordon Bilney standing next to a notice that said the Democrats would tax your home, implying the family house would not be exempt from the CGT. I also note that Bilney narrowly defeated Janine Haines.

In light of this and your lies in 1993, do you believe it is time to introduce a code of ethics legislation that would require all politicians, and potential ones to not tell lies or be guilty of misrepresentation?
As I said above it is unusual for me to write to a Prime Minister and I trust you will give me the respect of seriously answering each of the above questions.
I look forward to the answers to each of the questions listed above.
Thanking you in anticipation,
Alan Ashmore
I also look forward with anticipation to the reply from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the House to the economic vandalism being inflicted on the people of New South Wales by the coalition government of Premier John Fahey. In a state with one of the highest unemployment rates in Australia, the New South Wales government continues to underspend its capital works program. It has also cut 10,000 jobs in its recent state budget.

PARA.TAB: Before the last federal election in March this year, it was revealed that the Fahey government was underspending its capital works budget by up to $300 million. This was clearly designed to slow down economic growth and employment growth in the lead-up to the federal election so that the federal government would not get political credit for its job creating capital works initiatives such as One Nation and the local capital works program, which delivered over $100 million to New South Wales councils.

We now find that the Fahey government has made further cuts of over $200 million in this financial year on top of last year's cuts. This means a reduction of 4.2 per cent on capital works in real terms, which will cost over 4,000 jobs. Add this to the public sector job cuts totalling 3,500 in key authorities, including Elcom, the Water Board, Hunter Water and the SRA, as well as over 2,000 further job cuts in government departments, and we have more than 10,000 jobs down the drain. This is despite the fact that the federal government grants to New South Wales increased by $288 million in addition to the $100 million direct funding to the local government under the local capital works program. Yet the Fahey government has the hide to blame lack of federal funding for the state's problems. All that is happening is that Fahey is pocketing federal funding grants and reducing his own government's contribution to capital works so that he can save up to buy the next state election.

A particular example of this dishonesty is evident in health funding. The Fahey government's hype about increases to health funding is a giant fraud. In fact, most of the increased funding is Commonwealth money and the New South Wales government's contribution has dropped in real terms. One has only to look in my electorate of Macarthur for evidence of the Fahey government's disgraceful record in health funding.

In 1991-92 hospital funding in south-west Sydney was cut by $10 million to $214 million. Hospitals covered by the south-west Sydney area health service had productivity cuts of $4.7 million, and $1.7 million was withheld from the redevelopment of Liverpool hospital. If the south-west Sydney area health service were funded properly, it would get an extra $110 million—in other words, 50 per cent more than it currently gets. At Camden hospital in my electorate, staffing levels for nurses are dangerously low, but the administration still has to hand back funds to the state government as `savings'.

The nursing staff at Camden hospital have become so concerned about staffing levels and staff morale that they have asked their union to intervene. The maternity unit is a classic example. Even though the hospital's own protocol requires two staff in the delivery suite at any time, often only one nurse is rostered on of an evening. Recently, in the post- and ante-natal wards there have been only one nurse and one aide looking after 28 patients. The staff are scared of losing their jobs if they complain about the situation, and they are also scared of losing the lives of patients if they do not complain about it.

In 1989 the state coalition government under Nick Greiner closed the children's ward at the Camden hospital. The Camden area in the Macarthur electorate is the fastest growing area in New South Wales, with the youngest population. Half the population is under the age of 20. What does the state government do? It closes the children's ward at the hospital. Goodness gracious, what an absolute farce and what an indictment on a state liberal government in New South Wales. The government closed hospital services, closed beds and closed a children's ward in an area with the fastest growth and the youngest population.

Some of the other effects of the Fahey government's health cuts are as follows. Victims of sexual assault wait up to 12 months for counselling and five-month waits are common. There is the lack of a safe house for the victims of sexual assault and programs to challenge the social attitudes that allow sexual assault to occur. There is a lack of health facilities in the fast growing Bargo-Tahmoor-Picton area. There are 3,200 patients on waiting lists for surgery and there is an increase of about 13 per cent a year in waiting lists. There are 16,000 patients on waiting lists for dentistry and they are forced to wait between 18 months and three years.

Liverpool hospital, amongst many others, is threatened with privatisation. There were 20 beds cut from hospitals in the south-west Sydney area in 1991-92, and bed levels in south-west Sydney are 15 per cent below the New South Wales average. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the opportunity in this adjournment debate to rebut the continued assertion by misguided politicians and academics that Australia must inevitably become a republic, and that those who wish to retain our stable form of government—constitutional monarchists—are out of step with middle Australia, and especially out of step with young Australians. I have already stressed in a previous debate in this place that there is no inevitably about Australia becoming a republic because there is no burning desire in the hearts of most Australians for a republican form of government, be it on a minimalist or wider agenda.

PARA.TAB: Polls favouring a republic are already starting to turn. I draw attention to yesterday's Newspoll in the Australian showing a significant reversal of opinion, and I predict that the number of Australians favouring our present Westminster system of government will increase further with time. When do we hear of the republican cause being spontaneously supported by great numbers, despite the fact that members of the Republic Advisory Committee set up by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) are travelling the length and breadth of Australia at the taxpayers' expense to push the republican cause?

The crowd sizes recorded at such meetings have been extremely interesting. They are as follows: in Wollongong 60 people attended; in Rockhampton there were 50; in Geelong 45 people turned out; in Launceston 30 attended; in Manly, Sydney, they managed a crowd of 150, although among those there was a large contingent of young people defending a constitutional monarchy; in Brisbane 23 people attended; and in the town of Whyalla, that supposed great bastion of Labor, the organisers need not have bothered to hire a hall: one solitary person turned up.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of one.
—All of one. The meeting could have been held in a phone box outside instead.
—And it would have been empty.

—That is right. By contrast, the Australians for Constitutional Monarchy, who are completely unfunded by the taxpayer and rely on personal donations, held a rally at the Dallas Brooks Hall in Melbourne on 25 August and attracted a crowd of 800 people from all age groups. Certainly there were elderly Australians, and why not? After all, they have done a great deal to build this country.

PARA.TAB: There were also significant numbers of young men and women in their 20s. Two of the main speakers were also in their 20s—one young man of Irish Catholic descent and one young woman of Greek descent. Another young woman and mother of Asian descent in her 30s spoke movingly of what the stability of the Australian constitution means to her and her family.

In the only television coverage I have witnessed, when people in the street in Melbourne were intervened on this topic, the two young people asked to give their opinion, both of whom were women who looked to be in their early 20s, favoured the monarchy. Opinion is divided among the young people I know, many favouring the present system of government. It is therefore nonsense to assert that young people favour a republic, just as it is nonsense to say that a republic is inevitable. The fact is that young people, like the rest of the community, are divided on the issue, and unnecessarily so.

As has been said on a number of occasions previously—and with justification—the push for a republic is partly diversionary; it is to take public attention away from the disastrous state of the economy. It is partly caused by the Anglophobia of the Prime Minister which has been displayed petulantly on previous occasions. The Prime Minister's ostensible reason for the assertion that we must become a republic in order to secure our independence is ludicrous.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is nonsense.

—It is absolute nonsense. Australia has been independent from Britain since the Statute of Westminster in 1932. The last residual ties were severed completely by the Australia Act of 1986. The government and all its members are well aware of that.

PARA.TAB: If Australia is to ensure its independence, it must do so with sound policies in a stable constitutional system. There is none better than the Westminster system, which we know and trust. Why should we risk the vagaries of a republic or assume it to be inevitable? Australia's becoming a republic is not inevitable; nothing is inevitable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to record a brief tribute to a man who died 60 years ago on 8 October 1933. The anniversary of his death is one week from tomorrow. Harry Holland was born at Gungahlin outside present Canberra in 1868. As a young journalist, he worked on the Queanbeyan Times. His father was a farm labourer.

PARA.TAB: Holland never received the recognition he deserved for his contribution to the development of the Australian and New Zealand Labour parties and their socialist traditions. Harry Holland moved to Sydney in 1887 and met and married Annie McLachlan, whom he had met at a Salvation Army meeting. In 1892, faced with the need to support his family by delivering newspapers seven days a week, including Sunday, he left the Salvation Army because he could not maintain its principle of not working on the Sabbath.

His emotional concern for the welfare of people and his reaction against the hardship and deprivation associated with the Depression and the industrial conflict of the 1890s led him into the Australian Socialist League, which also included moderates such as W.A. Holman, Billy Hughes and George Black. He accepted the view of Sydney Webb that socialism is not an elaborate plan of society, but a principle of social action.

Holland and his friend Tom Batho became newspaper publishers. They moved to Newcastle in 1896 and occupied two semi-detached cottages facing the railway coal tip. They published the socialist paper Northern People. Holland and his family had no furniture and little food. He often suffered malnutrition to feed his family.

In 1898, Holland left the Labor Party when it retreated from its socialist objective. Shortly afterwards, he returned to Sydney and later founded the Socialist Labor Party. After a temporary flirtation with Labor Party publications, he returned to militant socialism and began to publish the International Socialist Review for Australasia in Sydney 1907.

Then followed an intense period of writing and trade union activity, during which his socialist thinking matured. Harry Holland firmed a friendship with Tom Mann, the militant English trade unionist, who came out to Melbourne in 1903. He was influenced by the Wobblies, or the Industrial Workers of the World, which was formed in Chicago in 1905. He became the general secretary of the Socialist Federation of Australasia in 1907.

Harry Holland and Tom Mann were prominent activists in the 1909 strike of the Broken Hill miners. One of the slogans of the Broken Hill miners in 1909 was, `Better a dead belly than an empty one'. Holland and Mann were arrested during the Broken Hill strike. Holland was charged with sedition when he advocated the use of dynamite to release his friend Tom Mann and declared that if the police used rifles on the workers, they should reciprocate with Gatling guns. He was sentenced to two years gaol. Holland was also a friend of Peter Bowling, the leader of the Newcastle coalminers, who was placed in leg irons after his arrest for leading the Newcastle miners strike.

Harry Holland once declared his vision to be the highest form of Christianity, where men should be so fully developed and live in such a state it would not be necessary for human laws to rule them. Holland and the militant socialists were dispirited by the defeat of the 1910 coalminers strike in Newcastle and his poor results in the electorate of West Sydney where he stood for election to parliament.

Harry Holland was invited to conduct a lecture tour of New Zealand. He arrived there in 1912. He participated in the formation of the New Zealand Labour Party in 1916. In 1918 he was elected to the New Zealand parliament. The next year he became leader of the parliamentary Labour Party. The Labour Party had mixed fortunes as it tried to forge a role in the political structure in New Zealand. At the 1931 general election, it won 24 of the 79 seats.

With increasing physical and emotional exhaustion and ill health, Harry Holland's support began to wane. His lack of political skills and his blunt honesty became greater burdens. In the parliamentary session of early 1933 he was less effective and his greater disillusionment was apparent. On 8 October 1933 Harry Holland attended the funeral of Te Rata Mahuta, a Maori king. He collapsed during the service and died later that day in Huntly. He was laid to rest in the cemetery above Wellington harbour. Had he survived, it is almost certain that he would have led the New Zealand Labour Party to victory when it formed its first government in 1935. M.J. Savage, his deputy, remarked to Holland's widow, `Harry's life of service enabled us to win.'.

Those people who had spurned and rejected Holland in life sang his praises in death. The unemployed and the destitute woke on 9 October 1933 to find they had lost a champion. Before he left Australia he had a number of poems published in Red Roses on the Highways. One of those poems reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Art thou grown faint and weary
Who fought so well for Right?
Dost feel the day is dreary,
And long for Rest—and Night?
Take heart, O Man of Sorrow!
The Coming Day is bright;
The Sun shall rise Tomorrow
And flood the world with Light.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1974, section 23G of the Income Tax Assessment Act was enacted after the High Court had ruled that credit unions were not exempt from tax under the mutuality principle. The exemption of credit unions from taxation was supported by both the government and opposition of the day. Now the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) proposes to remove this exemption for credit unions at the beginning of the 1994-95 year. This proposal means that credit unions will be taxed at the rate of 20 per cent until 1997-98, when it will increase to the full corporate rate.

PARA.TAB: I want to put on record my opposition to this measure and the opposition of the Hastings Credit Union, which is based in my electorate. By removing this tax exemption, the Treasurer has ignored the unique role credit unions play in the financial sector of our local communities. The Hastings Credit Union is owned and funded completely by its members. Any income earned by the credit union, apart from that required to meet expenses, is returned to the members in the form of better rates of interest on savings and loans.

This proposed tax is a tax on volunteers. The Hastings Credit Union relies on volunteer directors, elected by the membership, to manage its affairs. This tax is a tax on self-help. The Hastings Credit Union members work together to achieve a better life for themselves and their community. The `not for profit activities' differentiate the Hastings Credit Union from its competitors. The Hastings Credit Union is involved in financial support to Credit Line in New South Wales; supports attendees at the regularly held youth forums; supports community service announcements on local radio; sponsors and supports several local sporting and charitable organisations, such as the surf lifesaving club; as well as generally promoting the development of the local Hastings and Manning communities.

In the absence of its current tax exemption, the Hastings Credit Union will need to consider access to other capital instruments to support its growth. Access to permanent share capital would fundamentally alter the participatory structure around which credit unions operate. Their growth rates and their accessibility to consumers will be adversely affected by the proposed policy change. It is simply not true of the government to suggest that the needs previously satisfied by the credit unions are now adequately met by others.

Most obviously, the cooperative one member, one vote structure of credit unions provides a unique alternative to the consumers in the Hastings. The Hastings Credit Union provides particular services and products which are not available elsewhere. For example, credit unions continue to offer low value term loans while banks have withdrawn from this market in favour of high interest credit card facilities.

Despite their relatively small size, credit unions have been leaders in the introduction of new technology. For example, credit unions were the first to introduce automatic teller machines to Australia. As finance companies desert the consumer market and as building societies progressively strive for bank status, it is imperative for the credit union industry to remain viable and prosperous and for Australian consumers to continue to have access to an alternative form of financial institution. This need is even greater in a deregulated market. I have a letter here from Mr Neville Parsons, General Manager of the Hastings Credit Union, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: A tax on credit unions is a tax on choice. Whereas the government is handing out tax breaks and income support worth hundreds of millions of dollars to foreign and domestic banks, this tax will punish the growth potential of the credit union industry by taxing its only source capital.

This afternoon I was pleased to hear the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott) oppose this tax in his speech on the budget. I join with him in asking the government to drop this tax which will only cost more Australians their jobs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pyne Mr C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the lead-up to the Olympic games announcement last week, China released one of its most famous dissidents, Wei Jingsheng. In December 1978, an article he wrote advocating what he called the fifth modernisation, democracy, in addition to the four economic modernisations being advocated by the party, was pasted in its entirety on Beijing's Democracy Wall. Wei's work incurred the personal anger of Deng Xiaoping. He was arrested the following March and later sentenced to 15 years imprisonment. His early release did not sway IOC delegates, and quite rightly.

PARA.TAB: China has a terrible record on human rights. It holds around 15 million people in labour camps and executes 20,000 a year. The death penalty is applied for minor crimes and works partly through quotas allocated to each province. Chinese military power holds millions of people captive in Tibet, Xinjiang and inner Mongolia.

Economic liberalisation and development in China has not brought about the democracy—Wei Jingsheng's fifth freedom—that many Western observers hoped for. All the great modern portrayals of totalitarian states, from Orwell's 1984 to Godard's Alphaville, have been based on the ideas and intensive technology of the age of mass production. In the West we live in an age where new technology and business tools—personal computers, desktop publishing, fax machines and cellular phones—give us new ways to work and express ourselves. China, however, is using the old technology of mass production as a tool of oppression, and nowhere more so than in the Laogai, the system of labour camps where Wei was held. The human rights group, Asia Watch, has stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Laogai is the world's largest system of forced labour and imprisonment. It is a vast network of prisons, camps and jails in which millions of prisoners are held and forced to work on behalf of the state. It is grossly abusive of human rights—torture is rife, and squalor, abuse and degradation the norm. It is, in short, the last gulag.

The Laogai is a natural outgrowth of a political system that seeks to bring all Chinese under the control of government autocracy. Across the length and breadth of China there are 3,000 or more Laogai facilities. Under Deng Xiaoping's guiding principle of `socialism with Chinese characteristics', labour camps have been urged to become self-financing. In 1988 alone, the Laogai produced over two billion yuans worth of goods and services, contributing perhaps as much as 10 per cent to the national economy.

PARA.TAB: The Laogai, unlike its Nazi and Soviet counterparts, is so expansive that it pervades all aspects of national planning, and has such careful planning and organisation that the commodities produced in the camps form an integral part of the Chinese economy. Officially, this prison camp produce is for use by Chinese citizens alone, but increasing evidence shows that much of it is exported to earn hard foreign currency.

Asia Watch suggests that prison factories may be exporting to more than 30 countries around the world, earning at least $US700 million annually. There is virtually no product that the camps do not manufacture. The most popular goods for export are coffee, tea, spices, salt, cement, plastics, rubber, textiles, ceramics, glass, iron, steel, copper, lead, nuclear reactors, boilers, machinery, electrical goods and vehicles.

A camp with the internal name of `No. 1 Laogai Camp of Beijing' is publicly known as `State Operated Qinghe Farm' or`Qinghe Machine Factory'. Prison labour has played an important part in China's surge into the international market economy. Prison labour is cheap. Volvo recently refused to develop a Chinese plant after being offered Laogai labour. A company spokesman described the offer as revolting.

Much of the material I have raised tonight comes from a book by Harry Wu, an academic and Laogai inmate for 19 years, who toured Australia in June. Mr Wu does not support a trade boycott of China. Instead, he says that the West should not import items produced by Laogai blood. I am sure we all support ensuring this does not take place, and that Australia can continue to press for what will truly be a more open China.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to read into Hansard a short essay by Samantha Wong from Fulham North Primary. Samantha was the winner of an essay competition that I held last year. The essay is called `Proud to be an Australian'. It states:

PARA.TAB: I am proud to be an Australian, because the majority of us, in this young country are hard working, caring, and have a sense of fairness.

There is equal opportunity for all races. Australia has hardly any discrimination against women, but in other places such the Islamic countries, the women are treated very badly. Everyone is equal, male and female, instead of male domination.

Immigrants from different countries are free to obey their religion and customs. Unfortunately, in other countries where religion is very strong, there is no choice. In Australia, we are not forced to do what we do not believe. I am glad that I live in Australia, where I have a choice, whereas in other countries, I may have been forced to worship another god. If you are an immigrant in Australia, you can be proud of your heritage, and background instead of ashamed. No-one minds if you look, speak or think differently. People like different people, because if everyone was the same, Australia would become very dull.

I am glad that in Australia we have freedom of speech. In countries such as China, they do not allow freedom of speech, and so they protest for something they believe. In Australia, we can be on television, the radio, or any other media coverage. Australia lets you speak what you believe. Our nation is free, our values strong and I am glad to be part of it all.

(4) What was the total cost of changing logos.
(5) What advantage did Telecom gain by changing its logo.
(6) What is the meaning of the new logo and how is that meaning represented.
(7) What was the meaning of the old logo.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from Telecom, is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) In mid-April 1993, the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation (AOTC) changed its name to Telstra Corporation Limited. To reflect this change in name and to upgrade its overall corporate identity, a new logo was introduced.

(2) There has been a proliferation of brands and products introduced over the years which needed to be brought back under the Telecom umbrella. Whilst the Telecom "T" was one of the most recognised symbols in the country, market research showed that there had been some negative associations with the symbol (ie, a monopolistic and bureaucratic organisation).
(3) The new logo is central part of the new corporate identity for Telstra Corporation and reflects its move into a competitive environment.

(4) I am advised that Telstra paid $2 million for design, market research and legal protection for the new logo. The cost of replacing the livery on marketing materials, phone booths, service vans and phone bills will be absorbed over time within existing budgets by charging against deferred expenditure or within amortised budgets.
(5) The advantages to Telecom in changing its logo were:
to project one voice, one face to customers;
to signal positive change whilst building on existing strengths; and
the endorsement of a wide range of brands under a common symbol.

(6) The new symbol is represented by an updated "T" for telecommunications (reflecting positive change), the ellipse representing global communications and the colour system of orange (retention of the equity in the previous logo) is supported by a deep blue and combined with a field of white.
(7) The old logo was a stylized "T" symbolising various engineering elements of the Company and the orange symbolised the unique colour of the Australian outback.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Employment of Additional Staff

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: Has his Department employed additional staff in the Financial Information Service to handle inquiries concerning the treatment of unrealised capital gains in calculating pension entitlements; if so, (a) how many additional staff have been employed in each State and (b) what will be the cost of employing the additional staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: On the basis that the honourable member's question relates to the treatment of unrealised capital gains on shares, the answer is no.

As the honourable member is no doubt aware, provision for an additional 75 staff over 3 years for the Financial Information Service to provide a range of services was announced in the 1991-92 Budget. Of the additional 75, 31 are in place as follows, with 1 other awaiting placement.
New South Wales—13
Victoria—7
Queensland—4
South Australia—3
Western Australia—3
Tasmania—1
Estimated one-off set up costs involved in employing the 31 Officers is $169,780. Estimated ongoing costs for salary and administration total $1.63 million per annum.
Selections are now proceeding for the placement of an additional 21 staff.
A further 22 FIS positions will be provided for with effect from 1 July 1994. This will complete implementation of the 1991-92 Budget measure.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 18 August 1993:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: Yes. (Contract was actually signed in October 1992.)
(a) General Manager, Asset Services.

(b) The decision to seek advice on a name change was part of a broad `Customer Focus' initiative undertaken by Asset Services. Management was concerned that the name `Asset Services' might not properly reflect the commercial role of the business.

(c) The consultant advised that there was not sufficient reason to change the name of Asset Services. To achieve an identity separate from that of Australian Construction Services it was recommended that a change of logo would be an appropriate alternative to a change of name.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 31 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: What total sums in tax deductions were claimed by primary producers under (a) section 75B and (b) section 75D of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 in (i) 1988-89, (ii) 1989-90, (iii) 1990-91, (iv) 1991-92 and (v) 1992-93.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) The total sums deducted under section 75B of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 can not be provided as this item was not separately identified in income tax returns for the years specified.

(b) There is no information available on claims under section 75D of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 for the 1988-89, 1989-90 and 1990-91 income years as this item was not separately identified in income tax returns for those years.

The amount claimed by primary producers is not separately identifiable because after 21 August 1990 the deduction under section 75D included not only primary producers but also others carrying on a business on rural land (excluding mining or quarrying operations).
The total amount claimed on tax returns under section 75D in the 1991-92 income year was $38.1 million (This amount includes returns processed during the period 1 July 1992 to 19 September 1993).
Statistics are not yet available for the 1992-93 income year.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 2 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: Did Asset Services, Victoria, contract Asset Services, Clifton Hill, Vic., in 1992 for the supply of a judge's toilet; if so, what were the (a) specifications for the project and (b) costs of (i) the project and (ii) related expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: In 1991 Asset Services were commissioned by the Attorney-General's Department to design some wet areas at 450 Little Bourke Street. The Attorney-General's Department provided a brief for the design work. The Attorney-General's Department then asked Asset Services to project manage the construction of the toilets, kitchenette and cleaners' room based on the design specification. Work was commenced in 1992 but was not completed until 1993.
(a) The design specification included eight toilets for the use of judges, a kitchenette, a cleaners' room, and two female staff toilets.

(b) (i) & (ii) The cost of the judges' toilets cannot be separated from the related works of the female toilets, kitchenette and cleaners' room. The total cost of constructing the toilets, kitchenette and cleaners' room was $137,510.
